talk.title: TDD: Cultivating a Beginner's Mind
talk.description:
Even though Agile has been around for more than 15 years, many software organizations still practice Big Design Up Front. A lot of focus is put on the *initial development* aspect, before the first delivery, and little attention is given to the *maintenance phase* of the software system. With more and more organizations shifting to SaaS models, creating long-lived Internet systems that aren’t forgiving to downtimes or cumbersome data migrations, maintenance becomes much more important and critical to the overall design of the system than the initial development.

Agile offers a different, *Emergent* method to design software, with small iterations that, when combined with continuous delivery and learning, results in a design that’s much more adaptive to changing requirements. Taken to the extreme, we shorten the initial development phase to a minimum and focus mostly on iterative maintenance steps. 

However, the conditions required to facilitate Emergent Design require that the development team refrain from over-engineering and YAGNI violations - two problems that are prevalent in the software industry, especially with less-experienced engineers. Outside-In Development is a methodology that helps us focus on the Semantics rather the Mechanics of our software, protect us from YAGNI violations, and thus facilitate Emergent Design. Practicing TDD helps us implement this methodology in the scope of a commercial software project, by helping us cultivate a Beginner’s Mind towards software design.
talk.notes:
I will start by describing the gap between how engineers usually view software design and how Internet-scale systems actually evolves. I will then make the point that software isn’t like bridges, cars or other “classical” engineering projects. I will use the biological analogy, talking about software as a garden and how we always build on existing system state, and how software engineering is an ongoing, evolving effort. I will claim that a paradigm shift is needed towards wide adoption of Emergent Design.

Next, I will explain why traditional software engineering training is deleterious to this paradigm shift, with people learning to think about static, rather than evolving, software design, and are taught more about the mechanics of software (design patterns, technology) and less about the semantics (creating the right abstractions). I will discuss Outside-In Development and explain how it helps stick to the YAGNI principle, and how this facilitates Emergent Design. I will explain that it’s hard to adopt outside-in due to the way engineers are trained and how cultivating a Beginner’s Mind helps us put aside these problems and achieve outside-in.

Finally, I will explain how practicing TDD helps us cultivate the Beginner’s Mind and facilitate outside-in, with test-first serving as the outside user of a system or subsystem, and how the Refactoring phase of TDD helps design emerge.

### Presentation History:
Initially developed in 2014 as an internal Wix.com tech talk. Presented in:
Reversim Summit Tel Aviv 2015 
Voxxed Days Vilnius 2015 
Clean Code Days Munich 2015 
Continuous Lifecycle London 2016
XP2016 Edinburgh
Testcon Vilnius 2016
talk.abstract: Everyone’s talking about Agile, but most of us actually do Scrumfall. The rise of SaaS systems calls for a paradigm shift in software design. In this talk, I will discuss Emergent Design using TDD as a way around the inherent problems in Big Design Up Front and our education as software engineers.
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: The proposal seems solid. My biggest concern is with the matter that Michael raised with Shai--why is this presentation uniquely appropriate for an architecture conference? Shai didn't have a great answer to that. Final decision on this one may depend on the extent to which we want to include general-interest software engineering presentations along with those with a particular focus on architecture.

TDD has been established for a while now, I am not sure what new angle this talk would provide. I would like to see a balance between up-front design and TDD at an architecture conference.

Update: after reading the conversation with the speaker, I understand more and agree with Michael's sentiment. However, I find it disturbing that the speaker uses many terms/acronyms without defining them, also in the 'public' abstract.

Generally I like everything the speaker proposes but the topic seems extremely introductory.  It does not seem like there is anything new here or much that directly relates to software architecture topics.

Update: Given some of the discussions with Shai and the emphasis on design over mechanics I think his has potential to be a good session.

feedback.body:
Hi Shai,

I am a huge supporter of TDD and 100% agree with most everything in your abstract.  With that said, this topic has been around for a while.  What is new your talk compared to the common or prevailing lessons for using and benefits of TDD?  How will you relate TDD directly to software architecture topics (opposed to typical design or programming topics)?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,

Thanks for the feedback. First and foremost, I can't actually promise that anything I say is new to the audience of SATURN, although I have delivered this talk in earlier formats at various European conferences, including XP2016 in Edinburgh earlier this year, and got positive feedback.

One major difference is that I'm talking about Test-Driven *Design* rather than Test-Driven Development. Many talks and books deal with Test-Driven Development, focusing on the "how"s rather than the "why"s - how to write unit tests, for instance, rather than "what's in it for me". My talk, and to a greater extent my epiphany, has to do with our fallacies as software engineers, their origins, and how TDD, by helping us cultivate a beginner's mind, can aid in getting rid or taming these fallacies, which include YAGNI violation, over-engineering, pattern obsession and so on. 

While this talk doesn't relate to software architecture in the common sense (topology, microservices, databasesm etc), it does deal with how adhering to TDD as a methodology is beneficial for software organizations that develop web-scale, long-lived Internet systems, as was our experience at Wix.com.

Shai, Thanks for the update!  Thanks for explaining the nuance -- design over mechanics. TDD is a great way to dive into these topics and I think this would be the right approach for this conference.  Good luck in the review process!

Hi Shai,

I'm particularly interested in your emphasis on addressing the maintenance phase.  Is the approach you are describing something that can be applied to a system that is already in the maintenance phase?

In his book "Working Effectively with Legacy Code" Michael Feather describes a number of techniques for introducing tests to legacy code.  Are you talking about a similar approach here?

Or are you talking about anticipating the needs of maintenance during the initial phases?

Hi Ged,

I'm talking about anticipating the needs of maintenance during the initial phase. Furthermore, I'm claiming that the initial phase in itself is getting way too much attention, whereas the important bit of software development lies in maintenance. Taken to the extreme, an example would be deploying an empty application to production, then starting to add features to it ('Walking Skeleton' in GOOS lingua).

Shai
Hi Shai, from the YouTube video, it looks like a 30-minute talk. Is that correct? Thanks.

Hi Michele,
I'd say 40 minutes, 45 with Q&A. The video is edited a bit, and I was delivering after a sleepless night, which caused me to be really too fast.
Thanks! I'll tag it as 45 for the review committee's consideration. :)

Thank you for your submission. 

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. I don't understand what you mean by "more and more organizations shifting to SaaS models" in practice. Do you mean more development organizations are creating their software solutions as SaaS? Is it true for the enterprise? Or do you mean more organizations are using various SaaS solutions, such as dockerhub and github? 

2. I think maintainability is an important quality attribute requirement for software systems in general. If you use patterns and tactics that promote maintainability, I think you are giving attention to the maintenance phase. In the first paragraph, it seems you are saying that BDUF does not focus on maintainability. I don't think that's the problem with BDUF. The problem is that you design beyond what's known at the beginning. If you start coding earlier, initial releases will give you incredible understanding of runtime/maintainability issues that help to drive downstream design in the right direction. 

3. Here's what wikipedia says about Emergent Design: "With emergent design, a development organization starts delivering functionality and lets the design emerge. Development will take a piece of functionality A and implement it using best practices and proper test coverage and then move on to delivering functionality B. Once B is built, or while it is being built, the organization will look at what A and B have in common and refactor out the commonality, allowing the design to emerge. This process continues as the organization continually delivers functionality."
I'm not sure this is your interpretation of emergent design. In any case, it is important to reflect about some points. Is this approach good in all cases? If not, what's the criteria to decide when to use it? Aren't there tradeoffs related to following emergent design? What kinds of design decisions are in the scope of this approach? Does emergent design prevent the use of techniques (such as DDD) that ask you to design beyond the scope of a scrum sprint functionality? 

4. From the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program, I think the title+description don't make it clear what the talk is about. The title makes you think it's about TDD. The description may make you think the talk is about Emergent Design and/or the outside-in development approach. 

5. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

6. In the description, consider adding what participants will learn, that is, how do they benefit from this talk. 

Typos:

- "Semantics rather *than* the Mechanics"

- "protect*s* us from YAGNI"

- "and thus facilitate*s* Emergent Design"

Hi Paulo,
Re: 1 - I mean that companies start offering their products as SaaS rather than on-premise. I think this also applies to enterprise, yes - if you look at major software companies, such as HPE - who have traditionally been offering on-prem solutions only.

Re: 2 - yes, I agree with what you say. But I think that the mere act of *performing* a BDUF will create a mindset that thinks in terms of a deliverable ("car") rather than an evolvable ("garden").

Re: 3 - note that I'm not referring to scope, or to sprints. I'm referring to letting design emerge rather than forcing a design that stems from the mind of an architect (and not from evidence). What recently became clearer to me is that most of what I say is applicable mainly to Applications, as defined by Lehman (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lehman's_laws_of_software_evolution).

Re: 4 - what I'm trying to say is that TDD is a great way to promote emergent design, by helping the engineer cultivate a beginner's mind. Do you think this is not clear from the title/abstract?

(4) TDD (test-driven development) is a well known Agile practice. Emergent Design is not a familiar term for many. So, IMO one looking at the title can easily think this is a talk about test-driven development--more so, one may think it's about test-driven development for beginners (like the TDD Kata talk by Bob Martin).

talk.title: The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG) for the Linux Kernel
talk.description:
The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG)
======================================================

John F. Masinter, Intel Corporation 
Nathan R. Peterson, Intel Corporation

Summary
--------------

The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG) was developed at Intel Security for use with the many security products based upon the McAfee Linux OS platform. The ADRNG provides the NIST approved SP800-90A PRNG from the native Linux kernel API. It is continuously reseeded using high quality entropy bit data form the native Linux kernel Jitter entropy driver. This ADRNG is added to the Linux 4.4 kernel, and replaces the standard drivers for both /dev/random and /dev/urandom. The result is high quality random data delivered in high volume without call blocking.

Problem/Opportunity
-------------------------------

The ability to provide a high volume of quality random data is of interest to modern Linux server systems where a great deal of encryption requires a great deal of random data. A lack of large quantities of random data may cause encryption to run slowly. A lack of quality in the random data may cause encryption to be weak. 

The particular path that led us to develop this solution was increasing scrutiny of the NIST FIPS validation standards which are diving deeper into entropy quality. The ADRNG is based upon all the learning from a year long series of FIPS lab testing while validating McAfee Linux OS. 
Quality random data is in demande by all modern Linux servers, with or without FIPS requirements. By developing a standards based solution that plugs into the Linux kernel, we can easily share this solution with all groups at Intel, as well as making a significant contribution to the Linux kernel upstream.

Solution
-------------

The initial implementation of this idea was for the Linux 3.18 kernel. That kernel did not contain the native API for the SP800-90A PRNG nor the Jitter entropy driver. We back ported the Jitter enropy code from a later kernel, and adapted the SP800-90A routines from the Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) open source crypto library. This worked very well, but we were concerned about the large delta of kernel code required for this method.

However since that time, we have moved to the Linux 4.4 kernel, which does contains both the SP800-90A PRNG and the Jitter entropy driver within the kernel native API. So we have updated our solution to use only the native kernel resources. This vastly reduces the size of code required, and also provides greater confidence for those that consume the solution.
Scope

The initial motivation to develop the ADRNG was to meet increasingly strict NIST FIPS standards. However we have enable this solution for all modes of the kernel. Thus all products based on McAfee Linux OS will benefit from the faster and higher quality random data. This results in faster and more secure encryption.

McAfee Linux OS is used by many products at Intel Security, and all of these products will implicitly inherit the advantages of the ADRNG as they each update to the lastest MLOS kernel. Increased security will benefit the reputation and sales of Intel Security products.
Engineering teams working with cryptography on Linux systems, as well as Product Managers attempting to satisfy NIST FIPS standards, would all benefit from learning more about the ADRNG.

Results
-----------

For measuring the results we quantify two values: Speed and Quality. 

### Speed Test
+ Dell PE-R610 / Xeon E5540 / 2.53GHz

.            64-Bytes  1K-Bytes  64K-Bytes  64Kx64-Bytes
/dev/random  0m0.002s  0m0.002s  1h,36m,13s 103h,19m,46s
/dev/urandom 0m0.002s  0m0.002s  0m0.008s   2m10.672s
ADRNG        0m0.002s  0m0.003s  0m0.036s   2m25.836s

The speed test was performed using this simple command for each algo and block size:
$ time dd if=/dev/random of=/tmp/64_random.dat bs=64 count=1

We used memory based file system (/tmp/) to reduce file i/o overhead.
We can assume file i/o overhead is consistent between all tests, since all tests have the same number and size of writes.

### Quality Test
•	Dell PE-R610 / Xeon E5540 / 2.53GHz

.             Entropy  Arithmetic-Mean     SCC
/dev/random   7.999580    127.5092         -0.001245
/dev/urandom  7.999960    127.4892         -0.000524
ADRNG         7.999962    127.5570         -0.001057

Entropy bits per byte of perfect randomness = 8.000000
Arithmetic mean of perfect randomness = 127.5
Serial Correlation Coefficient of totally uncorrelated data = 0.0

The quality test was performed using the “ent” program which applies various entropy quality tests to byte sequences. This test was run against the sum of all data produced by the speed test above, 4,260,928 bytes.

Conclusion
----------------

The ADRNG provides random data at the speed of /dev/urandom and with the quality of /dev/random. Thus crypto applications no longer need to choose between speed and quality, because the ADRNG provides both.

Leadership
----------------

The ADRNG will provide greater overall quality to all Intel products which incorporate it. The ISecG security products are measured in the industry by their speed and security. The ability to run encryption faster, and with higher quality, results is something that can be measured and leveredged by product marketing to maintain and extend the Intel Security market leadership.
 
Lessons Learned
There were so many lessons learned from the FIPS process that we could write a book on the subject. But in summary, to track and report quality, you must collect this info:

+ FOR EACH: RNG, RNG-Seed, RNG-init, Entropy, Entropy-Seed, Entropy-init
+ You must be able to show this info:
+ Origin of algo
+ Source code of algo
+ Quality tests of algo
+ Performance tests of algo on various hardware platforms
+ Papers and Certifications of algo

It is far better to collect this info as you go through development, rather than going back at the end and attempting to compile this info.

References
----------------

1.	ENT, a program which applies various entropy quality tests to byte sequences,   http://www.fourmilab.ch/random/
2.	NIST Special Publication 800-90A, Recommendation for Random Number Generation Using Deterministic Random Bit Generators, Jan 2012, http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-90A/SP800-90A.pdf
3.	CPU Time Jitter Based Non-Physical True Random Number Generator, 2014, Stephan Müller, https://www.kernel.org/doc/ols/2014/ols2014-mueller.pdf
talk.notes:
- I am the manager and co-founder of the McAfee Linux OS project at Intel Corp. (previously McAfee Inc.)
- I am the originator of the idea and effort at Intel to incorporate a standards based RNG into the Linux kernel.
- I have previously given talks within Intel about this subject.
- This has great benefit, as all products using our kernel will automatically benefit from higher quality random data.
- If selected, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to reformat my paper for the SATURN desired publishing format. For example, HTML.
- This is a 15 minute talk.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. 

The Talk Abstract describes in two sentences the ADRNG. However, it does not describe the talk.  :^(

Here's what the conference submission web form says about the talk Description: "The description will be seen by reviewers during the CFP process and will eventually be seen by the attendees of the event. You should make the description of your talk as compelling and exciting as possible. Remember, you're selling both the organizers of the events to select your talk, as well as trying to convince attendees your talk is the one they should see."
I'm afraid your Talk Description does not describe a talk. It describes the ADRNG program, its motivation, technical requirements, compliance requirements, and even test benchmark results. 

Conference participants in general are not interested in a specific software product. But they want to learn from the experience, techniques, patterns, practices, tools and frameworks that were useful in any software project. So, I suggest you turn your talk description around. - challenges to create, evaluate, check conformance of the architecture.

The talk description should indicate what attendees will learn from your talk. 

Clarification: there's no paper submission and publication for SATURN. You're submitting a proposal to give a presentation but no paper is required.

- "which does contain*s* both the"
- "However*,* we have enable*d* this solution for all modes of the kernel"
- " to the la*s*test MLOS kernel"

talk.title: The benefits of going Serverless
talk.description:
The "Serverless Architecture" has become massively popular this year, and for the right reasons. It’s zero-administration nature and pay-per-execution pricing model enable developers to manage less infrastructure and build more than ever.

So what are developers actually building with it?  What are the obvious use-cases and what use-cases aren't so obvious?  Here, we'll chat about the benefits of the Serverless Architecture and take a tour of the expected and unexpected use-cases these benefits are inspiring. From bitcoin trading platforms to garden monitoring tools to the automation of everything, we’ll explore the potential of serverless, and how empowering it can be for companies and individual developers alike.

feedback.body:
Hi David,

The topic of serverless is going to be hot this year.  Could you provide some additional details for what you plan to cover in this proposed session?  Also, how is this talk going to be different from the other talk you proposed, _Event Driven Application Architectures_?

Good luck with the rest of the review process!

Regards,

Michael

Thanks for submitting a very interesting topic. 

Some suggestions around some of the common areas where general information is not readily available and few suggestions. 

Drawbacks of Serverless Architecture

Perceived vendor dependencies and immaturity of the technology

Details of various providers that support Serverless Architecture and how to chose a specific provider

Open-Source Cross-vendor Deployment Tools

What we need to work differently in terms of deployment, monitoring, scaling, security, networking, etc.

Ecosystem of Tools for common Cases (EX: API Gateways) Recommended Patterns if any?

An interesting short Demo demonstrating the ease? (Still I believe not many would have actually seen it in working)

All the Best!
Hi David, is this a 30- or 90-minute talk? Thanks.

Hi David,
Thank you for the submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. I fully agree with Yogeshwar. You should also discuss the challenges and drawbacks of serverless architecture. Software architects need to understand the tradeoffs that come with any design decision. A lot of material we see out there about the newest and brightest idea often only emphasize the benefits. Surely serverless is not the best solution for all cases.

2. The term serverless is actually quite broad and poorly defined. For example, [Mike Roberts](https://martinfowler.com/articles/serverless.html) associates serverless to the use of MBaaS (more common), or alternatively richer clients (SPA?) talking to services behind an API gateway. Thus, I hope your talk has a clear description of what a serverless architecture is. A brief definition of serverless in the talk description would also be helpful to correctly set the expectations of participants looking at the conference program.

3. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

4. Like Michael, I too see significant overlap with your other submission. Please provide more information on how do they differ.

talk.title: The future of delivery messenger channels with SMS-fallback.
talk.description: Probably everyone remembers earlier days, when SMS was one of the most used means of communication. This times, the dissemination of SMS in private communication is decreasing whereas SMS is still often used for commercial communication especially for one-directional distribution of information from company to customer. In the future, the SMS may also lose this position and then will only serve as fallback. New channels, especially internet-based messengers like Facebook Messenger, WhatsApp or Threema, will become more and more important and will compete with SMS. Instead of sending SMS to customers, companies will start using the same channels for commercial conversation as their customers for private. SMS then will only be used in case an internet-based channel is not available or for time critical services.
talk.abstract: Internet-based messengers like Facebook Messenger, Threema and WhatsApp will more and more compete with SMS in one-directional commercial communication. SMS will then only be used as fallback or in case of time critical services.

talk.title: The Intentional Architect
talk.description:
The title architect has been confusing for IT for years: enterprise architect, solution architect, systems architect, software architect, middleware architect, delivery architect. Whether you have been a "boxes and lines" or a "hands on keyboard" resource, the skills needed to an impactful architect are changing. You must make some intentional changes to keep your skills relevant:
  • Platforms over Projects - The resurgence of modularity as a focus is being fueled by cloud computing paradigm. Architects are often the "urban planner" identifying and stitching together right fit of components/modules and services for the enterprise instead of the monolithic design approach of the past. The result is a focus on design of platforms and frameworks that can absorb organic change in business needs over time.
  • Patterns and Pragmatism - Patterns have been around for over two decades and the rise of the API economy and platform focused design is shining a spot light on identifying the right fit patterns. Patterns are provided to the Developers and Designers freeing them to focus on building business features. The challenge is to avoid ivory-tower syndrome pragmatically apply patterns that will make them most impact and reduce risk.
  • Master Craftsman and Apprentice - The architect has a responsibility to mentor other techs. With the pace of change, the architect has to be open to being the apprentice as new ideas and techniques surface through the curious developers and passionate designers.
  • Master Communicator - Whether an junior architect in training in training or a well-seasoned senior arch, the ability to communicate crisply and succinctly is an imperative whether written or spoken.
talk.notes: I've been an architect for over 22 years and have continually reinvented and retooled myself.  I am seeing many mid-career and late-career architects struggle as they look through their old lens.  Especially for the enterprise, there needs to be a mind set shift away from monolithic solutions and toward modular platforms.  See bio for additional background.  This is a 30 minute session and participants will leave with a clear understanding of the imperative and a set of personal career guiding principles to keep them relevant and enable them as intentional architects.
talk.abstract: What does it take to be a software architect nowadays?  It means being an intentional focus on becoming a polymath who designs platforms and frameworks instead of projects, a focus on patterns and mastering the art of planning for organic growth.  This is the next evolution for our profession.

ratings.comments: I like the summarization, but there isn't much of novelty around the content to be presented.

After reading this submission I researched the speaker and watched her 2016 Saturn Presentation on the Hybrid Cloud and found it to be engaging and useful.  

I understand that her holistic approach means that there is a lack of focus in the submission, but I believe that the mindset being described is important.

I would suggest that this talk would fit in the the "Other topics of interest" track under the topic of "developing architects".

The submission is not very clear on what the talk wants "to leave behind". I feel the author is knowledgeable about the topic, but the take away from the talk is not sufficient to give it a thumbs up.

This abstract is very confusing and the message is not clear. I am not sure if the author is advocating patterns or against it? Not all projects can be platform architectures? What is the context that these lessons apply in?

Highly relevant topic, promising session title. So I had high expectations when opening the submission description. 

Regrettably, the submission fails to convince me that the submitter will be able to deliver a convincing presentation:  the abstract is almost content.free, and the talk description is loaded with buzzwords, but does not contain concrete examples of what the "Intentional Architect" would be and do.

feedback.body:
Thanks for the submission. Regardless of the title, some of the suggested changes have been widely accepted as key qualities of an Architect.

Ex:
Master Communicator 

Would it make better sense to focus more on some of the key changes that make someone an intentional Architect? Ex: Especially around being PolyMath.

user.name: Tracy Bannon  PMP, CSM, TOGAFv9, SEI SAP

feedback.body:
Thanks for the feedback.  I see that I was not as clear as in intended and would love to revise if you are open to that.  Here are some of the thoughts I can elaborate on.
	
I agree that some of the changes I mentioned, like master communicator, have been suggested and agreed to in the past as a quality.  Our profession, however, fell victim to over-granularity and many of these qualities were seen as "nice to have" and not a show stopper if they were missing.  
	
The dramatic changes in our profession make these qualities no longer are suggestions but imperatives.    The trait I mentioned are cornerstone though alone, will not be enough. 
	
Over the years, we've seen a proliferation of specializations for architects: middleware or integration architect, RDBMS architect, infrastructure architect, UI architect, enterprise,  and so on.  There is a gravitational pull driven by cloud and DevOps that is democratizing architectural activities and pushing the need for architects to wear many hats.  For example, the application architect understand integration and infrastructure architecture as well as operations.  An architect of any type must intentionally become more widely skilled.  We must strive to be   polymaths passionately commanding the full architectural continuum and more!   There will always be the need for a few edge architects who keep wholly focused on a single discipline though the vast majority must intentionally change their aperture. 
	
To keep the example simple, consider an organization adopting DevOps principles.  For the intentional architect, this means having a full command of their ecosystem from software defined infrastructure, to pipeline engineering and deployment automation, to operational monitoring and the resulting analytics.  
	
The intentional architect needs to be a passionate learner beyond technology to understand impacting business and law.  Why?  Consider cloud:  intentional architects have to understand security, policy and possibly international law, scalability, SLAs, and be able to suggest and drive right-sized governance.  The intentional architect also has to be a historian and able to analyze contributions to technical debt as organizations look to refactor, redesign, in addition to building new.  
	
It is somewhat daunting for experienced architects to change the aperture and cultivate a polymath mindset that actively focuses on using their myriad skills to keep drive simplicity and embrace pragmatism.   The commitment to being an intentional architect will be key for success as we enter this next epoch.

talk.title: The Power of Sketching for Developers
talk.description:
Sketching is an easily overlooked skill for developers yet the benefits that sketching brings cannot be overstated. Sketching helps with brainstorming ideas, iterating through concepts, and communicating your ideas to others. Whether working individually or in a group, your ability to sketch helps take the abstract ideas out of heads and into the real world. If you’re not comfortable sketching then there is little chance that your ideas will stick with you, your team members, and even your clients. Don’t worry—the confidence you need to put your pen to paper and start to sketch is close at hand! With the addition of a few simple approaches to your daily routine, you too can harness the power of sketching. 

Key Takeaways:
- Developers can sketch.
- Understand the benefits of sketching and why it is important for developers
- Learn specific techniques to power up your sketching skills
- See the power of sketching firsthand by taking part in sketching activities

Come prepared to do fun sketching activities in this hands-on talk so you can experience the power of sketching firsthand.
talk.notes:
The goal of my talk is to help both designers and non-designers understand the power of sketching. Everyone has great ideas to share and the faster we get them out of our heads and into the physical world the quicker we can move forward. 

Agenda of my talk:

- Talk about the power of sketching. 
- Comparison of two designers and how they approach sketching and what effects that has on their careers. 
- Tools needed to sketch. 
- Sketching Activities - I have the attendees do a few sketching activities to help them understand the power of sketching firsthand. (This has been a wild success at previous talks.)
After each activity, I have the attendees discuss the sketches with each other to help them practice talking about their sketches.
- Close out the talk by showing sketches from my 30-day sketching challenge and how it transformed my sketching skills.

I want the attendees to understand that the transformation from a little bit or not at all sketching to harnessing the power of sketching is not a long time. All it takes is some consistency and effort. I want to leave them inspired and pumped up to start sketching.
talk.abstract: The power of sketching lies in using sketching to ideate, iterate, and communicate our ideas. It is time to gain the confidence you need to sketch in person or in front of a group. By harnessing the power of sketching we all can become sketching machines.

ratings.comments: While sketching and power of diagrams is fundamental the connection of this proposal to software architecture is weak. More importantly the proposer himself also admits his lack of experience in software architecture. As such this would be a weak session to include.
Architects could use drawing practice and it may be fun. On the other hand the speaker does not seem to know is audience very well, which makes me doubtful about reception.

I see the value of sketching as a tool to create screen plays, user interaction scenarios and architectural ideas. Admiral Nelson's plan for how to take out the superior French/Spanish fleet was sketched on a napkin. That said, being good at sketching does not make you a better or worse architect, and that is why I feel a bit doubtful.

session is only about sketching with no clear connection to design.  contrast this with Simon Brown's sketching exercises, which are used as a means to teaching better modelling.  I watched the video linked and the speaker was boring, the exercises didn't seem appropriate for architectural modelling, most of them you can easily do on your own just by watching his video that is already available online.

feedback.body:
Hi Rizwan,

Thanks for your submission!  I'm a bit torn regarding your proposal.  On the one hand I agree that sketching is a useful and powerful tool.  I also enjoy sketching exercises and have seen the many positive benefits of becoming a confident sketcher - including my own 30 day sketch challenge.  On the other hand, at least with software architecture design, we are often concerned with models and reasoning.  I worry that your proposal overemphasizes sketching without a clear connection to modelling and using the sketches to reason about important system properties.

Pros I see in this talk

* Looks like a really interactive hands on session
* Presenter is passionate about the topic
* Sketching is a useful skill and something many developers could use more practice with.

Cons I see in this talk

* No clear connection to software architecture
* Risks further perpetuating boxology and "architecture is just boxes and lines" mentality with no connection to modelling or otherwise using diagrams to reason about system properties

Rizwan, What is your vision for where the sketching techniques you'll practice during the session will fit in a developer's tool box?  When and how would someone use these skills?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,
I completely understand your point. Since I don't have a full grasp of the software architecture domain I would start off by getting architects to understand the power of sketching, which is using sketching for ideation, iteration, and communication of ideas. The sketching activities are designed to show them how little time it takes to sketch and that anyone can sketch. After each activity, I ask the attendees to show their sketches to a person next to them to practice using sketching to communicate.

Developers can then take this knowledge and firsthand experience and apply it to their workflow/processes the very next day. 

To make a stronger connection with the conference topic I can add a specific software architecture sketching activity. I will do some research on which activity can be included in the talk.

I hope I have answered you questions. :) I am also open to any ideas you might have as well.

Thanks,
Rizwan

Thanks, Rizwan.  Your response is helpful.

As far as helping to make a stronger connection to architecture design, you might take a look at some of the work by [Simon Brown](http://www.codingthearchitecture.com/).  He's done some things with sketching and architecture in the past and might give you some ideas for making that connection.

Regards,

Michael

I found Simon Brown's presentation on sketching for architects interesting. He makes a great connection between the why and the how of sketching and architecture design. http://www.codingthearchitecture.com/presentations/saturn2013-effective-software-architecture-sketches

One of the exercises in my talk is Rapid Sketching. In this exercise, the audience sketches the same thing six times but each time there is less time to sketch. So we start from 2 minutes to sketch and then got to 1 minute, 45 seconds, 30 seconds, 15 seconds and end with 5 seconds to sketch. I want the attendees to realize how much detail we need to represent an idea. This activity can be tweaked to use a software architecture diagram that has a lot of detail and see how much detail is needed to quickly represent it. 

I see my talk as getting people excited and inspired to begin using sketching as a tool to visually communicate their ideas. 

I can tweak the other exercises to be software architecture focused as well. 

What do you think?

Thanks,
Rizwan

ratings.comments: More detail from the submitter would help in the evaluation of this proposal. feedback.body:
Hi Chris,

Thanks for your submission.  This looks like it could be a good fit on the technical track through the focus currently in the abstract seems very low level for the typical SATURN attendee.

Strengths I see in this proposal: tight technical focus around a single library, interesting potential use cases, comparison to other libraries.

Ways I think this proposal could be improved: make a clear connection to architectural concerns, add a little more detail about the proposed talk.

What system properties were considered that led you to select this library over others?

If you are able to add a tentative outline to the notes section it will help the reviewers better assess your proposal.

Technical talks like this are a great fit for SATURN but there is a fine line between a developer-focused talk about how to use a library and one that ties the technology and it's use to the impact on an overall design -- technology, people, business, etc.  The proposed talk currently seems to fall more on the pure technology side with less of a direct connection to architecture.

Regards,

Michael

profile.name: Jim van der Waal
profile.bio: I'm an IT Project Manager at bol.com, the biggest e-commerce company within The Netherlands and Belgium. With my creativity and passion I try to develop a drive in the company that will make things happen.

talk.title: Abuser stories: how we embedded a security culture within our business.
talk.description:
With bol.com we experienced the flight ecommerce took the last decade. As the biggest ecommerce company of the Netherlands and Belgium security risks grew exponentially. But it’s not scalable to let your security team grow with the same rate. That’s why we also focused on creating a security culture within the company: making security a responsibility of everyone, not only the security team.

To not only create this culture in IT but also in the rest of the company, we organized Abuser Story workshops for Product Owners and Business Analysts. Abuser stories are a fun way of thinking about the security of your new features. It triggers to think of unhappy flows, think of thresholds to monitor and so on. Making the systems Secure by Design, something really relevant for architects. We saw that Product Owners consulted the security team and architects way more for advice when designing new systems, they gave room and time to developers to write secure code, and discussions between the Security and development teams were actually constructive. It helped to get the “security, we are in this together” mindset. 

In this talk Jim will tell the journey of bol.com, the growing importance of security, and the way we tried to cope with it in a fun way. The lessons learned are valuable for every (growing) company that struggles with making security scalable, and assuring that you will not only be secure today or tomorrow but also in 5-10 years.
talk.notes: Creating awareness in (IT) companies regarding security is becoming really important, and we saw that this awareness should extend way beyond IT. This is really necessary if you want to work agile, and I experienced that first hand. That is why I came up with this concept to extend the security culture to the business as well. Since it is more or less something I came up with myself I am very enthusiastic and passionate to talk about it. Especially since I experience the succes from it every day now in my projects.
talk.abstract: How do you cope with the growth of security risks? Creating a security culture in your company becomes more important every day. Providing your IT teams with the right tools is one thing, but new features start way before it reaches the development phase. So how do you create such a culture?

ratings.comments:
This looks really interesting and I'm very keen on getting architects and developers to be more interested in security, so I like the topic!

I would expand your abstract to make it clear what you're covering.  It's not clear what the audience will leave with.

I don't think in 15 minutes you have time to tell the story of bol.com, how you created a culture, lessons learned, ... Just sounds too much to me.  Can you focus it down to a short sharp message?

I'm also not quite sure how much you plan to discuss the Abuser Stories technique.  They are in the title and there is a lot there in the description, but they're not mentioned in the last paragraph.  I think this needs to be made clear.

This is a talk that I would like to see.  It cover three topics that I find interesting that are identified within the submission guidelines.

It promises to provide a successful case study on helping to assure quality from a security perspective.

More importantly, it focuses on creating a culture of security awareness within agile teams.  That is not easy to achieve, and I would be interested in finding out how it has been done.

Personally I would like to see a longer session with practical elements such as role playing an workshop.

Given that security is an after thought in most development organizations, this topic can possibly bring to light how to truly make everybody think about security.  Also, since security is quickly becoming on of the "ility" requirements, applicable to SATURN.

I like it, I'm also an advocate for addressing safety and security requirements early. Safety and security can't be something we try to fix afterwords. That said, I found it hard to see how this fits with the architectural thinking of a system.
I like this workshop but I don't see a clear connection to architecture design in the abstract.  As a requirements elicitation method it seems quite interesting.

The talk is about disseminating a security culture across the organization and eliciting security requirements for applications (as "abuser stories"). Apparently, it does not get to discuss security as a quality attribute and design driver or tactics and approaches to achieve security.

feedback.body:
Hi Jim,

Thanks for your submission!  I'm a huge fan of misuse cases and simple threat modelling for specifying security requirements.  This is a great topic but I could use some additional information to understand the scope of the proposed talk.

It sounds like the focus of this talk will be on requirements elicitation using the abuser story workshop?  Could you share some details about what that workshop looks like?  A tentative outline for your talk would be extremely helpful.

How is this workshop different from other security requirement  elicitation methods?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Micheal,

Nice to hear from you. I will try to answer your questions below and give some additional information.

About what I will tell about how we embedded a security culture in the company:
So how do you already get that security mindset embedded in earlier stages. How do you get people excited to think about security? Security has the prejudice that it is boring, that is something you have to do, maybe because someone else says so. Like the security team/department. But security can also be fun! Fun? Yes! By stimulating the employees to think like a hacker, either technical or functional, they got motivated to think of security requirements by approaching it from the other side. This in combination with the right tools really helped to get our security level to high standards.

Some more information about the Abuser Story Workshop:
With abuser stories we touch on a subject everybody worked with: user stories. Normally with user stories you define new functionality that you develop with the customer in mind. But how can this functionality be abused? We stimulate the colleagues creativity to think evil and create a hacker mindset for themselves. Turn it around: write an Abuser story: As a hacker, I want…, So that… We were surprised by the evilness of our colleagues – we had some real hackers among us. We do this by introducing a simple proces, let one team think about abuser stories (so how could you as a hacker abuse this functionality), and the other team about user stories on how to avoid abuse. After that the 'Attacking' team presents its abuser stories, which the other team needs to 'Defend' with one of their user stories. We then stimulate the Product Owners to braintorm about abuser stories at the kickoff of each new functionality, more or less facilitate their own workshop. The outcome is then translated in requirements for the different user stories.


There are actually two ways of how you can approach this talk. 

1. A (comprehensive) talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, where I will deep dive more in how we did this with the use of Abuser Story Workshops. This focusses more on how we created this security culture, and the lessons we learned from this proces.

2. A short talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, and facilitating a Abuser Story Workshop to illustrate how we did this. This focusses more on teaching you how you could facilitate these workshops yourself. 


Relevance for audience: the first is relevant for a broader audience, where the second talk (workshop form) is more relevant for Analysts and Product Owners.

I hope this gives you more insights. If you have any questions or you want me to elaborate a bit more, just let me know.

Regards,

Jim
Thanks, Jim.  Your responses are helpful.

Hi Einar,

Thanks! The safety case method is new to me. Within our company we have very little formal methods and formal documentation, so it is not a surprise that I did not come across it before.

Jim
Hi Jim, what type of session should this fall under? It's currently in the DEV@SATURN 15-minute category but seems like it might be longer. Please let me know. Thanks.

Thanks for your reply. Hope this helps.

profile.bio:

I have worked on the architecture, design and implementation of many applications, in various domains including banking, insurance, retail, logistics, process control. Been a speaker in many SATURN conferences, as well as Scrum Gatherings, Agile Conferences.

talk.title: Agile Architecture and Design
talk.description:
Agile software development methodologies are mainstream now. But one of the nagging questions teams face is: how to establish the architecture for a system the agile way? After all, architectural decisions have a key impact on various qualities of a system, and therefore, these decisions have to be taken early and carefully. How does this fit with the incremental and iterative nature of agile methodologies? 

In this session, I'll cover the following aspects: 

* Creating an architecture vision, including desired architectural qualities, during Sprint Zero 
* Identifying potential strategies for achieving the desired architectural qualities, without creating an ivory tower architecture
* Prioritizing the architectural qualities and adding them to the Product Backlog along with the functional requirements 
* Implementing and verifying architectural qualities with the help of real stories from the Product Backlog.   

I will take concrete examples from projects on how to apply the above concepts.
talk.notes:
I have been in the IT industry for 32 years. Been a programmer, designer, architect, project manager, DBA, tester, business analyst, and now mostly trainer, coach and consultant. I have worked on the architecture, design and implementation of many applications, in various domains including banking, insurance, retail, logistics, process control. 

I regularly conduct training programs in the fields of Agile with Scrum, Agile Engineering Practices (XP), Solution Architecture, Enterprise Architecture, and Writing Good Programs.

I have presented various sessions relating to Agile Architecture in many SATURN conferences, as well as Scrum Gatherings, Agile Conferences.
talk.abstract: How to establish the architecture for a system in an agile way? How to avoid BDUF, and yet meet the architecture requirements and mitigate the risks aggressively? Concrete examples from projects to understand the concepts as well as practical insight.

ratings.comments: I have heard Pradyumn speak before and was to his NoSQL tutorial some SATURNs ago. I think this would make a valuable contribution to this year's SATURN.

Architecture's contribution (or otherwise) to agility is an enduring theme and many people have explored it in articles, papers and conference talks (with different degrees of credibility and usefulness).  Can you be clear what is new and novel here, or if it's not new and novel why it will be a great SATURN talk?

I think it would also be useful if you expanded your list of topics to explain what will actually be in each one.

This submission is an experience report on providing some guidelines for establishing an architecture in an agile way. The author correctly identifies that despite the acceptance of agile methodologies and recognition of the importance of architecture a lot of teams struggle marrying them both.

While I appreciate the motivation, I lack the actual experience piece of this talk. The points that the author lists are those that can be found in any blog post or article. The SATURN audience would like to see how these actual experience that work in practice. Unfortunately, this point is only made in passing as "I will take concrete examples from projects on how to apply the above concepts." What are the nature of the concrete examples and what lessons can be taken from them are missing for me to be able to judge this experience piece of this talk objectively.

This talk addresses a key question in the "Digital, Virtual Software Architect": How can we be effective in fast-moving agile environments?

I'm particularly interested in learning about the experiences behind Sprint Zero activities and how the managing of quality attributes on the backlog.
I think talks about architecture and agile should always be welcome.  Especially those that have come from experience.

I’ve attended talks by the speaker and he is well versed in architecture principles. I would categorize those talks as more basic than intermediate. It is possible that the presentation has evolved though there is not enough description to know for sure. The SATURN audience may want something with a little more substance.

Agile and architecture has been discussed often and there are many talks on it at SATURN and elsewhere.  There's really nothing that new proposed in the talk.  But it's always good to see experience reports that show how these practices are used in practice.
Sounds as a relevant, well structured talk by a experienced speaker.

talk.title: A Hands on Introduction To Docker
talk.description:
Have you heard the term "container" without a full understanding of what it means? This is the place for you. This session will provide some of the theory of containers and provide a supervised hands on experience where participants will construct a Docker container. They will execute the container and save it in a repository so that they can some day show their children - "This was my first container".

Participants should have preloaded Docker and run the Hello World application
talk.abstract:
Containers are light weight virtual machines that have become default packaging mechanisms for the deploying of systems. Docker is the pre-eminent container system. 

I will provide some explanations of how containers work and the participants will build,execute, deploy, and save a container.

It differs slightly in that there is an emphasis on IP addresses. I have a Javascript program  that the attendees would use. It prints out ip addresses from inside a container . This emphasizes the key differentiator between the new use of the word container and the old use of that word.

Thanks for the additional details!

Thanks for the topic. 

Would the presentation also touch base on the Container Ecosystem?? 
https://www.papercall.io/cfps/220/submissions/6278#
Example: 
Container Orchestration, Cloud Services Providing Docker Support, Container Image Registry, Monitoring and AutoScale Aspects

Considering this as a conference for Architects, would it be more appropriate to include some additional topics?

There is a difference what the presentation will touch on and the hands on portion. The hands on portion is simple use of docker.

The presentation will touch on Docker Swarm, EC2 Container Support and Lambda.

4) In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Paulo

Your other suggestions are good and I will do them before I finalize the abstract.

talk.title: An Architect's Framework for Navigating Complexity
talk.description:
We want our organizations and systems to be agile. We want them to evolve with the needs of the business, its customers and stakeholders, and to be resilient in the face of ever changing market conditions and the external environment. This level of adaptability and responsiveness needs to be supported by the architecture of the systems we create. The complexity of the environment that architects find themselves in is increasing in recent years, with cloud, DevOps, continuous deployment, micro services and other elements adding to the factors that architects must consider. With this growing complexity, architects need to be supported by effective decision-making approaches.

Size is also a factor. Larger systems and larger organizations have, by definition, a larger number of dependencies (internal and external) that must be managed, and a larger number of stakeholders (internal and external) whose needs must be addressed. The architecture of larger systems can involve hundreds or thousands of people, creating dozens to hundreds of products, components and subsystems that all need to work together. Maintaining the conceptual integrity of the architecture under such circumstances, and over time, presents many challenges and a greater need for coherence. 

To navigate all of this, agile architects need to be adaptive; they need the ability to dynamically shift their decision-making approach to match the complexity of the circumstances they face. This session will describe how lessons from complexity science, and in particular, sense making and the Cynefin framework, can help architects to be more agile in how they work, and in turn, help them develop architectures that are more agile and adaptive to the needs of the organizations they serve.

### Learning Outcomes
* Applying sense making in the context of architecture
* Applying the Cynefin framework to architecture problems and decisions
* Examples of architecture problems and decisions that can be mapped to the different domains represented by the Cynefin framework (obvious, complicated, complex, chaotic and disorder)
* How to manage the transition of architecture problems between these different domains
* Implications for organization structure and communications
* How such an approach leads to a more resilient architecture, and a more antifragile organization
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework supports emergent architecture
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework help the organization and the architecture to be more agile

### Format
For a 90-minute workshop I typically use the following format. 

Part 1 (5 minutes):
Introduction

* Overview of concepts

Part 2 (10 minutes): 

* Architecture descriptions
* Using narrative to understand architecture

Part 3 (40 minutes):

* Sense Making analysis of architectures and their influence on the organisation
* Analysing the patterns that emerge from the sense making activity

Part 4 (30 minutes):

* The Cynefin Framework, and how it applies to architecture
* Designing experiments

Part 5 (5 minutes):

* Debrief and wrap up
talk.notes:
The majority of the session is highly participatory. All five parts outlined in the session description have some element of participation. Parts 2-4 are the major parts of the session. In part 2, I guide participants through sketching their architecture and creating narrative about their architecture. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. In part 4, I guide participants in understanding the Cynefin framework in more detail and designing an experiment to address complex challenges that emerge in the analysis. Parts 1 and 5 have less activity, but still have dialog and interaction.

I will bring all the supplies that I need to run the exercise. It is more effective if the room is set up “banquet style”, with round tables that set groups of 6-10. 

I have been working with sensemaking and complexity for a few years now, and have run variations of this activity many times, both inside Cisco and at conferences and other forums. At the heart of this is the concept of applying sensemaking and the Cynefin framework to managing the complexity faced by architects. That complexity is not just in the architecture itself, but also in the problem domain, the organization, and the wider context within which architects do their work.

My background is in software engineering and architecture, in the context of product and systems development, and in transforming engineering organizations around the world. I use the techniques I present here in my own work, and I also help architects, engineers, and others, apply these techniques in their work.
talk.abstract: To create resilient and antifragile systems, architects must use decision-making approaches that help them better navigate the complexity of their environment. Participants in this hands-on session will learn how to apply sensemaking and the Cynefin framework to architecture-related challenges.

ratings.comments: I think this would be a valuable and engaging session.  Cynefin has been quite influential in the agile and lean communities and I think it would be really interesting to have a session exploring and explaining its use on architecture problems.

Like many, I've admired the Cynefin framework for some years.  It's ideas have always struck me as being elegant and potentially useful.

I would be very keen to hear about the experiences of somebody who how has been putting the framework to practical use.

This would fit within the other topics of interest as a practical example of innovative designs and solutions in general.
Seems appropriate for the SATURN conference.

A well thought-out participatory session on a topic relevant for SATURN. Ken is a good speaker and the presentation has a track record at other venues. The conference organizers will need to ensure the room setup supports his requirements.
Great topic. Ken is great too.
This seems like something that could be very useful in the architecture toolbox. I would like to see this at the conference.
The topic sounds very interesting . I am just concerned about the timing (90 Minutes).
This looks like a highly relevant and well structured workshop provided by a well renowned presenter.

feedback.body:
Thanks for submitting a very novel topic. Is there any real life use cases in the domain of architecture where this approach has been successfully used,  how the approach makes a real difference to what architects can achieve? Would they be presented along?

As you mentioned complexity could vary itself in terms of not just the architecture itself but also with respect to different aspects of the organization where Architects don't have an absolute control. Would you be detailing how the Architects need to handle those scenarios? 

Would there be any simulations or other participatory exercises for the audience considering that the session is for 90 Minutes ?

Here is another similar content I could find over Web http://www.agilearchitect.org/agile/articles/order%20and%20unorder.asp. In any way is your work related?

Hi Yogeshwar. Thank you for your feedback and review.

Yes, I will include real applications of this approach, together with experiences of how it can make a real difference.

I will provide examples of complexity and challenges in both architecture and the organisation aspects. The exercises encourage people to use their own examples that we will work through for 90 minutes. I leave it completely open to whatever people bring. These invariably include organisation challenges as well as technology challenges. The approach in the session deals equally well with both.

Yes, the majority of the session is highly participatory. I will edit the content to reflect that, and make it apparent. All five parts outlined in the session description have some element of participation. Parts 2-4 are the major parts of the session. In part 2, I guide participants through sketching their architecture and creating narrative about their architecture. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. In part 4, I guide participants in understanding the Cynefin framework in more detail and designing an experiment to address complex challenges that emerge in the analysis. Parts 1 and 5 have less activity, but still have dialog and interaction.

Regarding the article you refer to: yes, there is a relationship. We both draw on some of the same reference material. That article is based on the work of Dave Snowden, creator of the Cynefin framework. It is a nice summary of one paper that Dave wrote with Cynthia Kurtz. I draw on a broader set of Dave's work, as well as other work in sense making and complexity. I also take participants through how to apply this work in practice.

Regards,
Ken

Yes, the majority of the session is highly participatory. I will edit the content to reflect that, and make it apparent. All five parts outlined in the session description have some element of participation. Parts 2-4 are the major parts of the session. In part 2, I guide participants through sketching their architecture and creating narrative about their architecture. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. In part 4, I guide participants in understanding the Cynefin framework in more detail and designing an experiment to address complex challenges that emerge in the analysis. Parts 1 and 5 have less activity, but still have dialog and interaction.

Regarding the article you refer to: yes, there is a relationship. We both draw on some of the same reference material. That article is based on the work of Dave Snowden, creator of the Cynefin framework. It is a nice summary of one paper that Dave wrote with Cynthia Kurtz. I draw on a broader set of Dave's work, as well as other work in sense making and complexity. I also take participants through how to apply this work in practice.

Regards,
Ken

talk.title: An In-Depth Look at Event Sourcing with CQRS
talk.description:
Although Event Sourcing has been around for many years, it remains outside the mainstream paradigm of software development--much to our detriment.

With Event Sourcing, we place the highest value on the simple capture of essential business events without attempting to interpret them. We can then relegate all interpretations of those events to subsystems that are easy to build, change, and replace when necessary. The resulting systems have single responsibilities and are decoupled from each other, which makes them simple to modify. Event Sourcing can enable us to move faster by supporting rapid experimentation with new perspectives, new user interactions, and new insights into our business.

Event Sourcing is agnostic of technology stack and language style, but it goes well with another pattern called CQRS: Command Query Responsibility Segregation. In this talk, we will do a deep-dive into the two patterns and scope out a system that has:

* Receiving and validating Commands that, if successful, result in Events (with pseudocode to illustrate how it might work).
* Interpreting Events into denormalised projections for very fast reads.
* Single responsibility services for reacting to Events by creating other events and, if necessary, triggering external behaviour.

We will also cover more in-depth topics, such as:

* Strategies for evolving events and event schemas over time.
* Dealing with eventual consistency.
* Popular technologies for various system components, such as how to store and distribute events.
talk.notes:
This is a 90 minute talk. I gave a 30 minute version of this talk at SATURN 2016, which was very well received. I thought I'd see if there was interest in a longer version to expand on the many questions that followed. You can see the 2016 talk here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TeMYF_JjNg

Since last year, my involvement in building Event Sourced systems have grown exponentially. My company, Envato, has continued building Event Sourced systems and has emerged as a leader for this particular pattern in Australia. As the principal Software Architect at Envato, I have been a key part of this journey, which has also involved speaking with a variety of other companies about their Event Sourcing experiences.
talk.abstract: Event Sourcing is an approach to building software with a long track record of success. By placing business concepts at the heart of our code, we can decouple systems into small services that can be quickly built, changed, and replaced. This talk will show you how.

talk.title: Architecture Decision Records in Action
talk.description:
Documenting architecture design decisions is commonly considered a good practice but few teams take the time to write down the decisions they make.  In my experience this happens for a few reasons:  architecture documentation is rejected as being too heavyweight, documentation is typically out of sight and out of mind, and many developers don't know what to document.  Architecture Decision Records (ADRs), a lightweight documentation approach [proposed by Michael Nygard](http://thinkrelevance.com/blog/2011/11/15/documenting-architecture-decisions), solves these problems by recording design decisions in a simple markdown template in the same repository as the code affected by the ADR.  In this talk we will share our experiences and lessons using ADRs over the past year while working on multiple projects for IBM Watson.

By the end of this talk you will be able to create effective ADRs, introduce them to your team, and avoid common pitfalls with the method.
talk.notes:
This talk is intended to be a 30 minute experience report.  I can't figure out how to change the session type to match this.

The talk will have the following tentative outline.

1. Introduction / Problem overview: teammates don't have architectural context, decisions aren't communicated and are lost over time
   * Failed attempts to solve the problem -- wikis, dedicated repos, "official" documentation
2. ADRs Overview
   * Nygard's proposal
   * Connection to other work and research
3. How we use ADRs
4. Exercise: Create an ADR (optional, may fall out depending on timing, at most this is a 5-7 minute exercise)
5. Case Study: IBM Watson Information Retrieval Enhanced team
   * This section will include the proposed lessons and tips for adopting and using ADRs based on our experiences
   * Create a common template that everyone agrees to use
       * examples from case study
   * Identify an architecture champion to point out when architectural design decisions happen
   * Add ADR creation tasks to the backlog
   * Use pull requests and peer reviews to teach people how to record a decision and to
       spread konwledge about decisions
   * Use ADRs to grow architects on your team
       * Creating an ADR is a small slice of design responsibility.  It turns out to be a great way to
           infuse the team with architectural thinking and train new architects
   * Store ADRs with the code
   * Works great with microservices where small groups of people and the code
       they create work autonomously within a light governance framework
   * Revisit old ADRs every so often to update them and ensure you have accurate reflection of current thinking
6. Problems we ran into with ADRs and are still working through
   * Plain text diagramming is a pain point.
   * ADRs emphasize architectural decisions for a single component.  This is great for smaller projects and
      individual microservices but falls apart when multiple architectural components stored in multiple code
      repositories are involved.
      * Our solution was to create an "Architecture" repository, which stored ADRs that cut across multiple
         architectural components, linking to refinement ADRs as appropriate.
   * Overemphasis on design decisions at the expense of other design documentation
       * The team became awesome at recording ADRs to the point where they wouldn't document anything else!
       * ADRs were smashing success.  Complementary methods that are as simple and lightweight are needed for
          design concepts other than decisions.  examples: alternatives, governance policies, general design guidance,
          quality attribute scenarios and other architecturally significant requirements
7. Conclusion
   * closing thoughts on using ADRs as a way to "sneak in" architecture
   * great way to create a history of the project and explain not only where we are but how the system arrived at this point
   * Show where ADRs fit as part of an documentation strategy 
   * Links to additional resources
talk.abstract: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) capture key architectural design decisions in a lightweight, easy-to-create, plain text template stored in your existing version control system.  In this talk we will explore case studies from the IBM Watson IR Enhanced team and learn how to use ADRs.

feedback.body:
Michael-
The SEI Views and Beyond book discusses documenting architecture decisions (Section 6.5). That discussion was based on work by Jeff Tyree and Art Ackermann (https://www.utdallas.edu/~chung/SA/zz-Impreso-architecture_decisions-tyree-05.pdf). It might be worth including some comments in your talk about how your/Nygaard's approach compares and contrasts with this earlier work.

Hi John,  Thanks for your feedback.  I am familiar with the Tyree/Ackermann paper.  I actually [referenced the same paper as a comment on the blog](http://disq.us/p/18d4i4r) about 8 months ago in an attempt to point out the same thing!  We also include a link to Nygard's blog and that paper in our ADR template as background information.

I am certainly planning to make this connection in the talk, if accepted.  The two templates have the same goal in the end but collect slightly different information.  The ADR is significantly simpler, if nothing else.  I think a key difference and the thing that is kind of unique about Nygard's approach is in what is done with this information.  It sounds simple, but storing the design decisions in the version control system acted almost as a stealth way of injecting some of the ideas from Views and Beyond into the team.  What's more a small ecosystem of tools has sprung up around ADRs.  See https://github.com/npryce/adr-tools and https://github.com/holytshirt/dotnet-adr as examples.

Finally, Thougtworks recently [classified ADRs as "trial" methodology](https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/techniques/lightweight-architecture-decision-records).  It is my hope that an experience report like this might provide additional backing for either making this practice a recommended approach, or at least recommending it with caveats.

Regards,

Michael

That's a great topic and thanks for submitting. I first encountered the importance of maintaining Architectural Decisions ass a part of the SEI Views and Beyond book. I have been a great advocate and have used them ever since. I think its an important technique that needs good attention and would help many Architects attending the conference. The approach of understanding software architecture in terms of a variety of architecture decisions is now widely recognized.

However, I do have a suggestion. Instead of the talk just focusing on ADR as suggested by Michael Nygard, what would be even useful is discussing the approaching of Documenting Architecture Decisions as a whole, which decisions to document and not, the payback/benefits and the variants available for documenting them along with your case study.

Also, I am concerned about the idea of just storing the Architecture Decisions in isolation without many other significant Architectural Artifacts. I understand that the Thoughtworks seems to recommend including them in the “trial” methodology. However, I am just concerned with the misnomer that these are the only set of significant artifacts for all cases. Could the details be presented more on the lines of Evolutionary Architecture.

Hi Yogeshwar, thanks for your feedback!

I share your concerns and plan to address them in the talk.  I mentioned the points you raise under section 6.  I am certainly not suggesting this is the only set of artifacts required and recognize this is a trap teams easily fall into -- one of my teams did!

With respect to deciding when to document a decision vs. not, I plan to cover that under 5.4 and 5.5.  It turns out that people don't always know or recognize when an architectural decision has been made.  Pull requests and explicit architecture tasks combined with pairing was how we worked through some of those issues, in addition to including clear guidance in our template.  Basically we created situations for on the job training over time.

My goal is to attempt to place this technique within the context of the broader literature, as you suggest.  As you also point out, the idea of recording decisions is not new and is a commonly understood good practice.  The point of this talk is not to retread old ground but to look at good practice from the perspective of a newer method that people actually use and seems to resonate well with developers.  These ideas have been around for a while, and yet few teams practice them.  Why?  I think this method is another incremental step in the right direction.  By the end of the talk people will be armed with the knowledge they need to be successful with the method, not just try it out.

Regards,

Michael
Thanks for the detail! All the very best.

Looks like a very interesting session, Michael. I think maybe I would drop the exercise in a 30 min talk, the coordination can be potentially time consuming. Just a thought. Otherwise it looks like a solid outline.
