talk.title: The life and times of an architecture - Architectural decision making throughout the solution life cycle
talk.description:
Over the last decade, the architecture discipline has matured from up-front design to a stream of architectural decisions that address the concerns related to ever-evolving software systems. The word “stream” implies a continuous process, but in real life that stream is far from homogeneous. Architects (or whoever else owns the design decisions) find themselves making decisions with widely varying impact, based on information with differing levels of uncertainty, throughout the life of a software solution. On top of that, the way these decisions and their impact are communicated evolves as the audience and the focus of the architectural communication change.

In this tutorial, we explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making, throughout a software solution’s life cycle. Amid all the fluidity of the stream of design decisions, we will look for anchor points with common concerns to address and recurring communication needs. We will see how the nature of architectural decisions changes when we go from birth (the first architectural outline) to graduation (making the business case), and find guidance on communicating the architecture at times of life-defining milestones like marriage (committing to the architecture) and revolutionary changes to the solution. The points will be illustrated by real-life examples from an interesting case study.

The tutorial is based on Risk- and Cost-Driven Architecture, a popular approach to improve architecture practices in both traditional and agile contexts, with the aim of providing “just enough anticipation” in the architecture. No prior knowledge of RCDA is required to attend.
talk.notes:
This is a 90-minute tutorial.

During the product lifecycle, key aspects of architectural decisions change, depending on the life stage:

* level of risk and cost control: the cone of uncertainty
* available information to base architectural decisions on
* impact of architectural decisions
* number of architectural decisions
* cost of change to the architecture

Certain milestones like graduation (approving the business case for the solution) and marriage (the moment after which it becomes very expensive to change the architecture) occur in every solution life cycle. Such milesones lead to standard stakeholder concerns, like affordability, level of risk control and predictability. We use the commonality of these concerns to provide the architect with standard views in their documentation, enabling them to show how the architecture addresses these common concerns.

Contents
-----------

1. Introduction: 
 * Architecture as a stream of design decisions
 * Cone of uncertainty
 * Project vs. product life cycle
2. Birth:
 * From stakeholder need to solution concept
3. Graduation:
 * Making the business case
4. Marriage:
 * Committing to the architecture
5. Career and home life:
 * Fulfilling the architecture
 * Emergent architecture
 * Evolutionary changes
 * Health and debt control
6. Children:
 * Revolutionary changes
7. Legacy
talk.abstract: Explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making throughout a software system's life cycle. Find guidance on communicating your architecture at birth, graduation and marriage, after which changing the architecture becomes very expensive...

talk.title: Turning projects into products and wind into profit, or how GE Renewables was transformed into a Cloud SaaS Provider
talk.description:
At SATURN 2016, I introduced a novel lean approach to developing product architecture that combines Lean Model Canvas, Design Thinking, and Agile practices.  This year, I am excited to share a case study of how it was applied at GE Renewables Digital to bring software products to renewables assets.

In partnership with IT, field engineers, data scientists, and software engineers I watched an entire digital organization grow agile and innovating.  My fellow architects were the guides who captured the tribal wisdom and rallied both executive and product management sponsorship to launch two product lines in 2017 – Digital Wind Farm and Digital Hydro Plant, both demoed at GE Minds and Machines 2016 event. 

This session is based on my experience leading GE Digital Renewables architecture strategy for Asset Performance Management and Operations Optimization.  Renewables energy presents unique and diverse challenges when it comes to delivering software at scale.  Connecting hundreds and thousands of wind turbines and solar panels, fine-tuning analytics at the edge and the cloud, and assuring NERC compliance through Secure DevOps are some of the concerns to consider.

The participants will be walked through the journey and challenges on the way to migrating both existing applications and building brand new applications on a cloud platform and how architecture best practices accelerated the management and minimization of technical and functional debt.

The session also presents the trade-offs both at tactical and strategic level for moving forward with new technology without missing the beat of capturing the market opportunity for innovation leveraging horizontal products such as Asset Performance Management from Predix to accelerate renewables business objectives.

Two major product portfolios - The Digital Wind Farm and the Digital Hydro Plan were enabled with Common Renewables Asset Model based on IEC and S95 standards.   Model development was crowd-sourced to both IT, service engineering, and software development to capture both domain knowledge and leverage break-through features of distributed graph storage and scale with micro services.

This year, I am excited to share a case study of how it was applied at GE Renewables Digital to bring software products to renewables assets.

talk.title: Ultimate Architecture Enforcement – Write Your Own Rules and Enforce Them Continuously
talk.description:
The software architecture discussed and carefully created is often not entirely followed in the implementation. In this talk we'll examine the factors that lead to this disconnect between the architecture and the code. We'll learn that consequences of this problem go beyond maintainability issues. But most important, we'll look at an easy to use, automated solution to improve architecture conformance. This solution has been successfully applied in a mid-size organization. It uses free open source tools and also helps to raise architecture knowledge across the development team. 

Things you will learn:

- the importance of architecture conformance. 

- how to use free open source tools to create your own design rules. Through examples, you'll learn the basics of the SonarQube custom check API. 

- how to enforce the architecture continuously by integrating the custom rules to your CI infrastructure. 

- how to make this setup effective, based on lessons learned by the author in the past 6 years. 

No pre-requisite knowledge is required other than basic understanding of object-oriented programming.
talk.notes:
This talk is supposed to be a 90-minute tech tutorial. 

Early results of the approach discussed in the presentation were described in a [SATURN blog post](https://saturnnetwork.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/ultimate-architecture-enforcement-prevent-code-violations-at-code-commit-time/). 
More recent results were described in a [SPLASH Wavefront paper](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2508433).
The SATURN presentation is updated to reflect recent improvements and results.

*Session mechanics* 

This is a slide-based presentation. I'll also use the IDE to show and run some code. Questions and comments are welcome during the talk or at the end. 

*Talk outline*

- Introduction: Motivation for architecture conformance; factors that lead to lack of conformance; consequences of lack of conformance.
- Creating a custom rule: intro to static code analysis tools with an API to create custom rules
- Example 1 - enforcing a layered architecture (for each example, we'll examine the code and comment on the SonarQube API)
- Example 2 - enforcing mandated generalizations
- Example 3 - enforcing REST service design standards
- Automated tests for custom checks: quick overview of how to build and run automated tests
- Integration with continuous integration
- Running critical checks in a pre-commit hook on git or svn
- Our experience with custom checks: results and lessons learned in 6 years 

*Target audience*

This talk is particularly important to software architects, but is of interest to software developers in general. 

*Previous presentations* 

SPLASH 2013; The Brazilian Conference on Software - Theory and Practice 2013; 3er Congreso Internacional Escuela de Ingeniería de Sistemas y Computación (Peru); invited talks at different organizations.
talk.abstract: The architecture carefully created is often not entirely followed in the implementation. If you want to learn an easy to use, automated approach to avoid this issue, come join us in this tutorial. The approach has been successfully applied in our organization for over 6 years now.

talk.title: Using Conway’s to Architect a Team
talk.description:
In 1967 Melvin Conway submitted a paper to the Harvard Business Review titled “How do Committees invent.” In this paper he wrote that 

*Any organization that designs a system (defined more broadly here than just information systems) will inevitably produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure.*

 The paper was ultimately rejected on the grounds that Melvin had not submitted enough evidence to support his claims (It was published in Daatamation and is available online) . However his hypothesis became known as Conway’s law and many organizations can say that they have observed the same behaviors as outlined in Melvin’s original paper. 

Here at IBM Watson, we just completed an initial release of a new microservice-based cloud platform. This service involved multiple teams, multiple microservices and multiple timezones.  We took a cloud product from inception on a lightening fast roller coaster ride to GA in five months, and lived to tell the story. We didn’t get everything right, but we learned alot along the way and we’d like to share those learnings. 

In this presentation we will share our experience, and talk about some of the architectural successes and mistakes we made. We’ll talk about how we used Conway’s law, and the inverse Conway manuever to correct some of those mistakes. We’ll also touch on some of the issues confronting our teams with remote team members and how we solved them. We’ll provide a prescription for approaching team architecture based on our learnings. 

By the end of the presentation, attendees will gained a knowledge of Conway’s law, how to use it to their advantage, and how to take an architecture led focus for team creation and development.
talk.notes:
This will be a slide-based presentation with the following tentative outline:

* Problem statement: Architecting teams is hard to get right the first time. Conway's law seems to be the right thing to do, but presents a challenge in many organizations. Architecture led team formation as a strategy.
* Review: Conway’s law, Stages of Team Formation
* Motivating Example: Describe the team formation for Watson Cloud service
* Lessons learned
* Techniques used to overcome the challenges faced
* Outcomes of using those techniques
* A prescription for architecting teams based on our experiences
* What’s next? 
* Conclusions

### Learning outcomes
By the end of this session you will be able to answer the following questions:

* What is Conway’s law?
* What is the inverse Conway manuever
* When might a good time be to employ these techniques?


### Target audience and assumed knowledge
* Managers who want to learn how to use Conways law to their advantage.
* Architects interested in finding ways to influence team formation through architecture

### We assume the following audience background.
* Understands basic software development challenges with multiple teams
* Has heard of Conway's law

Has this content been presented before?
This material has not been presented in this format externally to IBM.
talk.abstract: For software managers and architects, this talk is intended to provide some guidelines for using Conway's law based on real experiences in the field so that they can find better ways to form teams in the age of microservices architecture.

ratings.comments: The topic is important and the execution of the topic promises to be a good balance between theory and case study. Will is a known presenter who has presented successfully at past SATURNs, and I'm confident that this talk would fit nicely into our program.
Yes, I like this. Using the observed organizational laws like Conway's law to our advantage is a very interesting premise that goes beyond simply being aware of them. Great talk suggestion.
Relevant topic, speaker has good track record. 30 minutes seems like the right length for the material.

feedback.body:
Will-

This proposal is interesting and relevant. A couple of comments:
- The title should be "Using Conway's Law..."?
- I would be interested in hearing how much of your successes and failures were due to fundamental architecture modularization issues (informed by Conway's Law), and how much was helped or hurt by the microservices implementation of that modularization.
- Although rejected by HBR, Conway's paper was published in Datamation magazine. Datamation was one of the most influential IT practitioner publications of that era, which broadened the exposure of the idea. I sometimes wonder if it had been accepted by HBR if we would be talking about it now, or if it would have been missed by practitioners.

Great feedback. Thank you. I agree that it would be very applicable to talk about success and failures - due to architectural modularization issues (through Conway's) vs the actual microservices implementation. This distinction is actually quite relevant - as it will allow us to think about how much of an impact a microservices architecture has on top of a modularized team approach, whether positive or negative. I will add that to the agenda.
You raise a very interesting point about the "luck" of being rejected by HBR. What a fascinating topic- you could well imagine that if it had been accepted by HBR - that it could have been missed entirely by the software architecture community and perhaps it would have sprouted more generally into other communities of practice. This is a perfect "What if" scenario and will fit nicely into the talk as food for thought.

Hi Will!

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. What do you mean by "a cloud product"? A software product that runs on the cloud? Is the cloud product the cloud platform that you mention in the previous sentence? In any case, can you say more about the nature of the software product?  

2. If I understood correctly, this talk focuses on the architecture of the *team*, not the software architecture. It talks about team creation, team architecture. Conway's law is indeed about the organizational structure. That's fine! But you say the product is microservice-based. I think microservices are not only independent deployment and runtime elements, but they enable independent, smaller teams. Microservice teams are hence easier to put together and manage. Following this line of thought, we would need more guidelines and wisdom about how to create a team for monolithic applications.  :^)

3. I often see Conway's Law (which should be Conway's Conjecture by the way) in texts that talk about microservices. I hope in your talk you can reflect about whether Conway's observation and the inverse maneuver can make sense to non-microservices software. 

Typos:

- "attendees will *have* gained"

- "we learned a* *lot along the way"

talk.title: Building composable abstractions
talk.description: Do you want to create robust and composable abstractions? In this talk Eric Normand will present an iterative process to define the essence of a domain and build composability into the core. The resulting abstractions lead to more robust code at the core of your application, and can give your business a competitive advantage. We will apply this process to the Processing graphics library to develop a composable vector graphics system.
talk.notes:
This is a 60 minute talk.

After attending the talk, the attendee will be able to:

1. Know the difference between Newtonian-style abstractions and Aristotelian-style abstractions. Aristotelian abstractions are built up piecemeal and are full of corner cases, like Aristotelian physics. Newtonian abstractions are elegant, formal, and composable.

2. Follow a design process for developing an algebraic abstraction that can compose and easily express solutions (Newtonian style). Building data transformation pipelines is the step most people who are learning functional programming get to from reading and experimenting. Building algebraic abstractions is the next step, but there isn't much literature on the topic (outside of academia)
    1. Elaborate a physical metaphor
    2. Describe the meaning of your metaphor as mathematical statements
    3. Construct the meaning using constructs from the language
    4. Implement the abstraction by refactoring the meaning
	
	The physical metaphor is an important first step that gives us an anchor from which we may use our intuition. We then query our metaphor for its properties and write them in math, which usually means types and equations. After that, we can construct a runnable version of the meaning, being careful to build it out of parts constrained by our statements from step 2. Finally, the implementation becomes an easy matter of refactoring our runnable version.


This topic idea comes from my experience teaching functional programming to people with all levels of experience. There seems to be a logical progression of insights that people go through as they learn about functional programming. I don't see many people getting past the "data transformation" step, so I want to present something further. It's hard to say whether it's THE next step, but it is at least one step beyond transformations.

A lot of the thinking comes from my experience as a professional Clojure and Haskell programmer and the work of Conal Elliott, John Hughes, and Gerald Sussman.

I have given a version of this talk at Clojure/conj 2016: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJIUoaIvD20 I would love to adapt this to a language like JavaScript. The example code will be given in JavaScript.

talk.title: Case studies of enterprise IT governance models for architecture and framework for architecture maturity assessment
talk.description:
Enterprise IT realized that architects play a critical role in evolving IT. Most large scale organizations have established the architecture teams to guide the organizations in constantly evolving IT. Architecture team structure and their governance maturity are critical to the success of an organization in navigating the IT challenges, bringing the innovation required to gain the edge in the marketplace and successfully delivering the IT projects for the organization. It is important for IT leaders and architects to understand the best practices in establishing the architecture teams in the organization, and how to assess the architecture team’s maturity. 
This session will present the experience from conducting many architecture assessments by one of the biggest consulting firms. Session topic begins with the evolution of an architect’s roles in evolving IT and how did architect’s responsibilities and influence change over the last 4 decades. Then, session moves to the observations from real-world on how organizations structure the architecture team and discuss the pros-cons of different architecture team structures observed in various industries. Also, the presenter shares the assessment model used to assess the architecture team’s maturity in enterprise IT and case studies from real-world architecture assessments. 
Attendees learn the best practices in structuring the architecture teams within an organization and how to increase the effectiveness of the architecture teams. Also, learn the architecture assessment model used in many assessments across the industries and multiple case studies presenting how did the architecture team influence the success and failure of organizations.

HI Thomas,

Thank-you for your submission.  The experiences you have to share sound very interesting.  Can I ask for a little more detail about the approach used?

When I hear of standardising on a common data model I think of the canonical data model pattern [1].  In recent years this approach has been  criticised [2] by those who favour the use of bounded contexts [3].

Do the pattern and solution from CRA relate to these patterns?  Are there other relevant patterns?  Does your experience reinforce or contradict any of these existing patterns?

Regards, 


Ged

[1] http://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/patterns/messaging/CanonicalDataModel.html 
[2] http://blog.xebia.com/microservices-architecture-principle-3-small-bounded-contexts-over-one-comprehensive-model/
[3] https://martinfowler.com/bliki/BoundedContext.html

Thank you for your insightful questions.  The first paragraph is the short answer and the next two paragraphs are background and explanation.  Your interest is greatly appreciated!

The model at CRA uses standards we developed for first data model for data collection which is bounded context.  In the ESRI data model we leveraged the Subtype and domains, where different subtypes drive the domains.  When we morphed the model into the ESRI standard electric utility model, the same holds true as the model is denormalized by mapping feature(i.e. transformer has a transformer layer rather than being one point feature in the point layer).

The modeling we applied has a time element.  There is a data collection stage of most any project which will require data to be normalized to geometry (points, lines and polygons representing features as electrical apparatus in the real world).  After this phase there is an information modeling aspect that requires use of standards to apply various third party tools and integrations.  The integrations vary depending on what solutions need to be integrated.  As budgets and priorities come into play the priorities are often different between power utilities.  However, Power utilities require Network Analysis and Power Outage Management Systems to maintain high systems availability.  The return on investment is staggering to implement the outage management and network analysis systems.  In addition the mapping must always tie to Work Management Systems.

Depending on the Utility size, microservices are typically used, however, there may need to be some cost saving, less expensive integrations such as ETL to move data into another format (i.e. daily job).  This is what happened with CRA and happens with most Power Utilities (even most very large ones).  There is a second reason for the reason web services cannot always be used – much of it has to do with the industry needs a network model that has sufficient performance.

talk.title: Connected Teams, Connected Code, and the Connected Device: The Challenges of IoT Software Delivery
talk.description:
Developing software for the Internet of Things (IoT) comes with its own set of challenges.  Security, privacy, and unified standards are a few key issues.  In addition, each IoT product is comprised of (at least) 3 separate application components: the software embedded in the device, the backend service, and the mobile application for the end user’s controls. Each component is developed by a different team, using different technologies and practices, and deployed to a different stack/target – this makes the integration of these separate pipelines and the coordination of software updates for IoT more problematic.  How do you coordinate the diverse moving parts that must come together when developing your IoT product or updating each of its components?

In this session we’ll deep dive to some off the challenges and share tips and best practices used by IoT developers to streamline and accelerate their product design, development, test and manufacturing

talk.title: Customer Experience Architecture Hands On
talk.description:
Architecture is about the customer. If you create an architecture that doesn’t give value to the customer you are wasting your time. When I talk to customers I often hear horror stories about how their current systems were developed by someone in an ivory tower who didn’t understand them or their work. So how do you make sure that you are bringing value to the customer through your architecture? Use customer centric design processes often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. These are fundamental parts of Lean and Agile and this session shows how to use them in architecture with hands on experience. In this highly interactive session participants redesign a system by interviewing a customer, creating a prototype, reviewing it with the group, and getting feedback on their design. Using the methods taught in this class you can create value for your customer through your architecture and become their hero, or at least not the person in the ivory tower who is ruining their life.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture
talk.notes:
My goal for this session is to help architects learn a customer centric design process. I learned this method from the "Deciding what to Design" course at Carnegie Mellon. The method is often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. Its a fundamental part of Lean and Agile. I've rarely seen people show how these methodologies apply to architecture, so thats my goal for class.

I use this process in my own work at GE and previously at Verizon.  I lead the End to End Customer Experience efforts at Verizon and enabled our architects and software engineers to talk to customers. I gave a talk on that experience at a past SATURN that generated a lot of interest.

At GE I am using this method to design a new CI/CD system for our Industrial Internet of Things platform called Predix. Customers (anyone who gets value from the system you are creating) really appreciate working with me. I find out very surprising things by using this method and create much better systems.


A slightly modified version of this session has been given before at Code on The Beach and was well received.  I used the "App for adding contact to network" use case and it ended up being a common but complex enough task that the groups had plenty to design. The Code on the Beach session was 60 minutes long and I assigned roles to each team member. I didn’t have time to have feedback given to each group, but I think it is an effective way to leverage the knowledge in the room. I didn’t have time to fit in the last wrap up session either, which I think is critical for people to concrete the new information. I've added those two parts to this 90 minute session.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture


The participatory session will include the following:
15 minutes
Introduction to Customer Experience Design
Introduce the hands on Exercise: Design a new system for adding a contact to your network (Linkedin, google+ , etc.)
Divide session into groups of 4 or 5 people.

10 minutes
Activity 1: Determine what matters to the customer including their functional requirements and quality attributes by watching how they do the task in their natural environment and asking lots of “why’s”. I will ask each group to select someone in their group to be the "customer." Each group will watch their customer collect a business card from a person and add a contact to their network of choice.

25 minutes 
Activity 2: Design the system around the customer’s needs and document it in a prototype. The prototype should be as interactive as possible, not just a flow chart. Prototype should show the architecture elements. Because the “customer” is involved, the team should be constantly getting input from the customer on their on going design. They should also write down any assumptions they are making and any reasons they made design decisions. Finalize the prototype, the assumptions, design decisions, and what they learned from the process.

30 minutes 
Activity 3: Review the prototype with the group. Receive feedback on design. About 5 minutes each group.

5 minutes
Wrap up: Allow the small groups to meet one last time to discuss the feedback and make any changes to their design.

10 minutes
Final Group discussion: Discuss what they learned from the session. Find out what they learned from receiving and giving feedback.

talk.title: Designing with NoSQL Databases
talk.description:
Schema design for NoSQL databases requires a very different approach from relational databases. The NoSQL databases have very high emphasis on huge data volumes, high and scalable performance, high availability and agility. As a result, the traditional concepts such as normalization, foreign key, join, strong transaction support, etc are done away with. How does one then design schema for various business applications?

In this session, we'll look at the concepts and best practices of schema design for three prominent NoSQL databases (MongoDB, Cassandra and Neo4j), with the help of diverse use cases, such as content management, single view, product catalog, social networks, system logs, fraud detection. We'll also look at the features for data analytics in these platforms. We'll also briefly look at when, why, and how to use polyglot persistence.
talk.notes:
I have presented tutorials on NoSQL in two earlier SATURN conferences. While those were beginner-level sessions, this one is for intermediate-to-advanced level users. 

I use NoSQL databases extensively in my work (architecture, teaching, consulting), and I have been helping organizations, primarily in the banking and retail sectors, in using NoSQL solutions for their business applications.
talk.abstract: In-depth discussion of concepts and best practices of schema design for three NoSQL databases (MongoDB, Cassandra, Neo4j), with the help of select use cases such as content management, single view, product catalog, social networks, system logs, fraud detection.

The topic of NoSQL schema design is something that I'm personally interested in and I think many others in the Saturn audience.  It would be easier to evaluate this proposal if it contained information about *what* the advice will be -- instead of asking questions, tell us what the answers are so we can judge if they sound interesting.

If accepted, I strongly encourage you to stick to one topic, not blend NoSQL schema design with polyglot persistence.  Yes, the topics arise on similar projects, but they are distinct design activities.  A talk on "best practices for NoSQL schema design" is a great topic by itself.

Hello George, 

Here are some of the "answers", which I'll illustrate with real usage scenarios:

For MongoDB:

* Nature of queries in your application determine the appropriate data model. 
* Aim to join while writing, not while reading.
* Embedding "many" side of a relationship) results in ease of retrieval, simpler queries, better performance. Variations for one-to-few, one-to-many, many-to-many. Tradeoffs. What to embed (_id / natural primary key / more than the natural primary key)?
* However, if an object frequently needs to be accessed on its own, embedding may not be the best choice.
* Don't embed very high cardinality documents on the "many" side. Variations and tradeoffs.
* Don't denormalize a "master" field / document if it needs to be updated frequently. The cost of finding and updating all the instances may be too high.
* If you frequently need to use data from documents from multiple collections when embedding is clumsy, don't be afraid of join at the application level.
* Use the power of the Aggregation Framework for complex query requirements.
* Get the best out of sharding. Choose shard keys for even distribution of writes and reads.

For Cassandra:

* Again, model around the queries in your application.
* Spread data evenly around the cluster.
* Think of the database as a nested, sorted map data structure.
* Denormalize for fast read performance. 
* Find the right balance between normalizing and denormalizing.
* Using column names for values, and leaving the column value empty is OK.
* Leverage wide rows for ordering, grouping and filtering.
* Choose the row key appropriately to partition your records for good performance.
* Segregate the read-heavy data from write-heavy data.

As suggested by you, I'll drop polyglot persistence, and model it as "best practices for NoSQL schema design". I think I should drop Neo4j, and limit myself to MongoDB and Cassandra for a more in-depth coverage.

talk.title: Location, Rewrite, Location: Tips and Tricks on Semantic URLs Architectures with nginx
talk.description:
The session will describe the best practices of semantic URL design and cache-friendly web architectures, based on the example of creating and rewriting a couple of web applications solely with the help of nginx.conf, the standard nginx configuration language.

On the example of [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/), we will show how it is possible to create a complete webapp entirely through nginx.conf from scratch; and on the example of [bxr.su](http://bxr.su/), we will show how to extensively modify the architecture of an existing legacy application to make it cache-friendly, and simultaneously improve the usability of the URL interface available to the user.

All of this will be accomplished through the internal directives of nginx and the machinery available through the standard rewrite module that is available and is enabled by default in all versions of nginx.

* Web applications are traditionally written in high-level programming languages such as Java, PHP, Python or Ruby.   But not [mdoc.su — a deterministic URL shortener for *BSD manual pages](http://mdoc.su/) — which stands apart from the established convention.   The whole [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/) web service is written in the standard and basic `nginx.conf` configuration language alone (with the help of regular expressions and dozens of `rewrite` and `location` directives), resulting in a high-performance semantic URL service without the help from any high-level programming languages like even Lua, Perl or JavaScript, being powered by [PCRE](http://ports.su/devel/pcre) and nginx.conf alone.

* On the example of [BXR.SU — Super User's BSD Cross Reference](http://BXR.SU/), we will also show how to `rewrite` the underlying architecture of Sun/Oracle OpenGrok, with the help of `nginx.conf`, without actually touching a line of the application itself. OpenGrok is written in Java, and is designed around the concept of cookies on every page (including the front page), and thus effectively cannot be cached or accelerated through a naive approach, due to the original architectural decisions that were made without considering their impact on the cacheability of the application. We will show how to successfully get rid of all the cookies with nginx, and how to greatly improve the usability and the URL interface of this Java application, all entirely through `nginx.conf`-fu.

No prior knowledge of nginx is required, but familiarity with HTTP is expected, and knowledge of regular expressions would come in handy, too.

Attendees will gain a clear understanding of how URL manipulation works within nginx, will surely be amused at the length to which the author went in creating the performant solutions, and will be able to design concise and deterministic URL shortening services using semantic URL schemes.
talk.notes: I'm affiliated with several BSD projects, being a member of the NetBSD Foundation (committer), and have already given this talk at several conferences and large crowds.
talk.abstract: Need to add support for semantic URLs to your website, but don't know where to start? Have to accelerate a legacy webapp, but have cookies coming in your way? Fear not, as we will show you the best practice on how to do both in nginx.conf, and without any non-default modules nor techniques.

I think to improve this abstract you should make it more clear _why_ someone would want to use nginx in these ways.  What are the specific use cases?  What are the pros and cons? Michael

talk.title: Making the switch to "serverless" full-stack development
talk.description:
"Serverless" is a newly-popular buzzword and as with many tech buzzwords, is a complete misnomer ("cloud", anyone?)  We're going to discuss what serverless really means (hint: it's a way of abstracting OS-level infrastructure management from server-side application code), what the difference is between the various providers, why you would want to consider using a serverless architecture, and how you would go about implementing one.  We'll discuss greenfield development as well as a migration path for existing web applications.  Other interesting aspects covered will be how the development workflow will change and why, what testing will look like in a serverless world, and some pitfalls to avoid.  While a serverless approach can be applied to applications written in a variety of languages, Javascript will be the language used for this talk, so we will examine some of the popular serverless Javascript frameworks, including apex.js, claudia.js, and serverless.js.

If you're interested in full-stack development, DevOps, micro-service architecture, containers, cutting operational costs, and/or just staying abreast with the latest application architecture approaches, this talk is for you.  This is a 90-minute, interactive, participatory workshop for which you will need your laptop, a Github account, and an Amazon AWS account.
talk.notes: I am an ex-IBMer who has been architecting and developing for nearly 20 years. I run a full-stack, custom software development shop in Los Angeles and Austin that's known for staying on the cutting-edge of tech.  I frequently speak at tech events (particularly JavaScript and Node.js focused events) and am passionate about designing great software.
talk.abstract: In the world of micro services and agile development, "serverless" architecture is now all the rage.  In this talk, you'll learn what it is, what it can do for you, why you would and wouldn't want to use it, and what you need to know to make the switch.  This will be a hands-on walk through.

Michael

Hi Michael!  I'll answer each question in turn below.

As this will be a hands on talk, what will participants need to bring with them to participate? 
-  Participants will need a laptop with git and node installed, an internet connection, and accounts on Amazon AWS and Github.  

Also, what tech stack will you be using during the session?
-  Full-stack Javascript: Angular.js on the front-end and Node.js on the back-end.  We'll use DynamoDB as the no-SQL database.  We'll also be discussing (and may use) some of the serverless frameworks like serverless.js or claudia.js.

I like that this is planned to be hands on and that you plan to discuss migration paths. We’ve had a lot of proposals around server-less architecture and only a few will be accepted.
-  Thank you!  We'll walk through taking an existing web application and refactoring routes over to a serverless architecture using AWS Lambda and AWS API Gateway.  Depending on time, we may get into testing, deployment, and other advanced topics.

In what situations would you recommend someone not adopt server-less architectures?
-  The biggest benefits for serverless are 1) decreased complexity for developers - abstracting away  server-level administration and devOps tasks and 2) lower costs for applications on VMs that spend time idling.  So, for those that have a mature, stable, and effective devOps infrastructure that already abstracts server complexity from developers and for those whose VMs don't have much idle computing time, transitioning to serverless probably isn't going to be cost/risk-effective.  

- There may be other reasons to not transition: risk aversion ("this is too new and unproven"), compliance ("we neither own the data center NOR manage any of the VM infrastructure??"), or simple mistrust ("how do I know it's going to scale when I really need it to?") It's important that application architects take into consideration their corporate policies, compliance and risk requirements, and organizational change tolerance when considering serverless.

talk.title: Quality Attribute Workshop in 2 hours
talk.description:
Our colleagues shared "Mini-QAW" presentation on SATURN-2016. I'd like to share not mini- , but nano-QAW approach best practices. 

Typical QAW is too massive for wide usage. That's why production reality of my global ISV company helped me to form shortened approach of QAW. I use this approach working with customers during architecture design, architecture assessment and other archtiectural activities. So, see how you can efficiently collect quality attributes and related metrics in, literally, couple of hours. I'll share best practices and real production case-study in this presentation.

So, efficiency comes from preliminary prepared list of quality attributes and related metrics. Being an expert you are doing your best guess to make initial draft cycle. And after that you are driving verification of your best guess vs opinion of representatives from customer. If you have representatives who are technical enough - they can provide you with good feed-back on your "guessed" attributes and improve your metrics. Business people are supposed to do final verification. 

So, if traditional approach based on "zero-cycle" with all stakeholders, this "nano" approach pushes from your expert opinion about what is important for customer in the future solution. And customer helps you to correct your guesses, customer representatives see the idea of QAW much faster in this case and you avoid draft steps and spending the time on them. 

At the same time, such approach is sensitive to the experience of the person who conducts nano-QAW and it is sensitive to competency of customer representatives.
talk.notes:
Presentation outlines:
1. Motivation for fast version of QAW
2. Nano-QAW approach in details
3. Nano-QAW approach best practices and artifacts
4. Production usage lessons learned
5. Case-study

What is the difference of nano-QAW from mini-QAW? See: 1. It is based on the experience of an Architect who prepares his/her best guesses about set of quality attributes and related metrics. 2. As the next step, Architect drives the workshop in a pretty dynamic manner, moving with technologists from customer side checking proposed list of attributes and metrics (by improving list of key attributes and getting threshold values from representatives' side). 3. Formed list of attributes is ranked by priority with technologists of customer. 4. Short meeting with business stakeholders is conducted in order to review formed list of attributes and metrics and checking priorities. 5. Work is done and list of attributes and related metrics is formed.

Such approach works extremely good when: 1. There are available technologists on customer side. 2. There are some ready-to-use expectations/understanding about future system performance/availability/etc on customer side.
talk.abstract: QAW is too massive. That's why production reality of global ISV company formed extremely shortened and fast form of QAW. See how you can efficiently collect quality attributes and related metrics in, literally, couple of hours. Best practices and real production case-study will be presented as well.

Thijmen, thank you for your questions.

talk.title: Rapid Specification of Quality Goals
talk.description:
Critical functional and quality goals and their conflicts must be understood in detail.  Unfortunately, many customers, managers, and developers have little understanding of how to specify, achieve, or verify quality goals.  Barry Boehm ranks qualities among his top 10 sources of serious project risk.

The SEI recommends that quality goals be identified in Quality Attribute Workshops (QAWs).  QAWs identify quality goals indirectly with scenarios and rely on “quality experts” to map scenarios onto quality goals.  Unfortunately, this indirect approach does not help customers make tradeoff decisions because of their poor understanding of quality relationships.  While scenarios are useful in describing some quality attributes, such as aspects of performance, they are not as useful for others, such as safety.

We propose an alternative approach based on the tailoring of a comprehensive quality attribute model to the needs of a project.  The model contains over 60 quality attributes.  Each attribute has over 30 characteristics including indicators and measures, supporting and conflicting qualities, threats and mitigations, and achievement and verification tactics.  The model also contains guidance on defining, achieving, and verifying quality goals.  The model is freely available at quality-aware.com.

This model distinguishes external qualities (visible to users e.g. reliability) from internal qualities (only visible to developers e.g. code readability).  We propose that goals for relevant external qualities be identified and defined in a tailoring workshop that includes most stakeholders.  Internal quality goals should be identified and defined in a meeting of technical management and senior developers.

This presentation will review the attributes model and simulate a tailoring workshop.
talk.abstract: Identification of quality goals is hindered by poor understanding of quality attributes.  We describe a specification strategy that relies on quality model tailoring.  This is compared to the development of scenarios in quality attribute workshops and the subsequent specification of quality goals.

talk.title: Real Life SOA Transformation: A journey at Rackspace from Monolithic to SOA and beyond (MicroServices)

- Rackspace - Legacy ESB Mayhem

- Use Cases and Decisions

Hi Yogeshwar!  

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. In the Talk Description, why is transformation capitalized in SOA Transformation? In particular, this phrase is not clear and somewhat intriguing: "the Software Transformation journey we should have in a fast-moving environment, where the agility is the key". Maybe there's more objective motivation for the specific transformations you will describe. 

2. I think most of the material out there is settling to using microservices as opposed to micro-services. 

3. If you find that your talk is too long, I suggest removing the first topic ("Rackspace - Business and System Perspective").

4. I think the description is somewhat vague, especially for a 90-minute session. If it's 90 minutes long, it takes the time equivalent to 3 30-minute talks, so the info should be clearly valuable. You mention a case study. Maybe you should say more about the case study.

5. Things you could add to the description to make it more interesting: what technology transformation will you talk about? If it's monolithic to microservices, what do your monoliths looked like? Java EAR apps? MS .NET? Where do you run your microservices? Docker? Kubernetes?  What tools and frameworks did you add to your runtime environment, development environment, continuous integration/deployment environment? 

6. I think the most challenging aspect of the monolith-to-microservice transition is finding the appropriate functional scope for the microservices. If they are too small, you may end up with chatty communications and lower autonomy and performance. If a microservice encompasses functional contexts that is too large, you move closer to the monolithic model and may not significantly realize the microservices benefits. What approaches have you used to help define the size of microservices? Did DDD help? 

7. What communication mechanisms did you use in microservices (what connector types)? Http (REST)? WebSocket? Asynchronous messages/events? 

8. I think "methods of how to accomplish large-scale technology transformations" is quite ambitious. If you don't have exactly methods, but guidelines or best practices derived from experience, that's ok too. 

9. I think you should say "a team of Architects from Rackspace will present" instead of "a team of Architects from Rackspace would attempt to present".

- "moving to new technologies come ** with significant challenges"

- "At the end of *the* presentation"

So, on one hand, we were doing a major re-haul of our systems and on another hand also making sure that we embrace SOA as well as providing incremental business value. talk.title: Hemispheric Data Capsules for Non-intrusive Testing of Time-Triggered Real-Time Systems
talk.description:
Without doubt, modularization and modules that apply the information-hiding principle – as originally described in Parnas’ “On the Criteria” paper – sustainably help to develop and manage systems that are complex and flexible, yet comprehensible. Modules are design-time units with fixed domains and hidden design decisions. Modules particularly promote systematic correctness analyses. However, these beneficial properties disappear once the modules have been integrated into and deployed on target machines. For embedded systems that run within tight real-time constraints, modules may even hamper integration tests and fault analyses, due to the inaccessibility of modules' internals. Hence, for an HW/SW-integration platform of an X-by-wire eCar, we developed HDCs in order to non-intrusively trace and test the behavior of single and multiple modules (HDCs) integrated into one or more platform nodes.

HDCs transfer modules from design-time entities to runtime entities. HDCs can be tested in integrated systems during field operation, without code instrumentation and probing effects. For this purpose, the HDC runtime environment captures data structures that flow within and between HDCs for one macro cycle (e.g. lasting 10 ms) of the time-triggered system; each macro cycle anew. An HDC can access only internal and parametric data structures. The probe is the only HDC with full access to all data structures, including its own. Because they are half-open for the probe and half-closed for all other HDCs, we call these data capsules hemispheric.

In the presentation, we will first reveal requirements behind HDCs originating from an industry study on an HW/SW-integration platform providing safety services to a fail-operational eCar (www.projekt-race.de/en). We will then sketch tests that can be run for HDCs. This motivates the design of an HDC system and its effect on the application and implementation of HDCs in general and the probe in particular, which we will describe afterwards. We will critically reflect on our experiences with HDCs during development, in the lab and in the field, as well as on the applicability of HDCs to event-triggered, object-oriented systems as basis for discussion.
talk.abstract: A Hemispheric Data Capsule (HDC) is a runtime entity of a module with externalized data structures. One probe, itself a HDC, suffices to reliably test a self-contained, time-triggered real-time system in terms of dataflows within and between HDCs.

ratings.comments: I am glad to see a submission about real-time systems. This area is still a minority of SATURN talks.

When I see people talking about "runtime modules", that has often indicated a fundamental misunderstanding of development-time coupling vs. runtime dependencies. This talk seems interesting, but may lack a mature architecture perspective (i.e. they have rediscovered and re-labeled something that is part of the architecture body of knowledge).
I like to see a diverse range of systems presented at SATURN as there is often much to learn form how other domains.
Technical, and in-depth, which may mean limited appeal. Yet an interesting design pattern idea in a hot area.
Would like to see the applicability of HDCs with software architecture

feedback.body:
Summary:
The presenters will explain their concept of HDCs that enable inspection of real-time system module’s private data structures at run-time.

The good and to improve:
I find the HDC design pattern proposition very interesting as it overcomes a real challenge of testing complex embedded systems. The relevance of such systems only increases with IoT, yet real-time/industrial systems pose challenges many ‘Internet’ or ‘IT’ style architects are unfamiliar with.

feedback.body:

Thank you again and kind regards.

This will help.

In your talk, I would like to hear about any disadvantages or costs (chronometric hits, for example) associated with implementing HDCs.

I would also like to hear about how you guide the use of these HDCs by developers through architecture, especially when there are many developers working on the same project. Are there particular mechanisms or rules that worked or didn't work for you?

user.name: Joachim Fröhlich, Florian Krautwurm, Stefan Rothbauer

feedback.body:
Dear reviewer, thank you very much for your comments.

(1) Ad "explanation of your definition of real-time" and "introduce the requirements behind your solution".

Our reference system and the environment for HDCs is the HW/SW-integration platform of an x-by-wire eCar. It is a time-triggered system that must perform critical functions within milliseconds. When we talk about the system context of HDC and requirements behind HDC we will also explain our definition of real-time. We announced already to talk about "requirements behind HDCs originating from …". Please see the agenda in last paragraph of the lecture description.

(2) Ad "implementation disadvantages and costs", "guide developers to HDCs" and "what worked or didn't work".

Considerations of issues and drawbacks are necessary for a balanced picture on HDC. Following your comments we will explicitly address chronometric hits because timing considerations are important for a real-time system that works with tight operation schedules.

A proper place for talking about challenges in general with HDC could be the section "critical reflection on HDC" which is already on the agenda. Currently, we do not intend to go into details regarding the development process. The presentation aims at technical matters of HDC. However, since modularization in general and working with HDC in particular affect the development organization and process, we are going to take a position on these points during the presentation as well.

Kind regards.

talk.title: Measuring DevOps: the Key Metrics that Matter
talk.description:
How is your DevOps transformation coming along? 
How do you measure Agility? Reliability? Efficiency? Quality? Culture? Success?!
How do you optimize your software delivery processes?

You can’t improve what you cannot measure. But are you measuring the right things? Are you measuring too little (or too late), or are you drowning in disparate data points that make it hard for you to get to the bottom line: where should you be focusing on next as you optimize your process?

Having the right goals, asking the right questions and learning by doing are paramount to achieving success with DevOps. Having specific milestones and shared KPIs play a critical role in guiding your DevOps adoption and lead to continuous improvement - towards realizing true agility, improved quality, and faster time to market throughout your organization.

This session will walk you through a practical framework for implementing measurement and tracking of your DevOps efforts and software delivery performance that will provide you with data you can act on!

These KPIs include metrics related to your software delivery pipeline and technical progress, as well as cultural indicators and business impact. In addition, we will cover common use cases and real world examples for implementing these metrics to drive DevOps success, as well as best practices for how to address certain challenges and problematic areas along your process that these metrics may bring to light.
talk.notes: This is developed to be a joint session with Electric Cloud CTO, Anders Wallgren: Anders Wallgren is chief technology officer at Electric Cloud. Anders has over 25 years’ experience designing and building commercial software. Prior to joining Electric Cloud, he held executive positions at Aceva, Archistra, and Impresse and management positions at Macromedia (MACR), Common Ground Software, and Verity (VRTY), where he played critical technical leadership roles in delivering awardwinning technologies such as Macromedia’s Director 7. Anders holds a B.SC from MIT.

profile.name: Jim van der Waal

talk.title: Abuser stories: how we embedded a security culture within our business.
talk.description:
With bol.com we experienced the flight ecommerce took the last decade. As the biggest ecommerce company of the Netherlands and Belgium security risks grew exponentially. But it’s not scalable to let your security team grow with the same rate. That’s why we also focused on creating a security culture within the company: making security a responsibility of everyone, not only the security team.

To not only create this culture in IT but also in the rest of the company, we organized Abuser Story workshops for Product Owners and Business Analysts. Abuser stories are a fun way of thinking about the security of your new features. It triggers to think of unhappy flows, think of thresholds to monitor and so on. Making the systems Secure by Design, something really relevant for architects. We saw that Product Owners consulted the security team and architects way more for advice when designing new systems, they gave room and time to developers to write secure code, and discussions between the Security and development teams were actually constructive. It helped to get the “security, we are in this together” mindset. 

In this talk Jim will tell the journey of bol.com, the growing importance of security, and the way we tried to cope with it in a fun way. The lessons learned are valuable for every (growing) company that struggles with making security scalable, and assuring that you will not only be secure today or tomorrow but also in 5-10 years.
talk.notes: Creating awareness in (IT) companies regarding security is becoming really important, and we saw that this awareness should extend way beyond IT. This is really necessary if you want to work agile, and I experienced that first hand. That is why I came up with this concept to extend the security culture to the business as well. Since it is more or less something I came up with myself I am very enthusiastic and passionate to talk about it. Especially since I experience the succes from it every day now in my projects.
talk.abstract: How do you cope with the growth of security risks? Creating a security culture in your company becomes more important every day. Providing your IT teams with the right tools is one thing, but new features start way before it reaches the development phase. So how do you create such a culture?

ratings.comments:
This looks really interesting and I'm very keen on getting architects and developers to be more interested in security, so I like the topic!

I would expand your abstract to make it clear what you're covering.  It's not clear what the audience will leave with.

I don't think in 15 minutes you have time to tell the story of bol.com, how you created a culture, lessons learned, ... Just sounds too much to me.  Can you focus it down to a short sharp message?

I'm also not quite sure how much you plan to discuss the Abuser Stories technique.  They are in the title and there is a lot there in the description, but they're not mentioned in the last paragraph.  I think this needs to be made clear.

This is a talk that I would like to see.  It cover three topics that I find interesting that are identified within the submission guidelines.

It promises to provide a successful case study on helping to assure quality from a security perspective.

More importantly, it focuses on creating a culture of security awareness within agile teams.  That is not easy to achieve, and I would be interested in finding out how it has been done.

Personally I would like to see a longer session with practical elements such as role playing an workshop.

Given that security is an after thought in most development organizations, this topic can possibly bring to light how to truly make everybody think about security.  Also, since security is quickly becoming on of the "ility" requirements, applicable to SATURN.

I like it, I'm also an advocate for addressing safety and security requirements early. Safety and security can't be something we try to fix afterwords. That said, I found it hard to see how this fits with the architectural thinking of a system.
I like this workshop but I don't see a clear connection to architecture design in the abstract.  As a requirements elicitation method it seems quite interesting.

The talk is about disseminating a security culture across the organization and eliciting security requirements for applications (as "abuser stories"). Apparently, it does not get to discuss security as a quality attribute and design driver or tactics and approaches to achieve security.

feedback.body:
Hi Jim,

Thanks for your submission!  I'm a huge fan of misuse cases and simple threat modelling for specifying security requirements.  This is a great topic but I could use some additional information to understand the scope of the proposed talk.

It sounds like the focus of this talk will be on requirements elicitation using the abuser story workshop?  Could you share some details about what that workshop looks like?  A tentative outline for your talk would be extremely helpful.

How is this workshop different from other security requirement  elicitation methods?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Micheal,

Nice to hear from you. I will try to answer your questions below and give some additional information.

About what I will tell about how we embedded a security culture in the company:
So how do you already get that security mindset embedded in earlier stages. How do you get people excited to think about security? Security has the prejudice that it is boring, that is something you have to do, maybe because someone else says so. Like the security team/department. But security can also be fun! Fun? Yes! By stimulating the employees to think like a hacker, either technical or functional, they got motivated to think of security requirements by approaching it from the other side. This in combination with the right tools really helped to get our security level to high standards.

Some more information about the Abuser Story Workshop:
With abuser stories we touch on a subject everybody worked with: user stories. Normally with user stories you define new functionality that you develop with the customer in mind. But how can this functionality be abused? We stimulate the colleagues creativity to think evil and create a hacker mindset for themselves. Turn it around: write an Abuser story: As a hacker, I want…, So that… We were surprised by the evilness of our colleagues – we had some real hackers among us. We do this by introducing a simple proces, let one team think about abuser stories (so how could you as a hacker abuse this functionality), and the other team about user stories on how to avoid abuse. After that the 'Attacking' team presents its abuser stories, which the other team needs to 'Defend' with one of their user stories. We then stimulate the Product Owners to braintorm about abuser stories at the kickoff of each new functionality, more or less facilitate their own workshop. The outcome is then translated in requirements for the different user stories.


There are actually two ways of how you can approach this talk. 

1. A (comprehensive) talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, where I will deep dive more in how we did this with the use of Abuser Story Workshops. This focusses more on how we created this security culture, and the lessons we learned from this proces.

2. A short talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, and facilitating a Abuser Story Workshop to illustrate how we did this. This focusses more on teaching you how you could facilitate these workshops yourself. 


Relevance for audience: the first is relevant for a broader audience, where the second talk (workshop form) is more relevant for Analysts and Product Owners.

I hope this gives you more insights. If you have any questions or you want me to elaborate a bit more, just let me know.

Regards,

Jim
Thanks, Jim.  Your responses are helpful.

Hi Einar,

Thanks! The safety case method is new to me. Within our company we have very little formal methods and formal documentation, so it is not a surprise that I did not come across it before.

Jim
Hi Jim, what type of session should this fall under? It's currently in the DEV@SATURN 15-minute category but seems like it might be longer. Please let me know. Thanks.

Thanks for your reply. Hope this helps.

talk.title: Agile Architecture and Design
talk.description:
Agile software development methodologies are mainstream now. But one of the nagging questions teams face is: how to establish the architecture for a system the agile way? After all, architectural decisions have a key impact on various qualities of a system, and therefore, these decisions have to be taken early and carefully. How does this fit with the incremental and iterative nature of agile methodologies? 

In this session, I'll cover the following aspects: 

* Creating an architecture vision, including desired architectural qualities, during Sprint Zero 
* Identifying potential strategies for achieving the desired architectural qualities, without creating an ivory tower architecture
* Prioritizing the architectural qualities and adding them to the Product Backlog along with the functional requirements 
* Implementing and verifying architectural qualities with the help of real stories from the Product Backlog.   

I will take concrete examples from projects on how to apply the above concepts.

I have worked on the architecture, design and implementation of many applications, in various domains including banking, insurance, retail, logistics, process control. 

I regularly conduct training programs in the fields of Agile with Scrum, Agile Engineering Practices (XP), Solution Architecture, Enterprise Architecture, and Writing Good Programs.

I have presented various sessions relating to Agile Architecture in many SATURN conferences, as well as Scrum Gatherings, Agile Conferences.

talk.title: An Architect's Framework for Navigating Complexity
talk.description:
We want our organizations and systems to be agile. We want them to evolve with the needs of the business, its customers and stakeholders, and to be resilient in the face of ever changing market conditions and the external environment. This level of adaptability and responsiveness needs to be supported by the architecture of the systems we create. The complexity of the environment that architects find themselves in is increasing in recent years, with cloud, DevOps, continuous deployment, micro services and other elements adding to the factors that architects must consider. With this growing complexity, architects need to be supported by effective decision-making approaches.

Size is also a factor. Larger systems and larger organizations have, by definition, a larger number of dependencies (internal and external) that must be managed, and a larger number of stakeholders (internal and external) whose needs must be addressed. The architecture of larger systems can involve hundreds or thousands of people, creating dozens to hundreds of products, components and subsystems that all need to work together. Maintaining the conceptual integrity of the architecture under such circumstances, and over time, presents many challenges and a greater need for coherence. 

To navigate all of this, agile architects need to be adaptive; they need the ability to dynamically shift their decision-making approach to match the complexity of the circumstances they face. This session will describe how lessons from complexity science, and in particular, sense making and the Cynefin framework, can help architects to be more agile in how they work, and in turn, help them develop architectures that are more agile and adaptive to the needs of the organizations they serve.

### Learning Outcomes
* Applying sense making in the context of architecture
* Applying the Cynefin framework to architecture problems and decisions
* Examples of architecture problems and decisions that can be mapped to the different domains represented by the Cynefin framework (obvious, complicated, complex, chaotic and disorder)
* How to manage the transition of architecture problems between these different domains
* Implications for organization structure and communications
* How such an approach leads to a more resilient architecture, and a more antifragile organization
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework supports emergent architecture
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework help the organization and the architecture to be more agile

### Format
For a 90-minute workshop I typically use the following format. 

Part 1 (5 minutes):
Introduction

* Overview of concepts

Part 2 (10 minutes): 

* Architecture descriptions
* Using narrative to understand architecture

Part 3 (40 minutes):

* Sense Making analysis of architectures and their influence on the organisation
* Analysing the patterns that emerge from the sense making activity

Part 4 (30 minutes):

* The Cynefin Framework, and how it applies to architecture
* Designing experiments

Part 5 (5 minutes):

* Debrief and wrap up
talk.notes:
The majority of the session is highly participatory. All five parts outlined in the session description have some element of participation. Parts 2-4 are the major parts of the session. In part 2, I guide participants through sketching their architecture and creating narrative about their architecture. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. In part 4, I guide participants in understanding the Cynefin framework in more detail and designing an experiment to address complex challenges that emerge in the analysis. Parts 1 and 5 have less activity, but still have dialog and interaction.

I will bring all the supplies that I need to run the exercise. It is more effective if the room is set up “banquet style”, with round tables that set groups of 6-10. 

I have been working with sensemaking and complexity for a few years now, and have run variations of this activity many times, both inside Cisco and at conferences and other forums. At the heart of this is the concept of applying sensemaking and the Cynefin framework to managing the complexity faced by architects. That complexity is not just in the architecture itself, but also in the problem domain, the organization, and the wider context within which architects do their work.

My background is in software engineering and architecture, in the context of product and systems development, and in transforming engineering organizations around the world. I use the techniques I present here in my own work, and I also help architects, engineers, and others, apply these techniques in their work.

I will provide examples of complexity and challenges in both architecture and the organisation aspects. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. profile.name: Sebastian von Conrad
profile.bio:

talk.title: An In-Depth Look at Event Sourcing with CQRS
talk.description:
Although Event Sourcing has been around for many years, it remains outside the mainstream paradigm of software development--much to our detriment.

With Event Sourcing, we place the highest value on the simple capture of essential business events without attempting to interpret them. We can then relegate all interpretations of those events to subsystems that are easy to build, change, and replace when necessary. The resulting systems have single responsibilities and are decoupled from each other, which makes them simple to modify. Event Sourcing can enable us to move faster by supporting rapid experimentation with new perspectives, new user interactions, and new insights into our business.

Event Sourcing is agnostic of technology stack and language style, but it goes well with another pattern called CQRS: Command Query Responsibility Segregation. In this talk, we will do a deep-dive into the two patterns and scope out a system that has:

* Receiving and validating Commands that, if successful, result in Events (with pseudocode to illustrate how it might work).
* Interpreting Events into denormalised projections for very fast reads.
* Single responsibility services for reacting to Events by creating other events and, if necessary, triggering external behaviour.

We will also cover more in-depth topics, such as:

* Strategies for evolving events and event schemas over time.
* Dealing with eventual consistency.
* Popular technologies for various system components, such as how to store and distribute events.
talk.notes:
This is a 90 minute talk. I gave a 30 minute version of this talk at SATURN 2016, which was very well received. I thought I'd see if there was interest in a longer version to expand on the many questions that followed. You can see the 2016 talk here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TeMYF_JjNg

Since last year, my involvement in building Event Sourced systems have grown exponentially. My company, Envato, has continued building Event Sourced systems and has emerged as a leader for this particular pattern in Australia. As the principal Software Architect at Envato, I have been a key part of this journey, which has also involved speaking with a variety of other companies about their Event Sourcing experiences.
talk.abstract: Event Sourcing is an approach to building software with a long track record of success. By placing business concepts at the heart of our code, we can decouple systems into small services that can be quickly built, changed, and replaced. This talk will show you how.
