talk.title: High-Performance Multi-Threaded Immutable Store for C++
talk.description:
We present an architecture for collaboration between loosely-coupled actors that share their state using an immutable store and a publish-subscribe pattern. This is different from the well-known [Actor model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actor_model) (Implemented for C++ in [[1]](https://github.com/actor-framework) and [[2]](http://www.theron-library.com/index.php)), which uses private state and peer-to-peer messaging, and is closer in spirit to the [Flux application architecture](https://facebook.github.io/flux/docs/in-depth-overview.html#content) and [Redux](https://github.com/reactjs/redux), with its single dispatcher and its unidirectional data flow.

Our data model is suitable for high performance and complicated algorithmic flows, where multiple threads require access to shared objects. We have implemented it in C++, and used it successfully as the application framework for the [iTero intra-oral Scanner](http://www.itero.com/en) (See demos [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_kYPyjUtbU) and [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tWuNPt33tho))

###Our architecture is based on the following principles:

1. All shared state is immutable and reference-counted
1. Each actor keeps a lightweight snapshot of the state, which consists of references to shared immutable objects
1. Actor snapshots are eventually consistent
1. Actors communicate using [Publish-Subscribe pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Publish%E2%80%93subscribe_pattern)
1. A single dispatch function is used for publishing both events and data updates
1. Persistence, replay, undo and application logging are handled by generic mechanisms
1. Objects can be marked as *invalidated*, allowing immediate, out-of-band signaling and cancellation of long-running computations
talk.notes:
##Primary track

I propose this talk for the track **"Development Tools, Frameworks, Techniques, and Patterns"**, because it introduces a new framework while referring to existing frameworks and patterns - the Actors model, Flux and Redux. The talk will be highly technical, with diagrams, code and a demonstration video. 

##Session type

This talk falls in the category of **"Technical Talks and Tutorials"** or **"Experience Report Presentation"** (30 minutes), because it is a highly technical presentation, based on my own experience and knowledge. The architecture framework I shall describe in the talk is one that I pioneered and developed, and it forms the basis for the application that drives the [iTero Element](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mdI5Pp2dVTg), a leading 3D intra-oral scanner for dentistry and orthodontics. The iTero software was developed under my technical leadership, as a chief architect and lead of the algorithms group. 


##About me

I have a Ph.D. in mathematics, and plenty of experience giving lectures. I have given 14 talks in international math conferences, including 2 Siggraph talks ([Siggraph 2006](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1141990), [Siggraph 1999](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=311541)). After 15 years of leading algorithms teams, I decided 4 years ago to become a software architect. Since then, I got a Software Architecture Professional Certification from SEI, and I have been constantly studying and teaching various domains of software engineering.

I am highly passionate about software architecture, and I love teaching software engineering and mentoring developers, as well as coding in multiple programming languages. See [My LinkedIn profile](https://www.linkedin.com/in/adi-levin-0a0a614).

I am also the submitter of a second talk, with the title **How to gain influence as a software architect**.

##Talk outline

 1. Present the challenge we faced
  - Show video and give a description of the [iTero intra-oral Scanner](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mdI5Pp2dVTg)
  - Explain the data model we use in earlier versions of iTero, and why it was inadequate for the new product
 1. Present the basics of the architecture
  - Define an "Actor"
  - Explain how actors access data and communicate via a dispatcher: All of the shared state is made of immutable data, and any modification is done by creating a new object, and broadcasting it
  - Explain the data model (each actor keeps a key-value dictionary, where the key-space is shared, and the values are pointers to reference-counted objects in the heap)
  - Explain about publish-subscribe and event handlers
 1. Explain how this architecture is different from the famous Actors Model
  - Provide links to existing implementations [1](https://github.com/actor-framework), [2](http://www.theron-library.com/index.php).
  - Explain how our model is based on shared state and publish-subscribe, while the Actors model is using private state and peer-to-peer messaging.
 1. Discuss more aspects of the architecture
  - Separation of concerns: Actors are responsible for message-passing and fetching data from the shared state, and they delegate computations to other objects that are tested in isolation
  - How an actor is created: the role of the dispatcher in making sure that a newly created actor has access to the most up-to-date state
  - A generic solution for persistence
  - Cancellation of long-running operations
  - Generic logging
  - A generic Record/Replay feature
 1. Discuss design trade-offs, and pros & cons of the architecture
  - Pros: Safe concurrency, and ease of implementing complex logic
  - Cons: Data model is flattened into a key-value dictionary, losing a natural hierarchy
 1. Shortly discuss a possible improvement of the data model
  - Use a persistent tree structure (as in [Redux](https://github.com/reactjs/redux)), instead of a flat key-value store, to restore the natural hierarchy of objects.

feedback.body:
Hi Adin,

Thanks for your submission.  Actors and actor systems are an important architectural pattern that have been around for a while but seem to have gained more traction in the past few years with the rise of frameworks such as Akka and an increase in distributed systems.  I like that this talk explores a hybrid pattern that combines actors, pub-sub, and peer-to-peer.  That is certainly an interesting combination and just hearing the thought process that led to the architecture design could be illustrative.

Here are a few thoughts for your consideration on how this abstract and tentative outline might be improved.

* Skip the video and get to the value as soon as possible.
* If the context of a specific project is important, this should be moved to the experience reports track instead of tech talks.  It looks like this is the case so I assume this is an experience report.
* I didn't see a clear discussion of the motivation. Why would someone what to use actors and pub-sub in this way?  What is the rationale behind the design decisions that were made?
* Sections 4 and 5 could use some tightening.  I like the discussion of trade-offs but section 4 seems like a general bucket of ideas.  If accepted please think about how this section can be organized to better convey your message.

One thing to think about: one are the top 2 or 3 things that someone who attends your talk should be able to do that they couldn't do before?    The answer to this question might help you find the right way to organized the latter parts of the talk.

Regards,

Michael

Thanks for the review, Michael. 

As you proposed, I will be happy to make this an experience report, and explain the thought process that led to our design.

I will make sure to clarify the motivation (indeed the outline I gave doesn't explain the motivation): The short video I want to show (approximately 45 seconds) is important in order to show the system in action, to provide context: I want the audience to understand what an intra-oral scanner is, and the speed at which it works, building a 3D model and providing feedback to the user in real time, with low latency (<200 milliseconds). This requires multiple threads to access large amounts of shared data for generating scans, refining them, repositioning them, rendering them and storing them to persistent storage - all simultaneously. This is why we chose to design a system where shared state can be accessed safely by collaborating threads. Pub-Sub was chosen because of the high complexity and the data-driven nature of the design (e.g. rendering is triggered when an object is changed, without the producer of the object having to communicate with the rendering actor; denoising and filtering algorithms are triggered when a new scan is created; etc...). Do you think this clarifies the motivation?

In answer to your comment about sections 4 & 5, I think I'll tighten this discussion by removing a couple of items from section 4 (the first two, probably), and incorporating the rest of them into the trade-offs discussion, showing how these aspects are added benefits: For example, the pub-sub nature, together with the dispatcher, enables a generic record/replay feature (like in Redux), and similarly, generic solutions for persistence and logging.

What will attendees be able to do that they couldn't do before? They will be able to implement a data model that supports efficient and safe sharing of memory in a multi-threaded application. This is useful for complex systems. Also, they will learn the benefits of channeling all writes through a single thread (dispatcher), which provides total ordering of messages, and is one way of ensuring consistency in concurrent systems.

WIth kind regards,

Adi.

talk.title: How to gain influence as a software architect
talk.description:
The best software architects combine strong creative and analytical skills, with the character traits of a leader. An architect needs to form collaborations with different teams, often with different styles of working and planning, in order to clarify the project's scope and requirements, and then design the architecture and implement it.

To achieve this, an architect needs to use all communication tools effectively: Meetings, architecture drawings, written documentation, design reviews, code reviews and informal conversations. In every opportunity, an architect should encourage the engagement of other stakeholders and must learn how to deal effectively with their concerns, and, in particular, how to deal with opposition and with conflict.

But communication techniques and technical excellence combined are not sufficient for sustainable effective leadership. To gain trust and credibility, one has to display consistent personal values and character ethics, and build relationships that are based on integrity and commitment.

In this talk, I will share with you my own experiences and lessons learned from years of working as a software architect in a global organization, and from studying dozens of the greatest writings from the field of business, leadership and communication.
talk.notes:
##Primary track

I propose this talk for the track **"Other topics of interest"**, since the lessons learned here are applicable to a wide range of circumstances, and are not related to any technology or software trend.

##Session type

This talk falls into the category of **"Experience Report Presentation"** (30 minutes, describing first-hand experiences and lessons learned). It is entirely based on my own experience, and the lessons I have learned in the past 4 years working in a global organization, gaining the trust and cooperation of stakeholders of all kinds.

##About me

I have a Ph.D. in mathematics and plenty of experience giving lectures. I have given 14 talks in international math conferences, including 2 Siggraph talks ([Siggraph 2006](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1141990), [Siggraph 1999](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=311541)). After 15 years of leading algorithms teams, I decided to become a software architect, 4 years ago. Since then, I got a Software Architecture Professional Certification from SEI, and I have been constantly studying and teaching various domains of software engineering. In addition, I have spent numerous hours studying the literature on leadership, personal growth, effective communication and influence, and I have successfully applied the techniques and principles to my work.

This will be my first talk in an international conference on software architecture. I created this talk after years of successful technical leadership in a global organization, gaining credibility with many people from remote locations and from various disciplines, in domains where I was often not an expert.

I am also the submitter of a second talk, with the title **High-Performance Multi-Threaded Immutable Store for C++**.

##Main theme

***Collaboration is power; Be genuinely interested in the concerns and challenges of others; Include them generously; Act with integrity***

All of the stories, insights, and tips that I share have the above theme in common. For example: When talking about effective online meetings, I share how useful it is to reflect people's concerns in writing and in real-time, as a way to verify that their concerns are understood correctly, and to give them the feeling that they have been heard; When naming components, I recommend to include others in choosing their names, as a way to encourage their collaboration; For dealing with opposition, I recommend to focus on a better understanding of the opposing party; On dealing with difficulties, I emphasize that this is the time to make extra efforts and display personal integrity, by being there for the developers, and by admitting and correcting one's own mistakes.

While those messages are all relevant to any leadership situation, I believe they are especially useful for software architects, whose effectiveness relies upon their ability to form a collaboration, often without the benefit of a position of authority.

##Talk outline

The talk will be filled with personal stories and examples from my own experience. The audience will be given a set of techniques that anyone can implement and principles that anyone can follow.

1. Challenges facing a software architect (based on my own experience):
  * Remote teams
  * Some teams not communicating well with one another
  * Teams not used to working with a designated software architect
  * Stakeholders from very different time zones
  * Different cultures of different teams; different levels of agility
  * Poorly documented legacy systems that need to evolve
  * Different opinions about whether to build or to buy
  * Unclear project scope
  * Unclear requirements
  * Stakeholders with prior commitments, who don’t have time to spend on your project
  * Tasks that require designing a kind of system that you have never designed before
1. How to recognize that you have influence?
  * Your designs come to life
  * People ask for your advice on various projects outside your area of responsibility
  * People want you to help them resolve disagreements
  * People tend to accept what you propose
  * People are copying your documentation style
  * People welcome your participation in meetings on any topic
1. Effective meetings (especially remote meetings)
  * Different kinds of meetings require smaller or larger groups
  * Declare the goal of a meeting
  * Publish agenda and slides up-front
  * Phrase questions to be answered during the meeting
  * Capture people's comments and opinions in writing and display in real-time them during the meeting
  * Finish in time, and share meeting notes with people
1. Effective architecture views to bring out the essence of an architecture
  * Depending on the audience, it is often better to present a simple and concise drawing, as opposed to complete sets of architecture views
  * Define names of components/modules/classes and their responsibilities. The other things follow from that. 
  * Naming something is an act of leadership. Declaring the name that someone else chose is even stronger. 
1. Use written documentation - this is especially important in a big and global organization
  * Writing is hard for people, so there’s an opportunity to stand out here
  * Make information accessible
  * Become the source of information by summarizing it better than others do
1. Encourage the engagement of others
  * Seek the subject matter experts and do 1:1 discussions with them
  * Look for opportunities to incorporate the ideas of others. If you accept someone’s idea, they will be more understanding next time you reject one of their ideas. 
  * Look for opportunities to show honest appreciation to other people’s contribution
1. Dealing with opposition, rejections and unknowns
  * If someone opposes an idea, ask questions about it - don’t just insist - regardless of how strongly you feel about your solution
  * Never get attached to a design. Recognize that there are multiple solutions and analyze both the benefits and the cost of any design decision
  * Seek first to understand, and only then to be understood 
  * When it is not clear how to make progress, phrase specific questions to be answered and ask for people's help
1. Build personal relationships with stakeholders
  * Get to know people on a personal level
  * Seek opportunities to show your appreciation
1. Be there for developers, after handing off the design to them
  * There will be unanswered questions and difficulties
  * Be there in weekly meetings and sprint planning
  * Notice the conversations between teams, and help where it's needed
1. References to literature
  * [5 levels of leadership by John C Maxwell](https://www.amazon.com/Levels-Leadership-Proven-Maximize-Potential/dp/B005SA65DI)
  * [The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People by Stephen R. Covey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_7_Habits_of_Highly_Effective_People)
  * [How to win friends and influence people by Dale Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_to_Win_Friends_and_Influence_People)
  * [Benjamin Franklin's autobiography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Autobiography_of_Benjamin_Franklin)
talk.abstract: The success of a software architect relies on his/her ability to influence development teams and decision makers and to gain trust with other stakeholders. In this talk you will learn the techniques, the mindset and the character traits that form the basis of effective technical leadership.

ratings.comments: Other reviewers have made excellent suggestions to improve this talk. I commented to encourage the submitter to listen to those comments and refine the submission. It appears that's happening. This could be a helpful talk for many.
Relevant topic. Enthusiastic speaker. What more to ask?

The topic seems good but the focus is too broad.  It's also not clear to me what the experience is.  Is this talk based on reading books and trying them or just reading books?

That said, I think this could still be a good talk for SATURN, unless there are better ones in this topic area.

Update: Based on the submitter's added details, clarified focus, and overwhelming enthusiasm I think this would be a great addition to the lineup.

feedback.body:
The talk outline seems long for the time available (30 minutes). If you need to shorten the presentation, I suggest dropping or shortening topics 1, 3, and 8. 

This sentence is not OK to me: "Depending on the audience, it is often better to present a simple and concise drawing, as opposed to complete sets of architecture views."  Here's how I think (based on "Documenting Software Architectures: Views and Beyond, Second Edition"): 
- a software architecture is described as a set of architecture views. There isn't a single diagram that shows everything.
- you should only create an architecture view if it has clear value to stakeholders (the audience for the software architecture).
- a given architecture view may consist of a simple and concise drawing. 

The following sentence is not clear to me: "Declaring the name that someone else chose is even stronger."

In the talk outline, item (4) recommends: "Define names of components/modules/classes and their responsibilities. The other things follow from that."
I think having expressive names for software elements is important, but that recommendation alone is not very helpful. In fact, item (4) is about effective architecture views and there are so many important recommendations under this topic, such as:
- Use a notation key in your diagrams (or indicate what standard notation you're using).
- Use different symbols for different types of elements and relations. 
- Use consistent symbology across diagrams. 
- If you're using a pattern in your design, name it. If the reader is familiar with the pattern, he/she will understand the design more easily.
- Use a template (standard organization) for your documentation. In particular, use the same template for all architecture views. (Subsections in a template may be N/A of course.)
- Keep the information up-to-date. If you can't update the documentation, discard, archive or mark it as out-of-date.
- Complement structural diagrams (e.g., UML class diagram) with behavior diagrams (e.g., UML sequence diagram).
- Record the rationale for important design decisions.
- Avoid ambiguity; write from the reader's point of view; review the documentation. 
These recommendations can be found in the book I mentioned above ("Documenting Software Architectures: Views and Beyond, Second Edition").

Typos:
- Notes: "trust and cooperation of *of* stakeholders"
- Notes: "Capture people’s comments *opinions* in writing "

Thanks for the thorough review, Paulo. I am going to use it to improve the presentation, and I am taking this opportunity to clarify my proposal.

My emphasis in this presentation will be on the human relations aspects and how they affect the level of influence of a software architect. 

Your comments about the architectural views are correct, and I should rephrase my intent: All of the architectural views are important for reasoning about a system's structure. I am not presenting a different theory of documenting software architecture, but I am commenting about the way in which I would present those architectural views to different stakeholders. In presentations, we often don't have time to go through all of the views; also, we may do it in a more constrained environment of online remote meetings, so we need to focus on the things that yield the most understanding and buy-in from the stakeholders. 

In this context, I claim that naming and stating the responsibilities of a component or a module, is of especially high value.  The list of responsibilities is a concise representation of the intent of the designer, which helps stakeholders review the architecture and ask good questions about it (e.g. "if this component is only responsible for X, then how come it depends on Y"?).

One way to make the most out of architectural discussions is to find opportunities where other people contribute. A very powerful application of this is when we name software elements. By asking someone else: "How would you name this component?" and accepting the name that they offer, we make them our partners in the project. Similarly, if someone proposes a modification and we accept it, we gain more of their their cooperation, and it will be wise to give credit to the contributors. 

My plan is to share other insights of this kind. This complements the more technical aspects of analysis, design and documentation, with wisdom that comes from the realm of leadership, effective communication and personal growth, and I have lots of relevant stories from my personal experience, which I think will be highly beneficial to the audience.

Indeed, I will need to shorten some of the topics - and I will shorten topics 1 & 3, as your proposed. As for topic #8, this is one I would like to emphasize, because my main point is how personal relationships make a difference.

With kind regards,

Adi.
Paulo - I also fixed the two typos you indicated. Thanks for this!

Hi Adi,

Thanks for your submission!  Overall I like the content and practical lessons in your outline, though I do agree with Paulo that it seems a bit long.  There is a lot of good lessons here!  But, focusing on 2-3 or so core lessons is about all the audience can take in 30 minutes.  You might be able to group or "chunk" your ideas in a different way to make them easier for the audience to digest.

What is the context of your experience?  Context is important for understanding how broadly applicable your lessons are.  For example, how big is the team?  What sorts of systems were you designing? Things like that.

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael. Thanks for the kind words and for your review.

Here is my context: I have been leading, and am still leading the technical design of a number of projects:

1. An application for a 3D intra-oral scanner (http://www.itero.com/en) - there were ~20 developers working on it, divided to 4 teams in two locations (Israel and Moscow). Made of C++, C#, high performance algorithms and 3D graphics, interacting with proprietary hardware and real-time components.

2. A HIPAA-compliant, scalable and highly available cloud-based storage system distributed in multiple data centers with integrations to ~10 applications. Involves ~6 development teams from 4 locations (East coast, West coast, Israel and Moscow), and other stakeholders from 3 more locations. Made of Java, NoSQL database, public cloud storage, REST API, caching layers, custom replication and workflow management, and a challenging data migration and transition strategy.

3. A scalable and highly available cloud-based architecture for enhancing web applications by server-side algorithms, with interactive-rate messaging between the web page and the dedicated server-side process. Involves 3 teams from 2 locations + stakeholders from 2 more locations. Made of Java, Websocket, REST, elastic cloud-based cluster, with fully automated deployments.

4. (Currently in early stages:) A cloud-based service for capturing, storing, displaying and manipulating doctor prescriptions. Emphasizes modifiability. Made of React, Java REST API, and document-oriented DB in the cloud.

I am also involved in multiple other projects related to identity management & authentication, cloud-based workflow management, storage, data analytics, cluster computations, and others.

----------

Regarding your main feedback: You're right - my presentation should focus on a few key messages. I think those will be:

1) Ways to get other people more engaged - this includes effective meetings, especially long-distance on-line conference calls, in which I have plenty of experience and success. For example, I want to demonstrate how I capture and display people's comments in real-time, and how satisfying this is to the participants: They know they are understood, and they know their opinion is heard, even when it is not accepted; Another example is getting people involved in the early stages of giving names to components.

2) Ways to deal with difficulty and opposition: being open to others' ideas; listening, and truly caring about the concerns of others; not being attached to a specific solution, and being ready to challenge your own ideas; This doesn't mean giving up on good design solutions: It means that you should be willing to explain both the advantages and the trade-offs in the design, not in order to defend it at all cost, but in order to truly search for the best solution, thereby laying the foundation for better collaboration in the future, regardless of whose opinion ends up being accepted.

3) Building long-term credibility. "They don't care how much you know until they know how much you care" - show commitment by being there when things are not clear, by allocating time for review and demo sessions; by providing specific feedback on detailed design decisions; by being there when teams disagree and need someone to resolve the dispute; by showing the appreciation and giving credit generously to others; And by admitting and correcting your design mistakes as soon as those come up.

I will also give useful references to literature, where people can learn more about influence & leadership.

----------

On a personal note: I attended Saturn 3 years ago. It was one of the best conferences I have ever attended, and I still remember some of the great presentations (Especially the keynotes by Dianne Marsh and Joe Justice; The course by Robert Wojcik; Scott Hanselman's great talk; And others...). I will be honored and deeply excited to be among this excellent group of speakers.

This talk is not finalized yet. I have so many stories and references to share. I am planning to use the reviewers' feedback, and to do my absolute best to make this a great presentation worthy of the high level of this conference.

Thank you for your submission. Your talk covers many "soft" skills that are critical to architecting. The examples in your notes are clear and concise.

Thank you for the thorough outline - very helpful for evaluation. You're packing a lot into 30 minutes though. The risk is that it goes by so fast that audience members don't absorb it all or well. I'll second the thoughts of Paulo Merson and Michael Keeling that you should consider trimming the outline.

I've nothing to add to the great advice they've provided. I wanted to comment to encourage you to refine the talk based on their comments (which it seems you are doing!) because I feel these people-oriented parts of architecting need attention. And we, as a community, can do more to help each other. (Paulo and Michael are great contributors to that so their comments are valuable.) This talk can be especially helpful to people who do not have readily available mentors or other architects within their organizations.

Thanks for the review and feedback, Anthony. I will use your input to improve the talk. 

I shall definitely refine the outline and trim the content of the talk, as you proposed, and in line with the feedback of Paulo and Michael. I know how to do it, because I know I am focusing on the people-oriented parts, and, in particular (as mentioned in my response to Michael): Practical ways to get other people more engaged; Practical ways to deal with difficulty and opposition; and building long-term credibility. These are my clear guidelines for the detailed design of the presentation. 

In particular, I will probably drop the documentation-related topics, trim the part on effective meetings (as Paulo proposed) and will not dwell on the challenges part (people know well their own challenges, right?).

talk.title: How to Perform a Rapid Assessment of any Software Architecture
talk.description: As a software architect for your organization, you may may be required to efficiently and effectively evaluate the validity, quality, health and/or maturity of a proposed, new or legacy software architecture. This presentation suggests a simple process you can follow to perform a rapid assessment of any software architecture effort regardless of its size, complexity or stage of development. The focus is on capturing the most critical aspects of the software architecture including: (a) Software Quality Attributes; (b) Key Architectural Decisions (including hardware platforms, software technology, development tools and reuse strategy); and (c) Architectural Design (primarily in the form of Unified Modeling Language or UML). Emphasis is placed on identifying and documenting references to existing artifacts. It generally requires an interview with the most knowledgeable software engineer on the proposal, development or maintenance team to identify the location of artifacts that are available and information that has never been documented. This is basically a two-day process. On the first day information is gathered and quickly recorded. On the second day, the information is analyzed, expert opinion(s) formulated, and a report is prepared and disseminated to all of the relevant Stakeholders. The process is a simple and straightforward mechanism for capturing software architecture and rapidly performing a valuable assessment during any time in the lifecycle of the product.
talk.notes:
This process is one that I developed at Raytheon for my own use as a software architect. It is my responsibility to periodically review proposed, new, and existing software architectures across the organization to maintain a consistent understanding of the validity, quality, health and maturity of our products. 

A questionnaire with the following outline is used to ensure all topics are considered in the process.

The applicable roles are as follows:
1. Software Architect performs the review, analysis and report
2. Software Technical Lead provides information
3. Software Architecture Review Board examines the report and recommends actions

It's a two-day event that requires about 24-32 hours of effort.

The process has been used for over a year on a half dozen projects to date.
It's so simple and affordable that there have been few challenges to hamper the process.

feedback.body:
Hi Tim,

This abstract sounds very interesting with some great potential, but I don't quite have enough information to assess it.  Would it be possible to add a few more details about the method in the notes section of the proposal?  A sample agenda would be helpful to understand what is involved.

Regards,

Michael

Tim -
This is an interesting and relevant topic. In addition to Michael's request for more details and an agenda, I had a couple of questions:
- will you be showing participant roles and responsibilities during the evaluation? can you provide enough detail so that if I wanted to use this method, I could estimate the cost of the evaluation?

Over the years, there have been a number of lightweight evaluation methods presented at SATURN (Don O'Connell from Boeing and Jeremy Carriere from Yahoo/Intuit/Google come to mind). ...John.

Michael and John. I believe I have answered most of the concerns by adding additional information in the notes section. Although there is no comparative analysis here, there is sufficient detail now in the outline that a comparison could be supported. Thanks

Thank you for the submission. Light, quick processes like what you have proposed here, when effective, provide good value in industry, where resources and time are often heavily constrained. I appreciate people sharing experiences like this.

talk.title: It can be done! Growing an Architect's Community - My Journey
talk.description:
Passionate individuals and businesses both try to create successful Communities of Practice (CoPs) for myriad reasons from honest desire to networking to a financially driven goal of sharpening worker skills. Why do some well-funded effort fail while rag-tag start-ups succeed? In this session, hear the story of my struggles and successes to grow a networked community of architects that now stretches across the globe. There is no single formula to creating a successful community. If you've got passion and take the time to really ask "Why?", your journey is starting off on the right foot! Choose vision driven techniques over old-school mechanics to jumpstart new groups or resurrect ailing ones. Attendees will talk away energized and ready to try a few of the techniques that worked including:
  • Sowing the seeds – Organic communities, whether jump started by a corporation or a hobbyist, tend to have the greatest growth and staying power. How and where to sow community seeds positions a community for possible success.
  • What are the success attributes of a boom? – How to define success and using qualitative and quantitative measures to detect a bust.
  • Value, Brand, and Localization – Communities thrive when there is ownership at all levels and pride. Understand how value definition impact a community’s charter and how building a brand provides community members with a sense of empowerment and worth.
  • Agile concepts for community leadership – Transparency, communication, and continual evaluation/reprioritization of next steps can situate community leaders to react nimbly to change and protect community health.
talk.notes:
When I joined Deloitte Consulting, there was a rag-tag group occasionally sending out an email newsletter that went straight into everyone's trash. I've taken that community of less that 40 to nearly 500 globally. While this could easily be a 30 minute session or longer, I want to energize my peers at SATURN to rethink how they are caring for and feeding their architects. I've won multiple national and global awards from Deloitte around my community building approaches. Interestingly, the journey includes needing to pivot and find ways to engage those smart millennials. Learning Outcomes: Participants will walk away energized with ideas for organizing and nurturing successful architecture communities:
  • Techniques to sowing organic growth
  • How to defining success attributes and what are associated measurement techniques
  • The impact of top-down support versus and bottom-up drive
  • Principles for defining value and brand for a community; understand the impact of localization on a community or chapter
  • Suggestions on applying agile techniques at the leadership level
talk.abstract: Growing a community is tougher than it looks!  There isn't a magic formula. There are tips and tricks from my journey building an international architect's community.  The big enabler? Asking "why" and staying true to that guiding principle.  Let's get the word out to the folks that care at SATURN!

ratings.comments:
This is a talk that I would like to see.  Building effective communities of practice is an important topic for architects because working in isolation seems to be an occupational hazard.  

I would have liked to have seen some of the other work in area referenced.  Authors have already proposed good frameworks for community development so I don't think we need to invent new ones.

Instead I hope the speaker will focus on sharing her experience at Deloitte and sharing the lessons she has learned while building the community there.

I have researched the speaker, and I found here Saturn 2016 presentation enjoyable and useful.
From a leadership perspective building passion for architecture design topics is a problem area everyone could benefit from.

Tracy is a credible speaker and friend of SATURN who has been with us before. She does not lack for confidence and enthusiasm, and those qualities are assets if this is indeed intended as a DEV@SATURN talk (she has not responded to Jørn's request for clarification about that). What prevents me from a full endorsement is the presence in the proposal of vaguely defined buzzwords and jargon that cause me to wonder how much real substance there will be in the proposed 15 minutes.
Relevant topic, I know too many lonely (within their organisation) architects. Thought out proposal with clear message.

I think this is a great idea for a talk. I agree with Tracy that it is better to have a high energy 15 minutes on this than to have a more drawn out 30. Tracy is also a good speaker and I believe she can make this work.

feedback.body: We have had some issues with PaperCall changing talk formats on editing of submissions. Could you please confirm that this is intended for a 15 min lightning talk? Also be aware that the plan is to run these on the main stage in front of the full attending audience (about 200 people). Please update your submission with the correct talk format and also indicate the length of the talk in the Notes section for future reference.

Hi Tracy,

Thanks for you submission, this looks like an interesting topic.

I feel that you may have "buried the lead" in your submission by leaving to the notes what appears to me the most important aspect: your personal experience at Deloitte Consulting of building a community.

Reading the description I had the impression that you would be sharing a "recipe" for community growth.  It was not until I read the notes that I realized that you were sharing your personal experience of building a community.

It sounds like a great story, leading the rag-tag group from publishing newsletters that nobody read into an energized global community.  I think it would have been beneficial to start with that compelling narrative and then explain how the audience will benefit from the value lessons you are sharing.

Also, your talk seems to share the same themes as the 2002 book "Cultivating Communities of Practice" by Wegner, McDermott and Synder.   Was that book been influential at all?  It has similar themes such as designing for evolution and focusing on value.

Regards, 


Ged

talk.title: Keep CALM and Architect On:  An Architects Role in DevOps
talk.description:
The key concepts in DevOps are CALM:  Culture, Automation, Lean, and Measurement.  How does an architect support the transformation to DevOps in the 4 CALM areas?
Culture: Removing silos, reducing fear of making mistakes and encouraging learning and experimentation
Automation: Changing the architecture to support dynamic infrastructure, automated deployments and automated tests
Lean:  Structuring capabilities and features to deliver higher value in smaller batch sizes
Measurement:  Architecting to expose, aggregate and route the right data for monitoring, analysis and trending 

In this presentation, we'll talk about patterns, interactions and behavior that architects will want to consider to keep CALM in the face of DevOps.
talk.notes:
I.	How does one keep CALM?
II.	Architect’s Role in Culture change
   a.	Ever wonder what happens after you throw something “over the wall”?
   b.	Cross functional team support
III.	Architecture Patterns that support Automation
   a.	Deployment – Infrastructure as Code (IaC), Versioning configurations
   b.	Test – Using Code Seams, Test harnesses,  Change Impact Analysis
   c.	Dynamic Infrastructure – Infrastructure as a Service, Auto-scaling, Stateless SW 
IV.	Getting Lean
   a.	Requiring Experimentation (Working with leadership to build in HW resources and schedule)
V.	Architecture Patterns that support Measurement
   a.	Microservices with metrics support built-in and accessible with the endpoint
   b.	CI/CD Integrated Code Coverage
   c.	Measuring spikes to determine experimentation
VI.	Conclusion
talk.abstract: The key concepts in DevOps are CALM:  Culture, Automation, Lean, and Measurement.  How does an architect support the transformation to DevOps in the 4 CALM areas?  We'll talk about patterns, interactions and behavior that architects will want to consider to keep CALM in the face of DevOps.

talk.title: Method for Business Function Allocation and Interface Definition in System-of-Systems Architecture .
talk.description:
System-of-Systems in Roche Diagnostics context
==============================================

Certain business processes in medical diagnostics areas involve many large scale systems (million connection points) distributed through Roche enterprise and customer clinical laboratories. The involved systems fulfill valid purposes in their own right, can operate separately and are managed for their own purpose rather than the purposes of the whole.

Allocation of business functions to specific system components and definition of interfaces with significant consequences for architecture of such large and complex IT and software system-of-systems (SoS) is a challenge. It requires data supporting decision criteria and accommodating fast evolution of the architecture in the agile organization.  

Roche Customized Method of Architecting SoS 
===========================================

For the architecting of the system-of-systems in Roche product context a customized method was defined based on the US Department of Defense Architecture Framework.

This method involves 6 steps with start/finish criteria and deliverables for each. I will illustrate these steps using examples from Roche.

1.  Business process Domain Analysis (identification of Business Drivers, Business Capabilities, Business Functions, Constraints, elaboration of User Stories and Workflows, definition of Quality Attributes).

2.  Integrated Dynamic Modeling (IDM) for multiple workflows within the business process.

3.  Derivation of Events, Activities and Resources for each workflow IDM.

4.  Alignment to elaborate Common Events, Common Activities and Common Resources for all modelled workflows.

5.  Identification of existing/overlapping/missing functionality (based on Activities) and data and processors (based on Resources) in involved systems. Preliminary allocation of the functions to the systems and verification of fulfillment of Business Criteria (based on Domain Analysis).

6.  Architecting of data, process, deployment, … models and preliminary design of interface between the involved systems.  Verification of Quality Attributes fulfillment.

This method can be applied in agile projects, if the sprints are oriented on implementation of workflow.

Results of application of the method at Roche
=============================================

The customized method for the architecting of system-of-systems was applied to business processes related to Remote Solutions and IoT. It led to quick definition of models and derived data supporting the decision making and allocation of business functions and resources to existing and to be developed systems as well as identification of common resources and interfaces for their exchange.
talk.notes:
As author of this method and part of the team applying it in the real world large scale projects I can give the practitioners view and probably answer most of questions. 
My talk at the SATURN 2016 related to multiple ATAMs gave a short introduction to a small subset of the entire system.

talk.title: Microservices and Docker at Scale: the PB&J of Modern Application Delivery
talk.description:
Docker has matured, and is expanding from being predominantly used in the Build/Test stages to Production deployments. Similarly, microservices are expanding from being used mostly for green-field web services to being used in the enterprise - as organizations explore ways to decompose their monolith to support faster release cycles.

Running microservices-based applications in a containerized environment makes a lot of sense – both for Build and Test, as well as from a runtime perspective in Production.

Docker and Microservices are natural companions, forming the foundation for modern application delivery. However, managing microservices and large-scale Docker deployments pose unique challenges for enterprise IT.

This talk discusses the modern requirements for building, deploying and operating microservices on a large-scale Docker-ized infrastructure. It covers:

• Patterns for microservices-based architectures
• What makes Docker such a good fit for microservices
• How to operationalize Docker orchestration, auto-scaling and DR in large-scale Production environments – recommended typologies and patterns
• Best practices for Docker configuration and registry management to ensure consistency throughout the pipeline and stability in Production
• Tips for integrating containers into complex existing environments, supporting the hybrid state of microservices and monolithic applications
• Tips and tooling for monitoring and managing clusters of containers as a single distributed application
• Putting an end to Shadow-IT: how can IT enable Dev and Ops to use Docker for both microservices and traditional application releases - while ensuring visibility, security, governance and compliance
talk.notes: This talk was developed as a joint session with Electric Cloud CTO, Anders Wallgren: Anders Wallgren is chief technology officer at Electric Cloud. Anders has over 25 years’ experience designing and building commercial software. Prior to joining Electric Cloud, he held executive positions at Aceva, Archistra, and Impresse and management positions at Macromedia (MACR), Common Ground Software, and Verity (VRTY), where he played critical technical leadership roles in delivering award winning technologies such as Macromedia’s Director 7. Anders holds a B.SC from MIT.

talk.title: Micro services architecture - lessons learned
talk.description:
The speaker works as Director of Software Engineering at Capital One. In this talk, he will share lessons from implementing microservices architecture for a regulatory initiative.

The talk will focus on –

- What are the business drivers for the microservices architecture?
- What are the lessons we learnt from an architecture perspective?
- Why Devops practices are important?
- What cultural and software engineering best practices help?
- What are the communication imperatives when you are building an enterprise microservice?
talk.notes:
I am a Director of Software Engineering at Capital One. My focus in on Marketing and Decisioning Technologies. I am in their Richmond, VA location.  I lead a team of 70 engineers developing architecture, building APIs and devops platforms. Over the last couple of years we built several mission critical APIs most of them are for customer facing and highly regulated capabilities. We learnt a lot breaking a monolithic application into micro services. I led delivery of several enterprise APIs and deployed into production. Hope to share my experiences in the session. I will also have some time for questions and answers at the end. The talk should last for 30 min.
I will be explaining the following success factors and considerations

Why did we go with micro services?

The initiative that I led was a regulatory project for Know Your Customer (KYC) regulation. It has very tight timelines and dependencies across the organization. The best way we could have accomplished the timelines is to go with a microservices architecture. So the business drivers for microservices architecture are

- Ability to break the solution into manageable micro services and have small teams solve them. That increased the speed of development by taking advantage of public cloud, strong devops, and automated testing
- To drive accountability and ownership in a cross enterprise initiative
- We also wanted to break some capabilities away from a monolithic application that was getting difficult to change

So, it is the business imperatives that drove us towards the micro services architecture.

In general, if it is a differentiating capability for the business (say credit decisioning for a bank) and agility is important, microservices approach helps. If it is not a differentiating capability like payroll and HR, better stick to a vendor product.

Architecture:

- When re-architecting a monolithic application, we achieved better success starting with the head (or customer facing functions) of the monolithic application. As we get deeper there will be more dependencies making it difficult to decompose the application.
- It is important to Identify the business capability and design the contract accordingly. The architecture should be aligned with product owner and it should clearly articulate the problem the specific micro service is solving.
- Use domain driven design as much as possible. It is important to define the domain and the bounded context for the micro service. This also helps to define the granularity of the micro service. If the service is too big, it replicates the monolithic. Maintainability and agility should be kept in mind while designing the micro service. Our definition of a bounded context was driven by the following:
  - Autonomy of the domain, its business context, and self-contained data store without need for replication across microservices
  - The domain is simple to explain
  - In one instance performance dictated its domain. We separated a high performing calculation engine as its own microservice and developed it in GO language.
- Architect should focus on the API contract, interplay of micro services, and ensuring the non-functional requirements are met. It is important for the architect to know where to stop in the design
- What you design for real time may not work for batch. We first designed the microservices for real time first with a requirement of low throughput. But when we started using the microservices for batch use cases that had a higher throughput requirement, the infrastructure design did not work. So, we had to tune and scale up the microservices.
- While building individual microservices was easy, orchestrating the services wasn't easy. We built Java orchestrations, but very soon the orchestration services became too big to manage. We are experimenting with reactive frameworks.

Devops :

- Benefit of micro services is speed of development. Unless the code migration and deployment is automated, it is difficult to manage a micro services factory
- Automate integration testing and performance testing. We built automated testing for individual APIs, but did not build automated integration scripts. That became a bottleneck at the end as we had to do manual testing.
- With micro services, there will be frequent release. Hence, doing blue green deployment helps to minimize the down time
- A cloud first approach works better for micro services
- ATDD is a mandatory practice for micro services

Best practices and culture:

- Encourage Small teams of 4-5. If a micro service takes more than 1-2 developer to understand fully, it is too big and will become unmanageable
- Encourage pair programming
- Encourage knowledge sharing. Leverage demos to ensure teams get the big picture. Otherwise, developers will know only their micro service and miss the big picture. We moved away from separate production support teams. Teams support what they build. When we deployed the microservices into production, initially it was difficult to support as developers did not have the entire architecture context.
- With small teams, teams slowly have to graduate to full stack teams that can do everything the micro service needs.

Communication to stakeholders:

- It is important to communicate to clients often and in detail. Write a blog and publish every detail
- Version management is critical
- Contract first design helps in better communication

Other practical considerations

- Level of granularity is very important. Be ready to redefine and re-architect often as you go along
- It is impossible to have a separate support team to whom you hand off the micro- sevices after they are built. The eco system gets more complex for some other team to own manage. integrate support into delivery teams
- Alerting and monitoring is extremely important. Automate to the extent delivery teams spend less than 10% of their time on production support

talk.title: Pragmatic Architecture, Today.
talk.description:
Software development has evolved. Agile is now the de-facto standard. The role of an architect in an agile project is very different than the typical role in a more classic waterfall approach. Using an updated interpretation of ‘viewpoints and perspectives’, this talk will demonstrate how to make rapid, agile delivery sustainable in a constantly changing world. These viewpoints and perspectives will be linked to easy-to-produce models that can be used immediately in your projects. The talk will provide examples on how to determine which models are architecturally significant and worth the effort.

Developers have always been very important stakeholders of an architectural description. A good agile architect needs to strive for consensus and buy-in.
talk.notes:
Software architecture has a bad name. Developers often think that architects have no feeling with the actual application that they're building .. Sometimes they're right. But having no architecture is also a recipe for disaster.

I want to present a model (observe-orient-decide-act or OODA) with feedback loops that can lead to better quality software. Sharing ownership, making the architecture valuable for everyone is necessary to deliver successful software products. I've been using this approach for multiple projects and want to share how architecture, change and development methodologies go hand-in-hand.

Outline:
- What? (theoretical)
- Really? (practical, attractive example)
- Visual? (tips & tricks, focus on change)

Hi Bart,
Thank you for the submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. The relation between agile development and architecture work has been examined and discussed for a decade. I'm curious to see your OODA approach. Indeed, I think you should name it in the talk description and make sure it is well described in the talk. 

2. As a sanity check, ask yourself if the approach works well for geographically distributed and/or outsourced teams. Also ask if it requires developers who are well versed in software design (in addition to architects who can code of course). 

3. Years ago I gave an interview to InfoQ. One of the questions was exactly about the topic of your talk. I'll reproduce here my answer. It's just food for thought for preparing your presentation...  

"It is a well known misconception that agile development means no documentation. In fact, as a [survey shows](http://www.ambysoft.com/surveys/modelingDocumentation2008.html), agile teams are more likely to model than traditional teams. A few things that agile architects (or perhaps any software architect) should remember: 

The key aspect of design/modeling in agile projects is not to avoid designing, but to avoid "big-design up-front" (BDUF). In general, high-level architectural strategies should be worked out up front, but many design decisions and design details can be left to when you need them. 

Only produce design documentation that will fulfill a need of the stakeholders. Stop designing as soon as you're ready to start coding. In the next sprint you can expand/refine the existing design as needed in order to capture design decisions required by next sprint's features. 

If it's not worth updating the design, throw it away. Some design diagrams are used to guide implementation, but at the end the code sometimes looks different from the diagram. If you don't have time to update the diagram to reflect the implementation, it's better to remove it than keeping an out-of-date diagram that may confuse a future reader. 

Many times, sketches are all you need. Don't spend too much time crafting the neatest diagram using the latest and richest notation available. Don't spend too much money on sophisticated modeling tools if you just need a drawing tool. In many agile projects, especially the ones with small, co-located teams, the true value of design diagrams comes from drawing them, which forces you to think through the issues; once the issues are solved, the diagrams lose much of their value. Many times the design is represented as a sketch on a whiteboard or piece of paper. If the sketch can be used to successfully convey the design to the team, that sketch, as is, can be *the* diagram in your architecture view. Why not?"

talk.title: Quality metrics: Nutritional Labels for Code
talk.description:
Software is an increasing part of our everyday lives. From the phones we carry, to the cars we drive, the thermostats that regulate our homes, even our lightbulbs - software is everywhere. But how much do we know about it? How secure is the banking app you use? What bugs might turn your home into a tropical paradise during your next winter trip? How convoluted is the code that runs your car? The last plane you took? The last traffic light you went through?

As consumers, we take nutrition labels on food for granted. A few simple, standard numbers let us make smart choices about the food we consume. Similarly, quality numbers should be routinely available for software, which is omnipresent and unavoidable in modern life. As consumers, we should have the data to make smart choices. After all, candy bars will only kill you slowly. Bad code could kill you very quickly.
talk.notes:
This is a lightning talk.

I work for SonarSource SA, the company behind SonarQube, a FLOSS platform to measure and monitor code quality. The purpose of the talk is not to flog the product, but to talk about why all software should be analyzed (by _some_ product) and the results published. But because it is easy (and the product is free!), I will propose that the 3 ratings from the SonarQube quality model be published: Reliability, Security, and Maintainability (Best Practices). Those ratings take the form of letter grades, which should be understandable to the general public. Teaching them _why_ they should care will take more time, but become more and more obvious as we're all able to correlate software failures with low ratings.
talk.abstract: Nutrition labels give us the chance to make smart choices about the food we consume. But there's no data to help us make smart choices about the software we consume. Quality metrics are easy to collect and should be just as universally available as nutrition labels.

talk.title: Refactoring with Cognitive Complexity, the new option for measuring understandability
talk.description:
For 40 years, Cyclomatic Complexity has been the de facto standard for measuring testability and maintainabiliy. While it's absolutely accurate for testability, the same can't be said for maintainability. Cognitive Complexity solves the problem, and returns "fair" relative measurements of control flow complexity. 

In this session, you'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, and why you should add it to your metric suite, see how it applies to a number of code samples from open source projects on SonarQube.com, and learn how to use a method's Cognitive Complexity score as a guide to designing better code, and refactoring existing code to be simpler and, more maintainable. You'll also see that because there's no "cost of entry" / increment for methods, high class-level Cognitive Complexity is a reliable indicator that a class contains a lot of logic, not just a lot of methods. That is, you can use Cognitive Complexity to sift domain classes from the logic-intense classes that impose a higher maintenance burden.

Cognitive Complexity is already available as a new rule in some Sonar code analyzers, and should be available throughout the SonarQube ecosystem by the end of 2017.
talk.notes:
30min Tech Talk

SonarSource (the company behind [SonarQube](http://sonarqube.org)) is introducing a new way of measuring complexity: [Cognitive Complexity](https://blog.sonarsource.com/cognitive-complexity-because-testability-understandability/), which gives a far more accurate measurement of the relative understandability of a method than Cyclomatic Complexity. 

I'll cover these topics:
* Cyclomatic Complexity: what it's good for and what's it's not, i.e. why a new standard/metric is needed
* Cognitive Complexity: motivations, specifics, benefits
* How to use Cognitive Complexity to guide refactoring. Hopefully I'll be able to use an IDE for this portion, but may have to fall back to slides, depending on what I can get the IDE to show.

I'll begin the presentation with slides and then hopefully switch to an IDE. Examples of code to be refactored will come from [sonarqube.com](https://sonarqube.com/issues#resolved=false|rules=squid%3AS3776).

I'm the best person to present this topic because, with the help and support of my SonarSource colleagues, I formulated Cognitive Complexity.
talk.abstract:

You'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, how it applies to a number of code samples, and how to use it as a guide to refactoring for simpler, more maintainable code.

talk.title: Reliable Statements about a Fault-Tolerant X-by-Wire eCar
talk.description:
A dependable cyber-physical system (CPS) correctly performs the functions for which it was conceived in its intended environment, without adverse effects. In particular, a dependable CPS responds correctly and timely even in situations where system parts have failed, either temporarily or permanently. This requirement also applies when tests check reliability, availability and performance properties of these systems in the lab and in the field. A CPS with test probes built-into all HW/SW-components throughout the CPS lifecycle can fulfill these requirements. Applied to an eCar, non-intrusive, deterministic fault-injection tests executed by test probes provide strong evidence for statements like: “While driving, the eCar can safely be steered when a fault fails a central, redundant HW/SW component that executes steering operations”.

Tests of such systems and properties pose various challenges, for example (1) stimulating selected CPS parts with correct data and with faulty data in rare and critical situations, (2) checking selected CPS parts at selected points in time, or during time intervals according to focused and measurable test goals, (3) differentiation of the CPS's treatment of temporary and permanent faults, and (4) absolute non-disturbance of the tested system's functionality or timing. The fourth challenge applies in particular to fault-injection tests that check CPS safety, or that operate near the border between the CPS and the physical process.

Meeting the challenges outlined above requires that the architecture of the system under evaluation be designed for testability. Starting from here, we first characterize the CPS we use as an example: an integration platform of an X-by-wire eCar (www.projekt-race.de/en). This motivates the need for reliable statements on the real-time behavior of the system from different tests, from which we derive testability requirements. Afterwards, we elaborate a series of design tactics that enable or improve the system’s testability, focusing on test probes. A test probe is a kind of Built-in Monitor (SEI: Testability tactic) or Maintenance Interface (R. Hanmer: Patterns for fault-tolerant systems) with particular demands in probe environments. When these demands are fulfilled, test probes can execute deterministic, efficient and reliable real-time tests, or act as safety monitors that observe and potentially intervene in a system.

Independent of the system domain you will learn two key aspects: how to design a testable system that incorporates test probes as central system elements, and how to write non-intrusive tests that yield reliable results.
talk.abstract: We discuss the practical use of novel HW/SW test probes to non-intrusively check functional, performance, and safety properties in fault-tolerant cyber-physical systems. The talk covers the application of test probes to test the dependability of automation and control systems of an eCar.

talk.title: Smelling out a bad security culture
talk.description:
Security challenges in the Age of Digitalization
=====================================

Some call it the fourth industrial revolution. Some call it the age of digitalization. No matter what you call it, we are harvesting more and more data about people and businesses. This data is then connected to other data and exposed as services which needs to be protected properly. As software architects, our primary security goal is to write secure software. Secure software has a technical aspect that is well covered (if not understood) in developer literature, but there is also a human and organizational aspect of security we as software architects must manage.  These aspects often go beyond the boundaries of the software development organization and are influenced by forces well beyond the company walls.

On the path to security there are a lot of trade-offs to be made, and some of these are made outside the IT organization. After working for more than 20 years in large organizations, I have found that there are certain signals that can be used to identify if you have a weak security culture. They do not necessarily identify security problems in themselves, but are indicators of topics that merit further investigation.

__In this talk I will cover topics such as:__

- Balancing prevention, detection and response
- Leadership
- Balancing Short term gains vs long time security impact
- Handling security incidents
- The importance of the curious mind
- Communicating security concerns beyond the IT organization
talk.notes:
__Note: This talk was originally submitted as a 30 minute talk. As I tried to edit some typos, the talk type options have changed to "non-SATURN"-variants. It is still intended as a 30 minute talk even if the submission shows something else.__

Security has been a long time interest and passion with me. Working for more than 20 years in the IT industry, I have seen security fail in the most spectacular ways. For the past year, the company I work for (Statoil, a global oil and gas company) has seen an increased focus on IT security in the wake of internal and external events. I have been part of a task force addressing some of these issues, and although the particulars are confidential, there are still general learning that can be made. Some of these learnings are technical, but a lot of them are organizational and are valid across organizations large and small. This talk will address the general learnings made as part of the task force, put into a context of more than 20 years experience as an industry practitioner.
talk.abstract: Security is many things. To developers it is mostly about developing secure code, but as architects it is so much more. In this talk I take a look at experiences from years of security observations that I find useful when identifying weak signals of a faulty security culture in a large organization.

talk.description:
The way we build systems is changing. From our history of monolithic systems, then distributed systems, to Internet connected systems, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice based, pay-for-usage system development. What does the history of software architecture tell us about the challenges of this new environment? And how does our approach to software architecture need to evolve in order to meet them?

Software architecture has been a mainstream discipline since the 1990s and in that time has become a recognised, widely researched and often valued part of the software engineering process. However architecture approaches must reflect the technologies and priorities of the systems we are building and in this regard its future has never looked more uncertain or more exciting. 

From our history of monolithic compile time architecture, to many tiered distributed systems, to Internet connected services, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice-based, pay-for-usage systems development. In this new world the boundaries of “my” system are no longer so clear and our systems are dissolving into complex webs of independently owned and evolved services, with nothing more in common than a shared credit card for billing and an agreement on the format of network requests. 

What can the history of software architecture tell us about the likely challenges in this environment? And how must it develop in order to meet them?
talk.notes:
The genesis of this session was an invited talk at OOP2016, exploring the history of software architecture, which I developed into this much more practical talk aimed at working architects, for GOTO London 2016, where it went down well.  Since then it has been presented at Endava a number of times and has always interested and engaged the audience.  It has not been presented in the USA yet.

The talk at present is a slightly full 60 minutes and so I would suggest extending to 90 for SATURN which will simply involve using more examples and questions to the audience.  However, if it fits better as a 30 minute talk, the essence of the message can be presented by just using the "Internet as the System", "Internet as the System Principles" and "Implications" parts of the talk (see the outline below).

Outline
-----------
The 5 Ages of Software Systems
	- Monolithic
	- Distributed Monoliths
	- Internet Connected
	- Current Era: Internet as the System
	- Future: Intelligent Connected

Internet as the System
	- Public API and mobile UI are the default interfaces
	- “Always On” is moving to “Access from Anywhere”
	- More dynamic architectural styles emerge (Microservices become popular)
	- Vendor concern now providing “platforms” (PaaS)

Architectural Drivers

I-A-T-S Principles 
	- Evolve continually
	- Respond dynamically
	- Analyse don’t ask
	- APIs for everything
	- Secure by Design
	- Internationalise instinctively

Implications
	- Design in CD from the start (remove obstacles to automation, testing, deployment)
	- Allow modular evolution (bounded contexts, “micro services”)
	- Assume “cloud” deployment (“cattle not pets”, no “snowflakes”, no static config, …)
	- Provide measurement in the core (instrumentation, store, analytics engine)
	- Structure around “public” APIs (the “Amazon” pattern)
	- Design and build to be securable (security principles, threat models, scanning, …)

On the Future
	- Intelligent Connected
	- Data and algorithms become key to achieving architectural qualities
	- Architecture becomes (more) runtime emergent
	- Vendor concern moves to “intelligent behaviour”
	- “Access from Anywhere”  moves to “Intelligent Assistance”

Summary and Conclusions
talk.abstract: We are moving from a world of static, monolithic systems to a point where systems are composed dynamically from fine grained "pay as you go" components.  This talk explores the history that led us here and presents a set of architecture principles for systems to meet these new challenges.
