talk.title: Story of an Architect Growing up in Mr. Agile's Neighborhood
talk.description:
If the agile manifesto were a boy (born circa February 2001), he'd be a high school junior today getting ready for college. Based on the past 16 years of his life, there is no question about the genius of this kid; but not so much can be said about some of his entourage and followers. Missteps in his career threw shadows of doubt at times about his potential. However, as he matured and opened up to his parents’ wisdom and history, he’s been able to build a well-rounded experience that’s making him competitive for the next phase of his life.

I wrote my first full-fledge program (app in today’s term) in the Spring of 2001, around the same time Mr. Agile moved into my neighborhood. I didn’t get to know him until early 2004 when his entourage grew into a dedicated community of fans and followers. Back then, I had one trusted mentor and an old friend, Mr. Architecture. Becoming friends with Mr. Agile was new and exciting but brought about challenges to my relationship with my old friend. Therefore, my growing up as a software professional was about learning how I could maintain friendships with both, reconciling their differences, and being better at what I do because of it.  

In a nutshell, I grow up in this kid’s world. So what does that look like? 

In this DEV@SATURN talk, I’ll narrate the story about growing up as friends with Mr. Agile and Mr. Architecture. I don’t intend to indulge the “agile vs architecture” debate. On the contrary, I’ll annotate my story with examples from our journeys together, sharing experiences with some of Mr. Agile’s friends who advocated architecture sabotage, as well as situations where the outcomes were better because I had a foot in both camps and had won the internal struggle as to how to reconcile.

Come join me in this talk as I’m sure you’ll find resemblances to your own journey.
talk.notes:
BACKGROUND

This talk is inspired by Linda Northrop’s keynote last year when she gestured a fist-bump to her chest, a sign of regret, about the stall/damage agile movement did to the progress of architecture adoption. It made me reflect on how I’ve lived the collision of these two worlds. After discussing an early version of this draft with her, I thought I should write and share my experience in the form of a TED@SATURN talk. My starting thought was the fact that being close to agile movement from the beginning propelled my growth as a software professional, and my practice of software development have been better for it. However, this didn’t come without a struggle against an entourage littered with misunderstanding, incompetence, and lack of discipline. In retrospect, it’s clear that the agile pendulum swung too far in the beginning in a zeal to fix the ills of non-agile approaches. But like all physical pendulums, this one had to come back to equilibrium as agile original proponents began to realize that they overlooked some methodology-neutral principles key to developing quality software, including architectural principles. The punch line in this talk is that at this point agile is a reality. We are at a stage where we need to forgo the discussion about agile for agile sake OR architecture for architecture sake. We need to embrace this agile pendulum equilibrium in the making, and regain the role of those who think about appropriate practices, regardless of methodology, to build high quality software – Software that is fit for its intended use, where fitness has many dimensions beyond pure functionality. The vehicle for me to deliver this is through storytelling based on my own software journey. I'll try to dig out old pictures to put in the background to color the scene.

TALK STRUCTURE (DRAFT)

For the purposes of this segment of SATURN, my talk will feature a storyline emphasizing a classic story ingredients.

Origination

Year 2001. A dozen or so smart software engineers with stellar backgrounds are holding a collective grudge against waterfall-like processes, titles, and roles. Like many revolutions, a manifesto is crafted in a mysteriously remote venue, and subsequently shared with the world: Baby agile is born. At the same time, my induction into the world of software development occurs. A baby software developer is born. Scene – we live in the same neighborhood.

Building towards a crisis

Time is going to flyby quickly here.
  • In the ensuing 10 years, agile grows to garnish a movement that dominates all descending voices challenging it. It's cool; it’s the buzz; and it’s unstoppable.
  • I meet Mr. Agile for the first time. I’m fascinated (anecdotal incidence here). I go running to my old friend, Mr. Architecture. He’s less fascinated. (I get to know why later).
  • It turns out, architecture best practices (and a lot of common sense) are the colloquial baby that was thrown out with the bathwater. Architecture vs Agile debate begins to take place.
  • This makes me extremely uncomfortable. I like both my old friend and my new friend but how can I hang out with them both?
  • Affiliated agile revolutionaries weren't grounded as leaders in software engineering thereby resulting in a number of documented software atrocities. I witness some of these first hand in my neighborhood.
  • Moment of truth: Agile is widely accepted but now the epiphany – It isn't the silver bullet after all. Adults in the neighborhood have been saying so all along but the wave was too noisy.

Beginning of resolution

In the last five years, architectural thinking begins to permeate the conversation among agile leaders. Voices of reason, architecture and agile leaders together, have begun to take charge of the discourse again. They’re beginning to have serious conversations about the real software development challenges at hand with a common goal to build software in a way that is both flexible and sustainable. I’m getting really uncomfortable as I now get to go out and watch game with both my old and new friends. (Anecdotal incidence here). Great headways are achieved but also challenges remain with a hopeful future – that of bringing our community together and embracing each other’s strengths.

Ending Monolog

While I feel privileged to have grown up with this boy and met & learned from many of his clique, my work experiences led me to also work in many cases with the cronies. So I finish the story with a call to action for the audience to avoid the dichotomy of us versus them and to regain our role as the chaperons of quality as manifested in the end-products and artifacts regardless of the adopted software development methodology. Curtain close. Audience cheers. Lights off. :)

talk.title: The Influential Architect: Succeeding At Scale Among Fully Autonomous Teams
talk.description:
Being the only software architect in a company with many fully autonomous and agile development teams can be an exasperating exercise. The role looks simple on paper: drive good, technical solutions to business problems. But with so much going on at any given moment and constant iteration, staying on top of and affecting outcomes across the board is practically impossible. If you can't even keep up, how can you find time to engage in the decision-making process?

In this environment, a 'command-and-control' style architect can encounter significant opposition and find themselves ineffective. Instead, we may consider exploring an entirely different approach. The Influential Architect is fusion of advisor, mentor, facilitator, communicator, and storyteller. As an Influential Architect, our aim is to improve outcomes across the organisation without the organisation becoming reliant on us making key decisions. To achieve this, we have to change the level of abstraction: where previously our purview has been decisions, we must now focus on people. When we can't be in every room where decisions are being made, we must affect the people who are and the process they use.

In this talk, we'll explore what it means to be an Influential Architect, as well as some of the tools and techniques we can use to succeed. We'll cover:

* Transparent Decision-making.
    * How may we efficiently document and communicate our intentions with regards to technical solutions and what would those documents look like?
    * How may we incorporate other development teams into our feedback cycle without creating bottlenecks?
* The Light on the Hill.
    * What is a technical vision and how does it help both the team and the wider organisation?
    * How do we go about establishing a technical vision and who needs to be involved in this process?
    * How do we hold teams accountable to technical visions, in order to ensure they work towards the same long-term goals?
* Visual Storytelling.
    * How can we effectively communicate technical outcomes to non-technical stakeholders?
    * What are the key components of a good story and how does a story help communicate intentions?
    * What does an example of a visual story that communicates a technical initiative look like?
* Architectural Principles.
    * What are architectural principles and why do we need them?
    * How and in what format are architectural principles articulated?
    * What does the process of establishing them look like to optimise for creating buy-in among technical teams?
    * How may we hold teams accountable to the architectural principles we've established?
* Sensible Defaults.
    * How can we use sensible defaults to avoid reinventing the wheel while at the same time not hinder innovation?
    * How do we go about establishing sensible defaults in an open and inclusive process?
    * How do teams incorporate using sensible defaults in their work process?
* Strategic Thinking.
    * How can we champion long-term concerns in an iterative agile process?

In the longer version of the talk, we'll expand on the aforementioned tools by going through them in greater detail with several real-life examples, and also cover:

* A case study of failures.
    * What were the approaches that didn't work so well?
    * Why did they fail and what can we learn from them?
* Team suitability.
    * Are there any _team_ characteristics that are necessary in order for an Influential Architect to be effective?
    * What can we do to prepare teams for greater autonomy if they are not ready for it?
* Architect suitability.
    * Are there any _personal_ characteristics that significantly make this type of role easier to fulfil for the Influential Architect?
* Evaluating outcomes.
    * How do we measure our own success in influencing teams?
    * How do we know which teams need more (or less) support than others?
    * Under what circumstances might it be acceptable to stray from the technical vision?
talk.notes:
This is probably best suited as a 30 minute talk, but can be expanded into a 90 minute talk if so desired. The presentation has no technical requirements other than a projector for the slides.

My presentations tend to be fun and engaging. I strive to offer ideas people can implement as soon as they get back from the conference, interwoven with self-deprecating humour. I gave a talk about Event Sourcing at last year's SATURN which was well received: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TeMYF_JjNg

Having lived and breathed the role of Influential Architect at Envato in Melbourne, Australia, I'm well-positioned to talk through the lessons I've learned throughout my journey. At Envato, we have 18 autonomous engineering teams working on several products in the digital marketplaces industry. Over 120 people are directly involved in the day-to-day development and delivery of software projects. As the only person with Software Architecture in my job title, I guide these teams and people to ensure that we are making sound technical descision and are all working towards the same technical vision.

The Influence approach we've been trialling at Envato has been very successful, with a transparent decision-making process and better outcomes. For the first time ever, we have a coherent long-term architectural vision that is understood and frequently referenced by both technical and non-technical stakeholders. Teams are able to move faster, with the reassurance of knowing they are heading in the same direction as everyone else.

I'm excited to share what I've learned about the role of a Software Architect at scale. The presentation is packed with advice on what's worked and what hasn't, and has concrete real-world examples rather than abstract ones. There should be interesting content for all types of architects even if they work in very different environments.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. This submission addresses a very real situation that many of us face -- operating through influence, not control, with teams that are not required to listen.

The bulleted list hits on many relevant topics. You've hit on what I'd like to hear about (being in a similar situation). I like the proposed use of real-world examples.

I'd like to see this expanded to a longer talk but would need to have more information to review it as such. The topic presents lots of opportunity to share lessons learned, strategies, tactics, etc. In this regard, an outline would be most helpful, perhaps just adding some detail to the existing bulleted list.

I'm also interested in how you document and communicate the resultant architecture information so that it is used by developers, not forgotten. Do you use models, text documents, process descriptions, etc.? How do you make this information attractive to the development teams? Any explanations on these things are appreciated.

Hi Conrad,

Thanks for your submission.  Overall I like the topic and think this could be a good talk at SATURN.  But I'm going to play devil's advocate in the review.  If accepted, I hope you're able to use the review to help improve the talk.

You assert that "a ‘command-and-control’ style architect is destined to fail" and yet we (the broader community) has managed to ship complex software under situations like this and have for decades.  There must be something other than leadership style at play?

How much does the team culture and experience play into success of the adopted leadership style?  What about the architect's experience?

You discuss only the positive benefits of this style of leadership.  I would think that empowering the team can have a downside if you don't find the right balance of vision and guidance.  How do you determine if your team is doing well with this approach or needs more oversight?

I do not believe all teams are ready for this leadership approach.  How do you know if a team is ready and how do you prepare them to handle greater autonomy?

Regards,

Michael
Sebastian, apologies, I don't usually address people only by their last names -- I was moving too fast and read the wrong text!

Anthony, 

Thank you for your comments. I'm very happy to hear that you think the talk is relevant to your interests! I have amended the submission with some additional information you might find useful. It's not a full outline, per se, but hopefully will give you enough context to understand what I intend to cover.

A longer version of the talk would allow me to go into each area in greater detail, but also cover additional topics. I have listed those in the talk description.

Thanks again for the feedback, and let me know if there is anything I can clarify further!

Michael,

Many thanks for your constructive feedback! I have made some alterations to the description, and I hope to be able to cover as many of the points you raised.

Regarding the "destined to fail" assertion you called out, I will happily concede that was probably erring too far on the side of hyperbole. I've edited that sentence (and the one following it) to use somewhat softer language that I hope more accurately communicates what I actually meant.

Thanks again for your comments, and for taking the time to consider my submission.

Looks like an interesting talk.  Can you tell me where the "command-and-control" phrase comes from?  I've been seeing it in other places and would like to know the origin, as it applies to software architecture leadership.

profile.name: Eltjo Poort

Eltjo R. Poort is Distinguished Solution Architect at CGI in The Netherlands. In his 30-year career in the software industry, he has fulfilled many engineering and project management roles. talk.title: The life and times of an architecture - Architectural decision making throughout the solution life cycle
talk.description:
Over the last decade, the architecture discipline has matured from up-front design to a stream of architectural decisions that address the concerns related to ever-evolving software systems. The word “stream” implies a continuous process, but in real life that stream is far from homogeneous. Architects (or whoever else owns the design decisions) find themselves making decisions with widely varying impact, based on information with differing levels of uncertainty, throughout the life of a software solution. On top of that, the way these decisions and their impact are communicated evolves as the audience and the focus of the architectural communication change.

In this tutorial, we explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making, throughout a software solution’s life cycle. Amid all the fluidity of the stream of design decisions, we will look for anchor points with common concerns to address and recurring communication needs. We will see how the nature of architectural decisions changes when we go from birth (the first architectural outline) to graduation (making the business case), and find guidance on communicating the architecture at times of life-defining milestones like marriage (committing to the architecture) and revolutionary changes to the solution. The points will be illustrated by real-life examples from an interesting case study.

The tutorial is based on Risk- and Cost-Driven Architecture, a popular approach to improve architecture practices in both traditional and agile contexts, with the aim of providing “just enough anticipation” in the architecture. No prior knowledge of RCDA is required to attend.
talk.notes:
This is a 90-minute tutorial.

During the product lifecycle, key aspects of architectural decisions change, depending on the life stage:

* level of risk and cost control: the cone of uncertainty
* available information to base architectural decisions on
* impact of architectural decisions
* number of architectural decisions
* cost of change to the architecture

Certain milestones like graduation (approving the business case for the solution) and marriage (the moment after which it becomes very expensive to change the architecture) occur in every solution life cycle. Such milesones lead to standard stakeholder concerns, like affordability, level of risk control and predictability. We use the commonality of these concerns to provide the architect with standard views in their documentation, enabling them to show how the architecture addresses these common concerns.

Contents
-----------

1. Introduction: 
 * Architecture as a stream of design decisions
 * Cone of uncertainty
 * Project vs. product life cycle
2. Birth:
 * From stakeholder need to solution concept
3. Graduation:
 * Making the business case
4. Marriage:
 * Committing to the architecture
5. Career and home life:
 * Fulfilling the architecture
 * Emergent architecture
 * Evolutionary changes
 * Health and debt control
6. Children:
 * Revolutionary changes
7. Legacy
talk.abstract: Explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making throughout a software system's life cycle. Find guidance on communicating your architecture at birth, graduation and marriage, after which changing the architecture becomes very expensive...

Hi Ged, no prior knowledge of RCDA is required. The RCDA principles and practices that I use (like the "Architecture as a stream of design decisions" principle and the "Architectural Decision Making" practice) will be explained as needed in the tutorial. I will clarify this in the description.

Hi Eltjo,

I agree with Ged, this looks great.  Knowing that you've presented on these topics before, what's new or different in this talk that we haven't seen before?  It appears that this is similar material presented in a completely new way from previous talks on this topic.  Is that a fair characterization?   Is there more to it than that?

Regards,

Michael

The life stage especially impacts decision making and documentation practices, and the tutorial teaches architects to recognize this and act accordingly.

Thanks, Eltjo!  It sounds like this is more related to application of the method rather than the method itself (other than covering necessary background).  To me this is a minor but important distinction.  Thanks for the extra information!

talk.title: Turning projects into products and wind into profit, or how GE Renewables was transformed into a Cloud SaaS Provider
talk.description:
At SATURN 2016, I introduced a novel lean approach to developing product architecture that combines Lean Model Canvas, Design Thinking, and Agile practices.  This year, I am excited to share a case study of how it was applied at GE Renewables Digital to bring software products to renewables assets.

In partnership with IT, field engineers, data scientists, and software engineers I watched an entire digital organization grow agile and innovating.  My fellow architects were the guides who captured the tribal wisdom and rallied both executive and product management sponsorship to launch two product lines in 2017 – Digital Wind Farm and Digital Hydro Plant, both demoed at GE Minds and Machines 2016 event. 

This session is based on my experience leading GE Digital Renewables architecture strategy for Asset Performance Management and Operations Optimization.  Renewables energy presents unique and diverse challenges when it comes to delivering software at scale.  Connecting hundreds and thousands of wind turbines and solar panels, fine-tuning analytics at the edge and the cloud, and assuring NERC compliance through Secure DevOps are some of the concerns to consider.

The participants will be walked through the journey and challenges on the way to migrating both existing applications and building brand new applications on a cloud platform and how architecture best practices accelerated the management and minimization of technical and functional debt.

The session also presents the trade-offs both at tactical and strategic level for moving forward with new technology without missing the beat of capturing the market opportunity for innovation leveraging horizontal products such as Asset Performance Management from Predix to accelerate renewables business objectives.

Two major product portfolios - The Digital Wind Farm and the Digital Hydro Plan were enabled with Common Renewables Asset Model based on IEC and S95 standards.   Model development was crowd-sourced to both IT, service engineering, and software development to capture both domain knowledge and leverage break-through features of distributed graph storage and scale with micro services.

Digital Hydro Plant is the product line for hydro plants and hydraulic turbine asset performance management and operation optimization which is a hybrid system of an on-prem and cloud solution both based on Predix platform.

I am not quite sure what you mean by gold plating.

talk.title: Ultimate Architecture Enforcement – Write Your Own Rules and Enforce Them Continuously
talk.description:
The software architecture discussed and carefully created is often not entirely followed in the implementation. In this talk we'll examine the factors that lead to this disconnect between the architecture and the code. We'll learn that consequences of this problem go beyond maintainability issues. But most important, we'll look at an easy to use, automated solution to improve architecture conformance. This solution has been successfully applied in a mid-size organization. It uses free open source tools and also helps to raise architecture knowledge across the development team. 

Things you will learn:

- the importance of architecture conformance. 

- how to use free open source tools to create your own design rules. Through examples, you'll learn the basics of the SonarQube custom check API. 

- how to enforce the architecture continuously by integrating the custom rules to your CI infrastructure. 

- how to make this setup effective, based on lessons learned by the author in the past 6 years. 

No pre-requisite knowledge is required other than basic understanding of object-oriented programming.
talk.notes:
This talk is supposed to be a 90-minute tech tutorial. 

Early results of the approach discussed in the presentation were described in a [SATURN blog post](https://saturnnetwork.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/ultimate-architecture-enforcement-prevent-code-violations-at-code-commit-time/). 
More recent results were described in a [SPLASH Wavefront paper](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2508433).
The SATURN presentation is updated to reflect recent improvements and results.

*Session mechanics* 

This is a slide-based presentation. I'll also use the IDE to show and run some code. Questions and comments are welcome during the talk or at the end. 

*Talk outline*

- Introduction: Motivation for architecture conformance; factors that lead to lack of conformance; consequences of lack of conformance.
- Creating a custom rule: intro to static code analysis tools with an API to create custom rules
- Example 1 - enforcing a layered architecture (for each example, we'll examine the code and comment on the SonarQube API)
- Example 2 - enforcing mandated generalizations
- Example 3 - enforcing REST service design standards
- Automated tests for custom checks: quick overview of how to build and run automated tests
- Integration with continuous integration
- Running critical checks in a pre-commit hook on git or svn
- Our experience with custom checks: results and lessons learned in 6 years 

*Target audience*

This talk is particularly important to software architects, but is of interest to software developers in general. 

*Previous presentations* 

SPLASH 2013; The Brazilian Conference on Software - Theory and Practice 2013; 3er Congreso Internacional Escuela de Ingeniería de Sistemas y Computación (Peru); invited talks at different organizations.

talk.title: Using Conway’s to Architect a Team
talk.description:
In 1967 Melvin Conway submitted a paper to the Harvard Business Review titled “How do Committees invent.” In this paper he wrote that 

*Any organization that designs a system (defined more broadly here than just information systems) will inevitably produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure.*

 The paper was ultimately rejected on the grounds that Melvin had not submitted enough evidence to support his claims (It was published in Daatamation and is available online) . However his hypothesis became known as Conway’s law and many organizations can say that they have observed the same behaviors as outlined in Melvin’s original paper. 

Here at IBM Watson, we just completed an initial release of a new microservice-based cloud platform. This service involved multiple teams, multiple microservices and multiple timezones.  We took a cloud product from inception on a lightening fast roller coaster ride to GA in five months, and lived to tell the story. We didn’t get everything right, but we learned alot along the way and we’d like to share those learnings. 

In this presentation we will share our experience, and talk about some of the architectural successes and mistakes we made. We’ll talk about how we used Conway’s law, and the inverse Conway manuever to correct some of those mistakes. We’ll also touch on some of the issues confronting our teams with remote team members and how we solved them. We’ll provide a prescription for approaching team architecture based on our learnings. 

By the end of the presentation, attendees will gained a knowledge of Conway’s law, how to use it to their advantage, and how to take an architecture led focus for team creation and development.
talk.notes:
This will be a slide-based presentation with the following tentative outline:

* Problem statement: Architecting teams is hard to get right the first time. Conway's law seems to be the right thing to do, but presents a challenge in many organizations. Architecture led team formation as a strategy.
* Review: Conway’s law, Stages of Team Formation
* Motivating Example: Describe the team formation for Watson Cloud service
* Lessons learned
* Techniques used to overcome the challenges faced
* Outcomes of using those techniques
* A prescription for architecting teams based on our experiences
* What’s next? 
* Conclusions

### Learning outcomes
By the end of this session you will be able to answer the following questions:

* What is Conway’s law?
* What is the inverse Conway manuever
* When might a good time be to employ these techniques?


### Target audience and assumed knowledge
* Managers who want to learn how to use Conways law to their advantage.
* Architects interested in finding ways to influence team formation through architecture

### We assume the following audience background.
* Understands basic software development challenges with multiple teams
* Has heard of Conway's law

Has this content been presented before?
This material has not been presented in this format externally to IBM.
talk.abstract: For software managers and architects, this talk is intended to provide some guidelines for using Conway's law based on real experiences in the field so that they can find better ways to form teams in the age of microservices architecture.

feedback.body:
Will-

This proposal is interesting and relevant. A couple of comments:
- The title should be "Using Conway's Law..."?
- I would be interested in hearing how much of your successes and failures were due to fundamental architecture modularization issues (informed by Conway's Law), and how much was helped or hurt by the microservices implementation of that modularization.
- Although rejected by HBR, Conway's paper was published in Datamation magazine. Datamation was one of the most influential IT practitioner publications of that era, which broadened the exposure of the idea. I sometimes wonder if it had been accepted by HBR if we would be talking about it now, or if it would have been missed by practitioners.

Great feedback. Thank you. I agree that it would be very applicable to talk about success and failures - due to architectural modularization issues (through Conway's) vs the actual microservices implementation. This distinction is actually quite relevant - as it will allow us to think about how much of an impact a microservices architecture has on top of a modularized team approach, whether positive or negative. I will add that to the agenda.
You raise a very interesting point about the "luck" of being rejected by HBR. What a fascinating topic- you could well imagine that if it had been accepted by HBR - that it could have been missed entirely by the software architecture community and perhaps it would have sprouted more generally into other communities of practice. This is a perfect "What if" scenario and will fit nicely into the talk as food for thought.

Hi Will!

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. What do you mean by "a cloud product"? A software product that runs on the cloud? Is the cloud product the cloud platform that you mention in the previous sentence? In any case, can you say more about the nature of the software product?  

2. If I understood correctly, this talk focuses on the architecture of the *team*, not the software architecture. It talks about team creation, team architecture. Conway's law is indeed about the organizational structure. That's fine! But you say the product is microservice-based. I think microservices are not only independent deployment and runtime elements, but they enable independent, smaller teams. Microservice teams are hence easier to put together and manage. Following this line of thought, we would need more guidelines and wisdom about how to create a team for monolithic applications.  :^)

3. I often see Conway's Law (which should be Conway's Conjecture by the way) in texts that talk about microservices. I hope in your talk you can reflect about whether Conway's observation and the inverse maneuver can make sense to non-microservices software. 

Typos:

- "attendees will *have* gained"

- "we learned a* *lot along the way"

talk.title: Building composable abstractions
talk.description: Do you want to create robust and composable abstractions? In this talk Eric Normand will present an iterative process to define the essence of a domain and build composability into the core. The resulting abstractions lead to more robust code at the core of your application, and can give your business a competitive advantage. We will apply this process to the Processing graphics library to develop a composable vector graphics system.
talk.notes:
This is a 60 minute talk.

After attending the talk, the attendee will be able to:

1. Know the difference between Newtonian-style abstractions and Aristotelian-style abstractions. Aristotelian abstractions are built up piecemeal and are full of corner cases, like Aristotelian physics. Newtonian abstractions are elegant, formal, and composable.

2. Follow a design process for developing an algebraic abstraction that can compose and easily express solutions (Newtonian style). Building data transformation pipelines is the step most people who are learning functional programming get to from reading and experimenting. Building algebraic abstractions is the next step, but there isn't much literature on the topic (outside of academia)
    1. Elaborate a physical metaphor
    2. Describe the meaning of your metaphor as mathematical statements
    3. Construct the meaning using constructs from the language
    4. Implement the abstraction by refactoring the meaning
	
	The physical metaphor is an important first step that gives us an anchor from which we may use our intuition. We then query our metaphor for its properties and write them in math, which usually means types and equations. After that, we can construct a runnable version of the meaning, being careful to build it out of parts constrained by our statements from step 2. Finally, the implementation becomes an easy matter of refactoring our runnable version.


This topic idea comes from my experience teaching functional programming to people with all levels of experience. There seems to be a logical progression of insights that people go through as they learn about functional programming. I don't see many people getting past the "data transformation" step, so I want to present something further. It's hard to say whether it's THE next step, but it is at least one step beyond transformations.

A lot of the thinking comes from my experience as a professional Clojure and Haskell programmer and the work of Conal Elliott, John Hughes, and Gerald Sussman.

I have given a version of this talk at Clojure/conj 2016: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJIUoaIvD20 I would love to adapt this to a language like JavaScript. The example code will be given in JavaScript.

talk.title: Customer Experience Architecture Hands On
talk.description:
Architecture is about the customer. If you create an architecture that doesn’t give value to the customer you are wasting your time. When I talk to customers I often hear horror stories about how their current systems were developed by someone in an ivory tower who didn’t understand them or their work. So how do you make sure that you are bringing value to the customer through your architecture? Use customer centric design processes often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. These are fundamental parts of Lean and Agile and this session shows how to use them in architecture with hands on experience. In this highly interactive session participants redesign a system by interviewing a customer, creating a prototype, reviewing it with the group, and getting feedback on their design. Using the methods taught in this class you can create value for your customer through your architecture and become their hero, or at least not the person in the ivory tower who is ruining their life.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture
talk.notes:
My goal for this session is to help architects learn a customer centric design process. I learned this method from the "Deciding what to Design" course at Carnegie Mellon. The method is often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. Its a fundamental part of Lean and Agile. I've rarely seen people show how these methodologies apply to architecture, so thats my goal for class.

I use this process in my own work at GE and previously at Verizon.  I lead the End to End Customer Experience efforts at Verizon and enabled our architects and software engineers to talk to customers. I gave a talk on that experience at a past SATURN that generated a lot of interest.

At GE I am using this method to design a new CI/CD system for our Industrial Internet of Things platform called Predix. Customers (anyone who gets value from the system you are creating) really appreciate working with me. I find out very surprising things by using this method and create much better systems.


A slightly modified version of this session has been given before at Code on The Beach and was well received.  I used the "App for adding contact to network" use case and it ended up being a common but complex enough task that the groups had plenty to design. The Code on the Beach session was 60 minutes long and I assigned roles to each team member. I didn’t have time to have feedback given to each group, but I think it is an effective way to leverage the knowledge in the room. I didn’t have time to fit in the last wrap up session either, which I think is critical for people to concrete the new information. I've added those two parts to this 90 minute session.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture


The participatory session will include the following:
15 minutes
Introduction to Customer Experience Design
Introduce the hands on Exercise: Design a new system for adding a contact to your network (Linkedin, google+ , etc.)
Divide session into groups of 4 or 5 people.

10 minutes
Activity 1: Determine what matters to the customer including their functional requirements and quality attributes by watching how they do the task in their natural environment and asking lots of “why’s”. I will ask each group to select someone in their group to be the "customer." Each group will watch their customer collect a business card from a person and add a contact to their network of choice.

25 minutes 
Activity 2: Design the system around the customer’s needs and document it in a prototype. The prototype should be as interactive as possible, not just a flow chart. Prototype should show the architecture elements. Because the “customer” is involved, the team should be constantly getting input from the customer on their on going design. They should also write down any assumptions they are making and any reasons they made design decisions. Finalize the prototype, the assumptions, design decisions, and what they learned from the process.

30 minutes 
Activity 3: Review the prototype with the group. Receive feedback on design. About 5 minutes each group.

5 minutes
Wrap up: Allow the small groups to meet one last time to discuss the feedback and make any changes to their design.

10 minutes
Final Group discussion: Discuss what they learned from the session. Find out what they learned from receiving and giving feedback.

talk.title: Making the switch to "serverless" full-stack development
talk.description:
"Serverless" is a newly-popular buzzword and as with many tech buzzwords, is a complete misnomer ("cloud", anyone?)  We're going to discuss what serverless really means (hint: it's a way of abstracting OS-level infrastructure management from server-side application code), what the difference is between the various providers, why you would want to consider using a serverless architecture, and how you would go about implementing one.  We'll discuss greenfield development as well as a migration path for existing web applications.  Other interesting aspects covered will be how the development workflow will change and why, what testing will look like in a serverless world, and some pitfalls to avoid.  While a serverless approach can be applied to applications written in a variety of languages, Javascript will be the language used for this talk, so we will examine some of the popular serverless Javascript frameworks, including apex.js, claudia.js, and serverless.js.

If you're interested in full-stack development, DevOps, micro-service architecture, containers, cutting operational costs, and/or just staying abreast with the latest application architecture approaches, this talk is for you.  This is a 90-minute, interactive, participatory workshop for which you will need your laptop, a Github account, and an Amazon AWS account.
talk.notes: I am an ex-IBMer who has been architecting and developing for nearly 20 years. I run a full-stack, custom software development shop in Los Angeles and Austin that's known for staying on the cutting-edge of tech.  I frequently speak at tech events (particularly JavaScript and Node.js focused events) and am passionate about designing great software.
talk.abstract: In the world of micro services and agile development, "serverless" architecture is now all the rage.  In this talk, you'll learn what it is, what it can do for you, why you would and wouldn't want to use it, and what you need to know to make the switch.  This will be a hands-on walk through.

feedback.body:
Hi David,

As this will be a hands on talk, what will participants need to bring with them to participate?  Also, what tech stack will you be using during the session?

I like that this is planned to be hands on and that you plan to discuss migration paths.  We've had a lot of proposals around server-less architecture and only a few will be accepted.

Surely server-less isn't for everyone?  In what situations would you recommend someone not adopt server-less architectures?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael!  I'll answer each question in turn below.

As this will be a hands on talk, what will participants need to bring with them to participate? 
-  Participants will need a laptop with git and node installed, an internet connection, and accounts on Amazon AWS and Github.  

Also, what tech stack will you be using during the session?
-  Full-stack Javascript: Angular.js on the front-end and Node.js on the back-end.  We'll use DynamoDB as the no-SQL database.  We'll also be discussing (and may use) some of the serverless frameworks like serverless.js or claudia.js.

I like that this is planned to be hands on and that you plan to discuss migration paths. We’ve had a lot of proposals around server-less architecture and only a few will be accepted.
-  Thank you!  We'll walk through taking an existing web application and refactoring routes over to a serverless architecture using AWS Lambda and AWS API Gateway.  Depending on time, we may get into testing, deployment, and other advanced topics.

In what situations would you recommend someone not adopt server-less architectures?
-  The biggest benefits for serverless are 1) decreased complexity for developers - abstracting away  server-level administration and devOps tasks and 2) lower costs for applications on VMs that spend time idling.  So, for those that have a mature, stable, and effective devOps infrastructure that already abstracts server complexity from developers and for those whose VMs don't have much idle computing time, transitioning to serverless probably isn't going to be cost/risk-effective.  

- There may be other reasons to not transition: risk aversion ("this is too new and unproven"), compliance ("we neither own the data center NOR manage any of the VM infrastructure??"), or simple mistrust ("how do I know it's going to scale when I really need it to?") It's important that application architects take into consideration their corporate policies, compliance and risk requirements, and organizational change tolerance when considering serverless.
Apologies for the odd message formatting above... Papercall did some weird things and won't let me edit my message to fix them.

No worries, I can still read it :-)

Thanks for your responses.  As I mentioned, competition is stiff for participatory sessions but I think this looks like a fun and informative hands on session.  I am a bit concerned about getting everyone set up.  If this talk is accepted please think about ways to minimize the setup time and make sure the workshop spends time on the things in your proposal and not installing software and registering for accounts.

Good luck!

Michael

Michael,

Absolutely!  We'll have a git repo for them to clone and the code will be set up maximize simplicity, but there's no way around the need for an AWS account if they want to follow along since AWS will be our serverless platform.  I will look for other optimizations beyond that. 

Thank you for your consideration, and please let me know if there is anything else I can do to clarify or improve my candidacy. 

Happy Holidays!

David

Hi David,
Thank you for the submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. The term serverless is actually quite broad and poorly defined. For example, [Mike Roberts](https://martinfowler.com/articles/serverless.html) associates serverless to the use of MBaaS (more common), or alternatively richer clients (SPA?) talking to services behind an API gateway. Your talk probably has a clear description of what a serverless architecture is to you, but I'm thinking a brief definition in the talk description itself would also be helpful to correctly set the expectations of participants looking at the conference program.

2. Assuming this is a 90-minute participatory session, the talk description (visible to conference participants) at some point has to clearly state this is a hands-on session and attendees should have a github and AWS account, and bring their laptops.

3. The description could also be explicit about what frameworks, languages, and technologies will be used in the hands-on.
Thank you for your feedback, Paulo!  I've updated the description to address your comments.  Please let me know if you'd like me to refine it further.  Thanks again!

talk.title: Real Life SOA Transformation: A journey at Rackspace from Monolithic to SOA and beyond (MicroServices)
talk.description:
Rackspace has been in a hyper growth for the past many years. This presented significant challenges around the Software Transformation journey we should have in a fast-moving environment, where the agility and producing tangible timely Business output is the key.
 
In this presentation, a team of Architects from Rackspace will present the SOA Transformation we are guiding at Rackspace.

- Rackspace - Legacy ESB Mayhem
- Goals and Challenges  
- Introducing SOA 
- Rackspace RESTIFIED
- Journey at Rackspace
- Use Cases and Decisions
- Journey towards CI/CD - Application Packaging/Delivery/Deployment 
- Lessons Learned
- The Future

At the end of the presentation, the audience should be able to relate the case study to similar technological transformation challenges they face at their organizations and learn about some of the suggested guidelines around how to accomplish large-scale technology transformations.
talk.notes:
There would be other presenters along with me. I had presented at "Saturn 2016" last year, on topic titled "Beyond REST". I have published many articles in online technology magazines.

Thanks, Jørn Ølmheim for the feedback. The original request for 45 Minutes presentation. The idea is to share a real-time use case/challenges to the audience and how we achieved some of the major transformations.
talk.abstract: Modernizing existing systems and moving to new technologies come with significant challenges. An enterprise-wide transformation like moving to SOA is not an easy task.  A team of Rackspace Architects will share their transformation journey and the planned future.

ratings.comments: Yes for 30 minute talk. Focus should be on the challenges, solutions, and lessons learned.

This is a presentation I would want to see.  Rackspace have been leading in cloud-enabled managed computing for a number of years now and I would seize any opportunity to learn more about the lessons they have learned.

I am also pleased to see a submission on the topic of SOA.  Many companies are still investing in service orientation.

Important topic, gained experience seems to be relevant and interesting for SATURN attendees. Regrettably, the abstract and the talk description come across as a bit (too) high level and tentative ("would").

feedback.body: We have had some issues with PaperCall changing talk formats on editing of the submission. Could you please confirm that this is intended for a 15 min lightning talk? Also be aware that the plan is to run these on the main stage in front of the full attending audience (about 200 people). Please update your submission with the correct talk format and also indicate the length of the talk in the Notes section for future reference.

Thanks, Jørn Ølmheim for the feedback. The original request for 45 Minutes/60 Minutes presentation.  I have changed to 30 minutes as that is what is available. The idea is to share a real-time use case/challenges to the audience and how we achieved some of the major transformations.

Changed to 90 minutes and what would be ideal for us is 60 Minutes. 30 Minutes seems to less and 90 minutes too long. But if we cannot have 60 minutes, we could come prepared for 90 minutes. Thanks for the feedback!

Hi Yogeshwar!  

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. In the Talk Description, why is transformation capitalized in SOA Transformation? In particular, this phrase is not clear and somewhat intriguing: "the Software Transformation journey we should have in a fast-moving environment, where the agility is the key". Maybe there's more objective motivation for the specific transformations you will describe. 

2. I think most of the material out there is settling to using microservices as opposed to micro-services. 

3. If you find that your talk is too long, I suggest removing the first topic ("Rackspace - Business and System Perspective").

4. I think the description is somewhat vague, especially for a 90-minute session. If it's 90 minutes long, it takes the time equivalent to 3 30-minute talks, so the info should be clearly valuable. You mention a case study. Maybe you should say more about the case study.

5. Things you could add to the description to make it more interesting: what technology transformation will you talk about? If it's monolithic to microservices, what do your monoliths looked like? Java EAR apps? MS .NET? Where do you run your microservices? Docker? Kubernetes?  What tools and frameworks did you add to your runtime environment, development environment, continuous integration/deployment environment? 

6. I think the most challenging aspect of the monolith-to-microservice transition is finding the appropriate functional scope for the microservices. If they are too small, you may end up with chatty communications and lower autonomy and performance. If a microservice encompasses functional contexts that is too large, you move closer to the monolithic model and may not significantly realize the microservices benefits. What approaches have you used to help define the size of microservices? Did DDD help? 

7. What communication mechanisms did you use in microservices (what connector types)? Http (REST)? WebSocket? Asynchronous messages/events? 

8. I think "methods of how to accomplish large-scale technology transformations" is quite ambitious. If you don't have exactly methods, but guidelines or best practices derived from experience, that's ok too. 

9. I think you should say "a team of Architects from Rackspace will present" instead of "a team of Architects from Rackspace would attempt to present".

Typos:

- "moving to new technologies come ** with significant challenges"

- "At the end of *the* presentation"

- "we are *g*uiding at Rackspace"

Thanks Paulo for the great feedback. Please find some of my responses.

1.	In the Talk Description, why is transformation capitalized in SOA Transformation? In particular, this phrase is not clear and somewhat intriguing: "the Software Transformation journey we should have in a fast-moving environment, where the agility is the key". Maybe there's more objective motivation for the specific transformations you will describe.

Most of the organizations which grow very fast tend to first focus on getting things done quickly and later worry about getting things done in the perfect fashion. This kind of accustoms business stakeholders used to seeing quick results. It takes some time to realize the importance of SOA, standardization, governance. When an organization attempts to do a Transformation Journey replacing the majority of the monolithic code base with industry standard COTS/SAAS/Systems/Custom Built Systems, coupled with the transition to SOA there is still a level of impatience to see quick results. Also, there is an expectation that buying SAAS/COTS products means they would start working immediately. These misconceptions posed significant challenges for us to keep providing continuous Business Value as well as working towards accomplishing embracing SOA. So, on one hand, we were doing a major re-haul of our systems and on another hand also making sure that we embrace SOA as well as providing incremental business value. We accomplished SOA not in isolation but by coupling tangible business benefits spread over a period of time also delivering incrementally. Those are the details I would like to share and that’s the reason why I would like to call it an SOA Transformation. 

2.	I think most of the material out there is settling to using microservices as opposed to micro-services.
I’ll have this corrected. Thank you!

3.	If you find that your talk is too long, I suggest removing the first topic ("Rackspace - Business and System Perspective").
Please see point 4.

4.	I think the description is somewhat vague, especially for a 90-minute session. If it's 90 minutes long, it takes the time equivalent to 3 30-minute talks, so the info should be clearly valuable. You mention a case study. Maybe you should say more about the case study.

The introduction around Rackspace - Business and System Perspective is supposed to say more about the case study. Based on the time that is allotted, I would get this condensed accordingly. I would ideally prefer 60 minutes. 90 minutes seems to be a stretch.

5.	Things you could add to the description to make it more interesting: what technology transformation will you talk about? If it's monolithic to microservices, what do your monoliths looked like? Java EAR apps? MS .NET? Where do you run your microservices? Docker? Kubernetes? What tools and frameworks did you add to your runtime environment, development environment, continuous integration/deployment environment?

Sure I would add more details. The presentation is more around how we introduced SOA, embraced a culture of SOA and the difficulties we faced in the transformation. We had a couple of huge monoliths built mainly using Python/Java and they had undergone many revisions. The processes that we had were initially divergent and people dependent. From there we moved towards SOA, standardization of technology, deployment processes, CI and partly CD, and we could add details around the exact technology selection and standardization process we have also including details about Docker and other technologies we use. The challenges that would be described would be more on the lines of the phased steps we took to provide incremental business value and to reduce risks which helped as accomplish a major transformation. This an ongoing journey and we would talk about how we are beginning to embrace Microservices.

6.	I think the most challenging aspect of the monolith-to-microservice transition is finding the appropriate functional scope for the microservices. If they are too small, you may end up with chatty communications and lower autonomy and performance. If a microservice encompasses functional contexts that is too large, you move closer to the monolithic model and may not significantly realize the microservices benefits. What approaches have you used to help define the size of microservices? Did DDD help?

Great point, As an enterprise organization, we have not gone into a spree of replacing everything into MicroService. We are finding right use cases where we really could provide value out of carving Micro Services or introducing new MicroServices. I plan to present a case study of one such real use case and the practical benefits we gained from it. We have applied DDD concepts like Bounded Context and also to further split into Sub Contexts to select MicroService Candidates which helps in defining an appropriate logical boundary. Sure I would rephrase as per your suggestion. Thanks for the feedback.


9.	I think you should say "a team of Architects from Rackspace will present" instead of "a team of Architects from Rackspace would attempt to present".
Typos:
•	"moving to new technologies come ** with significant challenges"
•	"At the end of the presentation"

Thank you would do those changes. I would have this corrected.
This should be a 30 min experience report. And the focus should be on the challenges, solutions, and lessons learned nothing more.

talk.title: A software architect and a big band drummer walk into a bar, and their parallel universes collide.
talk.description:
The software architect is the lone carrier of DNA for the vision of the product, but does not work alone. He/she is placed on a project (“situation”) where he/she must still deliver. The big band drummer can single handedly guide a band, and is placed on a gig (“situation”) where he/she must deliver. What is at the core of the big band drummer’s DNA to bring about success and what parallels might we draw between the two? Come and find out.

Sometimes the most efficient way to a fresh perspective is to sit in the seat of someone else from a totally unrelated field. Reading Harvard Business Review, competitive companies seek advice from totally unrelated fields to solve their most difficult problems. So why should it be any different for software architect?  The software architect’s role in leading teams and influencing business decisions cannot be overlooked. 

John Ryskowski would love to reveal the big band drummer’s strategy for success and its attendant parallels to the software architect’s “situation.”  Of course, band stories and drumming demonstrations will be included.
talk.notes:
Session Requirements:
1) To start a conversation that will last throughout the rest of the conference. 
2) To obtain a “fresh perspective” by taking folks down the path of a totally unrelated field and drawing pertinent parallels for and with them. 
3) As an architect one must create and nurture the vision for the DNA of the product, in spite of the project situation. The big band drummer must nurture a good sound from the big band, in spite of the gig situation. The parallels between the two should be realized, discussed, and brought to grounded historical experiences for each attendee. 
4) To introduce some new language that may help put project situations into perspective allowing one to return to clarity of thought. Psychologically speaking we get some relief from having name for some events or techniques. For example, I need to vary my intensity to get the group affect that I desire.

The session breakdown:
Handouts: The actual drum chart for the subject of the talk- Kubis’ arrangement of “A Train,” and the “Clapping at Camp” chart written for audience participation. Big sticky papers will be on the walls of the room. 

1) Explain how one path to a fresh perspective is to experience something that is totally unrelated, but at the same time reveals grounded parallels to your situation. Executing a big band chart requires a strategy with known techniques but the flexibility to grab opportunities to inspire and transcend the moment. Through subtle and timely queues, the drummer can instill a sense of confidence and inspire the band to play better than they imagined. The techniques we discuss could have the same effect for the people on the architect’s project.
2) Through demonstration, we discuss some of the possible variations the drum set can offer. This would include the elements of the drum set with each of their different sounds, the 4 limbs of the body, and just some of the combinations thereof. We will stick with the combinations that are most pertinent for this talk, and don’t forget the eyes and brain play a role as well. 
3) We get into a discussion about some of the situations the big band drummer must deal with. Does the band leader know little about music (or does the manager of the program or product owner know little about the technology)?  Does the lead trumpet think he is with the Count Bassie band (or is your development principle unaccustomed to this environment)? Can the bass player not play in time (or does your development principle have no sense of time)? Is the drum set in the absolute worst location to work with the rest of the band (or are you stuck without a reasonable means of communication with the rest of the team)? I will demonstrate how the big band drummer overcomes each of these situations. 
I then ask each member of the audience to choose which situation they resonate with most. Audience members will then join 1 of 4 groups to discuss their personal situations, their solutions or possible solutions then elect the top 3 solutions to brief the rest of the other groups. 
4) Two vital techniques in big band drumming are then discussed: “Distinguishing signal from noise” knowing the current location of the chart without listening to anyone’s sense of time, and “Some of your great ideas may not be so great.” The audience will then be asked to verbalize their own parallels, and If the interest and energy are present, we can briefly split into two groups, discuss and brief.
5) The “Kubis” chart is then projected on the screen and actually played on the drum set asking the audience to try and observe, as best they can, all that is going on with the drum set performance. We then deconstruct each element of successful drum chart execution. Each element and a lesson to take away:
a) Element- Initiating and maintaining a tempo for the band. Lesson- What is least exciting for you may be most important to them.  You set the tone for what is to come and instill a sense of calm. Sometimes you’re just a piece of leverage. Wow that last one hurt.
b) Element- Identify milestones. Lesson- Marking points in time to celebrate progress, ensure social/technical alignment, and instill confidence.
c) Element- Vary intensity as needed. Lesson- Selectively applying energy at the right times and in the right places, balancing support, teaching, and inspiration.
d) Element- Special care. Lesson- Sometimes hand-holding is necessary.
e) Element- Set them up for success. Lesson- Anytime you set someone up for success, they feel good and want to work with you. 
The audience is once again, asked to choose which of these they resonate with most. Audience members will then join 1 of 5 groups and discuss their personal situations (or parallels) amongst their group. Each group will then brief the other groups. 
6) The “Clapping at Camp” chart is introduced. I show how without even being able to read music (or a rhythm chart) I can still set them up for success. We rehearse the sections of the chart. Then we perform the chart together and they clap in time like they were born to do it. It’s really fun.

Presentation History
This topic has been presented at Agile West, Las Vegas, 2016. 
Summary score of 8.69. Total attendees 45. Total of 4 written comments here verbatim:
1- Fun! Fun! Fun! Perspective and musical metaphor
2- Novel application and most engaging session by far! 
3- Very unique, engaging, and appropriate. One of my favorite presentations and many parallels were illustrated.
4- Content was delivered in a muddled way. Good points were buried in musician stories and metaphors.

References to Speaking Ability
I like to pull people out of their everyday situations, immerse them into something completely different that is fun and interesting, then help them to draw parallels back to their everyday situations. This is an efficient path to a fresh perspective, which is the most valuable take-away from any conference.  
The ideal reaction cycle I strive for is: a) I wonder what that would be like, b) cool I didn’t know that, c) whoa I need to try this out. 
I have spoken at Agile West, CMMI Institute Conferences, Pacific Norhwest Software Quality Conference, National Defense Industrial Association. I have also delivered good and bad news to leaders of many corporations. 

References: 
Kerry Trujillo,  Kerry_Trujillo@raytheon.com, see linkedIn recommendation
Michael West, michael@naturalspi.com

Your notes provide a good sense of the topics covered and the flow through the session. A little more information about timing within the 90 minutes would be helpful. The breakdown into element and lesson gives a sense of the parallels between drummer and leadership (in general). Would you say more about the points you will make about how these relate more specifically to the architect’s “situation”.

Hi Robert- I appreciate the interest.

Timing and did any parallels to architect surface at Agile West- The Agile West presentation was limited to 45 minutes and so had a lot less group participation than what I am proposing for SATURN.  The group participation discussed in steps 3, 5, and possibly step 4, in the SATURN proposal are an addition to this version of the talk. These group exercises will allow for a richer processing experience for the folks than what happened at AW. All this added up gives me about 35 minutes for 2 or 3 group participation exercises which should be no problem. This is general time estimate, if specific time allocations are required I would be happy to add them.  Additionally, in this limited time, at AW no parallels to architect came up at AW.

As for being under topic 3, I am happy to go with that. People, process, or product- the parallels will focus mostly on people. People are the common point between BB drumming and architects. But to be honest with you, I am not sure where these group exercises will go. One of the verbal comments after my talk at AW was that I did not presuppose to know the parallels exactly, and left space for attendees to formulate their own. It is the opening of this space that is my objective, less so giving a direct answer.   

From you- The breakdown into element and lesson gives a sense of the parallels between drummer and leadership (in general). Would you say more about the points you will make about how these relate more specifically to the architect’s “situation”. 

Response- From the 5000 foot perspective, the BB Drummer and architect have the same challenge. Take responsibility for the vision and integrity of the product without being given any authority or owning any of the resources. From lower altitude I am happy to make some adjustments though I do worry about anchoring, or disrupting where participants can go with their parallels. How do you feel about the “additions” below?

5a) Element- Initiating and maintaining a tempo for the band. Lesson- What is least exciting for you may be most important to them.  You set the tone for what is to come and instill a sense of calm. Sometimes you’re just a piece of leverage. Wow that last one hurt. Addition- While trying to balance creativity, risk, stakeholders and the responsibility to change the world, it is good to have a basic rhythm that all can operate to. 

5b) Element- Identify milestones. Lesson- Marking points in time to celebrate progress, ensure social/technical alignment, and instill confidence. Addition-  Is there a build and release rhythm you can work to?

5c) Element- Vary intensity as needed. Lesson- Selectively applying energy at the right times and in the right places, balancing support, teaching, and inspiration. Addition- The creative process comes down to a give and take in real time. You must dabble in interactions with people in the “known” before you can step over to the “unknown.”

5d) Element- Special care. Lesson- Sometimes hand-holding is necessary. Addition- Sometimes you don’t have to blow up the village in order to save it. Education and patience can pay off. 

5e) Element- Set them up for success. Lesson- Anytime you set someone up for success, they feel good and want to work with you. Addition- Introduce people to the patterns that you see with grace and composure to assure overall success. 

Best- John

talk.title: C++: unexpected behaviour
talk.description:
Do you really think to know C++? Then you probably want to participate in this talk, you will discover the most surprising, weird, strange or really "WTF" language features you could encounter.
There are so many obscure corners of the language that seem to go against common programming intuition. The freedom that C++ gives the programmer may be a double-edged sword; while the user can do many things that have been abstracted away in other languages, it's very easy to shoot ourselves in the foot.
From unintended private member access to unexpected function definitions, in this talk, we will walk you through the quirks that still exist in the language today, and the motivations behind them.
talk.notes:
This talk is funny but at the same time engaging and useful to learn new unexpected things from programming. Even though it is going to be based on C++ features it is not really needed a deep knowledge of the language. 

This talk is co-authored by my colleague Jaime Alonso Lorenzo.

talk.title: Developing a High Performance Security Focussed Agile Team
talk.description:
Quality (security included) does not have to be neglected when you're planning, building and running a high performance development team.

Kim will set the stage with how and why Agile Development Teams fail, explained with a familiar anecdote taken from his new book "Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developers", coupled with how you can change this.

Kim will then discuss and demo a set of light weight processes, practises and tools, that when combined have proven their value in:

1. Aiding high throughput (reducing time to market)
2. Significantly increasing quality (finding and removing bugs)
3. Without descoping

and all while reducing total project cost (fact).
If this sounds like breaking the laws of physics, or to good to be true, then this workshop is for you.

Kim will finish off with the habits of top developers and how we can make them part of our lives.
talk.notes:
This is a workshop requiring some attendee setup. Further details provided upon acceptance.

## Workings

### Provide brief context of the following to set the stage:

* [30,000' View](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#starting-with-the-30000-foot-view)
* [10,000' View](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#10000-foot-view-and-lower)
* [Tooling](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#tooling-setup)
* [Process and Practises](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#process-and-practises)
* [Physical](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#physical)
* [People](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#people)

### Step (1)

Discuss how and why development teams fail explained with a familiar anecdote, along with how you can change this (Essentials for Creating and Maintaining a High Performance Development Team), taken from: [https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#leanpub-auto-essentials-for-creating-and-maintaining-a-high-performance-development-team](https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers/read#leanpub-auto-essentials-for-creating-and-maintaining-a-high-performance-development-team)

### Step (2)

Within every Sprint:

* Cheapest Place to Deal with Defects
* Establish Security Champion (must be within team, not external)
* Along with Test Conditions, create Evil Test Conditions -> basis for your "Security Focussed TDD" -> get these into your CI.
* Hand-crafted Penetration Testing. Let Security Champion lead the way and monitor developers doing this.
* Pair Programming (needs to become part of your culture)
* Code Review (incl automation)
* Linting, static and dynamic analysis
* Static Type Checking
* Consuming free and open source (don't need to stop doing this, address the issue, processes, practises and tooling to mitigate the issue)
* Security Regression Testing (hands on: [https://github.com/binarymist/NodeGoat/wiki/Security-Regression-Testing-with-Zap-API](https://github.com/binarymist/NodeGoat/wiki/Security-Regression-Testing-with-Zap-API)). [Short video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DrwXUOJWMoo&feature=youtu.be) of how this works

### Step (3) Forming Habits and Sharpening Skills
