feedback.body:
Hi Kim, thank you for your contribution. Aiming at a 90 minutes talk, I find the description a bit vague. Can you give an outline of how the time is intended spent and how the attendants are intended to contribute. 

Thanks

Have updated the Notes. The largest section is the hands on security regression testing, as attendees are getting a lot out of this. Step 2 is quite similar to this workshop: https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#security-regression-testing-with-zapapi-and-nodegoat-nodeconf-eu

Let me know if this needs any more clarification?

Thanks.

Hi Kim,

As written on your other similar proposal, please clarify which format you think works best for your material. The double proposals leave it up to us to judge what is the best way to get your message across, which may or may not work in your benefit.

I like the building a team aspect of your talk, architects often double as leads in one way or another, with or without reporting line responsibility. It seems that you have delivered or intend to deliver this material at developer oriented conferences. We usually see some (lead) developers at SATURN, but please clarify whom your presentation will work for or how it will work for different groups.

Your outline confuses as it is up-high (team-building) and down in the details (hands-on penetration testing). Now having read both proposals, I'd recommend you to update the 30 min session to a focussed talk with a clear value proposition for architects and lead-developers. Dropping more technical material. Think about your audience and what they need, looking at previous SATURN conference programs gives you an idea of what the reviewers think our audience likes.

Good luck with generating publicity around your book!
Thijmen

This submission is a tutorial or workshop. "Secrets of a High Performance Security Focussed Agile Team" is a 25-30 minute presentation.

Both of the two submissions work well, it depends mostly on how much time you can allow. The presentation is not hands on, where as the workshop is. Many people find that they learn better if they actually play with the tools. Playing with the tools is what happens in This workshop. The workshop will work well if we can get the VM I have to attendees before the workshop. Attendees need to have this setup and runable before the workshop, otherwise it usually takes up to much time during the workshop. If we can get a network share setup that attendees can download the VM, and follow the directions I provide before the workshop then it usually works well. Also having a box of NTFS formatted 16GB USB sticks loaded with my VM, that can be handed out on and/or during the conference or even in the workshop, has worked well as a backup plan.

This submission can also be run as a tutorial, which takes less time, due to the non hands on nature, no one has to set anything up other than myself. If run as a tutorial, I just run through the tooling parts as a workshop myself. This way attendees get more of an idea how things fit together than they would if it was just the short presentation.

Numbers also play a part in what works best. If a large number of people wish to attend, then the presentation works best. If over 20 - 30 developers attend, then usually the workshop turns into more of a tutorial, unless, we are really organised and attendees are fully setup before the tutorial/workshop. I have 4 USB  sticks that I can pass around during the workshop, but this only works if there are 20 or less developers in the class.

So in summary, the workshop offers the most, but only if you can support the facilities required and both of us provide excellent comms to people wishing to attend the workshop in the weeks and days leading up to it. My preference is the presentation, as it is less work, but it's your call, I'm happy to run either.

I have run quite a few training's similar to this before:

NodeConfEU (https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#security-regression-testing-with-zapapi-and-nodegoat-nodeconf-eu) was a similar workshop (45 people in the class), that may have ended up more of a tutorial, but didn't as we had a box of USB sticks loaded and a network share and had good comms with the attendees before the session.

DevSecCon (https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#devseccon-asia-2017-developing-a-high-performance-security-focussed-agile-team-2-hour-workshop) is aiming to host a similar workshop.


Yes, developers/engineers generally get a lot out of this. For me, I generally try not to differentiate to much between devs and architects. An excellent architect should still have their hands on the tools, it's just that they are also expected to be in a lot of other places at the same time. For the architects with less hands on involvement, the tutorial or even presentation style may be best suited to them. In saying that though, if everyone is setup before the workshop, then I can usually hold hands fairly firmly through the hands on content.

The content, whether hands on or not, in many cases is quite eye opening, so there are good take aways for all. My last presentation at AgileNZ (https://blog.binarymist.net/presentations-publications/#agilenz2016-agile-security-for-web-developers-50-minute-presentation) which was mostly targeted toward developers, was still well received by the audience which were mostly Product Owners, Managers and Architects. The AgileNZ presentation had quite a bit of the same content as what I've submitted here.


The high and low level together is what my book series addresses and encourages development teams (PO's, Managers, Architects, Engineers) to grasp and understand. First chapter being 30'000 foot view, which leads into 10,000 foot view, then into some fairly detailed asset identification, risk identification, countermeasure identification, etc... based on Bruce Schneier's Sensible Securitty Model (SSM). The content teaches all people involved in the process of building technical solutions to think outside of their tunnel vision. Architects to think about low level details and Engineers to think holistically, hence the title: "Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developer".

I'm not sure exactly what you mean by clear value proposition? Does the following not provide this:
"have proven their value in:
(1) Aiding high throughput (reducing time to market)
(2) Significantly increasing quality (finding and removing bugs)
(3) Without descoping
and all while reducing total project cost (fact)"


I'd be happy for some assistance to formulate this better for SATURN if you would be keen to help?


Hope that has clarified most of it?
Thanks.

Hi Kim, thank you for the clarification! As we have well over a 100 proposals to review until Friday, I cannot offer any further help right now. Stay tuned, other reviewers may chime in to help them form an opinion. /Thijmen

talk.title: Efficient Debugging: Taking bisecting to the next level
talk.description: One of the most useful techniques for debugging is applying binary search to reduce the scope of the haystack and more easily find the needle. Using binary search you can cover over 1000 revisions in 10 steps. Modern version control systems like git and mercurial have this functionality built it as the bisect command. This talk gives an overview of the bisecting – finding the commit that introduced a defect or some other issue, and how to automate that process. Knowing the faulty commit is a good first step and sometimes sufficient in itself to solve the issue at hand. In practice however, the next steps can be more complicated. The rest of the talk will discuss techniques to go beyond the initial commit and take bisect to the next level, reducing the haystack to just a few straws.

talk.title: Emacs vs. Vi - why not get the best of both worlds?
talk.description: The feud between emacs and vi is one of the oldest in computer history. Both editors have a long history and the tension between the two camps are tangible. Why can't we all just get along? In addition, you also have ready access to all of the goodness that emacs offers.

talk.title: git gone wild: how to recover from common git mistakes.
talk.description:
"Oh no! I just typed something into git and now my work is gone! Ahh!"

Don't panic. Contrary to popular belief, git is one of the most non-destructive version control systems available. When used right, git
never loses any data, and even when misused, chances are very high you can still recover.

This talk will present turn-by-turn directions on how to recover from a wide array of common git mistakes, and also provide some workflows
to minimize them.

Examples include, but are not limited to:
* Changing spelling errors in commit messages.
* Split commits into multiple commits with logical separation.
* Combining multiple commits into one.
* Resetting the base commit when you accidentally branch off of the wrong branch.
* Recovering from merge conflicts.

As well as more advanced topics, such as:
* Extracting parts (e.g. sub-directory) of a repository as a new repository.
* Merging multiple repositories into one while retaining version history.
* Removing confidential data accidentally committed.

talk.title: Global Applications & Architecture: What does it take to survive and thrive in the Global Jungle?
talk.description: When you can make a product successful across the “entire” globe you can provide incredible value to your business.  Although doing so is much much easier said than done.  Pitfalls and dangers exist at every turn in the Global Jungle (data sovereignty, currency, scale, right to left languages, legal risk, regulations, hackers, latency, global benchmarking/analytics… even natural disasters to name a few).  Most applications either barely limp through or don’t survive this unforgiving jungle.  Where do you start if you are building something from scratch?  What about if someone else built it but only built it thinking about their country (or for their limited users)?  In this session I will share my experience and equip you with the gear you need to survive the next time you enter the Global Jungle.  This will include over 20 architectural guidelines and considerations.  And maybe just maybe your next project can evolve to be a king in the jungle.

feedback.body:
Hi Scott,

Thanks for submitting!  Reading your proposal this looks like a good survey of many topics with an emphasis on getting your software system "production ready."  As a topic I think this is probably appropriate as long as the context is well established.  Reading your proposal I'm not sure what you mean by "global jungle" and whether the systems I work on would apply or not.  What is the context for the systems you are discussing?  Keep in mind that the SATURN audience comes from a variety of experiences from from cloud-based web services to embedded spacecraft control systems and more.

I'm worried this is too much information to cover during a single session.  How deep are you planning to go into each of the topic areas?

This seems closely related to your experience (good!) but seems to stop short of sharing a generally applicable lesson.  Where did your checklist come from?  Do you have any thoughts or advice on how someone might tailor your list to better fit their "jungle"?

Regards,

Michael

I have tried to respond to each of your comments below:

Production ready/Context/Jungle?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
I think characterizing it as emphasis of getting your system “production ready” is fair, although I think many systems consider themselves “production ready” and then fail in numerous ways when they try to grow/reach/impact the whole globe since they failed to consider key factors that could easily have been done ahead of time. This is not altogether different for how small startups often stumble or fail when they try to transition to the big leagues. As far as context goes, I think this applies to any web, desktop or mobile system (internal to an organization or used by the public) that is intended to be used by individuals in multiple countries across the globe. In particular if you are dealing with private or sensitive data. When I refer to the “global jungle” I am talking about the multitude of things that you often don’t think or worry about when you "first build" your solution for your "first user base", but can be a catastrophic problem when you try to transition to a new region or the globe (and forces you back to the drawing board or worse yet becomes a fatal flaw and threatens your overall business model). What do you feel is the best way to clarify the context due to its broad nature?

How Deep?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
My goal in this session is not to attempt to make anyone an expert in any given area. Instead I want to give them an awakening so that they walk away with a new found appreciation that there are a bunch of other things they should spend some critical time on; since by spending it now it may very well either save their project from an unanticipated problem or differentiate them since their competitors failed to consider them. Think back to when you first heard the horror stories around security and that had a lasting impact on your belief that it is something that shouldn’t be ignored. I want to try to do the same for many other aspects that few people take seriously until it’s too late.

ADVICE/TAILORING?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
This listing is what I have cultivated over the years and have used successfully to make both large and small systems “globally ready” and successful for the largest business unit of a 36.8 billion dollar company (for both internet and internal facing solutions). The last few parts 7, 8, 9 are where I would try to give them some structured advice on how to balance all of these considerations so that they can prioritize and mitigate the risks while still having rapid agility in "their jungle".
Thoughts? Appreciate the input btw!

Btw was my earlier message response sufficient to clarify the context questions you had before?  or should I go and modify the actual submission?  Thanks again for the input!

This looks like an interesting topic, but there isn't much information here to explain what a 2 hour session would contain (which is a long session) and indeed how you'd keep the audience engaged for that long.  Can you make it interactive?

It's quite possible that people will be put off by the implied need to read the pre-reading you suggest.  Can you make it clear whether attending will be valuable without this?

Risks -> exploitation is usually pretty interesting. This is a collection of some of the demos: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfv6teOacMIuh3VheioAXXe70IwwQySIp

Yeah, it's my intention to have this interactive. I also run run classes that are hands on, but people have to bring laptops and be well prepared/setup for that, so this is more of a watch and discuss tutorial based on the workflow of an attacker, whether the attacker is a black-hat or one of your team members testing as part of your Scrum process.

Attending without reading will be valuable, but once attendees have attended, they usually wish they had prepped before hand, to understand what's going on to a deeper level.

This (https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers-fascicle1-vps-network-cloud-webapplications/read#vps-identify-risks-adding-persistence-co-powersploit) is the sequence of events for one of the demos I would run through. This adds a persistent powershell payload to windows that is scheduled to open a reverse shell to the listening attacker. Survives reboots and many other user actions. This is one way to make sure you always have a door into your targets network. From here, we continue laterally owning the rest of the network. I've never seen anyone get board with these demos. Then we discuss mitigation techniques.

talk.title: How the real-time communication between things can simplify our everyday life: make it more secure and economic.
talk.description:
An implicit goal of developing applications in IoT is to increase the quality of life, or the general well-being of individuals and society as a whole. The insights to be gained from data are endless. In light of this a new paradigm of the real-time communication between things has emerged, in which the quality of life of citizens in dense urban environments is increased through the security of using big data and cloud technology. Future cities are likely to feature thousands of strategically placed sensors that would record everything from air pressure and temperature to microbial content, and the data would be relayed instantly to the smart devices of actively participating citizens, who will make critical contributions to urban planning, reducing pollution, and making the best use of finite resources.
The proposed solution is the mobile connectivity that provides the network coverage wherever devices may roam. Secure cellular connection together with SIM cards and endpoints can be easily managed in real-time via the intuitive user-interface or directly from the customer’s software application via an easy-to-integrate API. Key features, development and implementation stages, as well as use cases will be discussed.  
The talk includes a lot of real working IoT use cases and their potential impact on our daily life. Their focus direct towards a more practical improvement of the quality of our life. Attendees will explore what is the potential impact of IoT, what real IoT use cases was implemented in Germany, how can we increase the quality of life with the IoT.
talk.notes: As I now reflect back on my working experience and lots of conferences, I can personally attest to the wide range of benefits that international communication provides for IT development nowadays and the insight brought about through cooperating with techs from all over the globe. My mission is to enable public to realize innovative fast secure development and implementation in the field of IoT.

- Description: "The propos*ed* solution is the".

While IoT technologies become pervasive understanding their impact on daily life and potential use cases is definitely of increasing concern. However, this talk does not provide an architectural perspective on potential challenges/opportunities these use cases emphasize. As written, the abstract reads more like a contextual design talk rather than an architecture talk.

Thank you for your submission. As I understand it, this talk is about increasing the quality of life by improving the security and economics of using data from widely distributed devices connected by the internet.

You provide examples of the type of data that might be available and how it might be used (reducing pollution, for example). The proposed solution is some sort of mobile connectivity. I don't understand what the specific security and economics aspects of the solution are from the description. Could you explain how those quality attributes will appear in your talk?

Why is a single point of integration required? I take "integration" here to mean integration of all the data coming from distributed devices. Please correct me if I'm thinking incorrectly. Is that driven by security or economics? There could be other structures that might work too.

Thank you for your feedback!
I just would like to mention that from my point of view IoT solves the same problem for communication points as software architecture tries to solve for many years - distributed computing. 
Different nodes on different machines try to communicate with each other as well different devices and controllers do. These IoT devices can certainly connect through a lot of different ways, but in this talk we will focus on cellular connectivity.  
Obviously, other receptions are always limited to the access point, and also dependent on network and device configurations. Cellular has reception everywhere without any maintenance effort from the customer side, so with telecom access a large-scale investigation is possible. Given the ubiquity of sim based devices, cellular solutions can achieve an unbelievable level of coverage in both space and time for observing any events.
If we take IoT and wanna use it in a large scale for example in agriculture industry in Africa, we have to built a large suitable, secure and cost-efficient architecture/system. As low-energy network does not exist there and can provide connectivity only on one site, so the communication with the combine on the field will be always insecure.
Even SMS can play a role as an intermediate solution and help with device distribution or middleware as GSM network always can be used, even if internet is not available, which makes it reliable and persistent channel for IoT connectivity.
This talk is more focused on use cases with real-time or time-critical services, of course it can impact economic and security.

Snowy regards from Germany, 
Karina

talk.title: How to organize your code
talk.description: Most nontrivial software systems suffer from significant levels of technical and architectural debt. This leads to exponentially increasing cost of change, which is not sustainable for a longer period of time. The single best thing you can do to counter this problem is to give some love to your architecture by carefully managing and controlling the dependencies among the different elements and components of a software system. This session will first look at the major reasons why so many systems end up in an unmaintainable state and then show how to address the problem by using automated quality gates in combination with a domain-specific language that can be used to enforce an architectural blueprint over the lifetime of a software system.
talk.notes: 90 minutes
talk.abstract:
Why do so many software systems end up as the the dreaded big ball of mud?
This session will first analyze the major reasons and then show how to address the problem by defining an architectural blueprint for a system and then enforcing it over the lifetime of the system.
talk.talk_format: Tech Talks and Tech Tutorials (30 or 90 minutes - please specify the exact time in the Notes section)

ratings.comments: I think that this is a product demo. The speaker was at SATURN last year, and was pretty abrasive.
Not clear from the proposal what will actually be covered in during a 90 minute session.
I fail to understand the contribution of this talk: could it be how to use Lattix? For a 90-min session, I would expect a much more detailed description of how the time will be put to good use.

Unfortunately last year the SATURN audience perceived this discussion more focused on marketing and lacking objective technical evidence and discussion. Managing dependencies is definitely critical for overall architectural quality, but it for sure is not the single best thing to do. There is ample amount of evidence that as systems grow and as they start including hybrid frameworks and languages in fact dependencies do also increase. How would the lessons shared in this session allow the audience to make such trade offs, for example?
Relevant, but find it a bit hasty and unprepared for a 90 minutes. More on the negative side than the positive.

feedback.body: Alexander, thanks for contributing. Your topic is relevant, but I find it hard to grab the main takeaways from the text. It would also be beneficial if the structure of the talk was presented. 90 minutes is a looong time.

I gave this talk also on W-Jax conference in Munich and on Arch Conf in Clearwater, FL. In Munich it was 60 minutes, in Clearwater I had 3 hours and made a workshop out of it. I could integrate a practical exercise where people create an architectural model for a software of their choice, but he time for that would be very short. So I thought to go a little deeper with the talk.
 
The take aways would be
- Understand the importance of keeping an architectural blueprint for your code
- Negative impact of cyclic dependencies
- Learn to use a simple DSL to describe your architecture

talk.title: Predictive Business Analytics In the age of In Memory Computing
talk.description:
Disruptive Intelligence
====================
Never before in history, could we find a single largest contributor that has such a pervasive impact both on the bottom line as well as on customer relations.

Like beating a dead horse, traditional tactics to analytics has been delivering ample analysis only after the event. Business leaders who rely on information to make complex decisions in real time could not succeed as desired because technology could not cope up with their needs till today. This decades’ long wait has finally come to an end thanks to Artificial Intelligence and Real-time Analytics. Especially Real Time Analytics powered by In-Memory Computing (IMC) offers a way out from this rut. Further still, a truly disruptive hybrid model that shrewdly mixes both, “Relying on the past to predict the future” and “Real Time Analytics” is a fool proof approach for digital era analytics solutions. 
 
By embedding a select array of Artificial Intelligence techniques from cognitive research arena right into the core algorithms and using state of the art research projects such as SRI, CNTK and Google Tensor Flow, how we can leverage In Memory Computing to address predictive business analytics issues will be addressed in this session.

How to address complex and strategic decision needs in real time?
======================================================

By flexing and blending a variety of technologies within the realm of In Memory Computing, we can address all the three types of decisions, including Operational, Tactical and Strategic. While operational and tactical decisions tap into existing datamarts and datastores which house transactional, structured data, strategic decision making goes beyond the traditional stores and rely heavily on real time, unstructured data influx. 

Real time strategic decision making in digital era is impossible unless we shatter today’s speed and scale barriers. For speed, we can leverage In Memory Computing that tackles both latent and live streams of data. For planet scale, as the volume is huge and expected to grow exponentially, an on-demand, scalable infrastructure should be erected to contain the catastrophes. As strategic decisions need to factor in various parameters, an ensemble of machine-learning algorithms are employed to crunch data, to classify the outliers and recommend meaningful actions to deal with a specific problem at hand. An enormous number of simulations, trained models and tests are applied to the data which has been acquired and prepared before passed on to the intelligent analytics engine to arrive at precise real-time business decisions.

Applied IMC Use case - Customer Intimacy 
==================================

As the world is becoming more complex by the moment, strategic decision making in real time is also becoming extremely difficult and is compounded by the speed and scale with which information is generated and consumed. IMC furthers the decision-making process by employing cutting-edge tools, and conceiving and deploying disruptive models to address customer concerns. When it comes to meaningful engagement with customers, relying on heuristics and instinctive impulses for strategic making is no longer reliable, in today’s rapidly changing digital landscape.

This session is designed to shed some light on a practical use case on how to enhance customer intimacy using In-Memory Computing for business analytics.
talk.notes:
Functions and Algorithms
=====================

The driving force behind the use case is ‘enhancing customer experience’. With this is in mind, every customer interaction is funneled for use in a sentiment analysis. By examining every chat, email, tweet, voice transcript and logs, the attitudes, emotions, likes, preferences, habits behind the interactions are analysed using the following (indicative) machine and deep learning algorithms:
	
Naïve Bayes
Max ENT
SVM
CNN, HMM, GMM, 
DNN, RNN, LSTM

Architecture behind Real-Time In- Memory Analytics 
==========================================	
The following  architecture principles are applied in Predictive Real-Time Business Analytics :

* Real Time, In Memory Process.
* Loose coupling.
* Interoperability.
* Modularity.
* Scalability with built in CAPS.
* Cloud Centric.
* Mobile Centric.

By design Highly stable, open source products are plugged into the solution.
talk.abstract: Till today technology has failed business leaders miserably who wanted information to make complex decisions in real time.  Traditional tactics to analytics has been delivering ample analysis only after the events. Real-Time Analytics powered by in-memory computing offers a way out from this rut .

Pros - topic has wide applicability and growing importance and seems to have significant architectural content to explore
Cons - the submission description seems rambling and unfocused with too many distracting details on the business context. If the full materials are similar it will be difficult to follow and distill the relevant content for the SATURN audience.

It unfortunate that this talk has not been developed further, because the topics being discussed are very compelling.

However, the hyperbolic tone and sweeping rhetoric of the submission makes it unsuitable in it's current state.

After 10 days the speaker has not taken the opportunity to address the issues or questions raised in the communications.

This appears to be an missed opportunity.  A pity.
Abstract lack focus and the topic is not suited for a 15 minutes talk.
Probably a good topic but the abstract lacks focus, especially for a DEV@ talk.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. 

I believe authors and speakers should be careful with superlatives and absolutes. In your abstract, you say technology has miserably failed business leaders who wanted information to make complex decisions in real time. I'd rather say technology has often fallen short instead of failed miserably. Likewise, I think it's an overstatement to say that AI and real-time analytics are the single largest contributor to customer relations in history. What about the Internet? And another example of what sounds to me like an overstatement: "Real time strategic decision making in digital era is impossible unless we shatter today’s speed and scale barriers".

I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:

1) Description: The third paragraph under "Disruptive Intelligence" is one long sentence. Please try breaking it up. 

2) Description: The description uses too much space elaborating on the importance of real time strategic decision making, real time analytics and IMC. I think you should simplify the motivation part of the description and focus more on the technical presentation. And it turns out the technical part of the talk is a little vague. Are you going to talk about general solutions to real-time analytics and IMC? Or about a specific (of set of) solution/design/technology/framework/tool? Or is it a case study? 

3) Description: It's not clear what attendees will learn. For example, in the Notes you mention "Architecture behind Real-Time In-Memory Analytics". That would be an interesting topic for many attendees at SATURN, but is not mentioned in the talk Description (remember attendees see the Description, not the Notes).

In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Hi Venkidapathy,

Thanks for your submission.  I think this seems like an interesting topic and one that many will find interesting.  There are a few things about the submitted abstract that I think can be improved.

* The overall tone seems overly enthusiastic for the solution you're proposing, almost to the point that it reads like a sales pitch.  Surely there are some negatives to what you're proposing?
* The topic is unclear and seems to touch on numerous areas.  Is this talk about AI? In memory data structures?  Streaming analytics?  Cloud? Mobile? Modular design?  I'm not seeing the theme or core lesson.  What will someone who attends your talk be able to do that they couldn't do before?
* This is a lot of material to cover in 15 minutes.  Perhaps you meant to assign this to a different time slot? There does seem to be a bug in papercall about this.

I think if you could clarify and tighten the abstract a bit this has potential to be a great topic.

Regards,

Michael

We have had some issues with PaperCall changing talk formats on editing of the submission. Could you please confirm that this is intended for a 15 min lightning talk? Also be aware that the plan is to run these on the main stage in front of the full attending audience (about 200 people). Please update your submission with the correct talk format and also indicate the length of the talk in the Notes section for future reference.

talk.title: Responsive Design
talk.description:
This is a blog post I wrote recently to explain the importance of responsive design. In my talk I cover a lot of the how-to-dos of CSS and how to handle your UI/UX - I think it's a fun read and I try to keep the talk fun as well. Hopefully you'll join me and my dark sense of humor on this journey through measurement options (outside of the pixel), SEO, using min and max widths to cut down on media queries and discuss using vectors and images. I hope you enjoy the blog post as well:

Every time someone opens your website on a mobile device and it’s not responsive, a toddler punches a kitten. Okay, not really, but you are providing the equivalent as your user experience. This hurts your SEO potential, and drives traffic away from your site.

Let’s get a quick rundown on what responsive web design actually means within the context of an ordinary website. This definition from Small Business Trends sums it up nicely:

Responsive Web design is an approach whereby a designer creates a Web page that “responds to” or resizes itself depending on the type of device it is being seen through. That could be an oversized desktop computer monitor, a laptop, a 10-inch tablet, a 7-inch tablet, or a 4-inch smartphone screen.

So with this in mind, let’s take a look at hypothetical look at a website on a few different devices.

Guys…. Stop thinking about coffee and let’s focus!

Maybe the importance of this isn’t really seeping in and maybe you’re more of a numbers person… Let’s try another route.

80% of internet users own a smartphone per Smart Insights. According to MicKinsey & Company, Google says 61% of users are unlikely to return to a mobile site they had trouble accessing and 40% visit a competitor’s site instead. A report by Wolfgang Jaegel found that 91% of mobile users say that access to content is very important.

In all seriousness, it is a big deal if your site does not work on mobile devices. Think about the kittens!! And if you’re thinking, “there aren’t THAT many devices out there,” and “it can’t be THAT hard to be responsive,” think about those kittens one final time.

I am sure there is a number out there on the internet waiting to be found telling us how many devices are web capable, and I am also sure it’s large. Keep in mind each device is designed differently, with different software requirements, default browsers, and different hardware specs. That means, as a developer, no matter what you’re building, you will likely find yourself daydreaming of how many kittens you’d prefer were being hit in the face, while you debug the fifth CSS error you encounter in Safari, that never existed in Chrome…Sorry, that got a bit personal.

As much as I would like to believe my iPhone is having an identity crisis, that’s not the actual case. There are standards out there for web design (sometimes sketchy ones), that are intended to help developers and browsers work within boundaries that help to simplify things. And I know what you’re thinking.

Thank you, mobile gods. We’re saved!

But we haven’t quite saved those kitties just yet.

You may still be thinking, “Why do you need to know all this?”

If you’re a business owner looking to increase your audience and you haven’t taken the responsive route, that should be the first thing on your to-do list. Online shopping is already a huge trend and still growing at this rate. If you’re trying to get your blog out there over a product, what better place for someone to read that than on their device while in the restroom? I mean really… we’ve all done it…

If you’re looking to get a better return on your investment (ROI), responsiveness is another way to do that. If you do not have a fully responsive design, you are throwing away potential page views and potential dollars pulled in from your mobile shoppers.

Now onto saving all those kittens!

If you’re not familiar with WordPress or its standards, there are these things called themes. I mean, to take it directly from the WordPress Codex:

A WordPress Theme is a collection of files that work together to produce a graphical interface with an underlying unifying design for a weblog. These files are called template files. A Theme modifies the way the site is displayed, without modifying the underlying software.

To put it simply, a theme is the look and feel of your site via functionality and design. It’s the idea that you can do anything with your content within the provided templates and have a consistent and clean flow.

Popular WordPress themes from Elegant Themes

There are thousands of themes out there to pick from. Whether you’re building a store front, a restaurant front and menu, a non-profit donation location, a blog, or an educational site, there is something out there for you. There are many free options, usually offered through the CMS that’s been installed, and paid options that tend to be found via outside sources.

So get to searching for the responsive theme that fits your needs, either through WordPress or through a seller like ThemeForest. The kittens will thank you.

If you go searching and nothing seems to catch your eye (insert joke about cats chasing the red dot of doom), there are always custom themes. This is the option for businesses that are looking for a specific look or functionality that they can’t find anywhere else. Being unique can be a huge benefit to a business with the right design and implementation. This is a costlier option but usually has a higher turn around on traffic and offers more options for Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and design tactics. Marketing teams usually love this option!

That’s it, that’s all you have to do.

As developers, we have to do much much MUCH more to make something like a custom theme or purchased theme modifications (maybe I’ll write about that in the future for all the dev-heads out there wanting to help the kitties), but as a website owner using WordPress, that’s all you have to do; find a theme that is responsive. You can look more into the Jetpack plugin to help with SEO as well (yet, again, maybe another post for the future).

So get out there and start saving those kittens! I believe you will make the right decision!

Also, if you need some emergency kittens, go here. You’re welcome.
talk.notes:
This talk is great for those who are just starting to learn CSS or web design, but still helpful to those who have been creating sites for a few years. I try to not push too far into the depth of CSS with this talk but push more the audience to think about their user and their experience across multiple devices. As someone who works first hand with clients at Grok Interactive, I hear about all the pain points of older sites making a move to mobile and how visitors are hard to bring in, due to a lack of intuitive design. 

I'm also the person who usually discovers the state of a site before Grok gets to work fixing sites. I usually find developers have a hard time with layout concepts, basic min/max widths and the prevention of overlapping or loss information when rendering on a mobile device. I have come to understand many of the methods that everyone should have learned in the beginning of the design or layout teachings. 

I like to keep my talks fun for the sake of remembering the content. Dry content is usually the first to be forgotten, no matter how useful it may have been.

talk.title: Secrets of a high performance security focussed Agile Team
talk.description:
Quality (security included) does not have to be neglected when you're planning, building and running a high performance development team.

Kim will set the stage with how and why Agile development teams fail, explained with a familiar anecdote taken from his new book "Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developers", coupled with how you can change this.

Kim will then cover a set of light weight processes, practises and tools, that when combined have proven their value in:

1. Aiding high throughput (reducing time to market)
2. Significantly increasing quality (finding and removing bugs)
3. Without de-scoping  
  and all while reducing total project cost (fact).

If this sounds like breaking the laws of physics, or to good to be true, then this talk is for you.

Kim will finish off with the habits of top developers and how we can make them part of our lives.
talk.notes:
Provide brief context of the following to set the stage:  
* 30,000' View (what's in here)  
* 10,000' View (what's in here)  
* Tooling (what's in here)  
* Process and Practises (what I'm going to show you is part of this subsection)  
* Physical
* People

1. Discuss how and why development teams fail explained with a familiar anecdote, along with how you can change this (Essentials for Creating and Maintaining a High Performance Development Team).

2. Within every Sprint  
  * Cheapest Place to Deal with Defects
  * Establish Securitry Champion (must be within team, not external)
  * Along with Test Conditions, create Evil Test Conditions -> basis for your "Security Focussed TDD" -> get these into your CI  

   * Hand-crafted Penetration Testing. Let Security Champion lead the way and monitor developers doing this.
   * Pair Programming (needs to become part of your culture)
   * Code Review (incl automation)
   * Linting, static and dynamic analysis
   * Static Type Checking  

   * Consuming free and open source (don't need to stop doing this, address the issue, processes, practises and tooling to mitigate the issue)  

   * Security Regression Testing (10 minute demo)  

3. Forming Habits and Sharpening Skills

talk.title: The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG) for the Linux Kernel
talk.description:
The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG)
======================================================

John F. Masinter, Intel Corporation 
Nathan R. Peterson, Intel Corporation

Summary
--------------

The Advanced Deterministic Random Number Generator (ADRNG) was developed at Intel Security for use with the many security products based upon the McAfee Linux OS platform. The ADRNG provides the NIST approved SP800-90A PRNG from the native Linux kernel API. It is continuously reseeded using high quality entropy bit data form the native Linux kernel Jitter entropy driver. This ADRNG is added to the Linux 4.4 kernel, and replaces the standard drivers for both /dev/random and /dev/urandom. The result is high quality random data delivered in high volume without call blocking.

Problem/Opportunity
-------------------------------

The ability to provide a high volume of quality random data is of interest to modern Linux server systems where a great deal of encryption requires a great deal of random data. A lack of large quantities of random data may cause encryption to run slowly. A lack of quality in the random data may cause encryption to be weak. 

The particular path that led us to develop this solution was increasing scrutiny of the NIST FIPS validation standards which are diving deeper into entropy quality. The ADRNG is based upon all the learning from a year long series of FIPS lab testing while validating McAfee Linux OS. 
Quality random data is in demande by all modern Linux servers, with or without FIPS requirements. By developing a standards based solution that plugs into the Linux kernel, we can easily share this solution with all groups at Intel, as well as making a significant contribution to the Linux kernel upstream.

Solution
-------------

The initial implementation of this idea was for the Linux 3.18 kernel. That kernel did not contain the native API for the SP800-90A PRNG nor the Jitter entropy driver. We back ported the Jitter enropy code from a later kernel, and adapted the SP800-90A routines from the Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) open source crypto library. This worked very well, but we were concerned about the large delta of kernel code required for this method.

However since that time, we have moved to the Linux 4.4 kernel, which does contains both the SP800-90A PRNG and the Jitter entropy driver within the kernel native API. So we have updated our solution to use only the native kernel resources. This vastly reduces the size of code required, and also provides greater confidence for those that consume the solution.
Scope

The initial motivation to develop the ADRNG was to meet increasingly strict NIST FIPS standards. However we have enable this solution for all modes of the kernel. Thus all products based on McAfee Linux OS will benefit from the faster and higher quality random data. This results in faster and more secure encryption.

McAfee Linux OS is used by many products at Intel Security, and all of these products will implicitly inherit the advantages of the ADRNG as they each update to the lastest MLOS kernel. Increased security will benefit the reputation and sales of Intel Security products.
Engineering teams working with cryptography on Linux systems, as well as Product Managers attempting to satisfy NIST FIPS standards, would all benefit from learning more about the ADRNG.

Results
-----------

For measuring the results we quantify two values: Speed and Quality. 

### Speed Test
+ Dell PE-R610 / Xeon E5540 / 2.53GHz

.            64-Bytes  1K-Bytes  64K-Bytes  64Kx64-Bytes
/dev/random  0m0.002s  0m0.002s  1h,36m,13s 103h,19m,46s
/dev/urandom 0m0.002s  0m0.002s  0m0.008s   2m10.672s
ADRNG        0m0.002s  0m0.003s  0m0.036s   2m25.836s

The speed test was performed using this simple command for each algo and block size:
$ time dd if=/dev/random of=/tmp/64_random.dat bs=64 count=1

We used memory based file system (/tmp/) to reduce file i/o overhead.
We can assume file i/o overhead is consistent between all tests, since all tests have the same number and size of writes.

### Quality Test
•	Dell PE-R610 / Xeon E5540 / 2.53GHz

.             Entropy  Arithmetic-Mean     SCC
/dev/random   7.999580    127.5092         -0.001245
/dev/urandom  7.999960    127.4892         -0.000524
ADRNG         7.999962    127.5570         -0.001057

Entropy bits per byte of perfect randomness = 8.000000
Arithmetic mean of perfect randomness = 127.5
Serial Correlation Coefficient of totally uncorrelated data = 0.0

The quality test was performed using the “ent” program which applies various entropy quality tests to byte sequences. This test was run against the sum of all data produced by the speed test above, 4,260,928 bytes.

Conclusion
----------------

The ADRNG provides random data at the speed of /dev/urandom and with the quality of /dev/random. Thus crypto applications no longer need to choose between speed and quality, because the ADRNG provides both.

Leadership
----------------

The ADRNG will provide greater overall quality to all Intel products which incorporate it. The ISecG security products are measured in the industry by their speed and security. The ability to run encryption faster, and with higher quality, results is something that can be measured and leveredged by product marketing to maintain and extend the Intel Security market leadership.
 
Lessons Learned
There were so many lessons learned from the FIPS process that we could write a book on the subject. But in summary, to track and report quality, you must collect this info:

+ FOR EACH: RNG, RNG-Seed, RNG-init, Entropy, Entropy-Seed, Entropy-init
+ You must be able to show this info:
+ Origin of algo
+ Source code of algo
+ Quality tests of algo
+ Performance tests of algo on various hardware platforms
+ Papers and Certifications of algo

It is far better to collect this info as you go through development, rather than going back at the end and attempting to compile this info.

References
----------------

1.	ENT, a program which applies various entropy quality tests to byte sequences,   http://www.fourmilab.ch/random/
2.	NIST Special Publication 800-90A, Recommendation for Random Number Generation Using Deterministic Random Bit Generators, Jan 2012, http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-90A/SP800-90A.pdf
3.	CPU Time Jitter Based Non-Physical True Random Number Generator, 2014, Stephan Müller, https://www.kernel.org/doc/ols/2014/ols2014-mueller.pdf
talk.notes:
- I am the manager and co-founder of the McAfee Linux OS project at Intel Corp. (previously McAfee Inc.)
- I am the originator of the idea and effort at Intel to incorporate a standards based RNG into the Linux kernel.
- I have previously given talks within Intel about this subject.
- This has great benefit, as all products using our kernel will automatically benefit from higher quality random data.
- If selected, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to reformat my paper for the SATURN desired publishing format. For example, HTML.
- This is a 15 minute talk.

talk.title: Building composable abstractions
talk.description: Do you want to create robust and composable abstractions? In this talk Eric Normand will present an iterative process to define the essence of a domain and build composability into the core. The resulting abstractions lead to more robust code at the core of your application, and can give your business a competitive advantage. We will apply this process to the Processing graphics library to develop a composable vector graphics system.
talk.notes:
This is a 60 minute talk.

After attending the talk, the attendee will be able to:

1. Know the difference between Newtonian-style abstractions and Aristotelian-style abstractions. Aristotelian abstractions are built up piecemeal and are full of corner cases, like Aristotelian physics. Newtonian abstractions are elegant, formal, and composable.

2. Follow a design process for developing an algebraic abstraction that can compose and easily express solutions (Newtonian style). Building data transformation pipelines is the step most people who are learning functional programming get to from reading and experimenting. Building algebraic abstractions is the next step, but there isn't much literature on the topic (outside of academia)
    1. Elaborate a physical metaphor
    2. Describe the meaning of your metaphor as mathematical statements
    3. Construct the meaning using constructs from the language
    4. Implement the abstraction by refactoring the meaning
	
	The physical metaphor is an important first step that gives us an anchor from which we may use our intuition. We then query our metaphor for its properties and write them in math, which usually means types and equations. After that, we can construct a runnable version of the meaning, being careful to build it out of parts constrained by our statements from step 2. Finally, the implementation becomes an easy matter of refactoring our runnable version.


This topic idea comes from my experience teaching functional programming to people with all levels of experience. There seems to be a logical progression of insights that people go through as they learn about functional programming. I don't see many people getting past the "data transformation" step, so I want to present something further. It's hard to say whether it's THE next step, but it is at least one step beyond transformations.

A lot of the thinking comes from my experience as a professional Clojure and Haskell programmer and the work of Conal Elliott, John Hughes, and Gerald Sussman.

I have given a version of this talk at Clojure/conj 2016: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJIUoaIvD20 I would love to adapt this to a language like JavaScript. The example code will be given in JavaScript.

talk.title: Case studies of enterprise IT governance models for architecture and framework for architecture maturity assessment
talk.description:
Enterprise IT realized that architects play a critical role in evolving IT. Most large scale organizations have established the architecture teams to guide the organizations in constantly evolving IT. Architecture team structure and their governance maturity are critical to the success of an organization in navigating the IT challenges, bringing the innovation required to gain the edge in the marketplace and successfully delivering the IT projects for the organization. It is important for IT leaders and architects to understand the best practices in establishing the architecture teams in the organization, and how to assess the architecture team’s maturity. 
This session will present the experience from conducting many architecture assessments by one of the biggest consulting firms. Session topic begins with the evolution of an architect’s roles in evolving IT and how did architect’s responsibilities and influence change over the last 4 decades. Then, session moves to the observations from real-world on how organizations structure the architecture team and discuss the pros-cons of different architecture team structures observed in various industries. Also, the presenter shares the assessment model used to assess the architecture team’s maturity in enterprise IT and case studies from real-world architecture assessments. 
Attendees learn the best practices in structuring the architecture teams within an organization and how to increase the effectiveness of the architecture teams. Also, learn the architecture assessment model used in many assessments across the industries and multiple case studies presenting how did the architecture team influence the success and failure of organizations.
talk.notes: Siva Muthu is a seasoned architect with 20+ years of experience in information technology and large-scale enterprise solutions. He was one of the instrumental leaders created an Application Architecture practice for Deloitte Consulting and led many architecture assessments across the industries. He also developed the Deloitte Consulting’s standard custom development framework and provides architecture advisory services for many engagements on project assessment, architecture review, and estimation methodologies. Specialized in solution architecture, project assessment, Microsoft.net technologies, and related products, design patterns, framework development and development process engineering concepts.

HI Thomas,

Thank-you for your submission.  The experiences you have to share sound very interesting.  Can I ask for a little more detail about the approach used?

When I hear of standardising on a common data model I think of the canonical data model pattern [1].  In recent years this approach has been  criticised [2] by those who favour the use of bounded contexts [3].

Do the pattern and solution from CRA relate to these patterns?  Are there other relevant patterns?  Does your experience reinforce or contradict any of these existing patterns?

Regards, 


Ged

[1] http://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/patterns/messaging/CanonicalDataModel.html 
[2] http://blog.xebia.com/microservices-architecture-principle-3-small-bounded-contexts-over-one-comprehensive-model/
[3] https://martinfowler.com/bliki/BoundedContext.html

Thank you for your insightful questions.  The first paragraph is the short answer and the next two paragraphs are background and explanation.  Your interest is greatly appreciated!

The model at CRA uses standards we developed for first data model for data collection which is bounded context.  In the ESRI data model we leveraged the Subtype and domains, where different subtypes drive the domains.  When we morphed the model into the ESRI standard electric utility model, the same holds true as the model is denormalized by mapping feature(i.e. transformer has a transformer layer rather than being one point feature in the point layer).

The modeling we applied has a time element.  There is a data collection stage of most any project which will require data to be normalized to geometry (points, lines and polygons representing features as electrical apparatus in the real world).  After this phase there is an information modeling aspect that requires use of standards to apply various third party tools and integrations.  The integrations vary depending on what solutions need to be integrated.  As budgets and priorities come into play the priorities are often different between power utilities.  However, Power utilities require Network Analysis and Power Outage Management Systems to maintain high systems availability.  The return on investment is staggering to implement the outage management and network analysis systems.  In addition the mapping must always tie to Work Management Systems.

Depending on the Utility size, microservices are typically used, however, there may need to be some cost saving, less expensive integrations such as ETL to move data into another format (i.e. daily job).  This is what happened with CRA and happens with most Power Utilities (even most very large ones).  There is a second reason for the reason web services cannot always be used – much of it has to do with the industry needs a network model that has sufficient performance.

talk.title: Connected Teams, Connected Code, and the Connected Device: The Challenges of IoT Software Delivery
talk.description:
Developing software for the Internet of Things (IoT) comes with its own set of challenges.  Security, privacy, and unified standards are a few key issues.  In addition, each IoT product is comprised of (at least) 3 separate application components: the software embedded in the device, the backend service, and the mobile application for the end user’s controls. Each component is developed by a different team, using different technologies and practices, and deployed to a different stack/target – this makes the integration of these separate pipelines and the coordination of software updates for IoT more problematic.  How do you coordinate the diverse moving parts that must come together when developing your IoT product or updating each of its components?

In this session we’ll deep dive to some off the challenges and share tips and best practices used by IoT developers to streamline and accelerate their product design, development, test and manufacturing

talk.title: Customer Experience Architecture Hands On
talk.description:
Architecture is about the customer. If you create an architecture that doesn’t give value to the customer you are wasting your time. When I talk to customers I often hear horror stories about how their current systems were developed by someone in an ivory tower who didn’t understand them or their work. So how do you make sure that you are bringing value to the customer through your architecture? Use customer centric design processes often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. These are fundamental parts of Lean and Agile and this session shows how to use them in architecture with hands on experience. In this highly interactive session participants redesign a system by interviewing a customer, creating a prototype, reviewing it with the group, and getting feedback on their design. Using the methods taught in this class you can create value for your customer through your architecture and become their hero, or at least not the person in the ivory tower who is ruining their life.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture
talk.notes:
My goal for this session is to help architects learn a customer centric design process. I learned this method from the "Deciding what to Design" course at Carnegie Mellon. The method is often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. Its a fundamental part of Lean and Agile. I've rarely seen people show how these methodologies apply to architecture, so thats my goal for class.

I use this process in my own work at GE and previously at Verizon.  I lead the End to End Customer Experience efforts at Verizon and enabled our architects and software engineers to talk to customers. I gave a talk on that experience at a past SATURN that generated a lot of interest.

At GE I am using this method to design a new CI/CD system for our Industrial Internet of Things platform called Predix. Customers (anyone who gets value from the system you are creating) really appreciate working with me. I find out very surprising things by using this method and create much better systems.


A slightly modified version of this session has been given before at Code on The Beach and was well received.  I used the "App for adding contact to network" use case and it ended up being a common but complex enough task that the groups had plenty to design. The Code on the Beach session was 60 minutes long and I assigned roles to each team member. I didn’t have time to have feedback given to each group, but I think it is an effective way to leverage the knowledge in the room. I didn’t have time to fit in the last wrap up session either, which I think is critical for people to concrete the new information. I've added those two parts to this 90 minute session.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture


The participatory session will include the following:
15 minutes
Introduction to Customer Experience Design
Introduce the hands on Exercise: Design a new system for adding a contact to your network (Linkedin, google+ , etc.)
Divide session into groups of 4 or 5 people.

10 minutes
Activity 1: Determine what matters to the customer including their functional requirements and quality attributes by watching how they do the task in their natural environment and asking lots of “why’s”. I will ask each group to select someone in their group to be the "customer." Each group will watch their customer collect a business card from a person and add a contact to their network of choice.

25 minutes 
Activity 2: Design the system around the customer’s needs and document it in a prototype. The prototype should be as interactive as possible, not just a flow chart. Prototype should show the architecture elements. Because the “customer” is involved, the team should be constantly getting input from the customer on their on going design. They should also write down any assumptions they are making and any reasons they made design decisions. Finalize the prototype, the assumptions, design decisions, and what they learned from the process.

30 minutes 
Activity 3: Review the prototype with the group. Receive feedback on design. About 5 minutes each group.

5 minutes
Wrap up: Allow the small groups to meet one last time to discuss the feedback and make any changes to their design.

10 minutes
Final Group discussion: Discuss what they learned from the session. Find out what they learned from receiving and giving feedback.

talk.title: Designing with NoSQL Databases
talk.description:
Schema design for NoSQL databases requires a very different approach from relational databases. The NoSQL databases have very high emphasis on huge data volumes, high and scalable performance, high availability and agility. As a result, the traditional concepts such as normalization, foreign key, join, strong transaction support, etc are done away with. How does one then design schema for various business applications?

In this session, we'll look at the concepts and best practices of schema design for three prominent NoSQL databases (MongoDB, Cassandra and Neo4j), with the help of diverse use cases, such as content management, single view, product catalog, social networks, system logs, fraud detection. We'll also look at the features for data analytics in these platforms. We'll also briefly look at when, why, and how to use polyglot persistence.
talk.notes:
I have presented tutorials on NoSQL in two earlier SATURN conferences. While those were beginner-level sessions, this one is for intermediate-to-advanced level users. 

I use NoSQL databases extensively in my work (architecture, teaching, consulting), and I have been helping organizations, primarily in the banking and retail sectors, in using NoSQL solutions for their business applications.

feedback.body:
The topic of NoSQL schema design is something that I'm personally interested in and I think many others in the Saturn audience.  It would be easier to evaluate this proposal if it contained information about *what* the advice will be -- instead of asking questions, tell us what the answers are so we can judge if they sound interesting.

If accepted, I strongly encourage you to stick to one topic, not blend NoSQL schema design with polyglot persistence.  Yes, the topics arise on similar projects, but they are distinct design activities.  A talk on "best practices for NoSQL schema design" is a great topic by itself.

Hello George, 

Here are some of the "answers", which I'll illustrate with real usage scenarios:

For MongoDB:

* Nature of queries in your application determine the appropriate data model. 
* Aim to join while writing, not while reading.
* Embedding "many" side of a relationship) results in ease of retrieval, simpler queries, better performance. Variations for one-to-few, one-to-many, many-to-many. Tradeoffs. What to embed (_id / natural primary key / more than the natural primary key)?
* However, if an object frequently needs to be accessed on its own, embedding may not be the best choice.
* Don't embed very high cardinality documents on the "many" side. Variations and tradeoffs.
* Don't denormalize a "master" field / document if it needs to be updated frequently. The cost of finding and updating all the instances may be too high.
* If you frequently need to use data from documents from multiple collections when embedding is clumsy, don't be afraid of join at the application level.
* Use the power of the Aggregation Framework for complex query requirements.
* Get the best out of sharding. Choose shard keys for even distribution of writes and reads.

For Cassandra:

* Again, model around the queries in your application.
* Spread data evenly around the cluster.
* Think of the database as a nested, sorted map data structure.
* Denormalize for fast read performance. 
* Find the right balance between normalizing and denormalizing.
* Using column names for values, and leaving the column value empty is OK.
* Leverage wide rows for ordering, grouping and filtering.
* Choose the row key appropriately to partition your records for good performance.
* Segregate the read-heavy data from write-heavy data.

As suggested by you, I'll drop polyglot persistence, and model it as "best practices for NoSQL schema design". I think I should drop Neo4j, and limit myself to MongoDB and Cassandra for a more in-depth coverage.

talk.title: Location, Rewrite, Location: Tips and Tricks on Semantic URLs Architectures with nginx
talk.description:
The session will describe the best practices of semantic URL design and cache-friendly web architectures, based on the example of creating and rewriting a couple of web applications solely with the help of nginx.conf, the standard nginx configuration language.

On the example of [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/), we will show how it is possible to create a complete webapp entirely through nginx.conf from scratch; and on the example of [bxr.su](http://bxr.su/), we will show how to extensively modify the architecture of an existing legacy application to make it cache-friendly, and simultaneously improve the usability of the URL interface available to the user.

All of this will be accomplished through the internal directives of nginx and the machinery available through the standard rewrite module that is available and is enabled by default in all versions of nginx.

* Web applications are traditionally written in high-level programming languages such as Java, PHP, Python or Ruby.   But not [mdoc.su — a deterministic URL shortener for *BSD manual pages](http://mdoc.su/) — which stands apart from the established convention.   The whole [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/) web service is written in the standard and basic `nginx.conf` configuration language alone (with the help of regular expressions and dozens of `rewrite` and `location` directives), resulting in a high-performance semantic URL service without the help from any high-level programming languages like even Lua, Perl or JavaScript, being powered by [PCRE](http://ports.su/devel/pcre) and nginx.conf alone.

* On the example of [BXR.SU — Super User's BSD Cross Reference](http://BXR.SU/), we will also show how to `rewrite` the underlying architecture of Sun/Oracle OpenGrok, with the help of `nginx.conf`, without actually touching a line of the application itself. OpenGrok is written in Java, and is designed around the concept of cookies on every page (including the front page), and thus effectively cannot be cached or accelerated through a naive approach, due to the original architectural decisions that were made without considering their impact on the cacheability of the application. We will show how to successfully get rid of all the cookies with nginx, and how to greatly improve the usability and the URL interface of this Java application, all entirely through `nginx.conf`-fu.

No prior knowledge of nginx is required, but familiarity with HTTP is expected, and knowledge of regular expressions would come in handy, too.

Attendees will gain a clear understanding of how URL manipulation works within nginx, will surely be amused at the length to which the author went in creating the performant solutions, and will be able to design concise and deterministic URL shortening services using semantic URL schemes.
talk.notes: I'm affiliated with several BSD projects, being a member of the NetBSD Foundation (committer), and have already given this talk at several conferences and large crowds.
talk.abstract: Need to add support for semantic URLs to your website, but don't know where to start? Have to accelerate a legacy webapp, but have cookies coming in your way? Fear not, as we will show you the best practice on how to do both in nginx.conf, and without any non-default modules nor techniques.

ratings.comments:
I'm going to go on a leap here and say YES.

I put this session in the same bucket as the intro to Docker session proposed by Len Bass. At some point, you just want to get deep down with a technology to understand new architecture approaches to building/slicing/consuming software. 

Everything we build today has a web interface to it, and you see some horrible interface (URLs) designs. This is could be a useful workshop to just dig deep into the topic and learn something new. Not worried about the choice of technology. I like Nginx.
There is some valuable material in this session but I don't think it focuses on the "why" and "when" enough to be an architecture session

I was leaning towards "No" after I had read the abstract and description. After also having read the Communication with the Speaker and the other review comments, I give the submitter the benefit of the doubt. 

Yes, seems to be a technical deep dive, but one with architectural ramifications (which could be featured much stronger in talk description). And yes, there is a "product pitch" risk.

=> Conditional accept/wait list?

While I can see this as being of great interest to web developers, I am not sure how it is related to SATURN's architectural themes.

The idea of transforming legacy applications through configuration is interesting, but this does not seem to be the focus of the talk.

Having used the technology I think this could be a useful and illustrative talk.  The only reason I'm giving this a "maybe" is because there was not a clear and obvious connection between using the tech and software architecture or design topics.  That being said, it looks like it could be an interesting and useful tutorial.

feedback.body:
Hi Constantine,

Thanks for your submission!  This talk sounds like it's going to dive deep into a specific technology (nginx) and show how it can be used to implement a specific use case through configuration (instead of coding).  From my perspective, I'm concerned this is not a great fit for SATURN, but maybe with a little extra information it could be.

My main concern is that this is highly technology focused but doesn't seem to make connections to a bigger picture.  In other words, reading your abstract I wonder, what does this have to do with software architecture?

I see value in what you want to discuss and have actually used some of these things myself.  I think to improve this abstract you should make it more clear _why_ someone would want to use nginx in these ways.  What are the specific use cases?  What are the pros and cons?  How do I know when this is something I should do?

Please consider revising your abstract to include some of these ideas and make a clearer connection with software architecture and design.

Good luck with the remainder of the review process!

regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,

Thank you very much for your comments.  I've modified the description a little bit, hopefully to better adhere to the expected audience of SATURN, as well as to provide a bit more context into the type of material that I plan to be presenting.

I'm not sure how much more could be explained as to "why" you'd want to do something like what I've done.  I've had a guy from Gap Inc. attend my session at nginx.conf 2016, and he seemed very interested, asking me some details afterwards.  Basically, one is already expected to vaguely know the value of Semantic Web and Semantic URL Design coming into the talk (e.g., SEO, usability, ease-of-use in marketing etc), and what you see should serve as the final selling point on it.

Also, personally, I'd like to let you know that although the talk centres on nginx, the concepts presented concentrate on abstract and basic language constructs, and would be useful and entertaining even if you don't use nginx specifically.

If you have any further questions, concerns or comments, let me know.

Cheers,
Constantine.
Thanks, Constantine.  I think your updates are helpful and answer my questions.  Good luck in the rest of the review process!

talk.title: Making the switch to "serverless" full-stack development
talk.description:
"Serverless" is a newly-popular buzzword and as with many tech buzzwords, is a complete misnomer ("cloud", anyone?)  We're going to discuss what serverless really means (hint: it's a way of abstracting OS-level infrastructure management from server-side application code), what the difference is between the various providers, why you would want to consider using a serverless architecture, and how you would go about implementing one.  We'll discuss greenfield development as well as a migration path for existing web applications.  Other interesting aspects covered will be how the development workflow will change and why, what testing will look like in a serverless world, and some pitfalls to avoid.  While a serverless approach can be applied to applications written in a variety of languages, Javascript will be the language used for this talk, so we will examine some of the popular serverless Javascript frameworks, including apex.js, claudia.js, and serverless.js.

If you're interested in full-stack development, DevOps, micro-service architecture, containers, cutting operational costs, and/or just staying abreast with the latest application architecture approaches, this talk is for you.  This is a 90-minute, interactive, participatory workshop for which you will need your laptop, a Github account, and an Amazon AWS account.
talk.notes: I am an ex-IBMer who has been architecting and developing for nearly 20 years. I run a full-stack, custom software development shop in Los Angeles and Austin that's known for staying on the cutting-edge of tech.  I frequently speak at tech events (particularly JavaScript and Node.js focused events) and am passionate about designing great software.
talk.abstract: In the world of micro services and agile development, "serverless" architecture is now all the rage.  In this talk, you'll learn what it is, what it can do for you, why you would and wouldn't want to use it, and what you need to know to make the switch.  This will be a hands-on walk through.

feedback.body:
Hi David,

As this will be a hands on talk, what will participants need to bring with them to participate?  Also, what tech stack will you be using during the session?

I like that this is planned to be hands on and that you plan to discuss migration paths.  We've had a lot of proposals around server-less architecture and only a few will be accepted.
