Michael

Hi Michael!  I'll answer each question in turn below.

As this will be a hands on talk, what will participants need to bring with them to participate? 
-  Participants will need a laptop with git and node installed, an internet connection, and accounts on Amazon AWS and Github.  

Also, what tech stack will you be using during the session?
-  Full-stack Javascript: Angular.js on the front-end and Node.js on the back-end.  We'll use DynamoDB as the no-SQL database.  We'll also be discussing (and may use) some of the serverless frameworks like serverless.js or claudia.js.

I like that this is planned to be hands on and that you plan to discuss migration paths. We’ve had a lot of proposals around server-less architecture and only a few will be accepted.
-  Thank you!  We'll walk through taking an existing web application and refactoring routes over to a serverless architecture using AWS Lambda and AWS API Gateway.  Depending on time, we may get into testing, deployment, and other advanced topics.

In what situations would you recommend someone not adopt server-less architectures?
-  The biggest benefits for serverless are 1) decreased complexity for developers - abstracting away  server-level administration and devOps tasks and 2) lower costs for applications on VMs that spend time idling.  So, for those that have a mature, stable, and effective devOps infrastructure that already abstracts server complexity from developers and for those whose VMs don't have much idle computing time, transitioning to serverless probably isn't going to be cost/risk-effective.  

- There may be other reasons to not transition: risk aversion ("this is too new and unproven"), compliance ("we neither own the data center NOR manage any of the VM infrastructure??"), or simple mistrust ("how do I know it's going to scale when I really need it to?") It's important that application architects take into consideration their corporate policies, compliance and risk requirements, and organizational change tolerance when considering serverless.

talk.title: Quality Attribute Workshop in 2 hours
talk.description:
Our colleagues shared "Mini-QAW" presentation on SATURN-2016. I'd like to share not mini- , but nano-QAW approach best practices. 

Typical QAW is too massive for wide usage. That's why production reality of my global ISV company helped me to form shortened approach of QAW. I use this approach working with customers during architecture design, architecture assessment and other archtiectural activities. So, see how you can efficiently collect quality attributes and related metrics in, literally, couple of hours. I'll share best practices and real production case-study in this presentation.

So, efficiency comes from preliminary prepared list of quality attributes and related metrics. Being an expert you are doing your best guess to make initial draft cycle. And after that you are driving verification of your best guess vs opinion of representatives from customer. If you have representatives who are technical enough - they can provide you with good feed-back on your "guessed" attributes and improve your metrics. Business people are supposed to do final verification. 

So, if traditional approach based on "zero-cycle" with all stakeholders, this "nano" approach pushes from your expert opinion about what is important for customer in the future solution. And customer helps you to correct your guesses, customer representatives see the idea of QAW much faster in this case and you avoid draft steps and spending the time on them. 

At the same time, such approach is sensitive to the experience of the person who conducts nano-QAW and it is sensitive to competency of customer representatives.
talk.notes:
Presentation outlines:
1. Motivation for fast version of QAW
2. Nano-QAW approach in details
3. Nano-QAW approach best practices and artifacts
4. Production usage lessons learned
5. Case-study

What is the difference of nano-QAW from mini-QAW? See: 1. It is based on the experience of an Architect who prepares his/her best guesses about set of quality attributes and related metrics. 2. As the next step, Architect drives the workshop in a pretty dynamic manner, moving with technologists from customer side checking proposed list of attributes and metrics (by improving list of key attributes and getting threshold values from representatives' side). 3. Formed list of attributes is ranked by priority with technologists of customer. 4. Short meeting with business stakeholders is conducted in order to review formed list of attributes and metrics and checking priorities. 5. Work is done and list of attributes and related metrics is formed.

Such approach works extremely good when: 1. There are available technologists on customer side. 2. There are some ready-to-use expectations/understanding about future system performance/availability/etc on customer side.

talk.title: Rapid Specification of Quality Goals
talk.description:
Critical functional and quality goals and their conflicts must be understood in detail.  Unfortunately, many customers, managers, and developers have little understanding of how to specify, achieve, or verify quality goals.  Barry Boehm ranks qualities among his top 10 sources of serious project risk.

The SEI recommends that quality goals be identified in Quality Attribute Workshops (QAWs).  QAWs identify quality goals indirectly with scenarios and rely on “quality experts” to map scenarios onto quality goals.  Unfortunately, this indirect approach does not help customers make tradeoff decisions because of their poor understanding of quality relationships.  While scenarios are useful in describing some quality attributes, such as aspects of performance, they are not as useful for others, such as safety.

We propose an alternative approach based on the tailoring of a comprehensive quality attribute model to the needs of a project.  The model contains over 60 quality attributes.  Each attribute has over 30 characteristics including indicators and measures, supporting and conflicting qualities, threats and mitigations, and achievement and verification tactics.  The model also contains guidance on defining, achieving, and verifying quality goals.  The model is freely available at quality-aware.com.

This model distinguishes external qualities (visible to users e.g. reliability) from internal qualities (only visible to developers e.g. code readability).  We propose that goals for relevant external qualities be identified and defined in a tailoring workshop that includes most stakeholders.  Internal quality goals should be identified and defined in a meeting of technical management and senior developers.

This presentation will review the attributes model and simulate a tailoring workshop.
talk.abstract: Identification of quality goals is hindered by poor understanding of quality attributes.  We describe a specification strategy that relies on quality model tailoring.  This is compared to the development of scenarios in quality attribute workshops and the subsequent specification of quality goals.

talk.title: Real Life SOA Transformation: A journey at Rackspace from Monolithic to SOA and beyond (MicroServices)
talk.description:

In this presentation, a team of Architects from Rackspace will present the SOA Transformation we are guiding at Rackspace.

- Rackspace - Legacy ESB Mayhem
- Goals and Challenges  
- Introducing SOA 
- Rackspace RESTIFIED
- Journey at Rackspace
- Use Cases and Decisions
- Journey towards CI/CD - Application Packaging/Delivery/Deployment 
- Lessons Learned
- The Future

At the end of the presentation, the audience should be able to relate the case study to similar technological transformation challenges they face at their organizations and learn about some of the suggested guidelines around how to accomplish large-scale technology transformations.

Hi Yogeshwar!  

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. In the Talk Description, why is transformation capitalized in SOA Transformation? In particular, this phrase is not clear and somewhat intriguing: "the Software Transformation journey we should have in a fast-moving environment, where the agility is the key". Maybe there's more objective motivation for the specific transformations you will describe. 

2. I think most of the material out there is settling to using microservices as opposed to micro-services. 

3. If you find that your talk is too long, I suggest removing the first topic ("Rackspace - Business and System Perspective").

4. I think the description is somewhat vague, especially for a 90-minute session. If it's 90 minutes long, it takes the time equivalent to 3 30-minute talks, so the info should be clearly valuable. You mention a case study. Maybe you should say more about the case study.

5. Things you could add to the description to make it more interesting: what technology transformation will you talk about? If it's monolithic to microservices, what do your monoliths looked like? Java EAR apps? MS .NET? Where do you run your microservices? Docker? Kubernetes?  What tools and frameworks did you add to your runtime environment, development environment, continuous integration/deployment environment? 

6. I think the most challenging aspect of the monolith-to-microservice transition is finding the appropriate functional scope for the microservices. If they are too small, you may end up with chatty communications and lower autonomy and performance. If a microservice encompasses functional contexts that is too large, you move closer to the monolithic model and may not significantly realize the microservices benefits. What approaches have you used to help define the size of microservices? Did DDD help? 

7. What communication mechanisms did you use in microservices (what connector types)? Http (REST)? WebSocket? Asynchronous messages/events? 

8. I think "methods of how to accomplish large-scale technology transformations" is quite ambitious. If you don't have exactly methods, but guidelines or best practices derived from experience, that's ok too. 

9. I think you should say "a team of Architects from Rackspace will present" instead of "a team of Architects from Rackspace would attempt to present".

Typos:

- "moving to new technologies come ** with significant challenges"

- "At the end of *the* presentation"

- "we are *g*uiding at Rackspace"

From there we moved towards SOA, standardization of technology, deployment processes, CI and partly CD, and we could add details around the exact technology selection and standardization process we have also including details about Docker and other technologies we use. The challenges that would be described would be more on the lines of the phased steps we took to provide incremental business value and to reduce risks which helped as accomplish a major transformation. This an ongoing journey and we would talk about how we are beginning to embrace Microservices.

6.	I think the most challenging aspect of the monolith-to-microservice transition is finding the appropriate functional scope for the microservices. If they are too small, you may end up with chatty communications and lower autonomy and performance. If a microservice encompasses functional contexts that is too large, you move closer to the monolithic model and may not significantly realize the microservices benefits. What approaches have you used to help define the size of microservices? Did DDD help?

Great point, As an enterprise organization, we have not gone into a spree of replacing everything into MicroService. We are finding right use cases where we really could provide value out of carving Micro Services or introducing new MicroServices. I plan to present a case study of one such real use case and the practical benefits we gained from it. We have applied DDD concepts like Bounded Context and also to further split into Sub Contexts to select MicroService Candidates which helps in defining an appropriate logical boundary. We have also beginning to introduce Micro FrontEnds. Also during our SOA Transformation, we had already begun to apply many of the MicroService Principles even though the term hasn’t become popular. We would also provide those details.

7.	What communication mechanisms did you use in microservices (what connector types)? Http (REST)? WebSocket? Asynchronous messages/events?

We have standardized on HTTP/REST. We had also build our own Messaging Infra Structure using REST: Atom Hopper. ATOM was used as the Messaging Standard across the Services. However within the Bounded Context Teams were free to pick appropriate messaging platforms.

8.	I think "methods of how to accomplish large-scale technology transformations" is quite ambitious. If you don't have exactly methods, but guidelines or best practices derived from experience, that's ok too.
Sure I would rephrase as per your suggestion. Thanks for the feedback.


9.	I think you should say "a team of Architects from Rackspace will present" instead of "a team of Architects from Rackspace would attempt to present".
Typos:
•	"moving to new technologies come ** with significant challenges"
•	"At the end of the presentation"
•	"we are guiding at Rackspace"

Thank you would do those changes. I would have this corrected.
This should be a 30 min experience report. And the focus should be on the challenges, solutions, and lessons learned nothing more.
Thanks Amine. I could condense accordingly.

profile.name: Jim van der Waal
profile.bio: I'm an IT Project Manager at bol.com, the biggest e-commerce company within The Netherlands and Belgium. With my creativity and passion I try to develop a drive in the company that will make things happen.

talk.title: Abuser stories: how we embedded a security culture within our business.
talk.description:
With bol.com we experienced the flight ecommerce took the last decade. As the biggest ecommerce company of the Netherlands and Belgium security risks grew exponentially. But it’s not scalable to let your security team grow with the same rate. That’s why we also focused on creating a security culture within the company: making security a responsibility of everyone, not only the security team.

To not only create this culture in IT but also in the rest of the company, we organized Abuser Story workshops for Product Owners and Business Analysts. Abuser stories are a fun way of thinking about the security of your new features. It triggers to think of unhappy flows, think of thresholds to monitor and so on. Making the systems Secure by Design, something really relevant for architects. We saw that Product Owners consulted the security team and architects way more for advice when designing new systems, they gave room and time to developers to write secure code, and discussions between the Security and development teams were actually constructive. It helped to get the “security, we are in this together” mindset. 

In this talk Jim will tell the journey of bol.com, the growing importance of security, and the way we tried to cope with it in a fun way. The lessons learned are valuable for every (growing) company that struggles with making security scalable, and assuring that you will not only be secure today or tomorrow but also in 5-10 years.
talk.notes: Creating awareness in (IT) companies regarding security is becoming really important, and we saw that this awareness should extend way beyond IT. This is really necessary if you want to work agile, and I experienced that first hand. That is why I came up with this concept to extend the security culture to the business as well. Since it is more or less something I came up with myself I am very enthusiastic and passionate to talk about it. Especially since I experience the succes from it every day now in my projects.
talk.abstract: How do you cope with the growth of security risks? Creating a security culture in your company becomes more important every day. Providing your IT teams with the right tools is one thing, but new features start way before it reaches the development phase. So how do you create such a culture?

ratings.comments:
This looks really interesting and I'm very keen on getting architects and developers to be more interested in security, so I like the topic!

I would expand your abstract to make it clear what you're covering.  It's not clear what the audience will leave with.

I don't think in 15 minutes you have time to tell the story of bol.com, how you created a culture, lessons learned, ... Just sounds too much to me.  Can you focus it down to a short sharp message?

I'm also not quite sure how much you plan to discuss the Abuser Stories technique.  They are in the title and there is a lot there in the description, but they're not mentioned in the last paragraph.  I think this needs to be made clear.

This is a talk that I would like to see.  It cover three topics that I find interesting that are identified within the submission guidelines.

It promises to provide a successful case study on helping to assure quality from a security perspective.

More importantly, it focuses on creating a culture of security awareness within agile teams.  That is not easy to achieve, and I would be interested in finding out how it has been done.

Personally I would like to see a longer session with practical elements such as role playing an workshop.

Given that security is an after thought in most development organizations, this topic can possibly bring to light how to truly make everybody think about security.  Also, since security is quickly becoming on of the "ility" requirements, applicable to SATURN.

I like it, I'm also an advocate for addressing safety and security requirements early. Safety and security can't be something we try to fix afterwords. That said, I found it hard to see how this fits with the architectural thinking of a system.
I like this workshop but I don't see a clear connection to architecture design in the abstract.  As a requirements elicitation method it seems quite interesting.

The talk is about disseminating a security culture across the organization and eliciting security requirements for applications (as "abuser stories"). Apparently, it does not get to discuss security as a quality attribute and design driver or tactics and approaches to achieve security.

feedback.body:
Hi Jim,

Thanks for your submission!  I'm a huge fan of misuse cases and simple threat modelling for specifying security requirements.  This is a great topic but I could use some additional information to understand the scope of the proposed talk.

It sounds like the focus of this talk will be on requirements elicitation using the abuser story workshop?  Could you share some details about what that workshop looks like?  A tentative outline for your talk would be extremely helpful.

How is this workshop different from other security requirement  elicitation methods?

Regards,

Michael

Hi Micheal,

Nice to hear from you. I will try to answer your questions below and give some additional information.

About what I will tell about how we embedded a security culture in the company:
So how do you already get that security mindset embedded in earlier stages. How do you get people excited to think about security? Security has the prejudice that it is boring, that is something you have to do, maybe because someone else says so. Like the security team/department. But security can also be fun! Fun? Yes! By stimulating the employees to think like a hacker, either technical or functional, they got motivated to think of security requirements by approaching it from the other side. This in combination with the right tools really helped to get our security level to high standards.

Some more information about the Abuser Story Workshop:
With abuser stories we touch on a subject everybody worked with: user stories. Normally with user stories you define new functionality that you develop with the customer in mind. But how can this functionality be abused? We stimulate the colleagues creativity to think evil and create a hacker mindset for themselves. Turn it around: write an Abuser story: As a hacker, I want…, So that… We were surprised by the evilness of our colleagues – we had some real hackers among us. We do this by introducing a simple proces, let one team think about abuser stories (so how could you as a hacker abuse this functionality), and the other team about user stories on how to avoid abuse. After that the 'Attacking' team presents its abuser stories, which the other team needs to 'Defend' with one of their user stories. We then stimulate the Product Owners to braintorm about abuser stories at the kickoff of each new functionality, more or less facilitate their own workshop. The outcome is then translated in requirements for the different user stories.


There are actually two ways of how you can approach this talk. 

1. A (comprehensive) talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, where I will deep dive more in how we did this with the use of Abuser Story Workshops. This focusses more on how we created this security culture, and the lessons we learned from this proces.

2. A short talk about the journey of bol.com and how we embedded a security culture, and facilitating a Abuser Story Workshop to illustrate how we did this. This focusses more on teaching you how you could facilitate these workshops yourself. 


Relevance for audience: the first is relevant for a broader audience, where the second talk (workshop form) is more relevant for Analysts and Product Owners.

I hope this gives you more insights. If you have any questions or you want me to elaborate a bit more, just let me know.

Regards,

Jim
Thanks, Jim.  Your responses are helpful.

Hi Einar,

Thanks! The safety case method is new to me. Within our company we have very little formal methods and formal documentation, so it is not a surprise that I did not come across it before.

Jim
Hi Jim, what type of session should this fall under? It's currently in the DEV@SATURN 15-minute category but seems like it might be longer. Please let me know. Thanks.

Hi Michele, you are absolutely right. Indeed the talk is normally around 20-30 minutes. So it would then fall under an Experience Report Presentation. It would be doable to present it in a TED talk way, but I think the other format suits better for now. 

Thanks for your reply. Hope this helps.

profile.name: Pradyumn Sharma
profile.bio:
32 years of experience in IT industry. Been a programmer, designer, architect, project manager, DBA, tester, business analyst, and now mostly trainer, coach and consultant. I have worked on the architecture, design and implementation of many applications, in various domains including banking, insurance, retail, logistics, process control. I regularly provide consulting, coaching and mentoring services to software development organizations in India on grooming their experienced developers to play the role of application / solution / enterprise architects. I have designed and executed many in-depth training programs on various aspects of architecture for my clients.

Been a speaker in many SATURN conferences, as well as Scrum Gatherings, Agile Conferences.

talk.title: Agile Architecture and Design
talk.description:
Agile software development methodologies are mainstream now. But one of the nagging questions teams face is: how to establish the architecture for a system the agile way? After all, architectural decisions have a key impact on various qualities of a system, and therefore, these decisions have to be taken early and carefully. How does this fit with the incremental and iterative nature of agile methodologies? 

In this session, I'll cover the following aspects: 

* Creating an architecture vision, including desired architectural qualities, during Sprint Zero 
* Identifying potential strategies for achieving the desired architectural qualities, without creating an ivory tower architecture
* Prioritizing the architectural qualities and adding them to the Product Backlog along with the functional requirements 
* Implementing and verifying architectural qualities with the help of real stories from the Product Backlog.   

I will take concrete examples from projects on how to apply the above concepts.
talk.notes:
I have been in the IT industry for 32 years. Been a programmer, designer, architect, project manager, DBA, tester, business analyst, and now mostly trainer, coach and consultant. I have worked on the architecture, design and implementation of many applications, in various domains including banking, insurance, retail, logistics, process control. 

I regularly conduct training programs in the fields of Agile with Scrum, Agile Engineering Practices (XP), Solution Architecture, Enterprise Architecture, and Writing Good Programs.

I have presented various sessions relating to Agile Architecture in many SATURN conferences, as well as Scrum Gatherings, Agile Conferences.
talk.abstract: How to establish the architecture for a system in an agile way? How to avoid BDUF, and yet meet the architecture requirements and mitigate the risks aggressively? Concrete examples from projects to understand the concepts as well as practical insight.

ratings.comments: I have heard Pradyumn speak before and was to his NoSQL tutorial some SATURNs ago. I think this would make a valuable contribution to this year's SATURN.

Architecture's contribution (or otherwise) to agility is an enduring theme and many people have explored it in articles, papers and conference talks (with different degrees of credibility and usefulness).  Can you be clear what is new and novel here, or if it's not new and novel why it will be a great SATURN talk?

I think it would also be useful if you expanded your list of topics to explain what will actually be in each one.

This submission is an experience report on providing some guidelines for establishing an architecture in an agile way. The author correctly identifies that despite the acceptance of agile methodologies and recognition of the importance of architecture a lot of teams struggle marrying them both.

While I appreciate the motivation, I lack the actual experience piece of this talk. The points that the author lists are those that can be found in any blog post or article. The SATURN audience would like to see how these actual experience that work in practice. Unfortunately, this point is only made in passing as "I will take concrete examples from projects on how to apply the above concepts." What are the nature of the concrete examples and what lessons can be taken from them are missing for me to be able to judge this experience piece of this talk objectively.

This talk addresses a key question in the "Digital, Virtual Software Architect": How can we be effective in fast-moving agile environments?

I'm particularly interested in learning about the experiences behind Sprint Zero activities and how the managing of quality attributes on the backlog.
I think talks about architecture and agile should always be welcome.  Especially those that have come from experience.

I’ve attended talks by the speaker and he is well versed in architecture principles. I would categorize those talks as more basic than intermediate. It is possible that the presentation has evolved though there is not enough description to know for sure. The SATURN audience may want something with a little more substance.

Agile and architecture has been discussed often and there are many talks on it at SATURN and elsewhere.  There's really nothing that new proposed in the talk.  But it's always good to see experience reports that show how these practices are used in practice.
Sounds as a relevant, well structured talk by a experienced speaker.
Looks like just the sort of session that can help us build a bridge between developers who are familiar with agile development and the software architecture practices.

feedback.body: Thank you for an interesting submission. I think this topic sounds very interesting.

Hi Pradyumn,

Thanks for your submission.  On the one hand this looks like the same things we've seen for a while with agile architecture discussions.  On the other hand, this looks like an experience report with clear lessons and a tight focus on a topic many people care about.

I'm intrigued by the idea of design without a _paper architecture_.  What do you mean by this?  Why wouldn't a paper architecture be a desirable thing?    Paper prototyping is a wonderful technique for exploring design options quickly and cheaply.

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael,
Thanks for your feedback. Silly me! I meant to say "ivory tower" architecture. I am embarrassed.
Let me see if I can correct the submission now.
Pradyumn

talk.title: A Hands on Introduction To Docker
talk.description:
Have you heard the term "container" without a full understanding of what it means? This is the place for you. This session will provide some of the theory of containers and provide a supervised hands on experience where participants will construct a Docker container. They will execute the container and save it in a repository so that they can some day show their children - "This was my first container".

Participants should have preloaded Docker and run the Hello World application
talk.abstract:
Containers are light weight virtual machines that have become default packaging mechanisms for the deploying of systems. Docker is the pre-eminent container system.

talk.title: An Architect's Framework for Navigating Complexity
talk.description:
We want our organizations and systems to be agile. We want them to evolve with the needs of the business, its customers and stakeholders, and to be resilient in the face of ever changing market conditions and the external environment. This level of adaptability and responsiveness needs to be supported by the architecture of the systems we create. The complexity of the environment that architects find themselves in is increasing in recent years, with cloud, DevOps, continuous deployment, micro services and other elements adding to the factors that architects must consider. With this growing complexity, architects need to be supported by effective decision-making approaches.

Size is also a factor. Larger systems and larger organizations have, by definition, a larger number of dependencies (internal and external) that must be managed, and a larger number of stakeholders (internal and external) whose needs must be addressed. The architecture of larger systems can involve hundreds or thousands of people, creating dozens to hundreds of products, components and subsystems that all need to work together. Maintaining the conceptual integrity of the architecture under such circumstances, and over time, presents many challenges and a greater need for coherence. 

To navigate all of this, agile architects need to be adaptive; they need the ability to dynamically shift their decision-making approach to match the complexity of the circumstances they face. This session will describe how lessons from complexity science, and in particular, sense making and the Cynefin framework, can help architects to be more agile in how they work, and in turn, help them develop architectures that are more agile and adaptive to the needs of the organizations they serve.

### Learning Outcomes
* Applying sense making in the context of architecture
* Applying the Cynefin framework to architecture problems and decisions
* Examples of architecture problems and decisions that can be mapped to the different domains represented by the Cynefin framework (obvious, complicated, complex, chaotic and disorder)
* How to manage the transition of architecture problems between these different domains
* Implications for organization structure and communications
* How such an approach leads to a more resilient architecture, and a more antifragile organization
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework supports emergent architecture
* How complexity thinking and the Cynefin framework help the organization and the architecture to be more agile

### Format
For a 90-minute workshop I typically use the following format. 

Part 1 (5 minutes):
Introduction

* Overview of concepts

Part 2 (10 minutes): 

* Architecture descriptions
* Using narrative to understand architecture

Part 3 (40 minutes):

* Sense Making analysis of architectures and their influence on the organisation
* Analysing the patterns that emerge from the sense making activity

Part 4 (30 minutes):

* The Cynefin Framework, and how it applies to architecture
* Designing experiments

Part 5 (5 minutes):

* Debrief and wrap up
talk.notes:
The majority of the session is highly participatory. All five parts outlined in the session description have some element of participation. Parts 2-4 are the major parts of the session. In part 2, I guide participants through sketching their architecture and creating narrative about their architecture. In part 3, I guide participants in analysing their architecture/sketch/narrative using a sense making framework. In part 4, I guide participants in understanding the Cynefin framework in more detail and designing an experiment to address complex challenges that emerge in the analysis. Parts 1 and 5 have less activity, but still have dialog and interaction.

I will bring all the supplies that I need to run the exercise. It is more effective if the room is set up “banquet style”, with round tables that set groups of 6-10. 

I have been working with sensemaking and complexity for a few years now, and have run variations of this activity many times, both inside Cisco and at conferences and other forums. At the heart of this is the concept of applying sensemaking and the Cynefin framework to managing the complexity faced by architects. That complexity is not just in the architecture itself, but also in the problem domain, the organization, and the wider context within which architects do their work.

My background is in software engineering and architecture, in the context of product and systems development, and in transforming engineering organizations around the world. I use the techniques I present here in my own work, and I also help architects, engineers, and others, apply these techniques in their work.

talk.title: An In-Depth Look at Event Sourcing with CQRS
talk.description:
Although Event Sourcing has been around for many years, it remains outside the mainstream paradigm of software development--much to our detriment.

With Event Sourcing, we place the highest value on the simple capture of essential business events without attempting to interpret them. We can then relegate all interpretations of those events to subsystems that are easy to build, change, and replace when necessary. The resulting systems have single responsibilities and are decoupled from each other, which makes them simple to modify. Event Sourcing can enable us to move faster by supporting rapid experimentation with new perspectives, new user interactions, and new insights into our business.

Event Sourcing is agnostic of technology stack and language style, but it goes well with another pattern called CQRS: Command Query Responsibility Segregation. In this talk, we will do a deep-dive into the two patterns and scope out a system that has:

* Receiving and validating Commands that, if successful, result in Events (with pseudocode to illustrate how it might work).
* Interpreting Events into denormalised projections for very fast reads.
* Single responsibility services for reacting to Events by creating other events and, if necessary, triggering external behaviour.

We will also cover more in-depth topics, such as:

* Strategies for evolving events and event schemas over time.
* Dealing with eventual consistency.
* Popular technologies for various system components, such as how to store and distribute events.
talk.notes:
This is a 90 minute talk. I gave a 30 minute version of this talk at SATURN 2016, which was very well received. I thought I'd see if there was interest in a longer version to expand on the many questions that followed. You can see the 2016 talk here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TeMYF_JjNg

Since last year, my involvement in building Event Sourced systems have grown exponentially. My company, Envato, has continued building Event Sourced systems and has emerged as a leader for this particular pattern in Australia. As the principal Software Architect at Envato, I have been a key part of this journey, which has also involved speaking with a variety of other companies about their Event Sourcing experiences.
talk.abstract: Event Sourcing is an approach to building software with a long track record of success. By placing business concepts at the heart of our code, we can decouple systems into small services that can be quickly built, changed, and replaced. This talk will show you how.

talk.title: Architecture Decision Records in Action
talk.description:
Documenting architecture design decisions is commonly considered a good practice but few teams take the time to write down the decisions they make.  In my experience this happens for a few reasons:  architecture documentation is rejected as being too heavyweight, documentation is typically out of sight and out of mind, and many developers don't know what to document.  Architecture Decision Records (ADRs), a lightweight documentation approach [proposed by Michael Nygard](http://thinkrelevance.com/blog/2011/11/15/documenting-architecture-decisions), solves these problems by recording design decisions in a simple markdown template in the same repository as the code affected by the ADR.  In this talk we will share our experiences and lessons using ADRs over the past year while working on multiple projects for IBM Watson.

By the end of this talk you will be able to create effective ADRs, introduce them to your team, and avoid common pitfalls with the method.
talk.notes:
This talk is intended to be a 30 minute experience report.  I can't figure out how to change the session type to match this.

The talk will have the following tentative outline.

1. Introduction / Problem overview: teammates don't have architectural context, decisions aren't communicated and are lost over time
   * Failed attempts to solve the problem -- wikis, dedicated repos, "official" documentation
2. ADRs Overview
   * Nygard's proposal
   * Connection to other work and research
3. How we use ADRs
4. Exercise: Create an ADR (optional, may fall out depending on timing, at most this is a 5-7 minute exercise)
5. Case Study: IBM Watson Information Retrieval Enhanced team
   * This section will include the proposed lessons and tips for adopting and using ADRs based on our experiences
   * Create a common template that everyone agrees to use
       * examples from case study
   * Identify an architecture champion to point out when architectural design decisions happen
   * Add ADR creation tasks to the backlog
   * Use pull requests and peer reviews to teach people how to record a decision and to
       spread konwledge about decisions
   * Use ADRs to grow architects on your team
       * Creating an ADR is a small slice of design responsibility.  It turns out to be a great way to
           infuse the team with architectural thinking and train new architects
   * Store ADRs with the code
   * Works great with microservices where small groups of people and the code
       they create work autonomously within a light governance framework
   * Revisit old ADRs every so often to update them and ensure you have accurate reflection of current thinking
6. Problems we ran into with ADRs and are still working through
   * Plain text diagramming is a pain point.
   * ADRs emphasize architectural decisions for a single component.  This is great for smaller projects and
      individual microservices but falls apart when multiple architectural components stored in multiple code
      repositories are involved.
      * Our solution was to create an "Architecture" repository, which stored ADRs that cut across multiple
         architectural components, linking to refinement ADRs as appropriate.
   * Overemphasis on design decisions at the expense of other design documentation
       * The team became awesome at recording ADRs to the point where they wouldn't document anything else!
       * ADRs were smashing success.  Complementary methods that are as simple and lightweight are needed for
          design concepts other than decisions.  examples: alternatives, governance policies, general design guidance,
          quality attribute scenarios and other architecturally significant requirements
7. Conclusion
   * closing thoughts on using ADRs as a way to "sneak in" architecture
   * great way to create a history of the project and explain not only where we are but how the system arrived at this point
   * Show where ADRs fit as part of an documentation strategy 
   * Links to additional resources
talk.abstract: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) capture key architectural design decisions in a lightweight, easy-to-create, plain text template stored in your existing version control system.  In this talk we will explore case studies from the IBM Watson IR Enhanced team and learn how to use ADRs.

feedback.body:
Michael-
The SEI Views and Beyond book discusses documenting architecture decisions (Section 6.5). That discussion was based on work by Jeff Tyree and Art Ackermann (https://www.utdallas.edu/~chung/SA/zz-Impreso-architecture_decisions-tyree-05.pdf). It might be worth including some comments in your talk about how your/Nygaard's approach compares and contrasts with this earlier work.

Hi John,  Thanks for your feedback.  I am familiar with the Tyree/Ackermann paper.  I actually [referenced the same paper as a comment on the blog](http://disq.us/p/18d4i4r) about 8 months ago in an attempt to point out the same thing!  We also include a link to Nygard's blog and that paper in our ADR template as background information.

I am certainly planning to make this connection in the talk, if accepted.  The two templates have the same goal in the end but collect slightly different information.  The ADR is significantly simpler, if nothing else.  I think a key difference and the thing that is kind of unique about Nygard's approach is in what is done with this information.  It sounds simple, but storing the design decisions in the version control system acted almost as a stealth way of injecting some of the ideas from Views and Beyond into the team.  What's more a small ecosystem of tools has sprung up around ADRs.  See https://github.com/npryce/adr-tools and https://github.com/holytshirt/dotnet-adr as examples.

Finally, Thougtworks recently [classified ADRs as "trial" methodology](https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/techniques/lightweight-architecture-decision-records).  It is my hope that an experience report like this might provide additional backing for either making this practice a recommended approach, or at least recommending it with caveats.

Regards,

Michael

That's a great topic and thanks for submitting. I first encountered the importance of maintaining Architectural Decisions ass a part of the SEI Views and Beyond book. I have been a great advocate and have used them ever since. I think its an important technique that needs good attention and would help many Architects attending the conference. The approach of understanding software architecture in terms of a variety of architecture decisions is now widely recognized.

However, I do have a suggestion. Instead of the talk just focusing on ADR as suggested by Michael Nygard, what would be even useful is discussing the approaching of Documenting Architecture Decisions as a whole, which decisions to document and not, the payback/benefits and the variants available for documenting them along with your case study.

Also, I am concerned about the idea of just storing the Architecture Decisions in isolation without many other significant Architectural Artifacts. I understand that the Thoughtworks seems to recommend including them in the “trial” methodology. However, I am just concerned with the misnomer that these are the only set of significant artifacts for all cases. Could the details be presented more on the lines of Evolutionary Architecture.

Hi Yogeshwar, thanks for your feedback!

I share your concerns and plan to address them in the talk.  I mentioned the points you raise under section 6.  I am certainly not suggesting this is the only set of artifacts required and recognize this is a trap teams easily fall into -- one of my teams did!

With respect to deciding when to document a decision vs. not, I plan to cover that under 5.4 and 5.5.  It turns out that people don't always know or recognize when an architectural decision has been made.  Pull requests and explicit architecture tasks combined with pairing was how we worked through some of those issues, in addition to including clear guidance in our template.  Basically we created situations for on the job training over time.

My goal is to attempt to place this technique within the context of the broader literature, as you suggest.  As you also point out, the idea of recording decisions is not new and is a commonly understood good practice.  The point of this talk is not to retread old ground but to look at good practice from the perspective of a newer method that people actually use and seems to resonate well with developers.  These ideas have been around for a while, and yet few teams practice them.  Why?  I think this method is another incremental step in the right direction.  By the end of the talk people will be armed with the knowledge they need to be successful with the method, not just try it out.

Regards,

Michael
Thanks for the detail! All the very best.

talk.title: Automate ALL the Things: Taking Advantage of Free Tools to Automate Your End-to-End Release Pipelines
talk.description:
A myriad of point-tools, frameworks and infrastructures are involved in your software delivery process – from development, through build, testing, deployment, all the way to a Production Release.

While many of these tools are free/open source, the operational and technology overhead of orchestrating the hand-offs from one tool to the next in the process are not without cost.

To improve developer productivity and resource utilization – and to enable enterprise-scale, cross-project visibility and shorter time to market – organizations are working to automate and orchestrate the entire tool chain across the end-to-end delivery pipeline.
“Automate All the Things” is a key tenant to any DevOps or Continuous Delivery initiative.

This presentation will use a real case study to show how you can orchestrate your entire software delivery pipeline. Learn how to create a fully-automated release pipeline, tying-in common tools that you likely use in your process from CI build to Release: including Git, Jenkins, Selenium, Chef, Docker, and more.

Learn how to:

Seamlessly orchestrate third-party tools to automate your entire process- from start to finish

Get visibility into your end-to-end application release pipeline

Deploy any application to any environment using any tool-set – for free.
talk.notes:
As Global Technical Account Manager at Electric Cloud, I work with some of our largest customers, and help them use our solutions to improve their software development and delivery processes.  I help with overall strategy deploying our software across large organizations, design and implementation, as well as looking ahead to make sure the solution support future growth plans. Before joining Electric Cloud, I worked as a kernel developer at IBM for five years. 

I have previously presented at StackWorld 2016, StackWorld Virtual 2016, and Merge 2016. 

Outline: 

1. What does your software delivery pipeline look like?
2. What is a Commit Pipeline vs. Release Pipeline
3. How do you ensure fidelity of processes, environments, configuration and artifacts across the pipeline- from code check-in to Production
4. What point tools are involved in your pipeline, how many are open source/free?
5. What are the challenges with managing a myriad of tools, across different teams
6. Don’t replace your existing tools, orchestrate.
7. What is the difference between automation and orchestration
8. What do you need for end-to-end orchestration
9. A little bit about ElectricFlow – a free devops orchestration platform
10. What are the benefits and ROI of orchestration of the pipeline
11. Consider a common pipeline using free tools- from developer check-in with Git, through CI with Jenkins, Publish to repo w/ Docker, then to Staging for testing, run Selenium tests, upon success- deploy to Docker in Prod.
12. DEMO of this pipeline – orchestrating all the free tools with ElectricFlow.

talk.title: Blending Product Thinking with Architecture
talk.description:
Too much design up front and you are bumping into the design all of the time (and losing time).  Not enough design and your system can crumble in reality.  How do you blend architecture so you have the right decisions at the right time, and give them enough due dilligence?  How do you embrace cloud and microservices and not risk getting into different failure scenarios or overly complicated maintenance and ripple effects?

In this session we will walk through visualizations that help teams blend product thinking with architecture.  Along the way, we will look at microservices and domain modeling as well as chaos engineering and fault tolerance - blending all of these into a context that is consumable by all and gives the right emphasis at the right time.

Leave this session with simple visualizations and approaches that you can apply immediately to start blending product with architecture, especially if you are looking to run in a cloud world.

talk.title: Building Secure(r) applications using Language-theoretic security.
talk.description:
Building Secure(r) applications using Language-theoretic security
=============

Language-theoretic security is the approach of recognizing and handling all input before processing it. Traditionally, almost every software development project mixes this recognition of input and processing of the input. If the recognition wasn't done right, then poor input can be processed and lead to exploits. 
Language-theoretic security suggests, that the recognition be separated from the processing making it easier to audit the code, and fundamentally prevent parser bugs from recurring. 
In this talk, I would present an overview of Language-theoretic security and describe the parser combinator library hammer. I would then describe the approach to building language-theoretic security compliant implementations of some popular application layer IoT protocols like MQTT, and discuss the performance overhead in this approach.
talk.abstract: Parser bugs in the recent past have been infamous -- Heartbleed, Android Master Key, Apple's Goto. In this talk, I would present a  methodology using parser combinator libraries to building web and IoT applications to ensure it isn't susceptible to the same category of vulnerabilities.

talk.description:
As organizations invest in DevOps to release more frequently, there’s a need to treat the database tier as an integral part of your automated delivery pipeline – to build, test and deploy database changes just like any other part of your application.

However, databases (particularly RDBMS) are different from source code, and pose unique challenges to Continuous Delivery - especially in the context of deployments. Often, code changes require updating or migrating the database before the application can be deployed. A deployment method that works for installing a small database or a green-field application may not be suitable for industrial-scale databases. Updating the database can be more demanding than updating the app layer: database changes are more difficult to test, and rollbacks are harder. Furthermore, for organizations who strive to minimize service interruption to end users, database updates with no-downtime are a laborious operation. 

Your DB stores the most mission-critical and sensitive data of your organization (transaction data, business data, user information, etc.). As you update your database, you’d want to ensure data integrity, ACID, data retention, and have a solid rollback strategy - in case things go wrong …

This talk covers strategies for database deployments and rollbacks:

• What are some patterns and best practices for reliably deploying databases as part of your CD pipeline?
• How do you safely rollback database code? 
• How do you ensure data integrity?
• What are some best practices for handling advanced scenarios and back-end processes, such as scheduled tasks, ETL routines, replication architecture, linked databases across distributed infrastructure, and more.
• How to handle legacy database, alongside more modern data management solutions?
talk.abstract: Your DB stores the most mission-critical and sensitive data of your organization (transaction data, business data, user information, etc.). As you update your database, you’d want to ensure data integrity, ACID, data retention, and have a solid rollback strategy - in case things go wrong.

Chris

Hi Chris, 
Thanks for your submission. I agree this is an important topic for organizations that want to move to continuous deployment, especially when their systems use shared databases. Database changes are not handled directly by Jenkins, Docker, and Kubernetes. You need something else tool-wise. 
In our organization we are using Flyway. One of the challenges we are facing is that the DBAs lose operational control over table schemas. That's less of a problem if each system (or microservice) has its own dedicated database. But in many enterprise IT environments, there's still some centralization of database changes. Continuous delivery/deployment with Flyway (or similar) will typically ask developers to author DDL statements that will eventually be automatically executed in production upon system initialization. I hope your presentation will touch on this aspect.

talk.title: Cloud Detour – Resiliency Testing tool for the Cloud Resources
talk.description: Cloud is ubiquitous, but failures are unavoidable and unpredictable raising uncertainty and are risk to the systems. Traditional approaches can’t predict all failure modes because of changing data conditions, complex request patterns, ever increasing innovation and growing scale. Chaos engineering is a discipline to simulate these failures. In our cloud-detour solution, we describe how mission critical applications can register themselves to test against several failure scenarios and demonstrate their resiliency level and help them come up with solutions to provide adequate resiliency and solid disaster recovery strategy.
talk.notes: This will be a 30 min Technical talk about Cloud Resiliency facts, needs and what it takes to evaluate it. We describe this based on our in-depth experience based in resiliency in both on-premise and cloud deployments. The talk will include a co-presenter Gnani Dathathreya. The speakers have presented in AWS Reinvent:2016 and Serverless Conference London:2016 and also wrote a blog in AWS Compute blog.
talk.abstract: Cloud has enabled software industry with reduced time to market and low start up cost. But it takes huge undertaking to design applications with resiliency.  Cloud Detour a Chaos Engineering discipline subjects applications to failures in cloud and help them weigh against resiliency levels

feedback.body:
Hi Sathyia,

Thanks for your submission.  To me this seems like a highly relevant topic and a great experience.  It would be nice to see a little more detail in the notes section about specifically what you plan to cover during the talk.  What is your definition of chaos engineering?  How do you commonly work with teams to improve their microservices?  I also wonder how generally applicable the solution you use at Capital One is or whether it is highly specific to your needs.  Could, for example, anyone running on AWS do what you've done?

Regards,

Michael

Michael, 

Thanks for the feedback. Please find more information you have asked for below.

What is your definition of chaos engineering?

In our definition, Chaos Engineering is a discipline where we will simulate real world failures which occur rarely and cause catastrophic losses to the systems. This is much more important in cloud environments where we have completely relinquished the infrastructure management and high level service management to the cloud provider. Traditional testing mechanisms do not cover such self inflicted failures. Using Chaos Engineering tools, applications can subject themselves to failures and measure their resiliency.

How do you commonly work with teams to improve their microservices?

As part of integration and performance testing of applications, we engage them and set them up with cloud detour, the chaos engineering tool. The application teams can then start registering various failures against the application and infrastructure. For example random termination of servers and high CPU simulation affecting the processes. This will help evaluate how the microservice performed against the failures and if it still met the NFRs.

how generally applicable the solution you use at Capital One is or whether it is highly specific to your needs

The solution is very generic for applications deployed in AWS. Any AWS deployed application will be able to use the various aspects of solution whether the application just uses Infrastructure services like EC2 or higher level application services like ECS/S3

Additional information on AWS and general availability

The tool received a great feedback in its initial pilot and currently being aggressively adopted by various divisions. Over next few months, we will be able to make it Open Source ready for the community use. Also one of our objectives is to build an abstraction layer over the capabilities and make it available in other cloud providers like Azure and Google cloud. 

Let me know if you need more information.

Thanks
Sathiya

Hi Sathiya,
Thanks for your submission. I have a couple of suggestions: 

1. Your talk description does not mention automation anywhere. A conference participant who's not familiar with Chaos Monkey or "chaos engineering" may wonder if the approach being described is fully automated (on one end) or is about a strategy to "manually" engineer scenarios to test resiliency. Since today we pursue the "automation of all things", I think the description should say to what degree the solution uses automation and integrates to CI.

2. You mention mission critical applications, but don't qualify the applications any further. You could be more specific in the description. For example, the solution may work for failure testing of services that expose http endpoints, but not for failure testing of services that consume JMS messages.

Paulo - Great feedback, thank you. I have updated the abstract addressing your comments as below, please review.

Cloud is ubiquitous, but failures are unavoidable and unpredictable raising uncertainty and are risk to the systems. Traditional approaches can’t predict all failure modes because of changing data conditions, complex request patterns, ever increasing innovation and growing scale. Chaos engineering is a discipline to simulate these failures. In our cloud-detour solution, we describe how mission critical applications like high volume customer facing web applications or critical batch applications using compute/storage/networking services in the cloud can register themselves in an automated way to test against several failure scenarios and demonstrate their resiliency level.  This can help application engineers assess and provide adequate resiliency and solid disaster recovery strategy. Cloud Detour itself is management free with Serverless implementation and can be integrated with application CICD pipelines and provides approval workflows with application owners, application health checking before and after disruptions and alerting.

talk.title: Cloud Native Development, Cloud Nomadic Deployment
talk.description:
Industry practices around how we develop and deploy software are moving very quickly towards a few simple, yet wildly influential trends centred around software running and scaling in the cloud. Enterprises and startups alike are adopting cloud technologies, containerization, infrastructure automation and agile methodologies and applying them to large scale deployments. 

As a software engineer on a Cloud R&D team helping enterprise customers adopt these modern trends, Topher has experienced the gamut when it comes cloud transformation journeys and upcoming trends in how software is developed, deployed, and managed in the cloud.

This talk will give an overview of emerging trends; covering how Cloud Native applications, Platform as a Service, Automation, and Infrastructure as Code can help with deploying software, as well as migrating your software from one IaaS to another. Attendees will learn how to navigate through the buzzwords in cloud computing, and leave with an understanding of how to deploy, manage, and scale their software in the cloud.

talk.title: Component Systems in the Field: Integrating and Controlling System Services Easily using Connectors
talk.description:
In this talk, we view software architectures as systems of connectors. We treat connectors as self-contained, physical (i.e. binary), identifiable special-purpose components that isolate interfaces from communicating components. We intentionally place interfaces contained in connectors in the forefront of any kind of component system. 

Through interfaces in connectors, components can be supplied with extra-functional services, such as the monitoring and budgeting of system-resource usage, the profiling of architecturally relevant components, and the checking of communication protocols. These services are beneficial for industrial systems that are maintained and evolve in the field. Connectors are a means of realizing blue/green deployments, canary releases, and performance monitors; all of which are necessary for DevOps scenarios that work in industrial environments. Connectors take over these tasks. Components can focus on their core businesses.

Even without any extra-functional services, connectors provide two significant advantages to the development and operation of resource-constrained, safety-critical embedded systems. Firstly, connectors physically decouple communicating components, in the sense that components depend on (reference) connectors but connectors do not depend on components. Secondly, for implementation connectors do not need heavyweight component frameworks or middleware as usually in distributed systems.

Connectors can be built for and operated in rich runtime environments such as .NET CLR, and in thin runtime environments such as crt0 for C++ programs. Basically, for our purposes, build and runtime environments need only to support interfaces in the sense of the identically named language concept and linkable compilation units. To build connectors of different kinds, we use several techniques and design patterns of different pattern languages in various combinations, for example Factory, Strategy and Decorator from E. Gamma et al., Registry from M. Fowler, Bounded Context from E. Evans and Insulation from J. Lakos.

The presentation is divided into four parts. In the first part we introduce the minimal connector and explain the consequences and benefits for developing, testing and configuring component systems. In the second part we develop the minimal connector into light connectors containing plain interfaces (call and callback) and then into heavy connectors with additional extra-functional services. In the third part we apply connectors for structuring a system whose development follows the DevOps methodology. In the fourth and final part, with a better understanding of our motivation, objectives, nature, assemblage and application of connectors in our practice, we work out similarities and differences in comparison with the Interceptor pattern from D. Schmidt et al. and component-and-connector views (SEI: Documenting Software Architectures, 2nd ed.).
talk.abstract: Physically independent connectors decouple components without performance costs. Services optionally built into connectors intersect orthogonally with component functions. Connectors considerably simplify DevOps scenarios in industrial environments.

ratings.comments: I like this one. Connectors are good architectural means and Siemens has good people presenting.
The concept of connectors seems intriguing. I also have good experience with the guys from Siemens. They are usually good practitioners with excellent experience.

feedback.body:
Hi Joachim,

Thanks for your submission.  What are some examples of connectors?  From your description, FluentD and Docker log drivers come to mind.  Is this close?  Or is something more akin to a plug-in that is compiled or linked into the source?  This sounds like an interesting discussion and something many teams could use.

Michael

user.name: Joachim Fröhlich, Florian Krautwurm, Markus Lachenmayr

feedback.body:
Hi Michael. Thanks for your feedback.

Logging is just one example of a service that can be built into a connector. Perhaps it is the simplest one. With regard to Docker log drivers and FluentD, we assume that similar things can be implemented with connectors.
 
Supplementary to the examples already given in the lecture description we like to mention: observing faults, checking parameters (part of protocol checks), handling retries and automatic failover in case of worker components fail. We took these examples from fault-tolerant, safety-critical systems which we are primarily dealing with in our daily work. These and other services transparently built into "heavy" connectors are also useful for DevOps.

We would be pleased to present and discuss such considerations at the conference.

Kind regards.

Hi Joachim,

Thanks for your submission. I have a few comments on specific assertions you make in the talk description. 

1. "We view software architectures as systems of connectors."  Well, architecture is more than that. The literature on software architecture today is clear to say that software architecture encompasses multiple *views* (or perspectives, viewpoints). An architecture view that shows the components (runtime elements) and connectors is one of them. But a view that describes, for example, how the source code is organized in layers, or packages, namespaces is also part of the software architecture. A view that shows how different components are allocated to different hardware elements or nodes is also part of the software architecture. A view that shows the data entities and their relationships (one-to-one, one-to-many) in a data centric information system is also part of the software architecture. So, I think this statement should be more flexible to say something like "An important perspective of any software architecture is the one that shows a system of connectors."

2. "A connector is a self-contained, physical (i.e. binary), identifiable special-purpose component that isolates interfaces from communicating components."  There are overloaded definitions of components and connectors out there. I particularly like the ones in "Documenting Software Architectures, Second Edition". This book says a "Components are the principal computational elements and data stores that execute in a system."  Then it says "A connector is a runtime pathway of interaction between two or more components."  The book makes clear that connectors are first-class citizens in the software architecture. But your definition seems too strict. For example, when a Javascript web page (the client component) makes an http call to a REST service (the server component), I see the http communication as the connector. However, in my architecture I don't have a physical, binary, identifiable element for that connector.  I also find it confusing to say that a connector is a (type of) component. Conceptually, it's easier to separate components from connectors.

3. "Connectors are a means of realizing blue/green deployments, canary releases, and performance monitors". Often times, performance monitoring, logging, and other similar functionalities are performed by interceptors. An interceptor is not a connector, it's a special type of component. It's special because it is not called directly, it does not have a visible interface; instead, the interceptor will "listen" to the communication and will intercept messages/calls/events of interest. In the example I mentioned (JS component talking to a REST service), an interceptor could intercept the http calls for monitoring, logging, routing, message transformation, security controls. 

4. "Firstly, connectors physically decouple communicating components, in the sense that components depend on connectors but connectors do not depend on components."  The level of coupling actually varies based on the type of connector. For example, an EJB client component will use the EJB-specific RPC connector to call the EJB component. That EJB client is tightly coupled to the EJB. OTOH, if a Java component sends a message to a JMS queue and there is another Java component that consumes messages from that queue, these two components are indeed decoupled because of the presence of the message queue connector. 

5. "In the third part we apply connectors for structuring a system whose development follows the DevOps methodology."  I'm thinking much of what you call connectors is actually about interceptors. A DevOps strategy asks for health and performance monitoring that is visible to Devs as well as Ops. Much of that functionality is achieved by interceptors often provided by tools such as API gateways, zabbix, etc. 

I'm being picky wrt the use of core architecture concepts, but your talk seems pretty sound and valuable.

user.name: Joachim Fröhlich, Florian Krautwurm, Markus Lachenmayr

feedback.body:
Dear Paulo,

thank you for your valuable feedback.

While not able to address all your points, we have improved the talk description, in particular regarding connectors and the interceptor pattern.

We focus indeed on physical connectors, first-class citizens in the software architecture. Reduced to the minimum, a connector in our practice only contains one or more related interfaces (types) without implementations, and a somewhat special factory.
As the name suggests, interfaces are between components. Interfaces do not belong to the components communicating through interfaces, locally or remotely, sequentially or in parallel. In fact, we argue that interfaces rather than components carry component-based systems of any kind -- not just of distributed systems or of systems that rely on generalized middleware (component frameworks) containing or enabling interceptors. These thoughts should point out particular properties and advantages of "our" connectors and some differences to interceptors and to Aspect-Oriented Programming as well. 

We will compare and contrast related work, views, and approaches in the new fourth part of the presentation. It will reference the work of SEI on Component-and-Connector Views, Shaw and Garlan as well as that of Schmidt et al. and others.

Kind regards.

talk.title: Continuous Integration: A Lost Art
talk.description: Continuous integration (CI) is a development practice that we fell in love with, embraced and then never fully committed to. Based on research my team and I conducted in 2016 I’ll share with you the current state of CI, what development teams think they are doing when they say CI and what they are really doing in terms of CI. Then I’ll remind us all why we fell in love with CI in the first place and make some suggestions on how to get back to the important parts of the practice.

talk.title: Continuously Cooking: Our Path to Continuous Delivery
talk.description:
Four years ago, The New York Times launched NYT Cooking, a cooking-specific vertical showcasing 165 years of New York Times Recipes. That Rails Monolith is still in use today, delivering recipes, guides, and how-to videos to millions of users a month. 

After three years of legacy and working on a deprecated infrastructure, we were lucky if we shipped once every few weeks, and even then often led to deployment failures. Since then we've gone from shipping our monolith with very our fingers crossed to shipping every day with confidence. We'll look at how we changed our development practices, improved what and how we test, and automated our workflows. We'll also examine some of the unique enterprise concerns around continuous delivery and how we adapted and evolved our process so our engineering team works in tandem with design, and product to ship as often as possible.

Intended Audience: Developers, DevOps people who are working on complicated/large scale applications and haven't been able to recognize the benefits of continuous delivery. Audience members should walk away with some actionable takeaways about how they can ship faster, and how they can sell shipping faster to the rest of their organization.
talk.abstract: It's easy to continuously deliver a relatively simple app with low traffic, but the stakes get a lot higher when you have millions of users and four years of legacy code. We'll talk about how NYT Cooking has gone from shipping stale code every few weeks to shipping fresh code everyday.

We estimated that dealing with rebasing, keeping track of all the open PRs etc, was costing each developer on the team an hour of their day (basically costing us an entire person on our team of 8). talk.title: Continuously Validating Architectures in an Agile Centric World
talk.description:
Architecture validations are a key component of the software delivery life cycle, and they are essential to the successful implementation of modern IT systems. Architecture validations are becoming part of the processes used by IT groups to ensure software quality, and architecture review knowledge, reference materials and trained resources are becoming increasingly available. 
Continuous customer feedback is the best way to validate a software product and indirectly its architecture. Unfortunately, the system needs to be fully delivered in order to get that valuable feedback, and the cost of adjusting a software architecture after the system has been delivered is usually very high. The objective of the architecture validation techniques we describe in this presentation is to ensure that the future system meets its business objectives and quality attribute requirements, without slowing down the pace of delivery associated with Continuous Delivery.
Architecture validations deal with far more than just the technical issues, since business drivers are a key force in shaping an architecture. One of the key benefits of continuous architecture validations is that they periodically review the relations between business goals and architecture. As a result, they ensure that the system is designed, built and delivered in a way that provides the greatest benefit for its stakeholders.
This presentation describes how our approach can be leveraged to validate architectures in any type of project, and especially in a Continuous Delivery project.  First we define what we mean by Architecture Validation. Then we focus  on when to conduct Architecture Validations. We then discuss the roles required in an Architecture Validation. We finally detail how we can conduct architecture validations by describing some industry recognized techniques such as questionnaire-driven approaches, scenario-based approaches (including SEI's ATAM) and decision-based approaches (such as DCAM).
In order to illustrate the concepts introduced in this presentation, we will use a real-life example of Continuous Architecture Validation, showing how various approaches can be combined to effectively validate a project.
talk.notes:
Murat Erder (Deutsche Bank, London) will be a co-presenter. This presentation builds upon our presentation on Continuous Architecture at SATURN 2016, and is the result of significant research and practical and extensive experience in this field. Further details can be found in our "Continuous Architecture" book (Morgan Kaufman, Nov 2015), and especially in Chapter 6 of that book.
     
The tentative outline of the presentation would be as follows:

1. Introduction: Why do we need to continuously validate the architecture? ***Note: this section will introduce a case study which will be used throughout the presentation to illustrate the concepts 
 
2. What do we mean by ‘Architecture Validation’?***Note: this section will introduce the concept of Continuous Customer Feedback

3. When do we need to validate the architecture?

4. Who should validate?

5. How should we validate?

    a. Checklist-driven architecture validation

    b. Scenario-Based architecture validation

    c. Decision-Centric architecture validation

6. Summary & Recommendations
talk.abstract: As the pace of innovation increases, IT groups are using agile approaches & short release cycles to deliver systems rapidly. As a result IT architectures evolve quickly and validating architectures a few times is not enough. We are presenting a new approach for continuously validating architectures.
