talk.title: Crowdsourcing Software Architecture – The Distributed Architect
talk.description:
Software Architects need to have it all: exceptional technological know-how, up-to-date programming experience, good people skills, ability to abstract, knowledge of important architectural styles and tactics, visionary leadership a.s.o. It has always been difficult to find all of these aspects in a single person. Modern development efforts set in highly dynamic, agile contexts and the emergence of polyglott technological environments make it even more challenging.

This talk introduces alternatives to the classic role of the software architect that showed a boost in delivery speed, overall product quality and organizational flexibility in real life projects of various domains: 

* The work without formal architect roles
* The idea of ‚marshals‘ for architectural concerns or important drivers and 
* A variant of the architecture owner role

All of them do well in an agile project setup and embody a distributed approach of handling architectural concerns. Important factors for choosing between these approaches are shown as well as the core concepts that make them effective even in more complex environments - including low viscosity design, architecture communities and tests of quality attributes.
talk.notes:
This talk can be held as a *short introduction* (30 mins) or as an *interactive tutorial* with one or two small exercises (90 mins), which ever fits the conferences schedule best.

All of the concepts I present are field-tested. I wrote a published book on agile software architecture in 2013 (for the renowned German publisher 'Carl Hanser') that also covered the agile view on the role of the software architect. Since 2008 I worked with companies like Lufthansa, Volkswagen, Postfinance, Hamburg Süd and others in agile transformation initiatives to establish these role ideas that are presented and illustrated in real-life examples.

It has always been difficult to find all important aspects of an architect in a single person. Highly dynamic, agile contexts and polyglott technological environments make it even more challenging.

feedback.body:
Stephan-

This is an interesting topic, but I have a question:
There is a long-held idea that an architecture should have conceptual integrity, and that this comes from having a single architect or small, tight group create the architecture. Your approach challenges this, and I would like to see some comment in your talk about it. Is conceptual integrity not important? Or is it over-interpreted, and you have a lighter-weight definition that works in practice? Or is it possible to achieve conceptual integrity with a distributed architect (and if so, what is the key)?

Thank you.

Hi John,
Thanks for your comment and yes, conceptual integrity is an issue we have to tackle in our projects frequently. In this talk I discuss integrity on several levels: 

First, not all of the alternatives I present are actually a departure from persons or small groups driving the architecture. "Marshalls" are typically accountable for a cross-cutting concern spanning the whole system or big parts of it. They look after integrity in architectural approaches assotiated with security, performance or recurring technical problems with infrastructure etc. So the classic architect is splitted, but not in a functional fashion as the system itsself.
Also the approach of an architecture owner encapsulates important topics in one person. In this case it is a person with general overview, experience and a broad vision. He is more of a mentor and rises important topics. He isn't the one who decides and designs everything though. This is mapped to a team where he has the same possibilities and tools as everyone else. Conceptual Integrity is an important driver for him though. 
Only one of the presented options goes without a person or team explicitly and foremost responsible for the architecture. 

Second, the integrity of a system has big advantages in productivity, maintainability and derivatively in reliability, security and so on. Nevertheless it comes at a cost and many modern systems see conceptual integrity as a scale, where the maximum is not the ultimate goal. We could for instance define a minimum of common ground that works for a given project. Could be the deployment model, the general structure, the monitoring and security approaches and some interface standards. Inside these general rules a team could in fact develop solutions that are structured very differently and possibly use other technologies than other teams of the same project. Of course this poses problems in reusability and the other areas stated, on the other hand the teams can act on their own and usually deliver value faster. If the architectural drivers and the context allow it, a little less integrity could be optimal for a project.

Third, even without an architect that predefines approaches and tactics we were able to achieve a good level of architectural integrity. Integrity is driven by a good engineering process, broad architectural knowledge, experimenting developers and some kind of "natural selection process". This selection process includes that good solutions are broadcasted to all teams and their adaptation is made easier. Bad ideas or the divergence from a known best practice should be harder to implement. In the acstract I call that "low viscosity design". Architecture then focuses on the identification of good approaches, the support of their communication and the creation of space to abstract good solutions and make them more universal. This is another form of architectural work as the "standards-first" approach, with arguably lower conceptual integrity, but often faster innovation, better flexibility and more realistic architectural concepts. A combination of top-down and bottom-up architectural approaches is a good fit for most projects I work on, low viscosity can shift the boundary a little in the bottom-up direction without causing direct chaos.

All of these topics are introduced in this talk, not all of them are covered in great detail. I am open to shifting the focus of the talk a bit if certain aspects sound very interesting for you. The 90min version will have a deeper look and also an exercise on some veto-mechanisms we use to broaden the accountability but not lessen the influence of good architects.

Thanks,
Stefan

Thank you for accepting my talk for SATURN 2017! Very happy to be part of this great conference again.
It would be great if my talk fitted the schedule on Tuesday or Wednesday (2nd or 3rd of May) as my travel arrangements from Europe get quite complicated otherwise.  Would that be possible?
Thank you,
Stefan

talk.title: Deep Learning for Software Development
talk.description:
How can we apply machine learning (and visualization) to aid software development - specifically, software developers? While there is some work in this field, most of it has been devoted to metrics and estimates. Metrics are shadows of snowflakes, and thus not particularly informative when seeking to understand the purpose of a system or the behavior of a component. Improving estimation, while an interesting application and a laudable goal, likewise does not directly help developers create better software faster, nor manage the growing complexity of real-world systems. Can we apply ML in ways that help guide development, inform software archaeology, and reduce effort for developers? If so, can these things help us take on the systems-of-systems-of-systems of the future, where million-line code bases will be considered "quaint"?
After a brief survey of existing/past work in the area, we'll investigate the question of "what does software look like", examine the more interesting question of "what does good software look like", and use these insights to explore how we can enable developers to create and manage ever-larger software systems. No ML experience or math required. Lots of pretty pictures.
talk.notes: I've been research the applications of AI/ML/DL to software development, and experimenting with some unique approaches specifically intended to aid software developers, including the notion of 'semantic drift' (the 'distance' between classes and stories in semantic space) and topic-based clustering of software subsystems as a guide to refactoring. This talk avoids complex math, instead offering an intuition for how the main deep learning approaches work and why they work, includes a lot of pretty pictures, and outlines some future directions in software development principles and practices.
talk.abstract: Most of the AI breakthroughs in the last 4 years have been the result of deep learning; but what, if anything can deep learning do to help software developers?

feedback.body:
Hi Steven, this talks looks interesting and extremely timing given the recent ML and deep learning boom.  It looks like this will be more an "gentle" introduction to deep learning with an emphasis on things software engineers can (should?) do with deep learning to make better software, which I think would be appropriate for SATURN.

I have a couple of quick follow-up questions for you.

* Are you going to highlight or show any specific tech?
* Do we need to design software systems differently to take advantage of the techniques and approaches you'll discuss?
* Have you applied these ideas with teams working on "real" software?  It's OK if this is still in the "interesting idea" stage -- SATURN would be the place to get more people thinking about it.

Thanks for your submission!

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael!

Thanks, I'm glad you like it! To your questions -

- I will show some of the 'semantic drift', clustering, and visualization work that I've been doing, which *should* be open-sourced by the time of the conference
- re 'design systems differently to take advantage of the work': yes and no :) Using latent semantic analysis on software systems works best when the software source code uses relevant words from the domain (otherwise the software just talks about itself, i.e. what it is doing in stead of why it is doing things); the more domain knowledge/model/words that are embedded in the code, the better. I am explicitly using domain-driven design structures (bounded contexts, context maps) married with semantic visualizations (topic maps derived from natural language processing word-vector vocabularies) as a yardstick for what "good" software looks like .
- yes. My work in this area started because of a real problem: trying to quickly understand a 2-million-line codebase. I have applied earlier versions of the tools to real-world projects (e.g. mapping 72,000 stories and 8,000 classes into the same semantic space), and continue to do so. However, the purpose of the talk is not to present something as 'solved', but to introduce developers and architects (et al) to the intriguing possibilities in this space (which are largely unexplored) and to encourage them to get involved.

Thanks!

--S

talk.title: DevOps, architecture, and security in a cloud
talk.description:
The success of your DevOps team depends on the collaboration between developers and cloud operations teams, maturity of development processes, security architecture, guiding software architecture principles, and the ability of the team to automate the delivery of software and infrastructure to customers. These factors along with the infrastructure management and integration challenges will be amplified in a cloud or hybrid environment. 

In this presentation, we will describe our DevOps implementation plan from inception to cost management; share our operation automation practices, security guidelines for cloud-based services as well as solutions integrated with on-premises systems; compare deployment automation options and high availability solutions based on 2 container management approaches; review our software choices that include packages provided by several vendors (Amazon, Microsoft, Dell, and others) and open source software such as GitHub, Artifactory, Jenkins, Docker, Kubernetes, etc.

At the end we will summarize challenges we faced during the course of this initiative, positive impact on the organization, and DevOps roadmap in 2017.

UPMC Enterprises is the commercialization arm of UPMC with approximately 220 employees. At UPMC Enterprises, we both develop and invest in exceptional health care technology. Our portfolio includes 7 health information technology companies and several ongoing initiatives. Our current cloud footprint consists of 12 non-production and 8 production environments managed by 11 members of the Client Services team.
talk.notes:
Last year we worked out an all-encompassing plan for the DevOps initiative at UPMC Enterprises.  The materials of the ‘DevOps and Continuous Delivery: Practices, Architecture, and Security’ workshop presented at Saturn 2016 were used as a foundation for the plan. We have completed 2 phases of this effort addressing the security, continuous deployment/delivery, and integration requirements with minimal architectural debt. 
Due to the nature of the UPMCE structure our development environments have diverse infrastructure, development tools and platforms. They often combine building blocks that come from the AWS cloud as well as UPMC data centers. 
In this initiative we leveraged packages provided by several vendors (Amazon, Microsoft, Dell, and others) and open source software such as GitHub, Artifactory, Jenkins, Docker, Kubernetes, etc. 

This presentation will include the following topics
-UPMC Enterprises goals and objectives
-Overview of UPMCE development and client service environments 
-Major sections of the DevOps implementation plan: application infrastructure management, application infrastructure monitoring, application lifecycle management, cloud infrastructure optimization, information management and governance
-Security in a cloud
-High availability and container management
-Overview of software packages and tools
-Lessons learned and roadmap

talk.title: Django & Twitter bootstrap in the workplace: build 'em fast and furious
talk.description:
The modern web developer has an unenviable task. Users have become familiar with popular web applications, and expect perfect uptime, bug-free experiences, simple and intuitive UI, and perfect security. Fortunately, the proliferation of high-quality frameworks for virtually *everything*—front-end, back-end, infrastructure—has made the job of the developer significantly easier. In this talk, I'll outline how my team used Django and Twitter Bootstrap to build a complete production reporting solution in under three months. These tools are incredibly powerful and can save you hundreds of hours of work.

We'll also discuss the trade-offs associated with training, and the impacts of choosing to train your team extensively or more sparsely on the tools you develop. The decision on training turns out to be more nuanced than you would expected.

Specifically, we'll discuss:

talk.title: Enterprise IT - How to avoid mediocrity
talk.description:
Enterprise IT organizations attract and foster mediocrity. We argue that this is one of the fundamental reasons that keeps large enterprises from outperforming leaner organizations even though they have greater resources on hand.

This talk describes a fictional (albeit slightly inspired from reality) organization with huge cultural problems, and takes it to the extreme to illustrate how bad it can be and how it came to be this way.

Half of the time will be spent on describing the mess we're in and how we got there, the other half on possible ways we could have avoided this situation and possibly how we can get out of it in a culture that shuns firing people (which perhaps would have solved it in part).

Our premise is that a solid culture of learning and continuous improvement as well as a focus on good software architecture and practices could have prevented the mess, and that it is not to late to turn it around.

I promise an entertaining talk with a lot of humor (albeit of the dark kind), and possibly some insights that you can take back to your organization so that you don't end up in the same mess (if you aren't already there).

__Key takaways from this talk:__

* Architecture governance is key to combat technical debt
* Continuous focus on learning can help avoid the knowledge rot that often comes with a mediocre software group
* The Dreyfus model of skills acquisition and the Expert beginner.
* The common fallacy of tuning your corporate messages, governance, and technology choices for the mediocre or the underperforming, and thereby alienating your best performers.
talk.notes:
I have been spending much of my time in the resent years contemplating the challenges of a large organization, and I have recently gotten some insights that I would like to share with the SATURN audience. This is partly an experience report in the guise of humor and satire, basically an attempt at making light of a very serious and very real problem that I have experienced in our own organization.

I think there is a clear leadership story in this, and it pertains both to political leaders (management) and to technical leaders (software architects). A big part of the solution to the problem is the focus on good software practices and software architecture, which is where I see the main relevance for the SATURN audience.
talk.abstract: In our presentation "What happens when you break all the rules?" from a couple of years ago we stated that "large enterprises attract and cultivate mediocrity".  In this talk I will outline why this is the case, and suggest some measures that large organizations can take to avoid this phenomenon.

talk.title: "Failure" as Success: the Mindset, the Methods, and the Landmines
talk.description:
"Failing fast," "failing forward" and "Learning from failure" are all the rage in the software and tech industry right now.

The tech company "unicorns" seem to talk endlessly about how they reframe failure into success. And yet, many of us are still required to design and implement backup system capabilities, redundancies, and controls into our software and operations processes. And when those fail, we cringe at the conversation with management that will ensue.

So is all this talk of reframing "failure" as success within our organizations just that: talk? And what does that look like, anyway? We'll explore mindset, the history it's rooted in, as well as effective methods to move your organization toward it and some land mines to avoid along the way.

Specifically, we'll cover:

* The history of incident/accident modeling
* What safety science research has to do with IT and large-scale Internet operations
* Methods and strategies to facilitate your organization embracing and learning from failure
* Methods and strategies for conducting "blameless postmortems" after an operational incident
* Methods and strategies for introducing resilience engineering into organizational and technical design and operations.
* Various pitfalls organizations fall into when working on reframing failure
talk.notes:
This CFP is for a 90-minute tech talk.

Included in it is a review of techniques for "blameless postmortems," which is relevant in the context of software and Internet infrastructure operations; we also talk about the history of the safety sciences, and why they are more applicable to software and software architecture than one might think.

This talk also includes interactive audience exercises, where they get to interact with me and each other (though, not enough to make what SATURN defines a "participatory session")
talk.abstract: What do Internet operational incidents and software architecture have to do with aircraft carriers and chemical plants? What is this "blameless postmortem"-thing we keep hearing about? talk.title: From REST to gRPC: An API Evolution Story
talk.description:
The APIs for components in fine grained service-oriented architectures strongly influence the eventual properties expressed in the system.  REST over HTTP is a popular choice for microservices APIs because it promotes openness, self-discovery, and simplicity.  One alternative to REST is [gRPC](http://www.grpc.io/), an implementation of Protobuf.  As an RPC-based API, gRPC inhibits openness and self-discovery but promotes performance and, depending on the implementation, can provide stronger compile-time (or at least call-time) guarantees which help developers avoid mistakes.

In this talk we will share our experiences migrating a REST-based microservice to gRPC, as well as lessons learned implementing gRPC APIs in a suite of backing microservices for the Watson Discovery Service.

By the end of this talk, attendees will know

* What gRPC is and how it is different from REST
* How to organize code to make API transitions easier
* The benefits of functional testing using Cucumber and tips for creating extensible gRPC API tests using Ruby
* How to implement common REST patterns in gRPC
* Common pitfalls for using gRPC in a microservices architecture and some solutions
talk.notes:
This talk will have the following tentative outline.

1. Set the stage / Context
     * What my team was building
     * Why switch to gRPC?
2. Our architecture evolution plan
     * Spike -- gRPC prototypes and plan our transition
     * Phase 1: Design gRPC API, influenced by the current REST API
     * Phase 2: REST + GRPC
     * Phase 3: Transition functional tests written in Cucumber with Ruby
     * Phase 4: Remove REST functionality
3. Spike
     * What is gRPC?
     * Example with code
     * Required tools
     * REST facade was a bust
4. Design gRPC API
     * Killing the hypermedia dream
     * REST is not RPC -- need to rethink resources and relationships
     * One request, one response
     * Everything is optional
     * Impossible to send bad values: choose types wisely
     * New constructs: repeated, streaming
     * Enum names
     * method and message names
5. REST + gRPC: run two servers side-by-side
    * Spring boot: seemed like a good idea at the time...
    * Layers worked extremely well
    * Health checks
6. Transition functional tests
    * We implement functional tests in Cucumber and Ruby, quick example and benefits
    * Transition plan allowed us to run tests against gRPC and REST endpoints, useful for incremental evolution
    * Tips for testing gRPC endpoints using Ruby (meta programming FTW!)
7. Remove REST Functionality
   * As simple as deleting the REST API package
   * We were able to fork the microservice into a REST facade.
8. Microservices governance concerns: and our solutions
   * Usability tests are important
   * Health checks
   * How will you discover APIs?
   * How will you manage and version `.proto` files?
   * Documenting APIs (REST has standards and more tools)
9. Conclusions
   * Classic example of an architecture evolution
   * Classic example of how clean abstractions in static structures (layers in this case) can make it trivial to deal with certain kinds of change
   * gRPC practice is still emerging, we covered several useful patterns and our approaches to some common problems.
talk.abstract: An existing REST-based microservice.  A new requirement to use gRPC.  A team under pressure to ship.  In this talk we will describe how we moved backing Watson Discovery microservices from REST to gRPC and the lessons we learned in the process.

talk.title: Functional programming invades architecture
talk.description:
A few decades ago when the first architecture books were being written, today's large-scale web systems were an oddity but now they are mainstream.  Our architecture pattern languages have changed as have our development, deployment, and operating procedures (DevOps).  

During this transition, one source of ideas has been the functional programming community.  Functional programming itself mostly happens within a module and indeed many software architects treat it as an implementation choice, unrelated to architecture.  But it turns out that some ideas from the FP community are helpful in architectural design: statelessness, immutability, and pure functions.  They underlie DevOps practices and are at the core of many distributed systems patterns at the core of our architectures.

## Why now?  
Functional programming ideas have been around for a long time but conditions are ripe.

1.  Coping strategy for complexity.  As systems get bigger but our brains stay the same size, we invent tech to cope.  Statelessness, immutability, and pure functions make it easier to reason about how a system behaves.
2.  Problems grew in size.  No single computer big enough to run a system.  FP ideas suited to parallelism and concurrency, so many smaller computers can solve big problems.
3.  We have more money than sense.  You can buy 100 cloud machines for less than one junior developer.  So why not do Continuous Integration with every source code commit?  Why not have a farm of servers running different versions of your code during deployments?  Why not burn RAM with immutable data structures?

## Functional ideas in modern architectures

1. Client-side.  Reactive patterns and frameworks.  Eg React, CycleJS, Elm.
2. Server-side.  So-called "serverless" pure functions.  REST architectural style.  Reactive services.  Event queues between services.
3. Persistence.  Append-only datastores.  Event sourcing & Command Query Response Segregation (CQRS).
4. Batch sequential & pipeline architectures:  Big data processing (Hadoop, Spark), Map-Reduce, Tensorflow and other machine learning graph-based functional transformation.
5. Devops infrastructure.  Version control everything (append-only).  So-called "immutable" and "idempotent" infrastructure set up by running code, not by Linux admins.

## Reactive programming
1. What is it?  Evolution of Observer pattern.  Observable = Observer pattern plus onError and onCompletion.  Hot and cold streams.
2. Use in UI architectures.  Strong competitor to Model-View-Controller and sibling patterns.  

## What you will learn in this talk
The amount of innovation and hype in web technologies is intense and often overwhelming.  If you haven't been staying current, this talk should give you a mental map to start your learning.  If you have stayed current, this talk should reveal how functional ideas weave throughout modern web architectures and perhaps provide insight into why they work.

The talk surveys how modern web systems are built with FP patterns.  It will dig into one client-side example and show how FP ideas can simplify this task.
talk.notes:
I propose this as a 30-minute tech talk.  I can scale the material to fit into 22 mins + questions.

I have plenty of material so I'm happy to do a 90-minute tech talk that digs into more details if you think the topic is sufficiently interesting.  90-minute slots are rare at SATURN, so I don't want to presume.  

If you think 90 minutes is better than 30, please consider this as a participatory session.  If the audience is really new to FP ideas, it can take time to see how to accomplish work using these patterns.  There is a great game we could play a few rounds of ([Cube Composer](http://david-peter.de/cube-composer)) to warm them up (go ahead and try it now).  Then we could design a system using event queues and discuss the quality attribute tradeoffs, or go further into the UI reactive example.

talk.title: Get management attention and transform your software: communicating architecture with value proposition design
talk.description:
Getting the right attention and setting priorities for development projects can be hard, especially now that many product businesses try to adapt to a world of online services and new revenue targets. As an architect you understand the value of all the tasks on your backlog but limited budget and deadlines force you to prioritize. 

Inspired by the Strategyzer book, we have applied value proposition design to build transformation plans for some of ASSA ABLOY Scandinavia's software products. We profiled our customer's jobs and pains and try to match these to values enabled by our software products. Gaps between the stories of our customers and the functionality in our software help us to prioritize our backlog and build a plan that our sales and business colleagues understand.
talk.notes:
Strategyzer's business model canvas and value proposition design books gathered a large following in both start-ups and businesses reinventing themselves. The customer jobs concept core to their customer profile translates easily to Scrum and UX design stories. Customer pains and gains may translate to quality attributes or stories. Therefore, Strategyzer's tools should get a place in the architect's silver toolbox. 

The value proposition design book came out in 2014 and to the best of my knowledge it has had limited or only modest coverage at SATURN. The presentation will be based on my experience in applying the concepts on two software products at ASSA ABLOY Scandinavia. The material has not been presented before. 

## Learning objectives
After the talk the audience should

* have a basic understanding of the Strategyzer business model and customer value proposition canvases
* understand the relevance of Strategyzers tools to architecture practice for collecting business drivers and requirements
* be able to judge when to apply the Strategyzer tools

## Rough outline
* Problem statement: turning products into services
* Introduction to Strategyzer business model canvas
* Introduction to Strategyzer value proposition canvas and design method
* Story of how we applied Strategyzer's value proposition design at ASSA ABLOY
* Summary of lessons learned
talk.abstract: Overcome lengthy backlogs and tight development budgets. Win over your stakeholders by talking about how to deliver customer value quickly and iteratively. You'll learn how to use Strategyzer's value proposition design method to prioritize and communicate your development plan.

1. One may look at the description and ask: 'Sounds promising. But we use scrum/agile development in a low ceremony way. Would this work for me?'  So, is this approach applicable to Agile development? With small co-located teams and short sprints? 

2. If I had to guess, I'd say that profiling the jobs and pains of the customers takes time and requires some modeling and documentation effort. My feeling from experience is that developers will not be very keen on doing that. How much automation can be employed in this process? How long does it take? Is it hours in facilitated meeting with stakeholders like in  QAW or ATAM?

3. I see the value of the approach for companies that sell software products or products with software. Would it be equally attractive to enterprise IT? I work in enterprise IT for the government in an environment where this statement is not very appealing: "build a plan that our sales and business colleagues understand". 

(In the Notes you can use a blank line to make PaperCall render separate paragraphs.)

Hi Paulo,
Thank you for taking the time to write feedback! Let me give a short reply to your comments.

1. It could very much be applicable, the products I used this on have only a handful of developers. As written it can help decide what to do first during sprint planning. It would mostly be a tool for the product owner/architect though. SATURN is also an architecture conference, so some planning effort should be ok.

2. With three-four people knowledgeable about our business it took half a day to profile two customer groups in sufficient depth. Strategyzer very much encourages quick and iterative development of products. The methodology builds on posters with sticky notes and a whiteboard, tools I believe are popular in Agile teams.

3. I work both with products and enterprise IT, so I believe I understand your concern. Yet enterprise IT also has customers, the business. Business users also have jobs that they try to accomplish for our company. Business decision makers are economic decision makers and thereby a customer that wants something done efficiently. The methodology explicitly encourages you to distinguish between different types of customers, e.g. end-user, economic buyer, influencer, decision makers.

I'll work on the lay-out when I have access to a real keyboard again.

I hope this helped you understand the message and potential value of the talk better!

Thijmen

profile.name: Christopher Phillips
profile.bio: I have seven years of traditional software application development across a variety of languages and technologies. I have written distributed, highly available, resilient systems for CNN (including the system used to schedule and perform all of their video ingests worldwide), and have spent the last two years championing and leading the development of Serverless applications at Stanley Black and Decker's Digital Accelerator, as well as helping migrate existing legacy systems to be Serverless where it makes sense.

talk.title: Going Serverless: Building Production Applications Without Managing Infrastructure
talk.description: With the release of AWS Lambda and API Gateway, it has become possible to build RESTful interfaces without managing any server infrastructure. Leveraging this and other AWS services, it has become possible to build entire business applications in a secure, scalable fashion, without provisioning VMs or taking on the system administration tasks that entails. There has since been quite a bit of buzz around 'Serverless' development, with entire frameworks and tooling built to support such an approach. This talk is intended to discuss what the tradeoffs of taking such an approach are, how to technically execute on such an approach within AWS, and what my own experiences have been in building and running Serverless applications in production.
talk.notes:
90 minutes

As the backend tech lead at Stanley Black and Decker I have led the development and deployment of multiple applications into production that rely entirely on Serverless backends, along with a hybrid legacy app that we are currently moving toward being Serverless. 

I intend to cover the basics of building REST interfaces on top of the AWS API Gateway and AWS Lambda, delve into the tradeoffs of doing so, and then branch out into methods and considerations of data storage, access control (including authorization/authentication of users to your REST endpoints and other resources), continuous integration and development, messaging patterns (both solely on the backend, and between the backend and various user clients), backend generated events and triggers (i.e., responding to scheduled events, or building in logic to trigger additional behaviors outside of the context of a user request), and various best practices and considerations I've learned from my experiences.

In the course of this talk I will touch on the place of the following AWS services in a Serverless solution - Lambda, API Gateway, S3, Dynamo, RDS, Elasticache, IAM, Cognito, STS, SQS, SNS, IoT, CloudFormations, Cloudfront, Route 53.

The intended presentation mechanism is predominantly slides, with links to code and Cloudformations to illustrate less obvious implementation strategies  (i.e., not "here's how to write a record to DynamoDB", which is easily gleaned from API documents, but "here's code demonstrating the usage of the AWS IoT platform as a websocket for sending arbitrary messages across", or "here's an example Cloudformation for setting up an existing lambda to execute periodically, and to include a dead letter queue to report errors to". In general, my goal is not to give an end to end working example of everything I discuss (as that will be impossible to go over in detail in the time frame, and will be exceptionally contrived), but instead to go over enough to give people a high degree of confidence in speccing out their own projects, while also providing code or walk through an example for anything that did not strike me as inherently obvious on how to implement from glancing at AWS' documentation. 

Tentative high level outline - 

1. API Gateway and Lambda - demonstrate a Serverless endpoint, wherein we can see arbitrary code execution in response to an HTTP POST, in the context of a Lambda, which simply parrots back the body and one or two headers, to show how they can be mapped into the function. Discuss using the API Gateway as a passthrough to an existing REST API, to allow for the swapping out, endpoint by endpoint, to a serverless one, in the event of a legacy app.

2. Data storage options - largely high level discussion of considerations between Elasticache, DynamoDB, and S3 as storage mechanisms, in terms of cost, ease of use, and availability/consistency guarantees.

3. Backend processing and user notification - Discuss lambda event sources and their implications (the ability to trigger lambdas from writes to Dynamo or S3, a brief foray into SQS as a distributed queue, and how things can fail, and what to do about them). Demonstrate using AWS IoT for websocket pushes to web clients (and mention GCM and APNS as still being available for pushing to mobile). Discuss SNS as an option to broadcast events to custom HTTP endpoints, or to send emails, as well as a possible way to send mobile push messages.

4. Access Control - Discuss Cognito as an Amazon provided identity provider. Demonstrate how to go from a Cognito identity (or a custom identity, if using custom code to log someone in) to a set of temporary AWS credentials, that can be used to access resources. A brief foray into IAM policies (which control what a set of AWS credentials have access to). And how to leverage both IAM and AWS credentials to properly secure one's own REST API endpoints.

5. CI/CD - Discuss some of the frameworks for developing and deploying serverless code to AWS. Demonstrate an example using the Serverless (http://www.serverless.com/) framework. Demonstrate Cloudformations as a way to define and port infrastructure between environments. Suggest the use of AWS Config and Cloudtrail to track changes. 

6. Monitoring - Dive into Cloudwatch. Demonstrate executing lambdas, navigating the resulting logs, exporting to S3 for ingesting into another tool. Demonstrate available metrics, and how to set up alarms. Discuss integration points with tools we've used.

7. Latency and Cloudfront- Discuss latency of lambdas. How real it is, how to mitigate it, when to cache. Demonstrate setting up a Cloudfront instance in front of custom API, and when to use it vs the API Gateway's cache.
talk.abstract: This talk is to introduce Serverless computing, a new paradigm in the cloud for deploying applications that requires no server administration, and which scales transparently in both function and cost. My goal is to equip the viewer with enough knowledge to be comfortable trying this approach.

feedback.body:
Hi Christopher,
Thank you for the submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. The first sentence of the description implicates a causal relation that I believe doesn't exist ("With the release of AWS Lambda and API Gateway, it has become possible to build RESTful interfaces without any server infrastructure in the cloud").  One can build REST interfaces for enterprise systems on-premises for the intranet, without AWS Lambda or API Gateway. In any case, if you're using AWS Lambda, I think you *are* using cloud infrastructure, you just don't need to procure/manage/be aware of the servers.  

2. In the notes you say "I intend to cover the basics of building REST interfaces." Do you mean REST API design? That's a quite large topic on its own.  

3. In addition to benefits, I think you should also discuss the challenges and drawbacks of serverless architecture. Such discussion flows naturally into motivation for and risks associated with serverless. 

4. A 90-minute long talk takes the time equivalent to 3 30-minute talks, so the info should be clearly valuable. Serverless is a hot topic this year and many people want to know what it is, if it's a good fit for them, what's the roadmap to 'go serverless'. I think your talk goes over all of that. Do you intend to talk about serverless outside AWS? For example, simple use of MBaaS for mobile app authentication?  

5. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

6. What is "event pipelining"? Is there a more commonly used equivalent term? Maybe a term that's in wikipedia?  :^)

7. Just to clarify, what's the presentation mechanics? Slide-based presentation end-to-end? Or do you plan  to have a demo? Or is it a tutorial where participants will actually use their laptops to play with the technology?

Thanks so much for your input! I've endeavored to clarify much of what was indicated; on a point by point basis - 

1. Clarified.
2. Clarified.
3. That was very much the intent, to include complications/issues, what can be done about them, and when it makes sense to not go Serverless - in the description I mentioned 'discuss what the tradeoffs of taking such an approach are'; should I word things differently or elaborate there?
4. My intention was to focus on AWS; as part of that, I intended to discuss Cognito, AWS' mobile identity provider, along with how it provides STS tokens, themselves associated with IAM roles, and how those are used across AWS to access services directly, and can also be used to control access to individual API endpoints. That was my intent with mentioning access control in the description; does that need to be called out in the notes, or more clearly spelled out in the description?
5. Added
6. Clarified
7. Added in Notes.

Thanks for updating the submission. 
3. I think there's no need to word things differently or elaborate.
4. I think description and notes are ok as is. There are talks about serverless at a more conceptual level and others are more technology-specific. Both "kinds" are welcome and valuable. I just wanted to clarify.

talk.title: High-Performance Multi-Threaded Immutable Store for C++
talk.description:
We present an architecture for collaboration between loosely-coupled actors that share their state using an immutable store and a publish-subscribe pattern. This is different from the well-known [Actor model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actor_model) (Implemented for C++ in [[1]](https://github.com/actor-framework) and [[2]](http://www.theron-library.com/index.php)), which uses private state and peer-to-peer messaging, and is closer in spirit to the [Flux application architecture](https://facebook.github.io/flux/docs/in-depth-overview.html#content) and [Redux](https://github.com/reactjs/redux), with its single dispatcher and its unidirectional data flow.

Our data model is suitable for high performance and complicated algorithmic flows, where multiple threads require access to shared objects. We have implemented it in C++, and used it successfully as the application framework for the [iTero intra-oral Scanner](http://www.itero.com/en) (See demos [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_kYPyjUtbU) and [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tWuNPt33tho))

###Our architecture is based on the following principles:

1. All shared state is immutable and reference-counted
1. Each actor keeps a lightweight snapshot of the state, which consists of references to shared immutable objects
1. Actor snapshots are eventually consistent
1. Actors communicate using [Publish-Subscribe pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Publish%E2%80%93subscribe_pattern)
1. A single dispatch function is used for publishing both events and data updates
1. Persistence, replay, undo and application logging are handled by generic mechanisms
1. Objects can be marked as *invalidated*, allowing immediate, out-of-band signaling and cancellation of long-running computations
talk.notes:
##Primary track

I propose this talk for the track **"Development Tools, Frameworks, Techniques, and Patterns"**, because it introduces a new framework while referring to existing frameworks and patterns - the Actors model, Flux and Redux. The talk will be highly technical, with diagrams, code and a demonstration video. 

##Session type

This talk falls in the category of **"Technical Talks and Tutorials"** or **"Experience Report Presentation"** (30 minutes), because it is a highly technical presentation, based on my own experience and knowledge. The architecture framework I shall describe in the talk is one that I pioneered and developed, and it forms the basis for the application that drives the [iTero Element](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mdI5Pp2dVTg), a leading 3D intra-oral scanner for dentistry and orthodontics. The iTero software was developed under my technical leadership, as a chief architect and lead of the algorithms group. 


##About me

I have a Ph.D. in mathematics, and plenty of experience giving lectures. I have given 14 talks in international math conferences, including 2 Siggraph talks ([Siggraph 2006](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1141990), [Siggraph 1999](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=311541)). After 15 years of leading algorithms teams, I decided 4 years ago to become a software architect. Since then, I got a Software Architecture Professional Certification from SEI, and I have been constantly studying and teaching various domains of software engineering.

I am highly passionate about software architecture, and I love teaching software engineering and mentoring developers, as well as coding in multiple programming languages. See [My LinkedIn profile](https://www.linkedin.com/in/adi-levin-0a0a614).

I am also the submitter of a second talk, with the title **How to gain influence as a software architect**.

##Talk outline

 1. Present the challenge we faced
  - Show video and give a description of the [iTero intra-oral Scanner](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mdI5Pp2dVTg)
  - Explain the data model we use in earlier versions of iTero, and why it was inadequate for the new product
 1. Present the basics of the architecture
  - Define an "Actor"
  - Explain how actors access data and communicate via a dispatcher: All of the shared state is made of immutable data, and any modification is done by creating a new object, and broadcasting it
  - Explain the data model (each actor keeps a key-value dictionary, where the key-space is shared, and the values are pointers to reference-counted objects in the heap)
  - Explain about publish-subscribe and event handlers
 1. Explain how this architecture is different from the famous Actors Model
  - Provide links to existing implementations [1](https://github.com/actor-framework), [2](http://www.theron-library.com/index.php).
  - Explain how our model is based on shared state and publish-subscribe, while the Actors model is using private state and peer-to-peer messaging.
 1. Discuss more aspects of the architecture
  - Separation of concerns: Actors are responsible for message-passing and fetching data from the shared state, and they delegate computations to other objects that are tested in isolation
  - How an actor is created: the role of the dispatcher in making sure that a newly created actor has access to the most up-to-date state
  - A generic solution for persistence
  - Cancellation of long-running operations
  - Generic logging
  - A generic Record/Replay feature
 1. Discuss design trade-offs, and pros & cons of the architecture
  - Pros: Safe concurrency, and ease of implementing complex logic
  - Cons: Data model is flattened into a key-value dictionary, losing a natural hierarchy
 1. Shortly discuss a possible improvement of the data model
  - Use a persistent tree structure (as in [Redux](https://github.com/reactjs/redux)), instead of a flat key-value store, to restore the natural hierarchy of objects.

feedback.body:
Hi Adin,

Thanks for your submission.  Actors and actor systems are an important architectural pattern that have been around for a while but seem to have gained more traction in the past few years with the rise of frameworks such as Akka and an increase in distributed systems.  I like that this talk explores a hybrid pattern that combines actors, pub-sub, and peer-to-peer.  That is certainly an interesting combination and just hearing the thought process that led to the architecture design could be illustrative.

Here are a few thoughts for your consideration on how this abstract and tentative outline might be improved.

* Skip the video and get to the value as soon as possible.
* If the context of a specific project is important, this should be moved to the experience reports track instead of tech talks.  It looks like this is the case so I assume this is an experience report.
* I didn't see a clear discussion of the motivation. Why would someone what to use actors and pub-sub in this way?  What is the rationale behind the design decisions that were made?
* Sections 4 and 5 could use some tightening.  I like the discussion of trade-offs but section 4 seems like a general bucket of ideas.  If accepted please think about how this section can be organized to better convey your message.

One thing to think about: one are the top 2 or 3 things that someone who attends your talk should be able to do that they couldn't do before?    The answer to this question might help you find the right way to organized the latter parts of the talk.

Regards,

Michael

Thanks for the review, Michael. 

As you proposed, I will be happy to make this an experience report, and explain the thought process that led to our design.

I will make sure to clarify the motivation (indeed the outline I gave doesn't explain the motivation): The short video I want to show (approximately 45 seconds) is important in order to show the system in action, to provide context: I want the audience to understand what an intra-oral scanner is, and the speed at which it works, building a 3D model and providing feedback to the user in real time, with low latency (<200 milliseconds). This requires multiple threads to access large amounts of shared data for generating scans, refining them, repositioning them, rendering them and storing them to persistent storage - all simultaneously. This is why we chose to design a system where shared state can be accessed safely by collaborating threads. Pub-Sub was chosen because of the high complexity and the data-driven nature of the design (e.g. rendering is triggered when an object is changed, without the producer of the object having to communicate with the rendering actor; denoising and filtering algorithms are triggered when a new scan is created; etc...). Do you think this clarifies the motivation?

In answer to your comment about sections 4 & 5, I think I'll tighten this discussion by removing a couple of items from section 4 (the first two, probably), and incorporating the rest of them into the trade-offs discussion, showing how these aspects are added benefits: For example, the pub-sub nature, together with the dispatcher, enables a generic record/replay feature (like in Redux), and similarly, generic solutions for persistence and logging.

What will attendees be able to do that they couldn't do before? They will be able to implement a data model that supports efficient and safe sharing of memory in a multi-threaded application. This is useful for complex systems. Also, they will learn the benefits of channeling all writes through a single thread (dispatcher), which provides total ordering of messages, and is one way of ensuring consistency in concurrent systems.

WIth kind regards,

Adi.

talk.title: How to gain influence as a software architect
talk.description:
The best software architects combine strong creative and analytical skills, with the character traits of a leader. An architect needs to form collaborations with different teams, often with different styles of working and planning, in order to clarify the project's scope and requirements, and then design the architecture and implement it.

To achieve this, an architect needs to use all communication tools effectively: Meetings, architecture drawings, written documentation, design reviews, code reviews and informal conversations. In every opportunity, an architect should encourage the engagement of other stakeholders and must learn how to deal effectively with their concerns, and, in particular, how to deal with opposition and with conflict.

But communication techniques and technical excellence combined are not sufficient for sustainable effective leadership. To gain trust and credibility, one has to display consistent personal values and character ethics, and build relationships that are based on integrity and commitment.

In this talk, I will share with you my own experiences and lessons learned from years of working as a software architect in a global organization, and from studying dozens of the greatest writings from the field of business, leadership and communication.
talk.notes:
##Primary track

I propose this talk for the track **"Other topics of interest"**, since the lessons learned here are applicable to a wide range of circumstances, and are not related to any technology or software trend.

##Session type

This talk falls into the category of **"Experience Report Presentation"** (30 minutes, describing first-hand experiences and lessons learned). It is entirely based on my own experience, and the lessons I have learned in the past 4 years working in a global organization, gaining the trust and cooperation of stakeholders of all kinds.

##About me

I have a Ph.D. in mathematics and plenty of experience giving lectures. I have given 14 talks in international math conferences, including 2 Siggraph talks ([Siggraph 2006](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1141990), [Siggraph 1999](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=311541)). After 15 years of leading algorithms teams, I decided to become a software architect, 4 years ago. Since then, I got a Software Architecture Professional Certification from SEI, and I have been constantly studying and teaching various domains of software engineering. In addition, I have spent numerous hours studying the literature on leadership, personal growth, effective communication and influence, and I have successfully applied the techniques and principles to my work.

This will be my first talk in an international conference on software architecture. I created this talk after years of successful technical leadership in a global organization, gaining credibility with many people from remote locations and from various disciplines, in domains where I was often not an expert.

I am also the submitter of a second talk, with the title **High-Performance Multi-Threaded Immutable Store for C++**.

##Main theme

***Collaboration is power; Be genuinely interested in the concerns and challenges of others; Include them generously; Act with integrity***

All of the stories, insights, and tips that I share have the above theme in common. For example: When talking about effective online meetings, I share how useful it is to reflect people's concerns in writing and in real-time, as a way to verify that their concerns are understood correctly, and to give them the feeling that they have been heard; When naming components, I recommend to include others in choosing their names, as a way to encourage their collaboration; For dealing with opposition, I recommend to focus on a better understanding of the opposing party; On dealing with difficulties, I emphasize that this is the time to make extra efforts and display personal integrity, by being there for the developers, and by admitting and correcting one's own mistakes.

While those messages are all relevant to any leadership situation, I believe they are especially useful for software architects, whose effectiveness relies upon their ability to form a collaboration, often without the benefit of a position of authority.

##Talk outline

The talk will be filled with personal stories and examples from my own experience. The audience will be given a set of techniques that anyone can implement and principles that anyone can follow.

1. Challenges facing a software architect (based on my own experience):
  * Remote teams
  * Some teams not communicating well with one another
  * Teams not used to working with a designated software architect
  * Stakeholders from very different time zones
  * Different cultures of different teams; different levels of agility
  * Poorly documented legacy systems that need to evolve
  * Different opinions about whether to build or to buy
  * Unclear project scope
  * Unclear requirements
  * Stakeholders with prior commitments, who don’t have time to spend on your project
  * Tasks that require designing a kind of system that you have never designed before
1. How to recognize that you have influence?
  * Your designs come to life
  * People ask for your advice on various projects outside your area of responsibility
  * People want you to help them resolve disagreements
  * People tend to accept what you propose
  * People are copying your documentation style
  * People welcome your participation in meetings on any topic
1. Effective meetings (especially remote meetings)
  * Different kinds of meetings require smaller or larger groups
  * Declare the goal of a meeting
  * Publish agenda and slides up-front
  * Phrase questions to be answered during the meeting
  * Capture people's comments and opinions in writing and display in real-time them during the meeting
  * Finish in time, and share meeting notes with people
1. Effective architecture views to bring out the essence of an architecture
  * Depending on the audience, it is often better to present a simple and concise drawing, as opposed to complete sets of architecture views
  * Define names of components/modules/classes and their responsibilities. The other things follow from that. 
  * Naming something is an act of leadership. Declaring the name that someone else chose is even stronger. 
1. Use written documentation - this is especially important in a big and global organization
  * Writing is hard for people, so there’s an opportunity to stand out here
  * Make information accessible
  * Become the source of information by summarizing it better than others do
1. Encourage the engagement of others
  * Seek the subject matter experts and do 1:1 discussions with them
  * Look for opportunities to incorporate the ideas of others. If you accept someone’s idea, they will be more understanding next time you reject one of their ideas. 
  * Look for opportunities to show honest appreciation to other people’s contribution
1. Dealing with opposition, rejections and unknowns
  * If someone opposes an idea, ask questions about it - don’t just insist - regardless of how strongly you feel about your solution
  * Never get attached to a design. Recognize that there are multiple solutions and analyze both the benefits and the cost of any design decision
  * Seek first to understand, and only then to be understood 
  * When it is not clear how to make progress, phrase specific questions to be answered and ask for people's help
1. Build personal relationships with stakeholders
  * Get to know people on a personal level
  * Seek opportunities to show your appreciation
1. Be there for developers, after handing off the design to them
  * There will be unanswered questions and difficulties
  * Be there in weekly meetings and sprint planning
  * Notice the conversations between teams, and help where it's needed
1. References to literature
  * [5 levels of leadership by John C Maxwell](https://www.amazon.com/Levels-Leadership-Proven-Maximize-Potential/dp/B005SA65DI)
  * [The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People by Stephen R. Covey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_7_Habits_of_Highly_Effective_People)
  * [How to win friends and influence people by Dale Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_to_Win_Friends_and_Influence_People)
  * [Benjamin Franklin's autobiography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Autobiography_of_Benjamin_Franklin)

feedback.body:
The talk outline seems long for the time available (30 minutes). If you need to shorten the presentation, I suggest dropping or shortening topics 1, 3, and 8. 

This sentence is not OK to me: "Depending on the audience, it is often better to present a simple and concise drawing, as opposed to complete sets of architecture views."  Here's how I think (based on "Documenting Software Architectures: Views and Beyond, Second Edition"): 
- a software architecture is described as a set of architecture views. There isn't a single diagram that shows everything.
- you should only create an architecture view if it has clear value to stakeholders (the audience for the software architecture).
- a given architecture view may consist of a simple and concise drawing. 

The following sentence is not clear to me: "Declaring the name that someone else chose is even stronger."

In the talk outline, item (4) recommends: "Define names of components/modules/classes and their responsibilities. The other things follow from that."
I think having expressive names for software elements is important, but that recommendation alone is not very helpful. In fact, item (4) is about effective architecture views and there are so many important recommendations under this topic, such as:
- Use a notation key in your diagrams (or indicate what standard notation you're using).
- Use different symbols for different types of elements and relations. 
- Use consistent symbology across diagrams. 
- If you're using a pattern in your design, name it. If the reader is familiar with the pattern, he/she will understand the design more easily.
- Use a template (standard organization) for your documentation. In particular, use the same template for all architecture views. (Subsections in a template may be N/A of course.)
- Keep the information up-to-date. If you can't update the documentation, discard, archive or mark it as out-of-date.
- Complement structural diagrams (e.g., UML class diagram) with behavior diagrams (e.g., UML sequence diagram).
- Record the rationale for important design decisions.
- Avoid ambiguity; write from the reader's point of view; review the documentation. 
These recommendations can be found in the book I mentioned above ("Documenting Software Architectures: Views and Beyond, Second Edition").

Typos:
- Notes: "trust and cooperation of *of* stakeholders"
- Notes: "Capture people’s comments *opinions* in writing "

Thanks for the thorough review, Paulo. I am going to use it to improve the presentation, and I am taking this opportunity to clarify my proposal.

My emphasis in this presentation will be on the human relations aspects and how they affect the level of influence of a software architect. 

Your comments about the architectural views are correct, and I should rephrase my intent: All of the architectural views are important for reasoning about a system's structure. I am not presenting a different theory of documenting software architecture, but I am commenting about the way in which I would present those architectural views to different stakeholders. In presentations, we often don't have time to go through all of the views; also, we may do it in a more constrained environment of online remote meetings, so we need to focus on the things that yield the most understanding and buy-in from the stakeholders. 

In this context, I claim that naming and stating the responsibilities of a component or a module, is of especially high value.  The list of responsibilities is a concise representation of the intent of the designer, which helps stakeholders review the architecture and ask good questions about it (e.g. "if this component is only responsible for X, then how come it depends on Y"?).

One way to make the most out of architectural discussions is to find opportunities where other people contribute. A very powerful application of this is when we name software elements. By asking someone else: "How would you name this component?" and accepting the name that they offer, we make them our partners in the project. Similarly, if someone proposes a modification and we accept it, we gain more of their their cooperation, and it will be wise to give credit to the contributors. 

My plan is to share other insights of this kind. This complements the more technical aspects of analysis, design and documentation, with wisdom that comes from the realm of leadership, effective communication and personal growth, and I have lots of relevant stories from my personal experience, which I think will be highly beneficial to the audience.

Indeed, I will need to shorten some of the topics - and I will shorten topics 1 & 3, as your proposed. As for topic #8, this is one I would like to emphasize, because my main point is how personal relationships make a difference.

With kind regards,

Adi.
Paulo - I also fixed the two typos you indicated. Thanks for this!

Hi Adi,

Thanks for your submission!  Overall I like the content and practical lessons in your outline, though I do agree with Paulo that it seems a bit long.  There is a lot of good lessons here!  But, focusing on 2-3 or so core lessons is about all the audience can take in 30 minutes.  You might be able to group or "chunk" your ideas in a different way to make them easier for the audience to digest.

What is the context of your experience?  Context is important for understanding how broadly applicable your lessons are.  For example, how big is the team?  What sorts of systems were you designing? Things like that.

Regards,

Michael

Hi Michael. Thanks for the kind words and for your review.

Here is my context: I have been leading, and am still leading the technical design of a number of projects:

1. An application for a 3D intra-oral scanner (http://www.itero.com/en) - there were ~20 developers working on it, divided to 4 teams in two locations (Israel and Moscow). Made of C++, C#, high performance algorithms and 3D graphics, interacting with proprietary hardware and real-time components.

2. A HIPAA-compliant, scalable and highly available cloud-based storage system distributed in multiple data centers with integrations to ~10 applications. Involves ~6 development teams from 4 locations (East coast, West coast, Israel and Moscow), and other stakeholders from 3 more locations. Made of Java, NoSQL database, public cloud storage, REST API, caching layers, custom replication and workflow management, and a challenging data migration and transition strategy.

3. A scalable and highly available cloud-based architecture for enhancing web applications by server-side algorithms, with interactive-rate messaging between the web page and the dedicated server-side process. Involves 3 teams from 2 locations + stakeholders from 2 more locations. Made of Java, Websocket, REST, elastic cloud-based cluster, with fully automated deployments.

4. (Currently in early stages:) A cloud-based service for capturing, storing, displaying and manipulating doctor prescriptions. Emphasizes modifiability. Made of React, Java REST API, and document-oriented DB in the cloud.

I am also involved in multiple other projects related to identity management & authentication, cloud-based workflow management, storage, data analytics, cluster computations, and others.

----------

Regarding your main feedback: You're right - my presentation should focus on a few key messages. I think those will be:

1) Ways to get other people more engaged - this includes effective meetings, especially long-distance on-line conference calls, in which I have plenty of experience and success. For example, I want to demonstrate how I capture and display people's comments in real-time, and how satisfying this is to the participants: They know they are understood, and they know their opinion is heard, even when it is not accepted; Another example is getting people involved in the early stages of giving names to components.

2) Ways to deal with difficulty and opposition: being open to others' ideas; listening, and truly caring about the concerns of others; not being attached to a specific solution, and being ready to challenge your own ideas; This doesn't mean giving up on good design solutions: It means that you should be willing to explain both the advantages and the trade-offs in the design, not in order to defend it at all cost, but in order to truly search for the best solution, thereby laying the foundation for better collaboration in the future, regardless of whose opinion ends up being accepted.

3) Building long-term credibility. "They don't care how much you know until they know how much you care" - show commitment by being there when things are not clear, by allocating time for review and demo sessions; by providing specific feedback on detailed design decisions; by being there when teams disagree and need someone to resolve the dispute; by showing the appreciation and giving credit generously to others; And by admitting and correcting your design mistakes as soon as those come up.

I will also give useful references to literature, where people can learn more about influence & leadership.

----------

On a personal note: I attended Saturn 3 years ago. It was one of the best conferences I have ever attended, and I still remember some of the great presentations (Especially the keynotes by Dianne Marsh and Joe Justice; The course by Robert Wojcik; Scott Hanselman's great talk; And others...). I will be honored and deeply excited to be among this excellent group of speakers.

This talk is not finalized yet. I have so many stories and references to share. I am planning to use the reviewers' feedback, and to do my absolute best to make this a great presentation worthy of the high level of this conference.

Thank you for your submission. Your talk covers many "soft" skills that are critical to architecting. The examples in your notes are clear and concise.

Thank you for the thorough outline - very helpful for evaluation. You're packing a lot into 30 minutes though. The risk is that it goes by so fast that audience members don't absorb it all or well. I'll second the thoughts of Paulo Merson and Michael Keeling that you should consider trimming the outline.

I've nothing to add to the great advice they've provided. I wanted to comment to encourage you to refine the talk based on their comments (which it seems you are doing!) because I feel these people-oriented parts of architecting need attention. And we, as a community, can do more to help each other. (Paulo and Michael are great contributors to that so their comments are valuable.) This talk can be especially helpful to people who do not have readily available mentors or other architects within their organizations.

Thanks for the review and feedback, Anthony. I will use your input to improve the talk. 

I shall definitely refine the outline and trim the content of the talk, as you proposed, and in line with the feedback of Paulo and Michael. I know how to do it, because I know I am focusing on the people-oriented parts, and, in particular (as mentioned in my response to Michael): Practical ways to get other people more engaged; Practical ways to deal with difficulty and opposition; and building long-term credibility. These are my clear guidelines for the detailed design of the presentation. 

In particular, I will probably drop the documentation-related topics, trim the part on effective meetings (as Paulo proposed) and will not dwell on the challenges part (people know well their own challenges, right?).

talk.title: How to Perform a Rapid Assessment of any Software Architecture
talk.description: As a software architect for your organization, you may may be required to efficiently and effectively evaluate the validity, quality, health and/or maturity of a proposed, new or legacy software architecture. This presentation suggests a simple process you can follow to perform a rapid assessment of any software architecture effort regardless of its size, complexity or stage of development. The focus is on capturing the most critical aspects of the software architecture including: (a) Software Quality Attributes; (b) Key Architectural Decisions (including hardware platforms, software technology, development tools and reuse strategy); and (c) Architectural Design (primarily in the form of Unified Modeling Language or UML). Emphasis is placed on identifying and documenting references to existing artifacts. It generally requires an interview with the most knowledgeable software engineer on the proposal, development or maintenance team to identify the location of artifacts that are available and information that has never been documented. This is basically a two-day process. On the first day information is gathered and quickly recorded. On the second day, the information is analyzed, expert opinion(s) formulated, and a report is prepared and disseminated to all of the relevant Stakeholders. The process is a simple and straightforward mechanism for capturing software architecture and rapidly performing a valuable assessment during any time in the lifecycle of the product.
talk.notes:
This process is one that I developed at Raytheon for my own use as a software architect. It is my responsibility to periodically review proposed, new, and existing software architectures across the organization to maintain a consistent understanding of the validity, quality, health and maturity of our products. 

A questionnaire with the following outline is used to ensure all topics are considered in the process.

The applicable roles are as follows:

2. Software Technical Lead provides information
3. Software Architecture Review Board examines the report and recommends actions

It's a two-day event that requires about 24-32 hours of effort.

The process has been used for over a year on a half dozen projects to date.
It's so simple and affordable that there have been few challenges to hamper the process.

Michael

talk.title: It can be done! Growing an Architect's Community - My Journey
talk.description:
Passionate individuals and businesses both try to create successful Communities of Practice (CoPs) for myriad reasons from honest desire to networking to a financially driven goal of sharpening worker skills. Why do some well-funded effort fail while rag-tag start-ups succeed? In this session, hear the story of my struggles and successes to grow a networked community of architects that now stretches across the globe. There is no single formula to creating a successful community. If you've got passion and take the time to really ask "Why?", your journey is starting off on the right foot! Choose vision driven techniques over old-school mechanics to jumpstart new groups or resurrect ailing ones. Attendees will talk away energized and ready to try a few of the techniques that worked including:
  • Sowing the seeds – Organic communities, whether jump started by a corporation or a hobbyist, tend to have the greatest growth and staying power. How and where to sow community seeds positions a community for possible success.
  • What are the success attributes of a boom? – How to define success and using qualitative and quantitative measures to detect a bust.
  • Value, Brand, and Localization – Communities thrive when there is ownership at all levels and pride. Understand how value definition impact a community’s charter and how building a brand provides community members with a sense of empowerment and worth.
  • Agile concepts for community leadership – Transparency, communication, and continual evaluation/reprioritization of next steps can situate community leaders to react nimbly to change and protect community health.
talk.notes:
When I joined Deloitte Consulting, there was a rag-tag group occasionally sending out an email newsletter that went straight into everyone's trash. I've taken that community of less that 40 to nearly 500 globally. While this could easily be a 30 minute session or longer, I want to energize my peers at SATURN to rethink how they are caring for and feeding their architects. I've won multiple national and global awards from Deloitte around my community building approaches. Interestingly, the journey includes needing to pivot and find ways to engage those smart millennials. Learning Outcomes: Participants will walk away energized with ideas for organizing and nurturing successful architecture communities:
  • Techniques to sowing organic growth
  • How to defining success attributes and what are associated measurement techniques
  • The impact of top-down support versus and bottom-up drive
  • Principles for defining value and brand for a community; understand the impact of localization on a community or chapter
  • Suggestions on applying agile techniques at the leadership level
talk.abstract: Growing a community is tougher than it looks!  There isn't a magic formula. There are tips and tricks from my journey building an international architect's community.  The big enabler? Asking "why" and staying true to that guiding principle.  Let's get the word out to the folks that care at SATURN!

ratings.comments:
This is a talk that I would like to see.  Building effective communities of practice is an important topic for architects because working in isolation seems to be an occupational hazard.  

I would have liked to have seen some of the other work in area referenced.  Authors have already proposed good frameworks for community development so I don't think we need to invent new ones.

Instead I hope the speaker will focus on sharing her experience at Deloitte and sharing the lessons she has learned while building the community there.
