talk.title: Keep CALM and Architect On:  An Architects Role in DevOps
talk.description:
The key concepts in DevOps are CALM:  Culture, Automation, Lean, and Measurement.  How does an architect support the transformation to DevOps in the 4 CALM areas?
Culture: Removing silos, reducing fear of making mistakes and encouraging learning and experimentation
Automation: Changing the architecture to support dynamic infrastructure, automated deployments and automated tests
Lean:  Structuring capabilities and features to deliver higher value in smaller batch sizes
Measurement:  Architecting to expose, aggregate and route the right data for monitoring, analysis and trending 

In this presentation, we'll talk about patterns, interactions and behavior that architects will want to consider to keep CALM in the face of DevOps.
talk.notes:
I.	How does one keep CALM?
II.	Architect’s Role in Culture change
   a.	Ever wonder what happens after you throw something “over the wall”?
   b.	Cross functional team support
III.	Architecture Patterns that support Automation
   a.	Deployment – Infrastructure as Code (IaC), Versioning configurations
   b.	Test – Using Code Seams, Test harnesses,  Change Impact Analysis
   c.	Dynamic Infrastructure – Infrastructure as a Service, Auto-scaling, Stateless SW 
IV.	Getting Lean
   a.	Requiring Experimentation (Working with leadership to build in HW resources and schedule)
V.	Architecture Patterns that support Measurement
   a.	Microservices with metrics support built-in and accessible with the endpoint
   b.	CI/CD Integrated Code Coverage
   c.	Measuring spikes to determine experimentation
VI.	Conclusion

We'll talk about patterns, interactions and behavior that architects will want to consider to keep CALM in the face of DevOps.

talk.title: Method for Business Function Allocation and Interface Definition in System-of-Systems Architecture .
talk.description:
System-of-Systems in Roche Diagnostics context
==============================================

Certain business processes in medical diagnostics areas involve many large scale systems (million connection points) distributed through Roche enterprise and customer clinical laboratories. The involved systems fulfill valid purposes in their own right, can operate separately and are managed for their own purpose rather than the purposes of the whole.

Allocation of business functions to specific system components and definition of interfaces with significant consequences for architecture of such large and complex IT and software system-of-systems (SoS) is a challenge. It requires data supporting decision criteria and accommodating fast evolution of the architecture in the agile organization.  

Roche Customized Method of Architecting SoS 
===========================================

For the architecting of the system-of-systems in Roche product context a customized method was defined based on the US Department of Defense Architecture Framework.

This method involves 6 steps with start/finish criteria and deliverables for each. I will illustrate these steps using examples from Roche.

1.  Business process Domain Analysis (identification of Business Drivers, Business Capabilities, Business Functions, Constraints, elaboration of User Stories and Workflows, definition of Quality Attributes).

2.  Integrated Dynamic Modeling (IDM) for multiple workflows within the business process.

3.  Derivation of Events, Activities and Resources for each workflow IDM.

4.  Alignment to elaborate Common Events, Common Activities and Common Resources for all modelled workflows.

5.  Identification of existing/overlapping/missing functionality (based on Activities) and data and processors (based on Resources) in involved systems. Preliminary allocation of the functions to the systems and verification of fulfillment of Business Criteria (based on Domain Analysis).

6.  Architecting of data, process, deployment, … models and preliminary design of interface between the involved systems.  Verification of Quality Attributes fulfillment.

This method can be applied in agile projects, if the sprints are oriented on implementation of workflow.

Results of application of the method at Roche
=============================================

The customized method for the architecting of system-of-systems was applied to business processes related to Remote Solutions and IoT. It led to quick definition of models and derived data supporting the decision making and allocation of business functions and resources to existing and to be developed systems as well as identification of common resources and interfaces for their exchange.

talk.title: Microservices and Docker at Scale: the PB&J of Modern Application Delivery
talk.description:
Docker has matured, and is expanding from being predominantly used in the Build/Test stages to Production deployments. Similarly, microservices are expanding from being used mostly for green-field web services to being used in the enterprise - as organizations explore ways to decompose their monolith to support faster release cycles.

Running microservices-based applications in a containerized environment makes a lot of sense – both for Build and Test, as well as from a runtime perspective in Production.

Docker and Microservices are natural companions, forming the foundation for modern application delivery. However, managing microservices and large-scale Docker deployments pose unique challenges for enterprise IT.

This talk discusses the modern requirements for building, deploying and operating microservices on a large-scale Docker-ized infrastructure. It covers:

• Patterns for microservices-based architectures
• What makes Docker such a good fit for microservices
• How to operationalize Docker orchestration, auto-scaling and DR in large-scale Production environments – recommended typologies and patterns
• Best practices for Docker configuration and registry management to ensure consistency throughout the pipeline and stability in Production
• Tips for integrating containers into complex existing environments, supporting the hybrid state of microservices and monolithic applications
• Tips and tooling for monitoring and managing clusters of containers as a single distributed application
• Putting an end to Shadow-IT: how can IT enable Dev and Ops to use Docker for both microservices and traditional application releases - while ensuring visibility, security, governance and compliance
talk.notes: This talk was developed as a joint session with Electric Cloud CTO, Anders Wallgren: Anders Wallgren is chief technology officer at Electric Cloud. Anders has over 25 years’ experience designing and building commercial software. Prior to joining Electric Cloud, he held executive positions at Aceva, Archistra, and Impresse and management positions at Macromedia (MACR), Common Ground Software, and Verity (VRTY), where he played critical technical leadership roles in delivering award winning technologies such as Macromedia’s Director 7. Anders holds a B.SC from MIT.

talk.title: Micro services architecture - lessons learned
talk.description:
The speaker works as Director of Software Engineering at Capital One. In this talk, he will share lessons from implementing microservices architecture for a regulatory initiative.

The talk will focus on –

- What are the business drivers for the microservices architecture?
- What are the lessons we learnt from an architecture perspective?
- Why Devops practices are important?
- What cultural and software engineering best practices help?
- What are the communication imperatives when you are building an enterprise microservice?
talk.notes:
I am a Director of Software Engineering at Capital One. My focus in on Marketing and Decisioning Technologies. I am in their Richmond, VA location.  I lead a team of 70 engineers developing architecture, building APIs and devops platforms. Over the last couple of years we built several mission critical APIs most of them are for customer facing and highly regulated capabilities. We learnt a lot breaking a monolithic application into micro services. I led delivery of several enterprise APIs and deployed into production. Hope to share my experiences in the session. I will also have some time for questions and answers at the end. The talk should last for 30 min.
I will be explaining the following success factors and considerations

Why did we go with micro services?

The initiative that I led was a regulatory project for Know Your Customer (KYC) regulation. It has very tight timelines and dependencies across the organization. The best way we could have accomplished the timelines is to go with a microservices architecture. So the business drivers for microservices architecture are

- Ability to break the solution into manageable micro services and have small teams solve them. That increased the speed of development by taking advantage of public cloud, strong devops, and automated testing
- To drive accountability and ownership in a cross enterprise initiative
- We also wanted to break some capabilities away from a monolithic application that was getting difficult to change

So, it is the business imperatives that drove us towards the micro services architecture.

In general, if it is a differentiating capability for the business (say credit decisioning for a bank) and agility is important, microservices approach helps. If it is not a differentiating capability like payroll and HR, better stick to a vendor product.

Architecture:

- When re-architecting a monolithic application, we achieved better success starting with the head (or customer facing functions) of the monolithic application. As we get deeper there will be more dependencies making it difficult to decompose the application.
- It is important to Identify the business capability and design the contract accordingly. The architecture should be aligned with product owner and it should clearly articulate the problem the specific micro service is solving.
- Use domain driven design as much as possible. It is important to define the domain and the bounded context for the micro service. This also helps to define the granularity of the micro service. If the service is too big, it replicates the monolithic. Maintainability and agility should be kept in mind while designing the micro service. Our definition of a bounded context was driven by the following:
  - Autonomy of the domain, its business context, and self-contained data store without need for replication across microservices
  - The domain is simple to explain
  - In one instance performance dictated its domain. We separated a high performing calculation engine as its own microservice and developed it in GO language.
- Architect should focus on the API contract, interplay of micro services, and ensuring the non-functional requirements are met. It is important for the architect to know where to stop in the design
- What you design for real time may not work for batch. We first designed the microservices for real time first with a requirement of low throughput. But when we started using the microservices for batch use cases that had a higher throughput requirement, the infrastructure design did not work. So, we had to tune and scale up the microservices.
- While building individual microservices was easy, orchestrating the services wasn't easy. We built Java orchestrations, but very soon the orchestration services became too big to manage. We are experimenting with reactive frameworks.

Devops :

- Benefit of micro services is speed of development. Unless the code migration and deployment is automated, it is difficult to manage a micro services factory
- Automate integration testing and performance testing. We built automated testing for individual APIs, but did not build automated integration scripts. That became a bottleneck at the end as we had to do manual testing.
- With micro services, there will be frequent release. Hence, doing blue green deployment helps to minimize the down time
- A cloud first approach works better for micro services
- ATDD is a mandatory practice for micro services

Best practices and culture:

- Encourage Small teams of 4-5. If a micro service takes more than 1-2 developer to understand fully, it is too big and will become unmanageable
- Encourage pair programming
- Encourage knowledge sharing. Leverage demos to ensure teams get the big picture. Otherwise, developers will know only their micro service and miss the big picture. We moved away from separate production support teams. Teams support what they build. When we deployed the microservices into production, initially it was difficult to support as developers did not have the entire architecture context.
- With small teams, teams slowly have to graduate to full stack teams that can do everything the micro service needs.

Communication to stakeholders:

- It is important to communicate to clients often and in detail. Write a blog and publish every detail
- Version management is critical
- Contract first design helps in better communication

Other practical considerations

- Level of granularity is very important. Be ready to redefine and re-architect often as you go along
- It is impossible to have a separate support team to whom you hand off the micro- sevices after they are built. The eco system gets more complex for some other team to own manage. integrate support into delivery teams
- Alerting and monitoring is extremely important. Automate to the extent delivery teams spend less than 10% of their time on production support

talk.title: Our journey to Continuous Delivery
talk.description:
The journey to continuous delivery (CD) is long, winding and always evolving. We thought we had achieved all we could with continuous delivery and then... something changed. We soon realized that we weren’t doing all we could to continuously deliver our products. Come learn from our experiences moving on-premise products to the cloud and iterating between monoliths and micro-services to get better at continuous delivery.  

This is a practitioner-focused experience report sharing two different experiences with continuous delivery. I will start the talk by defining CD, talk about the underlying practices and cultures needed to get started, share the two experiences and finish by sharing some tips for attendees to leave with.
talk.notes:

talk.title: Pragmatic Architecture, Today.
talk.description:
Software development has evolved. Agile is now the de-facto standard. The role of an architect in an agile project is very different than the typical role in a more classic waterfall approach. Using an updated interpretation of ‘viewpoints and perspectives’, this talk will demonstrate how to make rapid, agile delivery sustainable in a constantly changing world. These viewpoints and perspectives will be linked to easy-to-produce models that can be used immediately in your projects. The talk will provide examples on how to determine which models are architecturally significant and worth the effort.

Developers have always been very important stakeholders of an architectural description. A good agile architect needs to strive for consensus and buy-in.
talk.notes:
Software architecture has a bad name. Developers often think that architects have no feeling with the actual application that they're building .. Sometimes they're right. But having no architecture is also a recipe for disaster.

I want to present a model (observe-orient-decide-act or OODA) with feedback loops that can lead to better quality software. Sharing ownership, making the architecture valuable for everyone is necessary to deliver successful software products. I've been using this approach for multiple projects and want to share how architecture, change and development methodologies go hand-in-hand.

Outline:
- What? (theoretical)
- Really? (practical, attractive example)
- Visual? (tips & tricks, focus on change)
- Why? (how much up-front, greenfield vs. existing)
- How? (OODA)

1. The relation between agile development and architecture work has been examined and discussed for a decade. I'm curious to see your OODA approach. Indeed, I think you should name it in the talk description and make sure it is well described in the talk. 

2. As a sanity check, ask yourself if the approach works well for geographically distributed and/or outsourced teams. Also ask if it requires developers who are well versed in software design (in addition to architects who can code of course). 

3. Years ago I gave an interview to InfoQ. One of the questions was exactly about the topic of your talk. I'll reproduce here my answer. It's just food for thought for preparing your presentation...  

"It is a well known misconception that agile development means no documentation. In fact, as a [survey shows](http://www.ambysoft.com/surveys/modelingDocumentation2008.html), agile teams are more likely to model than traditional teams. A few things that agile architects (or perhaps any software architect) should remember: 

The key aspect of design/modeling in agile projects is not to avoid designing, but to avoid "big-design up-front" (BDUF). In general, high-level architectural strategies should be worked out up front, but many design decisions and design details can be left to when you need them. 

Only produce design documentation that will fulfill a need of the stakeholders. Stop designing as soon as you're ready to start coding. In the next sprint you can expand/refine the existing design as needed in order to capture design decisions required by next sprint's features. 

If it's not worth updating the design, throw it away. Some design diagrams are used to guide implementation, but at the end the code sometimes looks different from the diagram. If you don't have time to update the diagram to reflect the implementation, it's better to remove it than keeping an out-of-date diagram that may confuse a future reader. 

Many times, sketches are all you need. Don't spend too much time crafting the neatest diagram using the latest and richest notation available. Don't spend too much money on sophisticated modeling tools if you just need a drawing tool. In many agile projects, especially the ones with small, co-located teams, the true value of design diagrams comes from drawing them, which forces you to think through the issues; once the issues are solved, the diagrams lose much of their value. Many times the design is represented as a sketch on a whiteboard or piece of paper. If the sketch can be used to successfully convey the design to the team, that sketch, as is, can be *the* diagram in your architecture view. Why not?"

talk.title: Quality metrics: Nutritional Labels for Code
talk.description:
Software is an increasing part of our everyday lives. From the phones we carry, to the cars we drive, the thermostats that regulate our homes, even our lightbulbs - software is everywhere. But how much do we know about it? How secure is the banking app you use? What bugs might turn your home into a tropical paradise during your next winter trip? How convoluted is the code that runs your car? The last plane you took? The last traffic light you went through?

As consumers, we take nutrition labels on food for granted. A few simple, standard numbers let us make smart choices about the food we consume. Similarly, quality numbers should be routinely available for software, which is omnipresent and unavoidable in modern life. As consumers, we should have the data to make smart choices. After all, candy bars will only kill you slowly. Bad code could kill you very quickly.
talk.notes:
This is a lightning talk.

I work for SonarSource SA, the company behind SonarQube, a FLOSS platform to measure and monitor code quality. The purpose of the talk is not to flog the product, but to talk about why all software should be analyzed (by _some_ product) and the results published. But because it is easy (and the product is free!), I will propose that the 3 ratings from the SonarQube quality model be published: Reliability, Security, and Maintainability (Best Practices). Those ratings take the form of letter grades, which should be understandable to the general public. Teaching them _why_ they should care will take more time, but become more and more obvious as we're all able to correlate software failures with low ratings.
talk.abstract: Nutrition labels give us the chance to make smart choices about the food we consume. But there's no data to help us make smart choices about the software we consume. Quality metrics are easy to collect and should be just as universally available as nutrition labels.

talk.title: Refactoring with Cognitive Complexity, the new option for measuring understandability
talk.description:
For 40 years, Cyclomatic Complexity has been the de facto standard for measuring testability and maintainabiliy. While it's absolutely accurate for testability, the same can't be said for maintainability. Cognitive Complexity solves the problem, and returns "fair" relative measurements of control flow complexity. 

In this session, you'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, and why you should add it to your metric suite, see how it applies to a number of code samples from open source projects on SonarQube.com, and learn how to use a method's Cognitive Complexity score as a guide to designing better code, and refactoring existing code to be simpler and, more maintainable. You'll also see that because there's no "cost of entry" / increment for methods, high class-level Cognitive Complexity is a reliable indicator that a class contains a lot of logic, not just a lot of methods. That is, you can use Cognitive Complexity to sift domain classes from the logic-intense classes that impose a higher maintenance burden.

Cognitive Complexity is already available as a new rule in some Sonar code analyzers, and should be available throughout the SonarQube ecosystem by the end of 2017.
talk.notes:
30min Tech Talk

SonarSource (the company behind [SonarQube](http://sonarqube.org)) is introducing a new way of measuring complexity: [Cognitive Complexity](https://blog.sonarsource.com/cognitive-complexity-because-testability-understandability/), which gives a far more accurate measurement of the relative understandability of a method than Cyclomatic Complexity. 

I'll cover these topics:
* Cyclomatic Complexity: what it's good for and what's it's not, i.e. why a new standard/metric is needed
* Cognitive Complexity: motivations, specifics, benefits
* How to use Cognitive Complexity to guide refactoring. Hopefully I'll be able to use an IDE for this portion, but may have to fall back to slides, depending on what I can get the IDE to show.

I'll begin the presentation with slides and then hopefully switch to an IDE. Examples of code to be refactored will come from [sonarqube.com](https://sonarqube.com/issues#resolved=false|rules=squid%3AS3776).

I'm the best person to present this topic because, with the help and support of my SonarSource colleagues, I formulated Cognitive Complexity.
talk.abstract:

You'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, how it applies to a number of code samples, and how to use it as a guide to refactoring for simpler, more maintainable code.

talk.title: Reliable Statements about a Fault-Tolerant X-by-Wire eCar
talk.description:
A dependable cyber-physical system (CPS) correctly performs the functions for which it was conceived in its intended environment, without adverse effects. In particular, a dependable CPS responds correctly and timely even in situations where system parts have failed, either temporarily or permanently. This requirement also applies when tests check reliability, availability and performance properties of these systems in the lab and in the field. A CPS with test probes built-into all HW/SW-components throughout the CPS lifecycle can fulfill these requirements. Applied to an eCar, non-intrusive, deterministic fault-injection tests executed by test probes provide strong evidence for statements like: “While driving, the eCar can safely be steered when a fault fails a central, redundant HW/SW component that executes steering operations”.

Tests of such systems and properties pose various challenges, for example (1) stimulating selected CPS parts with correct data and with faulty data in rare and critical situations, (2) checking selected CPS parts at selected points in time, or during time intervals according to focused and measurable test goals, (3) differentiation of the CPS's treatment of temporary and permanent faults, and (4) absolute non-disturbance of the tested system's functionality or timing. The fourth challenge applies in particular to fault-injection tests that check CPS safety, or that operate near the border between the CPS and the physical process.

Meeting the challenges outlined above requires that the architecture of the system under evaluation be designed for testability. Starting from here, we first characterize the CPS we use as an example: an integration platform of an X-by-wire eCar (www.projekt-race.de/en). This motivates the need for reliable statements on the real-time behavior of the system from different tests, from which we derive testability requirements. Afterwards, we elaborate a series of design tactics that enable or improve the system’s testability, focusing on test probes. A test probe is a kind of Built-in Monitor (SEI: Testability tactic) or Maintenance Interface (R. Hanmer: Patterns for fault-tolerant systems) with particular demands in probe environments. When these demands are fulfilled, test probes can execute deterministic, efficient and reliable real-time tests, or act as safety monitors that observe and potentially intervene in a system.

Independent of the system domain you will learn two key aspects: how to design a testable system that incorporates test probes as central system elements, and how to write non-intrusive tests that yield reliable results.
talk.abstract: We discuss the practical use of novel HW/SW test probes to non-intrusively check functional, performance, and safety properties in fault-tolerant cyber-physical systems. The talk covers the application of test probes to test the dependability of automation and control systems of an eCar.

talk.title: Smelling out a bad security culture
talk.description:
Security challenges in the Age of Digitalization
=====================================

Some call it the fourth industrial revolution. Some call it the age of digitalization. No matter what you call it, we are harvesting more and more data about people and businesses. This data is then connected to other data and exposed as services which needs to be protected properly. As software architects, our primary security goal is to write secure software. Secure software has a technical aspect that is well covered (if not understood) in developer literature, but there is also a human and organizational aspect of security we as software architects must manage.  These aspects often go beyond the boundaries of the software development organization and are influenced by forces well beyond the company walls.

On the path to security there are a lot of trade-offs to be made, and some of these are made outside the IT organization. After working for more than 20 years in large organizations, I have found that there are certain signals that can be used to identify if you have a weak security culture. They do not necessarily identify security problems in themselves, but are indicators of topics that merit further investigation.

__In this talk I will cover topics such as:__

- Balancing prevention, detection and response
- Leadership
- Balancing Short term gains vs long time security impact
- Handling security incidents
- The importance of the curious mind
- Communicating security concerns beyond the IT organization
talk.notes:
__Note: This talk was originally submitted as a 30 minute talk. As I tried to edit some typos, the talk type options have changed to "non-SATURN"-variants. It is still intended as a 30 minute talk even if the submission shows something else.__

Security has been a long time interest and passion with me. Working for more than 20 years in the IT industry, I have seen security fail in the most spectacular ways. For the past year, the company I work for (Statoil, a global oil and gas company) has seen an increased focus on IT security in the wake of internal and external events. I have been part of a task force addressing some of these issues, and although the particulars are confidential, there are still general learning that can be made. Some of these learnings are technical, but a lot of them are organizational and are valid across organizations large and small. This talk will address the general learnings made as part of the task force, put into a context of more than 20 years experience as an industry practitioner.
talk.abstract: Security is many things. To developers it is mostly about developing secure code, but as architects it is so much more. In this talk I take a look at experiences from years of security observations that I find useful when identifying weak signals of a faulty security culture in a large organization.

talk.title: Software Architecture as Systems Dissolve
talk.description:
The way we build systems is changing. From our history of monolithic systems, then distributed systems, to Internet connected systems, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice based, pay-for-usage system development. What does the history of software architecture tell us about the challenges of this new environment? And how does our approach to software architecture need to evolve in order to meet them?

Software architecture has been a mainstream discipline since the 1990s and in that time has become a recognised, widely researched and often valued part of the software engineering process. However architecture approaches must reflect the technologies and priorities of the systems we are building and in this regard its future has never looked more uncertain or more exciting. 

From our history of monolithic compile time architecture, to many tiered distributed systems, to Internet connected services, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice-based, pay-for-usage systems development. In this new world the boundaries of “my” system are no longer so clear and our systems are dissolving into complex webs of independently owned and evolved services, with nothing more in common than a shared credit card for billing and an agreement on the format of network requests. 

What can the history of software architecture tell us about the likely challenges in this environment? And how must it develop in order to meet them?
talk.notes:
The genesis of this session was an invited talk at OOP2016, exploring the history of software architecture, which I developed into this much more practical talk aimed at working architects, for GOTO London 2016, where it went down well.  Since then it has been presented at Endava a number of times and has always interested and engaged the audience.  It has not been presented in the USA yet.

The talk at present is a slightly full 60 minutes and so I would suggest extending to 90 for SATURN which will simply involve using more examples and questions to the audience.  However, if it fits better as a 30 minute talk, the essence of the message can be presented by just using the "Internet as the System", "Internet as the System Principles" and "Implications" parts of the talk (see the outline below).

Outline
-----------
The 5 Ages of Software Systems
	- Monolithic
	- Distributed Monoliths
	- Internet Connected
	- Current Era: Internet as the System
	- Future: Intelligent Connected

Internet as the System
	- Public API and mobile UI are the default interfaces
	- “Always On” is moving to “Access from Anywhere”
	- More dynamic architectural styles emerge (Microservices become popular)
	- Vendor concern now providing “platforms” (PaaS)

Architectural Drivers

I-A-T-S Principles 
	- Evolve continually
	- Respond dynamically
	- Analyse don’t ask
	- APIs for everything
	- Secure by Design
	- Internationalise instinctively

Implications
	- Design in CD from the start (remove obstacles to automation, testing, deployment)
	- Allow modular evolution (bounded contexts, “micro services”)
	- Assume “cloud” deployment (“cattle not pets”, no “snowflakes”, no static config, …)
	- Provide measurement in the core (instrumentation, store, analytics engine)
	- Structure around “public” APIs (the “Amazon” pattern)
	- Design and build to be securable (security principles, threat models, scanning, …)

On the Future
	- Intelligent Connected
	- Data and algorithms become key to achieving architectural qualities
	- Architecture becomes (more) runtime emergent
	- Vendor concern moves to “intelligent behaviour”
	- “Access from Anywhere”  moves to “Intelligent Assistance”

Summary and Conclusions

talk.title: Story of an Architect Growing up in Mr. Agile's Neighborhood
talk.description:
If the agile manifesto were a boy (born circa February 2001), he'd be a high school junior today getting ready for college. Based on the past 16 years of his life, there is no question about the genius of this kid; but not so much can be said about some of his entourage and followers. Missteps in his career threw shadows of doubt at times about his potential. However, as he matured and opened up to his parents’ wisdom and history, he’s been able to build a well-rounded experience that’s making him competitive for the next phase of his life.

I wrote my first full-fledge program (app in today’s term) in the Spring of 2001, around the same time Mr. Agile moved into my neighborhood. I didn’t get to know him until early 2004 when his entourage grew into a dedicated community of fans and followers. Back then, I had one trusted mentor and an old friend, Mr. Architecture. Becoming friends with Mr. Agile was new and exciting but brought about challenges to my relationship with my old friend. Therefore, my growing up as a software professional was about learning how I could maintain friendships with both, reconciling their differences, and being better at what I do because of it.  

In a nutshell, I grow up in this kid’s world. So what does that look like? 

In this DEV@SATURN talk, I’ll narrate the story about growing up as friends with Mr. Agile and Mr. Architecture. I don’t intend to indulge the “agile vs architecture” debate. On the contrary, I’ll annotate my story with examples from our journeys together, sharing experiences with some of Mr. Agile’s friends who advocated architecture sabotage, as well as situations where the outcomes were better because I had a foot in both camps and had won the internal struggle as to how to reconcile.

Come join me in this talk as I’m sure you’ll find resemblances to your own journey.
talk.notes:
BACKGROUND

This talk is inspired by Linda Northrop’s keynote last year when she gestured a fist-bump to her chest, a sign of regret, about the stall/damage agile movement did to the progress of architecture adoption. It made me reflect on how I’ve lived the collision of these two worlds. After discussing an early version of this draft with her, I thought I should write and share my experience in the form of a TED@SATURN talk. My starting thought was the fact that being close to agile movement from the beginning propelled my growth as a software professional, and my practice of software development have been better for it. However, this didn’t come without a struggle against an entourage littered with misunderstanding, incompetence, and lack of discipline. In retrospect, it’s clear that the agile pendulum swung too far in the beginning in a zeal to fix the ills of non-agile approaches. But like all physical pendulums, this one had to come back to equilibrium as agile original proponents began to realize that they overlooked some methodology-neutral principles key to developing quality software, including architectural principles. The punch line in this talk is that at this point agile is a reality. We are at a stage where we need to forgo the discussion about agile for agile sake OR architecture for architecture sake. We need to embrace this agile pendulum equilibrium in the making, and regain the role of those who think about appropriate practices, regardless of methodology, to build high quality software – Software that is fit for its intended use, where fitness has many dimensions beyond pure functionality. The vehicle for me to deliver this is through storytelling based on my own software journey. I'll try to dig out old pictures to put in the background to color the scene.

TALK STRUCTURE (DRAFT)

For the purposes of this segment of SATURN, my talk will feature a storyline emphasizing a classic story ingredients.

Origination

Year 2001. A dozen or so smart software engineers with stellar backgrounds are holding a collective grudge against waterfall-like processes, titles, and roles. Like many revolutions, a manifesto is crafted in a mysteriously remote venue, and subsequently shared with the world: Baby agile is born. At the same time, my induction into the world of software development occurs. A baby software developer is born. Scene – we live in the same neighborhood.

Building towards a crisis

Time is going to flyby quickly here.
  • In the ensuing 10 years, agile grows to garnish a movement that dominates all descending voices challenging it. It's cool; it’s the buzz; and it’s unstoppable.
  • I meet Mr. Agile for the first time. I’m fascinated (anecdotal incidence here). I go running to my old friend, Mr. Architecture. He’s less fascinated. (I get to know why later).
  • It turns out, architecture best practices (and a lot of common sense) are the colloquial baby that was thrown out with the bathwater. Architecture vs Agile debate begins to take place.
  • This makes me extremely uncomfortable. I like both my old friend and my new friend but how can I hang out with them both?
  • Affiliated agile revolutionaries weren't grounded as leaders in software engineering thereby resulting in a number of documented software atrocities. I witness some of these first hand in my neighborhood.
  • Moment of truth: Agile is widely accepted but now the epiphany – It isn't the silver bullet after all. Adults in the neighborhood have been saying so all along but the wave was too noisy.

Beginning of resolution

In the last five years, architectural thinking begins to permeate the conversation among agile leaders. Voices of reason, architecture and agile leaders together, have begun to take charge of the discourse again. They’re beginning to have serious conversations about the real software development challenges at hand with a common goal to build software in a way that is both flexible and sustainable. I’m getting really uncomfortable as I now get to go out and watch game with both my old and new friends. (Anecdotal incidence here). Great headways are achieved but also challenges remain with a hopeful future – that of bringing our community together and embracing each other’s strengths.

Ending Monolog

While I feel privileged to have grown up with this boy and met & learned from many of his clique, my work experiences led me to also work in many cases with the cronies. So I finish the story with a call to action for the audience to avoid the dichotomy of us versus them and to regain our role as the chaperons of quality as manifested in the end-products and artifacts regardless of the adopted software development methodology. Curtain close. Audience cheers. Lights off. :)

talk.title: The Influential Architect: Succeeding At Scale Among Fully Autonomous Teams
talk.description:
Being the only software architect in a company with many fully autonomous and agile development teams can be an exasperating exercise. The role looks simple on paper: drive good, technical solutions to business problems. But with so much going on at any given moment and constant iteration, staying on top of and affecting outcomes across the board is practically impossible. If you can't even keep up, how can you find time to engage in the decision-making process?

In this environment, a 'command-and-control' style architect can encounter significant opposition and find themselves ineffective. Instead, we may consider exploring an entirely different approach. The Influential Architect is fusion of advisor, mentor, facilitator, communicator, and storyteller. As an Influential Architect, our aim is to improve outcomes across the organisation without the organisation becoming reliant on us making key decisions. To achieve this, we have to change the level of abstraction: where previously our purview has been decisions, we must now focus on people. When we can't be in every room where decisions are being made, we must affect the people who are and the process they use.

In this talk, we'll explore what it means to be an Influential Architect, as well as some of the tools and techniques we can use to succeed. We'll cover:

* Transparent Decision-making.
    * How may we efficiently document and communicate our intentions with regards to technical solutions and what would those documents look like?
    * How may we incorporate other development teams into our feedback cycle without creating bottlenecks?
* The Light on the Hill.
    * What is a technical vision and how does it help both the team and the wider organisation?
    * How do we go about establishing a technical vision and who needs to be involved in this process?
    * How do we hold teams accountable to technical visions, in order to ensure they work towards the same long-term goals?
* Visual Storytelling.
    * How can we effectively communicate technical outcomes to non-technical stakeholders?
    * What are the key components of a good story and how does a story help communicate intentions?
    * What does an example of a visual story that communicates a technical initiative look like?
* Architectural Principles.
    * What are architectural principles and why do we need them?
    * How and in what format are architectural principles articulated?
    * What does the process of establishing them look like to optimise for creating buy-in among technical teams?
    * How may we hold teams accountable to the architectural principles we've established?
* Sensible Defaults.
    * How can we use sensible defaults to avoid reinventing the wheel while at the same time not hinder innovation?
    * How do we go about establishing sensible defaults in an open and inclusive process?
    * How do teams incorporate using sensible defaults in their work process?
* Strategic Thinking.
    * How can we champion long-term concerns in an iterative agile process?

In the longer version of the talk, we'll expand on the aforementioned tools by going through them in greater detail with several real-life examples, and also cover:

* A case study of failures.
    * What were the approaches that didn't work so well?
    * Why did they fail and what can we learn from them?
* Team suitability.
    * Are there any _team_ characteristics that are necessary in order for an Influential Architect to be effective?
    * What can we do to prepare teams for greater autonomy if they are not ready for it?
* Architect suitability.
    * Are there any _personal_ characteristics that significantly make this type of role easier to fulfil for the Influential Architect?
* Evaluating outcomes.
    * How do we measure our own success in influencing teams?
    * How do we know which teams need more (or less) support than others?
    * Under what circumstances might it be acceptable to stray from the technical vision?
talk.notes:
This is probably best suited as a 30 minute talk, but can be expanded into a 90 minute talk if so desired. The presentation has no technical requirements other than a projector for the slides.

My presentations tend to be fun and engaging. I strive to offer ideas people can implement as soon as they get back from the conference, interwoven with self-deprecating humour. I gave a talk about Event Sourcing at last year's SATURN which was well received: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TeMYF_JjNg

Having lived and breathed the role of Influential Architect at Envato in Melbourne, Australia, I'm well-positioned to talk through the lessons I've learned throughout my journey. At Envato, we have 18 autonomous engineering teams working on several products in the digital marketplaces industry. Over 120 people are directly involved in the day-to-day development and delivery of software projects. As the only person with Software Architecture in my job title, I guide these teams and people to ensure that we are making sound technical descision and are all working towards the same technical vision.

The Influence approach we've been trialling at Envato has been very successful, with a transparent decision-making process and better outcomes. For the first time ever, we have a coherent long-term architectural vision that is understood and frequently referenced by both technical and non-technical stakeholders. Teams are able to move faster, with the reassurance of knowing they are heading in the same direction as everyone else.

I'm excited to share what I've learned about the role of a Software Architect at scale. The presentation is packed with advice on what's worked and what hasn't, and has concrete real-world examples rather than abstract ones. There should be interesting content for all types of architects even if they work in very different environments.

I'm also interested in how you document and communicate the resultant architecture information so that it is used by developers, not forgotten. Do you use models, text documents, process descriptions, etc.? How do you make this information attractive to the development teams? Any explanations on these things are appreciated.

Hi Conrad,

Thanks for your submission.  Overall I like the topic and think this could be a good talk at SATURN.  But I'm going to play devil's advocate in the review.  If accepted, I hope you're able to use the review to help improve the talk.

You assert that "a ‘command-and-control’ style architect is destined to fail" and yet we (the broader community) has managed to ship complex software under situations like this and have for decades.  There must be something other than leadership style at play?

How much does the team culture and experience play into success of the adopted leadership style?  What about the architect's experience?

You discuss only the positive benefits of this style of leadership.  I would think that empowering the team can have a downside if you don't find the right balance of vision and guidance.  How do you determine if your team is doing well with this approach or needs more oversight?

I do not believe all teams are ready for this leadership approach.  How do you know if a team is ready and how do you prepare them to handle greater autonomy?

Regards,

Michael
Sebastian, apologies, I don't usually address people only by their last names -- I was moving too fast and read the wrong text!

Anthony, 

Thank you for your comments. I'm very happy to hear that you think the talk is relevant to your interests! I have amended the submission with some additional information you might find useful. It's not a full outline, per se, but hopefully will give you enough context to understand what I intend to cover.

A longer version of the talk would allow me to go into each area in greater detail, but also cover additional topics. I have listed those in the talk description.

Thanks again for the feedback, and let me know if there is anything I can clarify further!

Michael,

Many thanks for your constructive feedback! I have made some alterations to the description, and I hope to be able to cover as many of the points you raised.

Regarding the "destined to fail" assertion you called out, I will happily concede that was probably erring too far on the side of hyperbole. I've edited that sentence (and the one following it) to use somewhat softer language that I hope more accurately communicates what I actually meant.

Thanks again for your comments, and for taking the time to consider my submission.

talk.title: The life and times of an architecture - Architectural decision making throughout the solution life cycle
talk.description:
Over the last decade, the architecture discipline has matured from up-front design to a stream of architectural decisions that address the concerns related to ever-evolving software systems. The word “stream” implies a continuous process, but in real life that stream is far from homogeneous. Architects (or whoever else owns the design decisions) find themselves making decisions with widely varying impact, based on information with differing levels of uncertainty, throughout the life of a software solution. On top of that, the way these decisions and their impact are communicated evolves as the audience and the focus of the architectural communication change.

In this tutorial, we explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making, throughout a software solution’s life cycle. Amid all the fluidity of the stream of design decisions, we will look for anchor points with common concerns to address and recurring communication needs. We will see how the nature of architectural decisions changes when we go from birth (the first architectural outline) to graduation (making the business case), and find guidance on communicating the architecture at times of life-defining milestones like marriage (committing to the architecture) and revolutionary changes to the solution. The points will be illustrated by real-life examples from an interesting case study.

The tutorial is based on Risk- and Cost-Driven Architecture, a popular approach to improve architecture practices in both traditional and agile contexts, with the aim of providing “just enough anticipation” in the architecture. No prior knowledge of RCDA is required to attend.
talk.notes:
This is a 90-minute tutorial.

During the product lifecycle, key aspects of architectural decisions change, depending on the life stage:

* level of risk and cost control: the cone of uncertainty
* available information to base architectural decisions on
* impact of architectural decisions
* number of architectural decisions
* cost of change to the architecture

Certain milestones like graduation (approving the business case for the solution) and marriage (the moment after which it becomes very expensive to change the architecture) occur in every solution life cycle. Such milesones lead to standard stakeholder concerns, like affordability, level of risk control and predictability. We use the commonality of these concerns to provide the architect with standard views in their documentation, enabling them to show how the architecture addresses these common concerns.

Contents
-----------

1. Introduction: 
 * Architecture as a stream of design decisions
 * Cone of uncertainty
 * Project vs. product life cycle
2. Birth:
 * From stakeholder need to solution concept
3. Graduation:
 * Making the business case
4. Marriage:
 * Committing to the architecture
5. Career and home life:
 * Fulfilling the architecture
 * Emergent architecture
 * Evolutionary changes
 * Health and debt control
6. Children:
 * Revolutionary changes
7. Legacy

Find guidance on communicating your architecture at birth, graduation and marriage, after which changing the architecture becomes very expensive...

talk.title: Turning projects into products and wind into profit, or how GE Renewables was transformed into a Cloud SaaS Provider
talk.description:
At SATURN 2016, I introduced a novel lean approach to developing product architecture that combines Lean Model Canvas, Design Thinking, and Agile practices.  This year, I am excited to share a case study of how it was applied at GE Renewables Digital to bring software products to renewables assets.

In partnership with IT, field engineers, data scientists, and software engineers I watched an entire digital organization grow agile and innovating.  My fellow architects were the guides who captured the tribal wisdom and rallied both executive and product management sponsorship to launch two product lines in 2017 – Digital Wind Farm and Digital Hydro Plant, both demoed at GE Minds and Machines 2016 event. 

This session is based on my experience leading GE Digital Renewables architecture strategy for Asset Performance Management and Operations Optimization.  Renewables energy presents unique and diverse challenges when it comes to delivering software at scale.  Connecting hundreds and thousands of wind turbines and solar panels, fine-tuning analytics at the edge and the cloud, and assuring NERC compliance through Secure DevOps are some of the concerns to consider.

The participants will be walked through the journey and challenges on the way to migrating both existing applications and building brand new applications on a cloud platform and how architecture best practices accelerated the management and minimization of technical and functional debt.

The session also presents the trade-offs both at tactical and strategic level for moving forward with new technology without missing the beat of capturing the market opportunity for innovation leveraging horizontal products such as Asset Performance Management from Predix to accelerate renewables business objectives.

Two major product portfolios - The Digital Wind Farm and the Digital Hydro Plan were enabled with Common Renewables Asset Model based on IEC and S95 standards.   Model development was crowd-sourced to both IT, service engineering, and software development to capture both domain knowledge and leverage break-through features of distributed graph storage and scale with micro services.

talk.title: Ultimate Architecture Enforcement – Write Your Own Rules and Enforce Them Continuously
talk.description:
The software architecture discussed and carefully created is often not entirely followed in the implementation. In this talk we'll examine the factors that lead to this disconnect between the architecture and the code. We'll learn that consequences of this problem go beyond maintainability issues. But most important, we'll look at an easy to use, automated solution to improve architecture conformance. This solution has been successfully applied in a mid-size organization. It uses free open source tools and also helps to raise architecture knowledge across the development team. 

Things you will learn:

- the importance of architecture conformance. 

- how to use free open source tools to create your own design rules. Through examples, you'll learn the basics of the SonarQube custom check API. 

- how to enforce the architecture continuously by integrating the custom rules to your CI infrastructure. 

- how to make this setup effective, based on lessons learned by the author in the past 6 years. 

No pre-requisite knowledge is required other than basic understanding of object-oriented programming.
talk.notes:
This talk is supposed to be a 90-minute tech tutorial. 

Early results of the approach discussed in the presentation were described in a [SATURN blog post](https://saturnnetwork.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/ultimate-architecture-enforcement-prevent-code-violations-at-code-commit-time/). 
More recent results were described in a [SPLASH Wavefront paper](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2508433).
The SATURN presentation is updated to reflect recent improvements and results.

*Session mechanics* 

This is a slide-based presentation. I'll also use the IDE to show and run some code. Questions and comments are welcome during the talk or at the end. 

*Talk outline*

- Introduction: Motivation for architecture conformance; factors that lead to lack of conformance; consequences of lack of conformance.
- Creating a custom rule: intro to static code analysis tools with an API to create custom rules
- Example 1 - enforcing a layered architecture (for each example, we'll examine the code and comment on the SonarQube API)
- Example 2 - enforcing mandated generalizations
- Example 3 - enforcing REST service design standards
- Automated tests for custom checks: quick overview of how to build and run automated tests
- Integration with continuous integration
- Running critical checks in a pre-commit hook on git or svn
- Our experience with custom checks: results and lessons learned in 6 years 

*Target audience*

This talk is particularly important to software architects, but is of interest to software developers in general. 

*Previous presentations* 

SPLASH 2013; The Brazilian Conference on Software - Theory and Practice 2013; 3er Congreso Internacional Escuela de Ingeniería de Sistemas y Computación (Peru); invited talks at different organizations.

talk.title: Using Conway’s to Architect a Team
talk.description:
In 1967 Melvin Conway submitted a paper to the Harvard Business Review titled “How do Committees invent.” In this paper he wrote that 

*Any organization that designs a system (defined more broadly here than just information systems) will inevitably produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure.*

 The paper was ultimately rejected on the grounds that Melvin had not submitted enough evidence to support his claims (It was published in Daatamation and is available online) . However his hypothesis became known as Conway’s law and many organizations can say that they have observed the same behaviors as outlined in Melvin’s original paper. 

Here at IBM Watson, we just completed an initial release of a new microservice-based cloud platform. This service involved multiple teams, multiple microservices and multiple timezones.  We took a cloud product from inception on a lightening fast roller coaster ride to GA in five months, and lived to tell the story. We didn’t get everything right, but we learned alot along the way and we’d like to share those learnings. 

In this presentation we will share our experience, and talk about some of the architectural successes and mistakes we made. We’ll talk about how we used Conway’s law, and the inverse Conway manuever to correct some of those mistakes. We’ll also touch on some of the issues confronting our teams with remote team members and how we solved them. We’ll provide a prescription for approaching team architecture based on our learnings. 

By the end of the presentation, attendees will gained a knowledge of Conway’s law, how to use it to their advantage, and how to take an architecture led focus for team creation and development.
talk.notes:
This will be a slide-based presentation with the following tentative outline:

* Problem statement: Architecting teams is hard to get right the first time. Conway's law seems to be the right thing to do, but presents a challenge in many organizations. Architecture led team formation as a strategy.
* Review: Conway’s law, Stages of Team Formation
* Motivating Example: Describe the team formation for Watson Cloud service
* Lessons learned
* Techniques used to overcome the challenges faced
* Outcomes of using those techniques
* A prescription for architecting teams based on our experiences
* What’s next? 
* Conclusions

### Learning outcomes
By the end of this session you will be able to answer the following questions:

* What is Conway’s law?
* What is the inverse Conway manuever
* When might a good time be to employ these techniques?


### Target audience and assumed knowledge
* Managers who want to learn how to use Conways law to their advantage.
* Architects interested in finding ways to influence team formation through architecture

### We assume the following audience background.
* Understands basic software development challenges with multiple teams
* Has heard of Conway's law

Has this content been presented before?
This material has not been presented in this format externally to IBM.
talk.abstract: For software managers and architects, this talk is intended to provide some guidelines for using Conway's law based on real experiences in the field so that they can find better ways to form teams in the age of microservices architecture.

What a fascinating topic- you could well imagine that if it had been accepted by HBR - that it could have been missed entirely by the software architecture community and perhaps it would have sprouted more generally into other communities of practice. This is a perfect "What if" scenario and will fit nicely into the talk as food for thought.

Hi Will!

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. What do you mean by "a cloud product"? A software product that runs on the cloud? Is the cloud product the cloud platform that you mention in the previous sentence? In any case, can you say more about the nature of the software product?

Following this line of thought, we would need more guidelines and wisdom about how to create a team for monolithic applications.  :^)

talk.title: Building composable abstractions
talk.description: Do you want to create robust and composable abstractions? In this talk Eric Normand will present an iterative process to define the essence of a domain and build composability into the core. The resulting abstractions lead to more robust code at the core of your application, and can give your business a competitive advantage. We will apply this process to the Processing graphics library to develop a composable vector graphics system.
talk.notes:
This is a 60 minute talk.

After attending the talk, the attendee will be able to:

1. Know the difference between Newtonian-style abstractions and Aristotelian-style abstractions. Aristotelian abstractions are built up piecemeal and are full of corner cases, like Aristotelian physics. Newtonian abstractions are elegant, formal, and composable.

2. Follow a design process for developing an algebraic abstraction that can compose and easily express solutions (Newtonian style). Building data transformation pipelines is the step most people who are learning functional programming get to from reading and experimenting. Building algebraic abstractions is the next step, but there isn't much literature on the topic (outside of academia)
    1. Elaborate a physical metaphor
    2. Describe the meaning of your metaphor as mathematical statements
    3. Construct the meaning using constructs from the language
    4. Implement the abstraction by refactoring the meaning
	
	The physical metaphor is an important first step that gives us an anchor from which we may use our intuition. We then query our metaphor for its properties and write them in math, which usually means types and equations. After that, we can construct a runnable version of the meaning, being careful to build it out of parts constrained by our statements from step 2. Finally, the implementation becomes an easy matter of refactoring our runnable version.


This topic idea comes from my experience teaching functional programming to people with all levels of experience. There seems to be a logical progression of insights that people go through as they learn about functional programming. I don't see many people getting past the "data transformation" step, so I want to present something further. It's hard to say whether it's THE next step, but it is at least one step beyond transformations.

A lot of the thinking comes from my experience as a professional Clojure and Haskell programmer and the work of Conal Elliott, John Hughes, and Gerald Sussman.

I have given a version of this talk at Clojure/conj 2016: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJIUoaIvD20 I would love to adapt this to a language like JavaScript. The example code will be given in JavaScript.

talk.title: Case studies of enterprise IT governance models for architecture and framework for architecture maturity assessment
talk.description:
Enterprise IT realized that architects play a critical role in evolving IT. Most large scale organizations have established the architecture teams to guide the organizations in constantly evolving IT. Architecture team structure and their governance maturity are critical to the success of an organization in navigating the IT challenges, bringing the innovation required to gain the edge in the marketplace and successfully delivering the IT projects for the organization. It is important for IT leaders and architects to understand the best practices in establishing the architecture teams in the organization, and how to assess the architecture team’s maturity. 
This session will present the experience from conducting many architecture assessments by one of the biggest consulting firms. Session topic begins with the evolution of an architect’s roles in evolving IT and how did architect’s responsibilities and influence change over the last 4 decades. Then, session moves to the observations from real-world on how organizations structure the architecture team and discuss the pros-cons of different architecture team structures observed in various industries. Also, the presenter shares the assessment model used to assess the architecture team’s maturity in enterprise IT and case studies from real-world architecture assessments. 
Attendees learn the best practices in structuring the architecture teams within an organization and how to increase the effectiveness of the architecture teams. Also, learn the architecture assessment model used in many assessments across the industries and multiple case studies presenting how did the architecture team influence the success and failure of organizations.
talk.notes: Siva Muthu is a seasoned architect with 20+ years of experience in information technology and large-scale enterprise solutions. He was one of the instrumental leaders created an Application Architecture practice for Deloitte Consulting and led many architecture assessments across the industries. He also developed the Deloitte Consulting’s standard custom development framework and provides architecture advisory services for many engagements on project assessment, architecture review, and estimation methodologies. Specialized in solution architecture, project assessment, Microsoft.net technologies, and related products, design patterns, framework development and development process engineering concepts.

talk.title: Connected Teams, Connected Code, and the Connected Device: The Challenges of IoT Software Delivery

talk.title: Customer Experience Architecture Hands On
talk.description:
Architecture is about the customer. If you create an architecture that doesn’t give value to the customer you are wasting your time. When I talk to customers I often hear horror stories about how their current systems were developed by someone in an ivory tower who didn’t understand them or their work. So how do you make sure that you are bringing value to the customer through your architecture? Use customer centric design processes often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. These are fundamental parts of Lean and Agile and this session shows how to use them in architecture with hands on experience. In this highly interactive session participants redesign a system by interviewing a customer, creating a prototype, reviewing it with the group, and getting feedback on their design. Using the methods taught in this class you can create value for your customer through your architecture and become their hero, or at least not the person in the ivory tower who is ruining their life.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture
talk.notes:
My goal for this session is to help architects learn a customer centric design process. I learned this method from the "Deciding what to Design" course at Carnegie Mellon. The method is often called Contextual Design or Design Thinking. Its a fundamental part of Lean and Agile. I've rarely seen people show how these methodologies apply to architecture, so thats my goal for class.

I use this process in my own work at GE and previously at Verizon.  I lead the End to End Customer Experience efforts at Verizon and enabled our architects and software engineers to talk to customers. I gave a talk on that experience at a past SATURN that generated a lot of interest.

At GE I am using this method to design a new CI/CD system for our Industrial Internet of Things platform called Predix. Customers (anyone who gets value from the system you are creating) really appreciate working with me. I find out very surprising things by using this method and create much better systems.


A slightly modified version of this session has been given before at Code on The Beach and was well received.  I used the "App for adding contact to network" use case and it ended up being a common but complex enough task that the groups had plenty to design. The Code on the Beach session was 60 minutes long and I assigned roles to each team member. I didn’t have time to have feedback given to each group, but I think it is an effective way to leverage the knowledge in the room. I didn’t have time to fit in the last wrap up session either, which I think is critical for people to concrete the new information. I've added those two parts to this 90 minute session.

Objectives:
Participants will learn basic methods of contextual design and design thinking and how they apply to the architecture of a software system
Participants will learn customer interviewing techniques to gain knowledge of the customer's functional and non-functional requirements
Participants will learn creating prototypes of their architecture
Participants will learn how to give constructive feedback on an architecture
Participants will learn how to receive constructive feedback on an architecture


The participatory session will include the following:
15 minutes
Introduction to Customer Experience Design
Introduce the hands on Exercise: Design a new system for adding a contact to your network (Linkedin, google+ , etc.)
Divide session into groups of 4 or 5 people.

10 minutes
Activity 1: Determine what matters to the customer including their functional requirements and quality attributes by watching how they do the task in their natural environment and asking lots of “why’s”. I will ask each group to select someone in their group to be the "customer." Each group will watch their customer collect a business card from a person and add a contact to their network of choice.

25 minutes 
Activity 2: Design the system around the customer’s needs and document it in a prototype. The prototype should be as interactive as possible, not just a flow chart. Prototype should show the architecture elements. Because the “customer” is involved, the team should be constantly getting input from the customer on their on going design. They should also write down any assumptions they are making and any reasons they made design decisions. Finalize the prototype, the assumptions, design decisions, and what they learned from the process.

30 minutes 
Activity 3: Review the prototype with the group. Receive feedback on design. About 5 minutes each group.

5 minutes
Wrap up: Allow the small groups to meet one last time to discuss the feedback and make any changes to their design.

10 minutes
Final Group discussion: Discuss what they learned from the session. Find out what they learned from receiving and giving feedback.

talk.title: Designing with NoSQL Databases
talk.description:
Schema design for NoSQL databases requires a very different approach from relational databases. The NoSQL databases have very high emphasis on huge data volumes, high and scalable performance, high availability and agility. As a result, the traditional concepts such as normalization, foreign key, join, strong transaction support, etc are done away with. How does one then design schema for various business applications?

In this session, we'll look at the concepts and best practices of schema design for three prominent NoSQL databases (MongoDB, Cassandra and Neo4j), with the help of diverse use cases, such as content management, single view, product catalog, social networks, system logs, fraud detection. We'll also look at the features for data analytics in these platforms. We'll also briefly look at when, why, and how to use polyglot persistence.
talk.notes:
I have presented tutorials on NoSQL in two earlier SATURN conferences. While those were beginner-level sessions, this one is for intermediate-to-advanced level users. 

I use NoSQL databases extensively in my work (architecture, teaching, consulting), and I have been helping organizations, primarily in the banking and retail sectors, in using NoSQL solutions for their business applications.

The topic of NoSQL schema design is something that I'm personally interested in and I think many others in the Saturn audience.  It would be easier to evaluate this proposal if it contained information about *what* the advice will be -- instead of asking questions, tell us what the answers are so we can judge if they sound interesting.

If accepted, I strongly encourage you to stick to one topic, not blend NoSQL schema design with polyglot persistence.  Yes, the topics arise on similar projects, but they are distinct design activities.  A talk on "best practices for NoSQL schema design" is a great topic by itself.

Hello George, 

Here are some of the "answers", which I'll illustrate with real usage scenarios:

For MongoDB:

* Nature of queries in your application determine the appropriate data model. 
* Aim to join while writing, not while reading.
* Embedding "many" side of a relationship) results in ease of retrieval, simpler queries, better performance. Variations for one-to-few, one-to-many, many-to-many. Tradeoffs. What to embed (_id / natural primary key / more than the natural primary key)?
* However, if an object frequently needs to be accessed on its own, embedding may not be the best choice.
* Don't embed very high cardinality documents on the "many" side. Variations and tradeoffs.
* Don't denormalize a "master" field / document if it needs to be updated frequently. The cost of finding and updating all the instances may be too high.
* If you frequently need to use data from documents from multiple collections when embedding is clumsy, don't be afraid of join at the application level.
* Use the power of the Aggregation Framework for complex query requirements.
* Get the best out of sharding. Choose shard keys for even distribution of writes and reads.

For Cassandra:

* Again, model around the queries in your application.
* Spread data evenly around the cluster.
* Think of the database as a nested, sorted map data structure.
* Denormalize for fast read performance. 
* Find the right balance between normalizing and denormalizing.
* Using column names for values, and leaving the column value empty is OK.
* Leverage wide rows for ordering, grouping and filtering.
* Choose the row key appropriately to partition your records for good performance.
* Segregate the read-heavy data from write-heavy data.

As suggested by you, I'll drop polyglot persistence, and model it as "best practices for NoSQL schema design". I think I should drop Neo4j, and limit myself to MongoDB and Cassandra for a more in-depth coverage.

talk.title: Location, Rewrite, Location: Tips and Tricks on Semantic URLs Architectures with nginx
talk.description:
The session will describe the best practices of semantic URL design and cache-friendly web architectures, based on the example of creating and rewriting a couple of web applications solely with the help of nginx.conf, the standard nginx configuration language.

On the example of [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/), we will show how it is possible to create a complete webapp entirely through nginx.conf from scratch; and on the example of [bxr.su](http://bxr.su/), we will show how to extensively modify the architecture of an existing legacy application to make it cache-friendly, and simultaneously improve the usability of the URL interface available to the user.

All of this will be accomplished through the internal directives of nginx and the machinery available through the standard rewrite module that is available and is enabled by default in all versions of nginx.

* Web applications are traditionally written in high-level programming languages such as Java, PHP, Python or Ruby.   But not [mdoc.su — a deterministic URL shortener for *BSD manual pages](http://mdoc.su/) — which stands apart from the established convention.   The whole [mdoc.su](http://mdoc.su/) web service is written in the standard and basic `nginx.conf` configuration language alone (with the help of regular expressions and dozens of `rewrite` and `location` directives), resulting in a high-performance semantic URL service without the help from any high-level programming languages like even Lua, Perl or JavaScript, being powered by [PCRE](http://ports.su/devel/pcre) and nginx.conf alone.

* On the example of [BXR.SU — Super User's BSD Cross Reference](http://BXR.SU/), we will also show how to `rewrite` the underlying architecture of Sun/Oracle OpenGrok, with the help of `nginx.conf`, without actually touching a line of the application itself. OpenGrok is written in Java, and is designed around the concept of cookies on every page (including the front page), and thus effectively cannot be cached or accelerated through a naive approach, due to the original architectural decisions that were made without considering their impact on the cacheability of the application. We will show how to successfully get rid of all the cookies with nginx, and how to greatly improve the usability and the URL interface of this Java application, all entirely through `nginx.conf`-fu.

No prior knowledge of nginx is required, but familiarity with HTTP is expected, and knowledge of regular expressions would come in handy, too.

Attendees will gain a clear understanding of how URL manipulation works within nginx, will surely be amused at the length to which the author went in creating the performant solutions, and will be able to design concise and deterministic URL shortening services using semantic URL schemes.
talk.notes: I'm affiliated with several BSD projects, being a member of the NetBSD Foundation (committer), and have already given this talk at several conferences and large crowds.
talk.abstract: Need to add support for semantic URLs to your website, but don't know where to start? Have to accelerate a legacy webapp, but have cookies coming in your way? Fear not, as we will show you the best practice on how to do both in nginx.conf, and without any non-default modules nor techniques.
