feedback.body:
Hi Scott,

Thanks for submitting!  Reading your proposal this looks like a good survey of many topics with an emphasis on getting your software system "production ready."  As a topic I think this is probably appropriate as long as the context is well established.  Reading your proposal I'm not sure what you mean by "global jungle" and whether the systems I work on would apply or not.  What is the context for the systems you are discussing?  Keep in mind that the SATURN audience comes from a variety of experiences from from cloud-based web services to embedded spacecraft control systems and more.

I'm worried this is too much information to cover during a single session.  How deep are you planning to go into each of the topic areas?

This seems closely related to your experience (good!) but seems to stop short of sharing a generally applicable lesson.  Where did your checklist come from?  Do you have any thoughts or advice on how someone might tailor your list to better fit their "jungle"?

Regards,

Michael

I have tried to respond to each of your comments below:

Production ready/Context/Jungle?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
I think characterizing it as emphasis of getting your system “production ready” is fair, although I think many systems consider themselves “production ready” and then fail in numerous ways when they try to grow/reach/impact the whole globe since they failed to consider key factors that could easily have been done ahead of time. This is not altogether different for how small startups often stumble or fail when they try to transition to the big leagues. As far as context goes, I think this applies to any web, desktop or mobile system (internal to an organization or used by the public) that is intended to be used by individuals in multiple countries across the globe. In particular if you are dealing with private or sensitive data. When I refer to the “global jungle” I am talking about the multitude of things that you often don’t think or worry about when you "first build" your solution for your "first user base", but can be a catastrophic problem when you try to transition to a new region or the globe (and forces you back to the drawing board or worse yet becomes a fatal flaw and threatens your overall business model). What do you feel is the best way to clarify the context due to its broad nature?

How Deep?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
My goal in this session is not to attempt to make anyone an expert in any given area. Instead I want to give them an awakening so that they walk away with a new found appreciation that there are a bunch of other things they should spend some critical time on; since by spending it now it may very well either save their project from an unanticipated problem or differentiate them since their competitors failed to consider them. Think back to when you first heard the horror stories around security and that had a lasting impact on your belief that it is something that shouldn’t be ignored. I want to try to do the same for many other aspects that few people take seriously until it’s too late.

ADVICE/TAILORING?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
This listing is what I have cultivated over the years and have used successfully to make both large and small systems “globally ready” and successful for the largest business unit of a 36.8 billion dollar company (for both internet and internal facing solutions). The last few parts 7, 8, 9 are where I would try to give them some structured advice on how to balance all of these considerations so that they can prioritize and mitigate the risks while still having rapid agility in "their jungle".
Thoughts? Appreciate the input btw!
Hi Scott, I'm assuming this is a 90-minute talk. Is that correct? Thanks.

I easily have enough material for 45-60 min right now without doing much work.  Been thinking about adding some more supporting details to extend it a bit plus leaving some time for Q&A.  Alternatively,  if you felt it would be more impactful and leave a more significant impression (shock n awe), I could keep the energy really high and go rapid fire and squeeze it down into 30.  Btw was my earlier message response sufficient to clarify the context questions you had before?  or should I go and modify the actual submission?  Thanks again for the input!

Thanks! I'm going to tag it as 30 or 90 and let the reviewers and tech committee decide which would fit best into the program. I'll also ping Michael to see if you've answered his questions sufficiently. Thanks again. :)

talk.title: Hemispheric Data Capsules for Non-intrusive Testing of Time-Triggered Real-Time Systems
talk.description:
Without doubt, modularization and modules that apply the information-hiding principle – as originally described in Parnas’ “On the Criteria” paper – sustainably help to develop and manage systems that are complex and flexible, yet comprehensible. Modules are design-time units with fixed domains and hidden design decisions. Modules particularly promote systematic correctness analyses. However, these beneficial properties disappear once the modules have been integrated into and deployed on target machines. For embedded systems that run within tight real-time constraints, modules may even hamper integration tests and fault analyses, due to the inaccessibility of modules' internals. Hence, for an HW/SW-integration platform of an X-by-wire eCar, we developed HDCs in order to non-intrusively trace and test the behavior of single and multiple modules (HDCs) integrated into one or more platform nodes.

HDCs transfer modules from design-time entities to runtime entities. HDCs can be tested in integrated systems during field operation, without code instrumentation and probing effects. For this purpose, the HDC runtime environment captures data structures that flow within and between HDCs for one macro cycle (e.g. lasting 10 ms) of the time-triggered system; each macro cycle anew. An HDC can access only internal and parametric data structures. The probe is the only HDC with full access to all data structures, including its own. Because they are half-open for the probe and half-closed for all other HDCs, we call these data capsules hemispheric.

In the presentation, we will first reveal requirements behind HDCs originating from an industry study on an HW/SW-integration platform providing safety services to a fail-operational eCar (www.projekt-race.de/en). We will then sketch tests that can be run for HDCs. This motivates the design of an HDC system and its effect on the application and implementation of HDCs in general and the probe in particular, which we will describe afterwards. We will critically reflect on our experiences with HDCs during development, in the lab and in the field, as well as on the applicability of HDCs to event-triggered, object-oriented systems as basis for discussion.
talk.abstract: A Hemispheric Data Capsule (HDC) is a runtime entity of a module with externalized data structures. One probe, itself a HDC, suffices to reliably test a self-contained, time-triggered real-time system in terms of dataflows within and between HDCs.

ratings.comments: I am glad to see a submission about real-time systems. This area is still a minority of SATURN talks.

When I see people talking about "runtime modules", that has often indicated a fundamental misunderstanding of development-time coupling vs. runtime dependencies. This talk seems interesting, but may lack a mature architecture perspective (i.e. they have rediscovered and re-labeled something that is part of the architecture body of knowledge).
I like to see a diverse range of systems presented at SATURN as there is often much to learn form how other domains.
Technical, and in-depth, which may mean limited appeal. Yet an interesting design pattern idea in a hot area.
Would like to see the applicability of HDCs with software architecture

feedback.body:
Summary:
The presenters will explain their concept of HDCs that enable inspection of real-time system module’s private data structures at run-time.

The good and to improve:
I find the HDC design pattern proposition very interesting as it overcomes a real challenge of testing complex embedded systems. The relevance of such systems only increases with IoT, yet real-time/industrial systems pose challenges many ‘Internet’ or ‘IT’ style architects are unfamiliar with.

The wording of the proposal is somewhat academic and not very easy to grasp, which matches the selected audience level for the talk (intermediate). I think it is important that the presenters consider the wide-range of skill and variety background the average SATURN audience has.

It would be useful for participants to understand how and when to apply the HDC concept/pattern. The proposal description does not include much information on the applicability or possible generalisations of the concept.

feedback.body:
Hi, Thank you very much for your feedback. Accordingly, we now directly address questions relating the general applicability of HDC in the last paragraph of the presentation (everything else unchanged).

Thank you again and kind regards.

Thank you for your submission. I am glad to see a submission about real-time systems. This area is still a minority of SATURN talks. I agree with Thijmen de Gooijer that this may be unfamiliar territory for some audience members. A clear explanation of your definition of "real-time" would be helpful for them. They may consider their systems to be real-time even though their systems are very different from the type you describe. I like that you will introduce the requirements behind your solution. This will help.

In your talk, I would like to hear about any disadvantages or costs (chronometric hits, for example) associated with implementing HDCs.

I would also like to hear about how you guide the use of these HDCs by developers through architecture, especially when there are many developers working on the same project. Are there particular mechanisms or rules that worked or didn't work for you?

user.name: Joachim Fröhlich, Florian Krautwurm, Stefan Rothbauer

feedback.body:
Dear reviewer, thank you very much for your comments.

(1) Ad "explanation of your definition of real-time" and "introduce the requirements behind your solution".

Our reference system and the environment for HDCs is the HW/SW-integration platform of an x-by-wire eCar. It is a time-triggered system that must perform critical functions within milliseconds. When we talk about the system context of HDC and requirements behind HDC we will also explain our definition of real-time. We announced already to talk about "requirements behind HDCs originating from …". Please see the agenda in last paragraph of the lecture description.

(2) Ad "implementation disadvantages and costs", "guide developers to HDCs" and "what worked or didn't work".

Considerations of issues and drawbacks are necessary for a balanced picture on HDC. Following your comments we will explicitly address chronometric hits because timing considerations are important for a real-time system that works with tight operation schedules.

A proper place for talking about challenges in general with HDC could be the section "critical reflection on HDC" which is already on the agenda. Currently, we do not intend to go into details regarding the development process. The presentation aims at technical matters of HDC. However, since modularization in general and working with HDC in particular affect the development organization and process, we are going to take a position on these points during the presentation as well.

Kind regards.

feedback.body:
This looks like an interesting topic, but there isn't much information here to explain what a 2 hour session would contain (which is a long session) and indeed how you'd keep the audience engaged for that long.  Can you make it interactive?

It's quite possible that people will be put off by the implied need to read the pre-reading you suggest.  Can you make it clear whether attending will be valuable without this?

Finally, what would the difference between the 90 minute and 120 minute versions be?

Risks -> exploitation is usually pretty interesting. This is a collection of some of the demos: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfv6teOacMIuh3VheioAXXe70IwwQySIp

Yeah, it's my intention to have this interactive. I also run run classes that are hands on, but people have to bring laptops and be well prepared/setup for that, so this is more of a watch and discuss tutorial based on the workflow of an attacker, whether the attacker is a black-hat or one of your team members testing as part of your Scrum process.

Attending without reading will be valuable, but once attendees have attended, they usually wish they had prepped before hand, to understand what's going on to a deeper level.

This (https://leanpub.com/holistic-infosec-for-web-developers-fascicle1-vps-network-cloud-webapplications/read#vps-identify-risks-adding-persistence-co-powersploit) is the sequence of events for one of the demos I would run through. This adds a persistent powershell payload to windows that is scheduled to open a reverse shell to the listening attacker. Survives reboots and many other user actions. This is one way to make sure you always have a door into your targets network. From here, we continue laterally owning the rest of the network. I've never seen anyone get board with these demos. Then we discuss mitigation techniques.

talk.title: How the real-time communication between things can simplify our everyday life: make it more secure and economic.
talk.description:
An implicit goal of developing applications in IoT is to increase the quality of life, or the general well-being of individuals and society as a whole. The insights to be gained from data are endless. In light of this a new paradigm of the real-time communication between things has emerged, in which the quality of life of citizens in dense urban environments is increased through the security of using big data and cloud technology. Future cities are likely to feature thousands of strategically placed sensors that would record everything from air pressure and temperature to microbial content, and the data would be relayed instantly to the smart devices of actively participating citizens, who will make critical contributions to urban planning, reducing pollution, and making the best use of finite resources.
The proposed solution is the mobile connectivity that provides the network coverage wherever devices may roam. Secure cellular connection together with SIM cards and endpoints can be easily managed in real-time via the intuitive user-interface or directly from the customer’s software application via an easy-to-integrate API. Key features, development and implementation stages, as well as use cases will be discussed.  
The talk includes a lot of real working IoT use cases and their potential impact on our daily life. Their focus direct towards a more practical improvement of the quality of our life. Attendees will explore what is the potential impact of IoT, what real IoT use cases was implemented in Germany, how can we increase the quality of life with the IoT.
talk.notes: As I now reflect back on my working experience and lots of conferences, I can personally attest to the wide range of benefits that international communication provides for IT development nowadays and the insight brought about through cooperating with techs from all over the globe. My mission is to enable public to realize innovative fast secure development and implementation in the field of IoT.

The rapidly changing social and environmental order is becoming more complex, it requires one technical integration point for IoT, which can provide technological fluency in the use of big data for public benefit.

ratings.comments: The description doesn't help me understand the details of the proposed solution or what of the solution will be presented. Without additional information about those things, it is difficult to evaluate. For now, because that information is missing, I rate this as a "no."

While IoT technologies become pervasive understanding their impact on daily life and potential use cases is definitely of increasing concern. However, this talk does not provide an architectural perspective on potential challenges/opportunities these use cases emphasize. As written, the abstract reads more like a contextual design talk rather than an architecture talk.

IoT is certainly an interesting and relevant topic these days, with many arch. ramifications. That said, the proposed talk seems to be a business development/tech. evangelism type of tak, motivating why IoT is great but not discussing the sw architectures of IoT solutions. 

I gave the submitter the benefit of the doubt, this could also be a "No".
Got the feeling that is made with haste, and as far as I see it, no response to Paulo's question. So negative from my side.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:

1) Abstract: the term "technical integration point" is not clear. 
2) Description: I suggest replacing "and the data would be relayed instantly to the laptops of actively participating smart citizens" with "and the data would be relayed instantly to the smart devices of actively participating citizens".
3) Description: The description uses too much space ellaborating on the grand benefits to society of large-scale IoT. These benefits should be briefly mentioned as an introduction/motivation to the technical presentation. And it turns out the technical part of the talk is a little vague. Are you going to talk about general connectivity mechanisms commonly used in IoT? Or about a specific solution or design? Or is it a case study on IoT? 
4) Description: It's not clear what attendees will learn. 

In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Typos:
- Abstract: "in the use *of* big data". 
- Description: "In light of this*,* a** new paradigm".
- Description: "through the security of us*ing* big data and cloud technology".
- Description: "The propos*ed* solution is the".

While IoT technologies become pervasive understanding their impact on daily life and potential use cases is definitely of increasing concern. However, this talk does not provide an architectural perspective on potential challenges/opportunities these use cases emphasize. As written, the abstract reads more like a contextual design talk rather than an architecture talk.

Thank you for your submission. As I understand it, this talk is about increasing the quality of life by improving the security and economics of using data from widely distributed devices connected by the internet.

You provide examples of the type of data that might be available and how it might be used (reducing pollution, for example). The proposed solution is some sort of mobile connectivity. I don't understand what the specific security and economics aspects of the solution are from the description. Could you explain how those quality attributes will appear in your talk?

Why is a single point of integration required? I take "integration" here to mean integration of all the data coming from distributed devices. Please correct me if I'm thinking incorrectly. Is that driven by security or economics? There could be other structures that might work too.

Thank you for your feedback!
I just would like to mention that from my point of view IoT solves the same problem for communication points as software architecture tries to solve for many years - distributed computing. 
Different nodes on different machines try to communicate with each other as well different devices and controllers do. These IoT devices can certainly connect through a lot of different ways, but in this talk we will focus on cellular connectivity.  
Obviously, other receptions are always limited to the access point, and also dependent on network and device configurations. Cellular has reception everywhere without any maintenance effort from the customer side, so with telecom access a large-scale investigation is possible. Given the ubiquity of sim based devices, cellular solutions can achieve an unbelievable level of coverage in both space and time for observing any events.
If we take IoT and wanna use it in a large scale for example in agriculture industry in Africa, we have to built a large suitable, secure and cost-efficient architecture/system. As low-energy network does not exist there and can provide connectivity only on one site, so the communication with the combine on the field will be always insecure.
Even SMS can play a role as an intermediate solution and help with device distribution or middleware as GSM network always can be used, even if internet is not available, which makes it reliable and persistent channel for IoT connectivity.
This talk is more focused on use cases with real-time or time-critical services, of course it can impact economic and security.

Snowy regards from Germany, 
Karina

talk.title: How to organize your code
talk.description: Most nontrivial software systems suffer from significant levels of technical and architectural debt. This leads to exponentially increasing cost of change, which is not sustainable for a longer period of time. The single best thing you can do to counter this problem is to give some love to your architecture by carefully managing and controlling the dependencies among the different elements and components of a software system. This session will first look at the major reasons why so many systems end up in an unmaintainable state and then show how to address the problem by using automated quality gates in combination with a domain-specific language that can be used to enforce an architectural blueprint over the lifetime of a software system.

talk.title: Internet of Things Testing in Real World
talk.description:
Internet of Things (IoT) is a network of physical devices connected to each other. One device sends data to other device that can use this data.IoT can make the existing healthcare system more efficient in terms of Time, Energy and Cost.
By embedding IoT devices into existing medical equipment, patients can be monitored more effectively. Data obtained from these devices can be used to make proactive decisions.
•	The Learning:
•	Massive impact on life and business.
•	Huge incoming data from connected devices and ensuring devices can hold data securely.
•	Challenges in managing enormous volume of data.
•	Quality of data and power consumptions.
The Act:
•	High performance data management systems.
•	Innovations in sensor technologies and setting up secure networks.

Market Trend and Prospect: 
•	The Internet of Things will be the largest device market in the world. It is estimated that by 2019 it will be more than double the size of the smartphone, PC, tablet, connected car, and the wearable market combined.
•	The IoT will result in $1.7 trillion in value added to the global economy in 2019. This includes hardware, software, installation costs, management services, and economic value added from realized IoT efficiencies.
•	Device shipments will reach 6.7 billion in 2019 for a five-year CAGR of 61%. Revenue from hardware sales will be only $50 billion or 8% of the total revenue from IoT-specific efforts, as software makers and infrastructure companies will earn the lion's share.
•	The enterprise sector will lead the IoT, accounting for 46% of device shipments this year, but that share will decline as the government and home sectors gain momentum. By 2019, government will be the leading sector for IoT device shipments.
•	The main benefit of growth in the IoT will be increased efficiency and lower costs. The IoT promises increased efficiency within the home, city, and workplace by giving control to the user. However, many are hesitant to use devices as security problems are still an issue.

Case study:
Smart Hospitals Using Internet of Things (IoT)
Most of the time, due to negligence of hospital staff, excessive number of patients or inattentiveness of relatives it may happen that saline bottle is not monitored properly and it may lead to cause heart attack due to “AIR EMBOLISM”. In a hospital, numbers of electrical equipments (fan, lights) are more so energy is more. Thus, it is important to use electricity as per the requirement. Thus, in this paper we have proposed a system which include combination of sensor technology and Internet of Things (IoT).Using this system one can control switch of the electricity and monitor level of the saline bottle from distant position.
IoT Testing

About MQTT Protocol
According to the specifications, MQTT is client/server publish/subscribe messaging transport protocol. It is lightweight, open, simple, and designed so as to be easy to implement. These characteristics make it ideal for use in many situations, including constrained environments such as communications in Machine-to-Machine (M2M) and Internet-of-Things (IoT) contexts, where a small code footprint is required and network bandwidth is at a premium.

Client/Server Message Pattern
MQTT uses publish/subscribe model to deliver all messages to interested clients. In this model, a publishing client (publisher) does not send requests directly to each receiving client. Instead, it publishes the message to the server known as broker, which, in its turn, forwards data to the clients that need them.
This way the publisher can send only messages to the specific address. Otherwise, it would have to update the list of clients constantly and send multiple messages on every update. This may be impossible for publishers with low processing power or limited Internet connection.
Clients, who want to receive data, subscribe to the broker. They subscription model allows them to subscribe to specific topics and, thus, filter out the messages they do not need.
 Both the publishers and clients send a Connect message to work with the broker.
The described solution also allows the broker to send messages if the publisher has connection issues, or if the client is offline when a message is published. The broker stores the message and sends it to all newly connected subscribers and a Will message is sent when the publisher has connection issues.

Will Message
MQTT ensures the message delivery even if the network issues happen, or if the publisher suddenly goes offline. This mechanism is known as a Will message. The Will message is sent to the broker when the publisher connects, and it is published in case the publisher disconnects without sending the Disconnect message. If this happens, the Will message will be posted, and the broker will send it to all subscribed clients.

MQTT Testing in Ready! API
Ready! API can act both as a publisher and as a client for MQTT broker. We can use it to create functional and load tests.

MQTT Functional Testing
To test the broker's functionality, we need to create a SoapUI NG test that uses the MQTT-related test steps:
Test Step	                               Description
Publish Using MQTT	               Establishes MQTT connection and publishes the message specified in test step properties.
Receive MQTT Message	       Subscribes to an MQTT topic and waits for the first message posted to it.
Drop MQTT Connection	       Simulates the publisher disconnecting from the server, either in the normal way by sending a Disconnect message, or unexpectedly.

MQTT Load Testing
To see how MQTT broker performs under heavy load, We need to create a load test for it in LoadUI NG. We first create an MQTT test case in SoapUI NG, and then create a load test that simulates this test case with dozens and hundreds of virtual users running on a locally or remote machines.

talk.title: Is Your Project in Trouble on System Performance?
talk.description:
Performance is one of the critical architecture quality attributes and it is a non-functional requirement that is used as an acceptance criteria for almost every project / system. Performance also impacts the usability and user adoption rate after the system goes live. However, performance issues usually show up during the later phases of the project or during system implementation such as Load / Stress Test and / or User Acceptance Test (UAT) when data volume scales up. The probable cause is a lack of non-functional requirements on performance at an early stage of the architectural design. This presentation is to conceive and show how to salvage a troubled project with performance issues that focuses on performance and storage trade-offs, and how Architecture Analysis Tradeoff Method (ATAM) is used to leverage the performance and storage trade-offs. The specific tailored solution I wanted to share is to move data aggregation and sorting from backend database to Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time and be accessed over http through query parameters. I will also discuss performance concerns from end-to-end in systems the deal with heavy data aggregation and sorting using real-world implementation examples. Perspectives on how to address performance concerns and turn around a troubled project in a very short period of time will also be elaborated.

Introduction and Architecture Quality Attributes (5 minutes) 
Performance and Storage Trade-offs by example (15 minutes) 
Architectural Dynamics, Challenges, and Impacts (5 minutes) 
Q&A (5 minutes)
talk.notes:
The take away for this presentation will be the practical techniques to salvage projects with severe system performance issues. This presentation is based on my real-world experiences in salvaging two multiple-million dollar projects in a very short period. Neither project conducted architecture quality attributes workshop (QAW). The performance issues were so severe that the projects were subject to be cancelled. The root of causes were extensive data aggregation with heavy computation and sorting on a low-end databases. One of the two projects simply tried to reuse a simple mobile application architecture with 2 search criteria and less than 100 thousand records on a PostgreSQL to a full blown application with 100 million records with over 20 search criteria. When performance issues appeared at UAT, $2 million dollars were already invested in the project. I will present a quick turnaround options including tailored solutions ranging from increasing hardware / network capacity, database tuning / query optimization, API optimization, to the implementation of Solr or Elasticsearch to address the performance issue. The examples I will use in the presentation will be performance and storage trade-offs that leverage the Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time. The architectural dynamics, challenges, and impacts such as Solr indexing time impact to the existing ETL process and PaaS issues will also be presented. The practical knowledge of this presentation will benefit architects and business decision makers to understand the important of Architecture Quality Attributes and how to address performance issues with tailored solutions.

I think the presentation belongs to Track 3: Other topics interest - Addressing quality attribute concerns, such as performance, availability, usability, security, and interoperability
talk.abstract: Why do so many projects have system performance issues at a later stage of implementation? Are projects with severe performance issues salvageable? feedback.body:
Summary:
The talk reminds the audience of the importance of designing for key quality attributes based on the author’s industry experience. The author applies accepted practices (for example, QAW, ATAM, UAT) during a turn-around of stranded projects. Finally, the talk would give practical guidance on the suitability of various database technologies for two projects the author worked on.

The good and to improve:
The author correctly points out the importance of designing for important quality attributes up-front and gives concrete examples of the potential cost of failing to do so. While a real world story could engage the audience, we should expect most SATURN attendees to already be aware of these risks.

Concrete guidance on dealing with performance issues could be of interest to the SATURN community. The proposal does not tell us how the ‘tailored solutions’ used may generalise to other software systems that the audience works on. I would like to see some hints about what classes of systems or problems could benefit from the solutions.

Idea:
A talk outline with rough timing could help the reviewers better judge the focus of the talk. Please also elaborate your idea on how your talk may impact the work/actions of others. You could also look at this blog for a checklist: https://insights.sei.cmu.edu/saturn/2016/11/seven-proposal-writing.html

Excellent feedback! The specific tailored solution I wanted to share is to move data aggregation and sorting from backed end database to Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time and be access over http through query parameters. This tailored solution is a trade-off between performance and storage in addition to other traditional performance turning approaches.

Introduction, background, and problem statement (5 minutes)
The Importance of Designing for Key Architecture Quality Attributes (5 minutes)

Hello Thilmen, Thanks for the feedback. I updated my Talk Description as follows, but was not able to edit the original description.  Any help I can get from you to revise the original submission?
---------
Performance is one of the critical architecture quality attributes. The performance Service Level Agreement (SLA) is a non-functional requirement that is used as an acceptance criteria for almost every project / system. Performance SLA also impacts the usability and user adoption rate after the system goes live. However, performance issues usually show up during the later phases of the project or during system implementation such as Load / Stress Test and / or User Acceptance Test (UAT) when data volume scales up. The probable cause is a lack of defined architecture quality attributes and vague non-functional requirements on performance at the early stage of the project such as architectural design. This presentation is to conceive and show how to salvage a troubled project with performance SLA issues that focuses on performance and storage trade-offs, and how Architecture Analysis Tradeoff Method (ATAM) is used to leverage the performance and storage trade-offs. The specific tailored solution I wanted to share is to move data aggregation and sorting from backed end database to Solr or Elasticsearch as an indexing service so that data aggregation and sorting can be indexed ahead of time and be access over http through query parameters. I will also discuss detailed issue resolution approaches to address performance concerns from end-to-end, real-world implementation on performance and storage trade-offs to turn the project around in a very short period of time to meet the performance SLA.

Architectural Dynamics, Challenges, and Impacts (5 minutes)
Q&A (5 minutes)
--------

Hi Thilmen, please discard my prior feedback / comment. I was able to update the Talk Description based on your feedback.

Thanks for your feedback.

Charles

Hi Charles,

I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. I think the talk description uses the term SLA inaccurately. SLA is a document that may specify perfomance requirements, among other things. I'd argue that the majority of software systems out there do not have such a document in effect. So, saying "The performance Service Level Agreement (SLA) is a non-functional requirement that is used as an acceptance criteria for almost every project / system" is an overstatement to me. But if you drop the term "Service Level Agreement (SLA)", the sentence sounds quite valid. 

2. Likewise, the SLA document doesn't impact usability. It's performance that affects usability. 

3. The talk description uses quite some space to discuss the general importance of performance as a quality attribute requirement. I believe that's not the focus of the talk, but as is the description becomes less interesting, because many SATURN attendees are well aware that performance requirements are important. The title and description could be more specific and clearly indicate what kind of performance optimization is discussed. In other words, I suggest you say in the title and abstract what specific kind of performance solution you'll present. 

4. You say "The probable cause is a lack of defined architecture quality attributes and vague non-functional requirements on performance at the early stage of the project such as architectural design." It's not clear to me what is "defined architecture quality attributes" versus " non-functional requirements on performance."  Also, I think it would make more sense to say "at an early stage of the architectural design" instead of "at the early stage of the project such as architectural design."

5. The phrase "I will also discuss detailed issue resolution approaches to address performance concerns from end-to-end"  sounds very general and hence too ambitious. Maybe you should be more specific, such as "... performance concerns from end-to-end in systems that deal with text search on indexed data sets. 

6. The term "storage trade-offs" is not clear. Is is about tradeoffs regarding the choice of infrastructure used for persisting data? Maybe RDBMS vs NoSQL databases? Maybe tradeoffs related to Lucene indexing options? 

7. SATURN attendees are interested in technologies, tools, frameworks that have been used successfully. So, in an unbiased fashion, you could try to mention tools such as profilers and performance monitors that you have used. Learning about the experience of others with such tools may raise the interest in your talk. 

Typos:

- "sorting from back**end database to Solr "

- "and be access*ed* over http"

I'm drawn to this talk because of the specifics of the case studies as described in the Notes section.  I like talks that have a clear example from which a clear lesson can be taken away.  It works well in 30-minute conference slots.

But, and I'm slightly embarrassed to admit how I'm jumping to conclusions, I'm concerned that the way the author has written the descriptions (ie, a big paragraph of "we will discuss X, Y, and Z" without a clear takeaway message) will translate into clear value for the audience.  Many authors provide an outline of the talk or topics, which makes it clear how they are organizing their thoughts and linearizing the knowledge.

Hi Paulo, thanks for the detailed feedback. I updated the "Talk Description" to reflect your comments and suggestions. Regarding performance / storage trade-offs, my intent is to discuss the details via several examples since there are pros and cons for each technology. Tailor the solution to the business needs to turn the troubled project around successfully is something I would like share with the audience. 

Again, Thanks
Charles

Hi George, thanks for your feedback. To address your concerns, I updated the Note section with take away / value to the potential audience - "The take away for this presentation will be the practical techniques to salvage projects with severe system performance issues".  I also updated the Talk Description section to be more descriptive on the take away. The outline of talks is at the end of the Talk Description section. 

Thanks
Charles

feedback.body: Thanks Pradyumn for submitting an interesting topic. Would you be providing details from your vast experience to cover the mental thinking that needs to change from being a Developer? ie What is it that an Architect need to do differently from a Developer or a Dev Lead? How to achieve that transition. I think that would be useful for the audience as well.

Yes, I would cover that too. Mindset change is very important. Things like business focus, the big picture, collaboration, conflict resolution, learning, sharing cannot be ignored for a successful transition.  And I intend to cover such aspects also.

Thank you for your submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. Today Software Architecture is taught at many undergrad and graduate academic programs in the US and abroad. Also, there are many professional training classes available. Some are vendor agnostic (such as the SEI courses), others are offered by vendors, such as Microsoft and Oracle. In your presentation, do you consider taking classes on software architecture an effective possible step in the roadmap? 

2. The software architect should also have a clear understanding of quality attributes, such as modifiability, availability, performance, and security. He/she should know how to elicit and document quality attribute requirements, because these requirements are the most important architecture drivers. 

3. The architect should also understand that architecture consists of multiple structures, which are documented in multiple views. He/she should know how to communicate the multi-view architecture effectively. Many times this communication involves diagrams, so the architect should know UML or know how to create and use an informal diagram notation consistently. 

4. A question that could be discussed in your presentation: is there value in pursuing one of the different available software architecture certifications? 

5. The architect should also know how to create, document, and evaluate an architecture. 

6. Years ago people at the SEI software architecture group engaged in a discussion about the duties, skills and knowledge of an architect. One of the results of that discussion is on [this web page](https://www.sei.cmu.edu/architecture/research/previousresearch/duties.cfm). It might have useful information for your presentation. 

7. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

8. It would be interesting to see a discussion of what has changed in recent years in the role of architect in the "digital era", the era of microservices, containers, and agile development.

talk.title: Love Your Architecture II
talk.description:
Last year at SATURN Alexander von Zitzewitz gave a presentation titled 'Love Your Architecture!'. I was immediately drawn by the title. 
Alexander talked about the importance of architecture conformance and showed a tool to help with that. 
When I was watching I thought: 'In our organization, we do the same thing in a different way, also with great results. Maybe I could give a talk with the same title.' So, this is it. 
Our approach to architecture conformance is fully automated, incredibly simple and yet powerful and flexible. It's based on free open-source tools, but requires some coding (the fun part). Developers can find out they're violating, for example, your layered design, when they insert an undesirable dependency in the code. They can see that on the IDE itself. If they ignore, the CI build will detect and report the issue. For more strict design rules, you also have the option to block code commit to the git or svn repository. This approach shows how much we care about the architecture--we create it carefully and make sure it is not neglected for the entire life cycle of the project.

talk.title: Measuring DevOps: the Key Metrics that Matter
talk.description:
How is your DevOps transformation coming along? 
How do you measure Agility? Reliability? Efficiency? Quality? Culture? Success?!
How do you optimize your software delivery processes?

You can’t improve what you cannot measure. But are you measuring the right things? Are you measuring too little (or too late), or are you drowning in disparate data points that make it hard for you to get to the bottom line: where should you be focusing on next as you optimize your process?

Having the right goals, asking the right questions and learning by doing are paramount to achieving success with DevOps. Having specific milestones and shared KPIs play a critical role in guiding your DevOps adoption and lead to continuous improvement - towards realizing true agility, improved quality, and faster time to market throughout your organization.

This session will walk you through a practical framework for implementing measurement and tracking of your DevOps efforts and software delivery performance that will provide you with data you can act on!

These KPIs include metrics related to your software delivery pipeline and technical progress, as well as cultural indicators and business impact. In addition, we will cover common use cases and real world examples for implementing these metrics to drive DevOps success, as well as best practices for how to address certain challenges and problematic areas along your process that these metrics may bring to light.

talk.description: An implicit goal of developing applications is to increase the quality of life, or the general well-being of individuals and society as a whole. Dear George, thank you for your feedback! 

I would like to add some comments that in reality IoT solves the same problem for communication points as software architecture tries to solve for many years - distributed computing. Different nodes on different machines try to communicate with each other as well different devices and controllers do. 
These IoT devices can certainly connect through a lot of different ways, but in this talk I focus on cellular connectivity. Obviously, other receptions are always limited to the access point, and also dependent on network and device configurations. Cellular has reception everywhere without any maintenance effort from the customer side, so with telecom access a large-scale investigation is possible. Given the ubiquity of sim based IoT devices, cellular solutions can achieve an unbelievable level of coverage in both space and time for observing any events.
If we take IoT and wanna use it in a large scale for example in agriculture industry in Africa, we have to built a suitable large architecture. As low-energy network does not exist there and can provide connectivity only on one site, so the communication with the combine on the field will be always insecure. Even SMS can play a role as an intermediate solution and help with device distribution or middleware. GSM network always can be used, even if internet is not available, which makes it reliable and persistent channel for IoT connectivity.
In my talk I include not only an agriculture, but also e-health, logistic and alarm system cases, with journey map and code demonstration.

Cheers, Karina

talk.title: Planning for Huge Scale: Designing Your Pipelines for Scalability and Resiliency
talk.description:
Installing one CI server or configuring a deployment pipeline for a specific application might be easy enough. However, as enterprises look to scale their DevOps adoption and optimize their software delivery practices across the organization (to support additional teams, product lines, application releases, processes and infrastructure) -- software delivery pipeline(s) need to scale to support enterprise workloads.

For some enterprises, this means having a pipeline that can withstand the velocity and throughput of thousands of product releases, supporting tens of thousands of developers and distributed teams, hundreds of thousands of infrastructure nodes, multitudes of inter-dependent application components, or millions of builds and test-cases.

This scale poses unique challenges and implications for your pipeline design. This talk covers best practices for analyzing and (re)designing your software delivery pipeline – regardless of your chosen tool-set or technologies. Obtain tips and tools for ensuring your pipelines and DevOps infrastructure have the right architecture and feature-set to support your software production as it scales, while also ensuring manageability, governance, security, and compliance. 

Learn best practices for how to:

1) Plan for scale: how to project for the types of performance indicators/vectors you’d need to scale across.
2) How to design of your pipeline and supporting infrastructure and operations (such as data retention, artifact retrieval, monitoring, etc.).
3) Design your pipeline workflows and processes to allow reusability and standardization across the organization, while also enabling flexibility to support the needs of specific teams/apps.
4) Design your pipeline in a way that enables fast rollout- easy onboarding thousands of applications, across hundreds of teams
5) Incorporate security access controls, approval gates and compliance checks as part of your pipeline and have them standard across all releases
6) Ensure your architecture support HA, DR and business continuity.

A lot of design work goes into good infrastructure.  I'd rather DevOps engineers learn take a more disciplined and mature approach to that design work.

Aside: I wonder if this is the next big area for discipline growth?  The margin between the average software developer and software architect is shrinking every year.  I wonder if we're at a "last 10%" problem.  At the same time, there is a huge gap between DevOps and architecture design principles such that even small gains there could have a huge impact (while small gains with developers will have only a marginal impact).

Getting people like this to share their stories and also introducing them to the SATURN community is the way we start closing the big gap.  Plus it's only a 30 minute talk.

talk.title: Predictive Business Analytics In the age of In Memory Computing
talk.description:
Disruptive Intelligence
====================
Never before in history, could we find a single largest contributor that has such a pervasive impact both on the bottom line as well as on customer relations.

Like beating a dead horse, traditional tactics to analytics has been delivering ample analysis only after the event. Business leaders who rely on information to make complex decisions in real time could not succeed as desired because technology could not cope up with their needs till today. This decades’ long wait has finally come to an end thanks to Artificial Intelligence and Real-time Analytics. Especially Real Time Analytics powered by In-Memory Computing (IMC) offers a way out from this rut. Further still, a truly disruptive hybrid model that shrewdly mixes both, “Relying on the past to predict the future” and “Real Time Analytics” is a fool proof approach for digital era analytics solutions. 
 
By embedding a select array of Artificial Intelligence techniques from cognitive research arena right into the core algorithms and using state of the art research projects such as SRI, CNTK and Google Tensor Flow, how we can leverage In Memory Computing to address predictive business analytics issues will be addressed in this session.

How to address complex and strategic decision needs in real time?
======================================================

By flexing and blending a variety of technologies within the realm of In Memory Computing, we can address all the three types of decisions, including Operational, Tactical and Strategic. While operational and tactical decisions tap into existing datamarts and datastores which house transactional, structured data, strategic decision making goes beyond the traditional stores and rely heavily on real time, unstructured data influx. 

Real time strategic decision making in digital era is impossible unless we shatter today’s speed and scale barriers. For speed, we can leverage In Memory Computing that tackles both latent and live streams of data. For planet scale, as the volume is huge and expected to grow exponentially, an on-demand, scalable infrastructure should be erected to contain the catastrophes. As strategic decisions need to factor in various parameters, an ensemble of machine-learning algorithms are employed to crunch data, to classify the outliers and recommend meaningful actions to deal with a specific problem at hand. An enormous number of simulations, trained models and tests are applied to the data which has been acquired and prepared before passed on to the intelligent analytics engine to arrive at precise real-time business decisions.

Applied IMC Use case - Customer Intimacy 
==================================

As the world is becoming more complex by the moment, strategic decision making in real time is also becoming extremely difficult and is compounded by the speed and scale with which information is generated and consumed. IMC furthers the decision-making process by employing cutting-edge tools, and conceiving and deploying disruptive models to address customer concerns. When it comes to meaningful engagement with customers, relying on heuristics and instinctive impulses for strategic making is no longer reliable, in today’s rapidly changing digital landscape.

This session is designed to shed some light on a practical use case on how to enhance customer intimacy using In-Memory Computing for business analytics.
talk.notes:
Functions and Algorithms
=====================

The driving force behind the use case is ‘enhancing customer experience’. With this is in mind, every customer interaction is funneled for use in a sentiment analysis. By examining every chat, email, tweet, voice transcript and logs, the attitudes, emotions, likes, preferences, habits behind the interactions are analysed using the following (indicative) machine and deep learning algorithms:
	
Naïve Bayes
Max ENT
SVM
CNN, HMM, GMM, 
DNN, RNN, LSTM

Architecture behind Real-Time In- Memory Analytics 
==========================================	
The following  architecture principles are applied in Predictive Real-Time Business Analytics :

* Real Time, In Memory Process.
* Loose coupling.
* Interoperability.
* Modularity.
* Scalability with built in CAPS.
* Cloud Centric.
* Mobile Centric.

By design Highly stable, open source products are plugged into the solution.

Thank you for your submission. 

I believe authors and speakers should be careful with superlatives and absolutes. In your abstract, you say technology has miserably failed business leaders who wanted information to make complex decisions in real time. I'd rather say technology has often fallen short instead of failed miserably. Likewise, I think it's an overstatement to say that AI and real-time analytics are the single largest contributor to customer relations in history. What about the Internet? And another example of what sounds to me like an overstatement: "Real time strategic decision making in digital era is impossible unless we shatter today’s speed and scale barriers".

I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:

1) Description: The third paragraph under "Disruptive Intelligence" is one long sentence. Please try breaking it up. 

2) Description: The description uses too much space elaborating on the importance of real time strategic decision making, real time analytics and IMC. I think you should simplify the motivation part of the description and focus more on the technical presentation. And it turns out the technical part of the talk is a little vague. Are you going to talk about general solutions to real-time analytics and IMC? Or about a specific (of set of) solution/design/technology/framework/tool? Or is it a case study? 

3) Description: It's not clear what attendees will learn. For example, in the Notes you mention "Architecture behind Real-Time In-Memory Analytics". That would be an interesting topic for many attendees at SATURN, but is not mentioned in the talk Description (remember attendees see the Description, not the Notes).

In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Hi Venkidapathy,

Thanks for your submission.  I think this seems like an interesting topic and one that many will find interesting.  There are a few things about the submitted abstract that I think can be improved.

* The overall tone seems overly enthusiastic for the solution you're proposing, almost to the point that it reads like a sales pitch.  Surely there are some negatives to what you're proposing?
* The topic is unclear and seems to touch on numerous areas.  Is this talk about AI? In memory data structures?  Streaming analytics?  Cloud? Mobile? Modular design?  I'm not seeing the theme or core lesson.  What will someone who attends your talk be able to do that they couldn't do before?
* This is a lot of material to cover in 15 minutes.  Perhaps you meant to assign this to a different time slot? There does seem to be a bug in papercall about this.

I think if you could clarify and tighten the abstract a bit this has potential to be a great topic.

Regards,

Michael

talk.title: Qualities are Very Complex
talk.description:
At the beginning of a software project, you should identify likely project risks.  Quality goals such as those for safety and security may be among them.  These goals must be defined, achieved, and verified.  We show that current quality models, such as ISO 25010, are simplistic and then describe a quality model of sufficient complexity.

We highlight the features of a quality knowledge base that outlines over 60 quality attributes, their support and conflict relationships, and their tactics for goal definition, achievement, and verification.  This knowledge base is freely available and enables you to identify your quality goals and strategies at the beginning of a project.  If you don’t use it, you may waste time and increase project risk.

feedback.body:
Hi David,

Thank-you for your submission.  I'm very interested in the topic of software quality, but I'm sorry to say that I'm finding your description a little perplexing.

The title is confusing me.  My initial thought was that you were saying "Software Quality Attributes Considered Harmful."

However, reading the introduction paragraph makes me think you are actually saying is "Poor Quality is Risky", or perhaps "A Little Quality Model is a Dangerous Thing" because you need one that is big enough to do the job properly.

By "essentially complex" do you mean "necessarily complex"?  i.e.  This is the level of complexity that is needed as a minimum, you cannot go any simpler than this?

When you say "essentially complex" do you actually mean that the model is complex by nature.  Complexity is often seen as a undesirable, , so complex nature could be a bad thing.

Reading on I see that you are presenting a quality knowledge base.  Am I right in thinking that this is the "Essentially complex quality model."  Since you are presenting it, then I assume it must be a good thing.  The title and introduction don't make this clear.

Also, you begin the second paragraph referring to "some at the SEI."  You then refer to "We".  Is the "We" the people at the SEI, or are you referring to the people ClearSpecs Enterprises? 

I hope you can understand my confusion and can help me clarify my understanding.

Regards, 


Ged

Sorry for the confusion. 

I changed the title to "Qualities are Very Complex" because that is my message.  I am using "essential complexity" as Fred Brooks does.  DNA, the London subway, and Einstein's theory of relativity are each more complex than a triangle or benzene molecule.  

"Essential complexity" is neither bad nor good.  It is a scalar characteristic, like weight.  By definition, if I build a model or solve a problem, the essential complexity of the thing being modeled or the problem being solved determines the essential complexity of an accurate model or an effective solution.

While understanding higher levels of essential complexity is very difficult, simplistic understanding can be dangerous.  If the software in a self-driving car is simplistic, people will die needlessly.  

“A Simplistic Quality Model is a Dangerous Thing” because you need one that is big enough to do the job properly. – Yes   Complexity is often seen as undesirable, [just like too much weight], so complex nature could be a bad thing – No [Human intelligence is not a bad thing, but unnecessary complexity is a bad thing.]  Reading on I see that you are presenting a quality knowledge base. Am I right in thinking that this is the “Essentially complex quality model.” – Yes

Here is the rewrite:  Qualities are Very Complex

At the beginning of a project, you should identify likely project risks.  Quality goals may be among them.  These goals must be defined, achieved, and verified.  We show that current quality models are simplistic and then describe a quality model of sufficient complexity.

We highlight the features of a quality knowledge base that outlines over 60 quality attributes, their support and conflict relationships, and their tactics for goal definition, achievement, and verification.  This knowledge base is freely available and enables you to identify your quality goals and strategies at the beginning of a project.  If you don’t use it, you may waste time and increase project risk.

Improvement suggestions much appreciated.  Thanks.

Thanks for the submission. I have a few suggestions from the perspective of a conference participant looking at the conference program:
1) The talk abstract sounds a little vague. Maybe you could say "software project" instead of just project. Maybe say "Quality goals, such as..."
2) It's not clear what you mean by quality models. Examples? 
3) Many software developers simply ignore quality attribute requirements. I think we need techniques that make specification, design, and validation of quality goals simple and practical. IMO, a "quality model of sufficient complexity" doesn't sound very enticing to the agile, framework-oriented developer of today. 

Also, in the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

Hi Paulo:

Great suggestions - see revision.  This talk is meant to fill the 15 min. slots that I thought were described in the CFP, even though this duration is not included in this online system.  I have a pdf of my 12 slides, but there is no provision for uploading files.  If you provide an email address, I will be happy to supply them.

You wrote: "Many software developers simply ignore quality attribute requirements. I think we need techniques that make specification, design, and validation of quality goals simple and practical. IMO, a “quality model of sufficient complexity” doesn’t sound very enticing to the agile, framework-oriented developer of today."

I agree with all but the word "simple".  The set of quality attributes and some individual attributes like safety and security are NOT simple (just like DNA).  Some attributes have entire books written about them. Their specification, design, and verification is NOT simple.

I understand that I am "selling" complexity (reality?), but the earth is not flat and orbits are not circular.  Simplistic models of quality attributes will never produce predictable quality.

As to enticing the Agile crowd, there are many problems.  I have written that "Agile is a Quality Antipattern" and "Fixing Agile".  "Pure" agile is simplistic.  It can work great as long as you ignore quality goals.  These goals don't fit the Agile paradigm because they should be identified and specified early and achieved and verified in every iteration.  In surveys of current Agile practice, over 50% of the responders don't following any coding standards.  These Agile projects build huge quality debt starting from the first increment.  True Agile believers are not my target audience,  Those using Agile, but concerned about quality, are.

talk.title: Responsive Design
talk.description:
This is a blog post I wrote recently to explain the importance of responsive design. In my talk I cover a lot of the how-to-dos of CSS and how to handle your UI/UX - I think it's a fun read and I try to keep the talk fun as well. Hopefully you'll join me and my dark sense of humor on this journey through measurement options (outside of the pixel), SEO, using min and max widths to cut down on media queries and discuss using vectors and images. I hope you enjoy the blog post as well:

Every time someone opens your website on a mobile device and it’s not responsive, a toddler punches a kitten. Okay, not really, but you are providing the equivalent as your user experience. This hurts your SEO potential, and drives traffic away from your site.

Let’s get a quick rundown on what responsive web design actually means within the context of an ordinary website. This definition from Small Business Trends sums it up nicely:

Responsive Web design is an approach whereby a designer creates a Web page that “responds to” or resizes itself depending on the type of device it is being seen through. That could be an oversized desktop computer monitor, a laptop, a 10-inch tablet, a 7-inch tablet, or a 4-inch smartphone screen.

So with this in mind, let’s take a look at hypothetical look at a website on a few different devices.

Guys…. Stop thinking about coffee and let’s focus!

Maybe the importance of this isn’t really seeping in and maybe you’re more of a numbers person… Let’s try another route.

80% of internet users own a smartphone per Smart Insights. According to MicKinsey & Company, Google says 61% of users are unlikely to return to a mobile site they had trouble accessing and 40% visit a competitor’s site instead. A report by Wolfgang Jaegel found that 91% of mobile users say that access to content is very important.

In all seriousness, it is a big deal if your site does not work on mobile devices. Think about the kittens!! And if you’re thinking, “there aren’t THAT many devices out there,” and “it can’t be THAT hard to be responsive,” think about those kittens one final time.

I am sure there is a number out there on the internet waiting to be found telling us how many devices are web capable, and I am also sure it’s large. Keep in mind each device is designed differently, with different software requirements, default browsers, and different hardware specs. That means, as a developer, no matter what you’re building, you will likely find yourself daydreaming of how many kittens you’d prefer were being hit in the face, while you debug the fifth CSS error you encounter in Safari, that never existed in Chrome…Sorry, that got a bit personal.

As much as I would like to believe my iPhone is having an identity crisis, that’s not the actual case. There are standards out there for web design (sometimes sketchy ones), that are intended to help developers and browsers work within boundaries that help to simplify things. And I know what you’re thinking.

Thank you, mobile gods. We’re saved!

But we haven’t quite saved those kitties just yet.

You may still be thinking, “Why do you need to know all this?”

If you’re a business owner looking to increase your audience and you haven’t taken the responsive route, that should be the first thing on your to-do list. Online shopping is already a huge trend and still growing at this rate. If you’re trying to get your blog out there over a product, what better place for someone to read that than on their device while in the restroom? I mean really… we’ve all done it…

If you’re looking to get a better return on your investment (ROI), responsiveness is another way to do that. If you do not have a fully responsive design, you are throwing away potential page views and potential dollars pulled in from your mobile shoppers.

Now onto saving all those kittens!

If you’re not familiar with WordPress or its standards, there are these things called themes. I mean, to take it directly from the WordPress Codex:

A WordPress Theme is a collection of files that work together to produce a graphical interface with an underlying unifying design for a weblog. These files are called template files. A Theme modifies the way the site is displayed, without modifying the underlying software.

To put it simply, a theme is the look and feel of your site via functionality and design. It’s the idea that you can do anything with your content within the provided templates and have a consistent and clean flow.

Popular WordPress themes from Elegant Themes

There are thousands of themes out there to pick from. Whether you’re building a store front, a restaurant front and menu, a non-profit donation location, a blog, or an educational site, there is something out there for you. There are many free options, usually offered through the CMS that’s been installed, and paid options that tend to be found via outside sources.

So get to searching for the responsive theme that fits your needs, either through WordPress or through a seller like ThemeForest. The kittens will thank you.

If you go searching and nothing seems to catch your eye (insert joke about cats chasing the red dot of doom), there are always custom themes. This is the option for businesses that are looking for a specific look or functionality that they can’t find anywhere else. Being unique can be a huge benefit to a business with the right design and implementation. This is a costlier option but usually has a higher turn around on traffic and offers more options for Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and design tactics. Marketing teams usually love this option!

That’s it, that’s all you have to do.

As developers, we have to do much much MUCH more to make something like a custom theme or purchased theme modifications (maybe I’ll write about that in the future for all the dev-heads out there wanting to help the kitties), but as a website owner using WordPress, that’s all you have to do; find a theme that is responsive. You can look more into the Jetpack plugin to help with SEO as well (yet, again, maybe another post for the future).

So get out there and start saving those kittens! I believe you will make the right decision!

Also, if you need some emergency kittens, go here. You’re welcome.

profile.name: Shai Yallin
profile.bio: I'm an engineering manager at the Wix Backend Group, where I have introduced and spread the use of the Scala programming language. talk.title: TDD: Cultivating a Beginner's Mind
talk.description:
Even though Agile has been around for more than 15 years, many software organizations still practice Big Design Up Front. A lot of focus is put on the *initial development* aspect, before the first delivery, and little attention is given to the *maintenance phase* of the software system. With more and more organizations shifting to SaaS models, creating long-lived Internet systems that aren’t forgiving to downtimes or cumbersome data migrations, maintenance becomes much more important and critical to the overall design of the system than the initial development.

Agile offers a different, *Emergent* method to design software, with small iterations that, when combined with continuous delivery and learning, results in a design that’s much more adaptive to changing requirements. Taken to the extreme, we shorten the initial development phase to a minimum and focus mostly on iterative maintenance steps. 

However, the conditions required to facilitate Emergent Design require that the development team refrain from over-engineering and YAGNI violations - two problems that are prevalent in the software industry, especially with less-experienced engineers. Outside-In Development is a methodology that helps us focus on the Semantics rather the Mechanics of our software, protect us from YAGNI violations, and thus facilitate Emergent Design. Practicing TDD helps us implement this methodology in the scope of a commercial software project, by helping us cultivate a Beginner’s Mind towards software design.
talk.notes:
I will start by describing the gap between how engineers usually view software design and how Internet-scale systems actually evolves. I will then make the point that software isn’t like bridges, cars or other “classical” engineering projects. I will use the biological analogy, talking about software as a garden and how we always build on existing system state, and how software engineering is an ongoing, evolving effort. I will claim that a paradigm shift is needed towards wide adoption of Emergent Design.

Next, I will explain why traditional software engineering training is deleterious to this paradigm shift, with people learning to think about static, rather than evolving, software design, and are taught more about the mechanics of software (design patterns, technology) and less about the semantics (creating the right abstractions). I will discuss Outside-In Development and explain how it helps stick to the YAGNI principle, and how this facilitates Emergent Design. I will explain that it’s hard to adopt outside-in due to the way engineers are trained and how cultivating a Beginner’s Mind helps us put aside these problems and achieve outside-in.

Finally, I will explain how practicing TDD helps us cultivate the Beginner’s Mind and facilitate outside-in, with test-first serving as the outside user of a system or subsystem, and how the Refactoring phase of TDD helps design emerge.

### Presentation History:
Initially developed in 2014 as an internal Wix.com tech talk. Presented in:
Reversim Summit Tel Aviv 2015 
Voxxed Days Vilnius 2015 
Clean Code Days Munich 2015 
Continuous Lifecycle London 2016
XP2016 Edinburgh
Testcon Vilnius 2016
talk.abstract: Everyone’s talking about Agile, but most of us actually do Scrumfall. The rise of SaaS systems calls for a paradigm shift in software design. In this talk, I will discuss Emergent Design using TDD as a way around the inherent problems in Big Design Up Front and our education as software engineers.
