talk.title: Crowdsourcing Software Architecture – The Distributed Architect
talk.description:
Software Architects need to have it all: exceptional technological know-how, up-to-date programming experience, good people skills, ability to abstract, knowledge of important architectural styles and tactics, visionary leadership a.s.o. It has always been difficult to find all of these aspects in a single person. Modern development efforts set in highly dynamic, agile contexts and the emergence of polyglott technological environments make it even more challenging.

This talk introduces alternatives to the classic role of the software architect that showed a boost in delivery speed, overall product quality and organizational flexibility in real life projects of various domains: 

* The work without formal architect roles
* The idea of ‚marshals‘ for architectural concerns or important drivers and 
* A variant of the architecture owner role

All of them do well in an agile project setup and embody a distributed approach of handling architectural concerns. Important factors for choosing between these approaches are shown as well as the core concepts that make them effective even in more complex environments - including low viscosity design, architecture communities and tests of quality attributes.
talk.notes:
This talk can be held as a *short introduction* (30 mins) or as an *interactive tutorial* with one or two small exercises (90 mins), which ever fits the conferences schedule best.

All of the concepts I present are field-tested. I wrote a published book on agile software architecture in 2013 (for the renowned German publisher 'Carl Hanser') that also covered the agile view on the role of the software architect. Since 2008 I worked with companies like Lufthansa, Volkswagen, Postfinance, Hamburg Süd and others in agile transformation initiatives to establish these role ideas that are presented and illustrated in real-life examples.

feedback.body:
Stephan-

This is an interesting topic, but I have a question:
There is a long-held idea that an architecture should have conceptual integrity, and that this comes from having a single architect or small, tight group create the architecture. Your approach challenges this, and I would like to see some comment in your talk about it. Is conceptual integrity not important? Or is it over-interpreted, and you have a lighter-weight definition that works in practice? Or is it possible to achieve conceptual integrity with a distributed architect (and if so, what is the key)?

Thank you.

Hi John,
Thanks for your comment and yes, conceptual integrity is an issue we have to tackle in our projects frequently. In this talk I discuss integrity on several levels: 

First, not all of the alternatives I present are actually a departure from persons or small groups driving the architecture. "Marshalls" are typically accountable for a cross-cutting concern spanning the whole system or big parts of it. They look after integrity in architectural approaches assotiated with security, performance or recurring technical problems with infrastructure etc. So the classic architect is splitted, but not in a functional fashion as the system itsself.
Also the approach of an architecture owner encapsulates important topics in one person. In this case it is a person with general overview, experience and a broad vision. He is more of a mentor and rises important topics. He isn't the one who decides and designs everything though. This is mapped to a team where he has the same possibilities and tools as everyone else. Conceptual Integrity is an important driver for him though. 
Only one of the presented options goes without a person or team explicitly and foremost responsible for the architecture. 

Second, the integrity of a system has big advantages in productivity, maintainability and derivatively in reliability, security and so on. Nevertheless it comes at a cost and many modern systems see conceptual integrity as a scale, where the maximum is not the ultimate goal. We could for instance define a minimum of common ground that works for a given project. Could be the deployment model, the general structure, the monitoring and security approaches and some interface standards. Inside these general rules a team could in fact develop solutions that are structured very differently and possibly use other technologies than other teams of the same project. Of course this poses problems in reusability and the other areas stated, on the other hand the teams can act on their own and usually deliver value faster. If the architectural drivers and the context allow it, a little less integrity could be optimal for a project.

Third, even without an architect that predefines approaches and tactics we were able to achieve a good level of architectural integrity. Integrity is driven by a good engineering process, broad architectural knowledge, experimenting developers and some kind of "natural selection process". This selection process includes that good solutions are broadcasted to all teams and their adaptation is made easier. Bad ideas or the divergence from a known best practice should be harder to implement. In the acstract I call that "low viscosity design". Architecture then focuses on the identification of good approaches, the support of their communication and the creation of space to abstract good solutions and make them more universal. This is another form of architectural work as the "standards-first" approach, with arguably lower conceptual integrity, but often faster innovation, better flexibility and more realistic architectural concepts. A combination of top-down and bottom-up architectural approaches is a good fit for most projects I work on, low viscosity can shift the boundary a little in the bottom-up direction without causing direct chaos.

All of these topics are introduced in this talk, not all of them are covered in great detail. I am open to shifting the focus of the talk a bit if certain aspects sound very interesting for you. The 90min version will have a deeper look and also an exercise on some veto-mechanisms we use to broaden the accountability but not lessen the influence of good architects.

Thanks,
Stefan

Thank you for accepting my talk for SATURN 2017! Very happy to be part of this great conference again.
It would be great if my talk fitted the schedule on Tuesday or Wednesday (2nd or 3rd of May) as my travel arrangements from Europe get quite complicated otherwise.  Would that be possible?

talk.title: Deep Learning for Software Development
talk.description:
How can we apply machine learning (and visualization) to aid software development - specifically, software developers? While there is some work in this field, most of it has been devoted to metrics and estimates. Metrics are shadows of snowflakes, and thus not particularly informative when seeking to understand the purpose of a system or the behavior of a component. Improving estimation, while an interesting application and a laudable goal, likewise does not directly help developers create better software faster, nor manage the growing complexity of real-world systems. Can we apply ML in ways that help guide development, inform software archaeology, and reduce effort for developers? If so, can these things help us take on the systems-of-systems-of-systems of the future, where million-line code bases will be considered "quaint"?
After a brief survey of existing/past work in the area, we'll investigate the question of "what does software look like", examine the more interesting question of "what does good software look like", and use these insights to explore how we can enable developers to create and manage ever-larger software systems. No ML experience or math required. Lots of pretty pictures.
talk.notes: I've been research the applications of AI/ML/DL to software development, and experimenting with some unique approaches specifically intended to aid software developers, including the notion of 'semantic drift' (the 'distance' between classes and stories in semantic space) and topic-based clustering of software subsystems as a guide to refactoring. This talk avoids complex math, instead offering an intuition for how the main deep learning approaches work and why they work, includes a lot of pretty pictures, and outlines some future directions in software development principles and practices.
talk.abstract: Most of the AI breakthroughs in the last 4 years have been the result of deep learning; but what, if anything can deep learning do to help software developers?

* Are you going to highlight or show any specific tech?
* Do we need to design software systems differently to take advantage of the techniques and approaches you'll discuss?

Hi Michael!

Thanks, I'm glad you like it! To your questions -

- I will show some of the 'semantic drift', clustering, and visualization work that I've been doing, which *should* be open-sourced by the time of the conference
- re 'design systems differently to take advantage of the work': yes and no :) Using latent semantic analysis on software systems works best when the software source code uses relevant words from the domain (otherwise the software just talks about itself, i.e. what it is doing in stead of why it is doing things); the more domain knowledge/model/words that are embedded in the code, the better. I am explicitly using domain-driven design structures (bounded contexts, context maps) married with semantic visualizations (topic maps derived from natural language processing word-vector vocabularies) as a yardstick for what "good" software looks like .
- yes. My work in this area started because of a real problem: trying to quickly understand a 2-million-line codebase. I have applied earlier versions of the tools to real-world projects (e.g. mapping 72,000 stories and 8,000 classes into the same semantic space), and continue to do so. However, the purpose of the talk is not to present something as 'solved', but to introduce developers and architects (et al) to the intriguing possibilities in this space (which are largely unexplored) and to encourage them to get involved.

Thanks!

--S

talk.title: DevOps, architecture, and security in a cloud
talk.description:
The success of your DevOps team depends on the collaboration between developers and cloud operations teams, maturity of development processes, security architecture, guiding software architecture principles, and the ability of the team to automate the delivery of software and infrastructure to customers. These factors along with the infrastructure management and integration challenges will be amplified in a cloud or hybrid environment. 

In this presentation, we will describe our DevOps implementation plan from inception to cost management; share our operation automation practices, security guidelines for cloud-based services as well as solutions integrated with on-premises systems; compare deployment automation options and high availability solutions based on 2 container management approaches; review our software choices that include packages provided by several vendors (Amazon, Microsoft, Dell, and others) and open source software such as GitHub, Artifactory, Jenkins, Docker, Kubernetes, etc.

At the end we will summarize challenges we faced during the course of this initiative, positive impact on the organization, and DevOps roadmap in 2017.

UPMC Enterprises is the commercialization arm of UPMC with approximately 220 employees. At UPMC Enterprises, we both develop and invest in exceptional health care technology. Our portfolio includes 7 health information technology companies and several ongoing initiatives. Our current cloud footprint consists of 12 non-production and 8 production environments managed by 11 members of the Client Services team.
talk.notes:
Last year we worked out an all-encompassing plan for the DevOps initiative at UPMC Enterprises.  The materials of the ‘DevOps and Continuous Delivery: Practices, Architecture, and Security’ workshop presented at Saturn 2016 were used as a foundation for the plan. We have completed 2 phases of this effort addressing the security, continuous deployment/delivery, and integration requirements with minimal architectural debt. 
Due to the nature of the UPMCE structure our development environments have diverse infrastructure, development tools and platforms. They often combine building blocks that come from the AWS cloud as well as UPMC data centers. 
In this initiative we leveraged packages provided by several vendors (Amazon, Microsoft, Dell, and others) and open source software such as GitHub, Artifactory, Jenkins, Docker, Kubernetes, etc. 

This presentation will include the following topics
-UPMC Enterprises goals and objectives
-Overview of UPMCE development and client service environments 
-Major sections of the DevOps implementation plan: application infrastructure management, application infrastructure monitoring, application lifecycle management, cloud infrastructure optimization, information management and governance
-Security in a cloud
-High availability and container management
-Overview of software packages and tools
-Lessons learned and roadmap

talk.title: Django & Twitter bootstrap in the workplace: build 'em fast and furious
talk.description:
The modern web developer has an unenviable task. Users have become familiar with popular web applications, and expect perfect uptime, bug-free experiences, simple and intuitive UI, and perfect security. Fortunately, the proliferation of high-quality frameworks for virtually *everything*—front-end, back-end, infrastructure—has made the job of the developer significantly easier. In this talk, I'll outline how my team used Django and Twitter Bootstrap to build a complete production reporting solution in under three months. These tools are incredibly powerful and can save you hundreds of hours of work.

We'll also discuss the trade-offs associated with training, and the impacts of choosing to train your team extensively or more sparsely on the tools you develop. The decision on training turns out to be more nuanced than you would expected.

Specifically, we'll discuss:

* Why Django—ORM, Security, Usability, Modularity
* Why Bootstrap—benefits of smooth, consistent, popular UI
* Django admin, CBVs—save time by getting to know the framework
* How to set up the team for success—necessary training, knowledge, etc.

We've had great success with these tools, and you can too!
talk.notes:
I've been writing django apps for a number of years now. I've managed three teams writing django applications, which gives me significant insight into what worked and what didn't, as well as what would have made it better; I would love to give that advice over to potential users. 

The talk should probably be given to either technical managers or developers who understand what a database is and know at least basics of coding.

This can be expanded into an interactive tutorial if necessary. We really can build a fully-functional website in 90 minutes, and people may be interested in trying.

talk.title: Enterprise IT - How to avoid mediocrity
talk.description:
Enterprise IT organizations attract and foster mediocrity. We argue that this is one of the fundamental reasons that keeps large enterprises from outperforming leaner organizations even though they have greater resources on hand.

This talk describes a fictional (albeit slightly inspired from reality) organization with huge cultural problems, and takes it to the extreme to illustrate how bad it can be and how it came to be this way.

Half of the time will be spent on describing the mess we're in and how we got there, the other half on possible ways we could have avoided this situation and possibly how we can get out of it in a culture that shuns firing people (which perhaps would have solved it in part).

Our premise is that a solid culture of learning and continuous improvement as well as a focus on good software architecture and practices could have prevented the mess, and that it is not to late to turn it around.

I promise an entertaining talk with a lot of humor (albeit of the dark kind), and possibly some insights that you can take back to your organization so that you don't end up in the same mess (if you aren't already there).

__Key takaways from this talk:__

* Architecture governance is key to combat technical debt
* Continuous focus on learning can help avoid the knowledge rot that often comes with a mediocre software group
* The Dreyfus model of skills acquisition and the Expert beginner.
* The common fallacy of tuning your corporate messages, governance, and technology choices for the mediocre or the underperforming, and thereby alienating your best performers.
talk.notes:
I have been spending much of my time in the resent years contemplating the challenges of a large organization, and I have recently gotten some insights that I would like to share with the SATURN audience. This is partly an experience report in the guise of humor and satire, basically an attempt at making light of a very serious and very real problem that I have experienced in our own organization.

I think there is a clear leadership story in this, and it pertains both to political leaders (management) and to technical leaders (software architects). A big part of the solution to the problem is the focus on good software practices and software architecture, which is where I see the main relevance for the SATURN audience.
talk.abstract: In our presentation "What happens when you break all the rules?" from a couple of years ago we stated that "large enterprises attract and cultivate mediocrity".  In this talk I will outline why this is the case, and suggest some measures that large organizations can take to avoid this phenomenon.

talk.title: From REST to gRPC: An API Evolution Story
talk.description:
The APIs for components in fine grained service-oriented architectures strongly influence the eventual properties expressed in the system.  REST over HTTP is a popular choice for microservices APIs because it promotes openness, self-discovery, and simplicity.  One alternative to REST is [gRPC](http://www.grpc.io/), an implementation of Protobuf.  As an RPC-based API, gRPC inhibits openness and self-discovery but promotes performance and, depending on the implementation, can provide stronger compile-time (or at least call-time) guarantees which help developers avoid mistakes.

In this talk we will share our experiences migrating a REST-based microservice to gRPC, as well as lessons learned implementing gRPC APIs in a suite of backing microservices for the Watson Discovery Service.

By the end of this talk, attendees will know

* What gRPC is and how it is different from REST
* How to organize code to make API transitions easier
* The benefits of functional testing using Cucumber and tips for creating extensible gRPC API tests using Ruby
* How to implement common REST patterns in gRPC
* Common pitfalls for using gRPC in a microservices architecture and some solutions
talk.notes:
This talk will have the following tentative outline.

1. Set the stage / Context
     * What my team was building
     * Why switch to gRPC?
2. Our architecture evolution plan
     * Spike -- gRPC prototypes and plan our transition
     * Phase 1: Design gRPC API, influenced by the current REST API
     * Phase 2: REST + GRPC
     * Phase 3: Transition functional tests written in Cucumber with Ruby
     * Phase 4: Remove REST functionality
3. Spike
     * What is gRPC?
     * Example with code
     * Required tools
     * REST facade was a bust
4. Design gRPC API
     * Killing the hypermedia dream
     * REST is not RPC -- need to rethink resources and relationships
     * One request, one response
     * Everything is optional
     * Impossible to send bad values: choose types wisely
     * New constructs: repeated, streaming
     * Enum names
     * method and message names
5. REST + gRPC: run two servers side-by-side
    * Spring boot: seemed like a good idea at the time...
    * Layers worked extremely well
    * Health checks
6. Transition functional tests
    * We implement functional tests in Cucumber and Ruby, quick example and benefits
    * Transition plan allowed us to run tests against gRPC and REST endpoints, useful for incremental evolution
    * Tips for testing gRPC endpoints using Ruby (meta programming FTW!)
7. Remove REST Functionality
   * As simple as deleting the REST API package
   * We were able to fork the microservice into a REST facade.
8. Microservices governance concerns: and our solutions
   * Usability tests are important
   * Health checks
   * How will you discover APIs?
   * How will you manage and version `.proto` files?
   * Documenting APIs (REST has standards and more tools)
9. Conclusions
   * Classic example of an architecture evolution
   * Classic example of how clean abstractions in static structures (layers in this case) can make it trivial to deal with certain kinds of change
   * gRPC practice is still emerging, we covered several useful patterns and our approaches to some common problems.
talk.abstract: An existing REST-based microservice.  A new requirement to use gRPC.  A team under pressure to ship.  In this talk we will describe how we moved backing Watson Discovery microservices from REST to gRPC and the lessons we learned in the process.

talk.title: Functional programming invades architecture
talk.description:
A few decades ago when the first architecture books were being written, today's large-scale web systems were an oddity but now they are mainstream.  Our architecture pattern languages have changed as have our development, deployment, and operating procedures (DevOps).  

During this transition, one source of ideas has been the functional programming community.  Functional programming itself mostly happens within a module and indeed many software architects treat it as an implementation choice, unrelated to architecture.  But it turns out that some ideas from the FP community are helpful in architectural design: statelessness, immutability, and pure functions.  They underlie DevOps practices and are at the core of many distributed systems patterns at the core of our architectures.

## Why now?  
Functional programming ideas have been around for a long time but conditions are ripe.

1.  Coping strategy for complexity.  As systems get bigger but our brains stay the same size, we invent tech to cope.  Statelessness, immutability, and pure functions make it easier to reason about how a system behaves.
2.  Problems grew in size.  No single computer big enough to run a system.  FP ideas suited to parallelism and concurrency, so many smaller computers can solve big problems.
3.  We have more money than sense.  You can buy 100 cloud machines for less than one junior developer.  So why not do Continuous Integration with every source code commit?  Why not have a farm of servers running different versions of your code during deployments?  Why not burn RAM with immutable data structures?

## Functional ideas in modern architectures

1. Client-side.  Reactive patterns and frameworks.  Eg React, CycleJS, Elm.
2. Server-side.  So-called "serverless" pure functions.  REST architectural style.  Reactive services.  Event queues between services.
3. Persistence.  Append-only datastores.  Event sourcing & Command Query Response Segregation (CQRS).
4. Batch sequential & pipeline architectures:  Big data processing (Hadoop, Spark), Map-Reduce, Tensorflow and other machine learning graph-based functional transformation.
5. Devops infrastructure.  Version control everything (append-only).  So-called "immutable" and "idempotent" infrastructure set up by running code, not by Linux admins.

## Reactive programming
1. What is it?  Evolution of Observer pattern.  Observable = Observer pattern plus onError and onCompletion.  Hot and cold streams.
2. Use in UI architectures.  Strong competitor to Model-View-Controller and sibling patterns.  

## What you will learn in this talk
The amount of innovation and hype in web technologies is intense and often overwhelming.  If you haven't been staying current, this talk should give you a mental map to start your learning.  If you have stayed current, this talk should reveal how functional ideas weave throughout modern web architectures and perhaps provide insight into why they work.

The talk surveys how modern web systems are built with FP patterns.  It will dig into one client-side example and show how FP ideas can simplify this task.

profile.name: Christopher Phillips
profile.bio: I have seven years of traditional software application development across a variety of languages and technologies. talk.title: Going Serverless: Building Production Applications Without Managing Infrastructure
talk.description: With the release of AWS Lambda and API Gateway, it has become possible to build RESTful interfaces without managing any server infrastructure. Leveraging this and other AWS services, it has become possible to build entire business applications in a secure, scalable fashion, without provisioning VMs or taking on the system administration tasks that entails. There has since been quite a bit of buzz around 'Serverless' development, with entire frameworks and tooling built to support such an approach. This talk is intended to discuss what the tradeoffs of taking such an approach are, how to technically execute on such an approach within AWS, and what my own experiences have been in building and running Serverless applications in production.
talk.notes:
90 minutes

As the backend tech lead at Stanley Black and Decker I have led the development and deployment of multiple applications into production that rely entirely on Serverless backends, along with a hybrid legacy app that we are currently moving toward being Serverless. 

I intend to cover the basics of building REST interfaces on top of the AWS API Gateway and AWS Lambda, delve into the tradeoffs of doing so, and then branch out into methods and considerations of data storage, access control (including authorization/authentication of users to your REST endpoints and other resources), continuous integration and development, messaging patterns (both solely on the backend, and between the backend and various user clients), backend generated events and triggers (i.e., responding to scheduled events, or building in logic to trigger additional behaviors outside of the context of a user request), and various best practices and considerations I've learned from my experiences.

In the course of this talk I will touch on the place of the following AWS services in a Serverless solution - Lambda, API Gateway, S3, Dynamo, RDS, Elasticache, IAM, Cognito, STS, SQS, SNS, IoT, CloudFormations, Cloudfront, Route 53.

The intended presentation mechanism is predominantly slides, with links to code and Cloudformations to illustrate less obvious implementation strategies  (i.e., not "here's how to write a record to DynamoDB", which is easily gleaned from API documents, but "here's code demonstrating the usage of the AWS IoT platform as a websocket for sending arbitrary messages across", or "here's an example Cloudformation for setting up an existing lambda to execute periodically, and to include a dead letter queue to report errors to". In general, my goal is not to give an end to end working example of everything I discuss (as that will be impossible to go over in detail in the time frame, and will be exceptionally contrived), but instead to go over enough to give people a high degree of confidence in speccing out their own projects, while also providing code or walk through an example for anything that did not strike me as inherently obvious on how to implement from glancing at AWS' documentation. 

Tentative high level outline - 

1. API Gateway and Lambda - demonstrate a Serverless endpoint, wherein we can see arbitrary code execution in response to an HTTP POST, in the context of a Lambda, which simply parrots back the body and one or two headers, to show how they can be mapped into the function. Discuss using the API Gateway as a passthrough to an existing REST API, to allow for the swapping out, endpoint by endpoint, to a serverless one, in the event of a legacy app.

2. Data storage options - largely high level discussion of considerations between Elasticache, DynamoDB, and S3 as storage mechanisms, in terms of cost, ease of use, and availability/consistency guarantees.

3. Backend processing and user notification - Discuss lambda event sources and their implications (the ability to trigger lambdas from writes to Dynamo or S3, a brief foray into SQS as a distributed queue, and how things can fail, and what to do about them). Demonstrate using AWS IoT for websocket pushes to web clients (and mention GCM and APNS as still being available for pushing to mobile). Discuss SNS as an option to broadcast events to custom HTTP endpoints, or to send emails, as well as a possible way to send mobile push messages.

4. Access Control - Discuss Cognito as an Amazon provided identity provider. Demonstrate how to go from a Cognito identity (or a custom identity, if using custom code to log someone in) to a set of temporary AWS credentials, that can be used to access resources. A brief foray into IAM policies (which control what a set of AWS credentials have access to). And how to leverage both IAM and AWS credentials to properly secure one's own REST API endpoints.

5. CI/CD - Discuss some of the frameworks for developing and deploying serverless code to AWS. Demonstrate an example using the Serverless (http://www.serverless.com/) framework. Demonstrate Cloudformations as a way to define and port infrastructure between environments. Suggest the use of AWS Config and Cloudtrail to track changes. 

6. Monitoring - Dive into Cloudwatch. Demonstrate executing lambdas, navigating the resulting logs, exporting to S3 for ingesting into another tool. Demonstrate available metrics, and how to set up alarms. Discuss integration points with tools we've used.

7. Latency and Cloudfront- Discuss latency of lambdas. How real it is, how to mitigate it, when to cache. Demonstrate setting up a Cloudfront instance in front of custom API, and when to use it vs the API Gateway's cache.
talk.abstract: This talk is to introduce Serverless computing, a new paradigm in the cloud for deploying applications that requires no server administration, and which scales transparently in both function and cost. feedback.body:
Hi Christopher,
Thank you for the submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. The first sentence of the description implicates a causal relation that I believe doesn't exist ("With the release of AWS Lambda and API Gateway, it has become possible to build RESTful interfaces without any server infrastructure in the cloud").  One can build REST interfaces for enterprise systems on-premises for the intranet, without AWS Lambda or API Gateway. In any case, if you're using AWS Lambda, I think you *are* using cloud infrastructure, you just don't need to procure/manage/be aware of the servers.  

2. In the notes you say "I intend to cover the basics of building REST interfaces." Do you mean REST API design? That's a quite large topic on its own.  

3. In addition to benefits, I think you should also discuss the challenges and drawbacks of serverless architecture. Such discussion flows naturally into motivation for and risks associated with serverless. 

4. A 90-minute long talk takes the time equivalent to 3 30-minute talks, so the info should be clearly valuable. Serverless is a hot topic this year and many people want to know what it is, if it's a good fit for them, what's the roadmap to 'go serverless'. I think your talk goes over all of that. Do you intend to talk about serverless outside AWS? For example, simple use of MBaaS for mobile app authentication?  

5. In the notes section, consider including an outline of your talk, even if it’s only tentative.

6. What is "event pipelining"? Is there a more commonly used equivalent term? Maybe a term that's in wikipedia?  :^)

7. Just to clarify, what's the presentation mechanics? Slide-based presentation end-to-end? Or do you plan  to have a demo? Or is it a tutorial where participants will actually use their laptops to play with the technology?

Thanks so much for your input! I've endeavored to clarify much of what was indicated; on a point by point basis - 

1. Clarified.
2. Clarified.
3. That was very much the intent, to include complications/issues, what can be done about them, and when it makes sense to not go Serverless - in the description I mentioned 'discuss what the tradeoffs of taking such an approach are'; should I word things differently or elaborate there?
4. My intention was to focus on AWS; as part of that, I intended to discuss Cognito, AWS' mobile identity provider, along with how it provides STS tokens, themselves associated with IAM roles, and how those are used across AWS to access services directly, and can also be used to control access to individual API endpoints. That was my intent with mentioning access control in the description; does that need to be called out in the notes, or more clearly spelled out in the description?
5. Added
6. Clarified
7. Added in Notes.

Thanks for updating the submission. 
3. I think there's no need to word things differently or elaborate.
4. I think description and notes are ok as is. There are talks about serverless at a more conceptual level and others are more technology-specific. Both "kinds" are welcome and valuable. I just wanted to clarify.

talk.title: How to Perform a Rapid Assessment of any Software Architecture
talk.description: As a software architect for your organization, you may may be required to efficiently and effectively evaluate the validity, quality, health and/or maturity of a proposed, new or legacy software architecture. This presentation suggests a simple process you can follow to perform a rapid assessment of any software architecture effort regardless of its size, complexity or stage of development. The focus is on capturing the most critical aspects of the software architecture including: (a) Software Quality Attributes; (b) Key Architectural Decisions (including hardware platforms, software technology, development tools and reuse strategy); and (c) Architectural Design (primarily in the form of Unified Modeling Language or UML). Emphasis is placed on identifying and documenting references to existing artifacts. It generally requires an interview with the most knowledgeable software engineer on the proposal, development or maintenance team to identify the location of artifacts that are available and information that has never been documented. This is basically a two-day process. On the first day information is gathered and quickly recorded. On the second day, the information is analyzed, expert opinion(s) formulated, and a report is prepared and disseminated to all of the relevant Stakeholders. The process is a simple and straightforward mechanism for capturing software architecture and rapidly performing a valuable assessment during any time in the lifecycle of the product.
talk.notes:
This process is one that I developed at Raytheon for my own use as a software architect. It is my responsibility to periodically review proposed, new, and existing software architectures across the organization to maintain a consistent understanding of the validity, quality, health and maturity of our products.

talk.title: Method for Business Function Allocation and Interface Definition in System-of-Systems Architecture .
talk.description:
System-of-Systems in Roche Diagnostics context
==============================================

Certain business processes in medical diagnostics areas involve many large scale systems (million connection points) distributed through Roche enterprise and customer clinical laboratories. The involved systems fulfill valid purposes in their own right, can operate separately and are managed for their own purpose rather than the purposes of the whole.

Allocation of business functions to specific system components and definition of interfaces with significant consequences for architecture of such large and complex IT and software system-of-systems (SoS) is a challenge. It requires data supporting decision criteria and accommodating fast evolution of the architecture in the agile organization.  

Roche Customized Method of Architecting SoS 
===========================================

For the architecting of the system-of-systems in Roche product context a customized method was defined based on the US Department of Defense Architecture Framework.

This method involves 6 steps with start/finish criteria and deliverables for each. I will illustrate these steps using examples from Roche.

1.  Business process Domain Analysis (identification of Business Drivers, Business Capabilities, Business Functions, Constraints, elaboration of User Stories and Workflows, definition of Quality Attributes).

2.  Integrated Dynamic Modeling (IDM) for multiple workflows within the business process.

3.  Derivation of Events, Activities and Resources for each workflow IDM.

4.  Alignment to elaborate Common Events, Common Activities and Common Resources for all modelled workflows.

5.  Identification of existing/overlapping/missing functionality (based on Activities) and data and processors (based on Resources) in involved systems. Preliminary allocation of the functions to the systems and verification of fulfillment of Business Criteria (based on Domain Analysis).

6.  Architecting of data, process, deployment, … models and preliminary design of interface between the involved systems.  Verification of Quality Attributes fulfillment.

This method can be applied in agile projects, if the sprints are oriented on implementation of workflow.

Results of application of the method at Roche
=============================================

The customized method for the architecting of system-of-systems was applied to business processes related to Remote Solutions and IoT. It led to quick definition of models and derived data supporting the decision making and allocation of business functions and resources to existing and to be developed systems as well as identification of common resources and interfaces for their exchange.
talk.notes:
As author of this method and part of the team applying it in the real world large scale projects I can give the practitioners view and probably answer most of questions. 
My talk at the SATURN 2016 related to multiple ATAMs gave a short introduction to a small subset of the entire system.

talk.title: Microservices and Docker at Scale: the PB&J of Modern Application Delivery
talk.description:
Docker has matured, and is expanding from being predominantly used in the Build/Test stages to Production deployments. Similarly, microservices are expanding from being used mostly for green-field web services to being used in the enterprise - as organizations explore ways to decompose their monolith to support faster release cycles.

Running microservices-based applications in a containerized environment makes a lot of sense – both for Build and Test, as well as from a runtime perspective in Production.

Docker and Microservices are natural companions, forming the foundation for modern application delivery. However, managing microservices and large-scale Docker deployments pose unique challenges for enterprise IT.

This talk discusses the modern requirements for building, deploying and operating microservices on a large-scale Docker-ized infrastructure. It covers:

• Patterns for microservices-based architectures
• What makes Docker such a good fit for microservices
• How to operationalize Docker orchestration, auto-scaling and DR in large-scale Production environments – recommended typologies and patterns
• Best practices for Docker configuration and registry management to ensure consistency throughout the pipeline and stability in Production
• Tips for integrating containers into complex existing environments, supporting the hybrid state of microservices and monolithic applications
• Tips and tooling for monitoring and managing clusters of containers as a single distributed application
• Putting an end to Shadow-IT: how can IT enable Dev and Ops to use Docker for both microservices and traditional application releases - while ensuring visibility, security, governance and compliance
talk.notes: This talk was developed as a joint session with Electric Cloud CTO, Anders Wallgren: Anders Wallgren is chief technology officer at Electric Cloud. Anders has over 25 years’ experience designing and building commercial software. Prior to joining Electric Cloud, he held executive positions at Aceva, Archistra, and Impresse and management positions at Macromedia (MACR), Common Ground Software, and Verity (VRTY), where he played critical technical leadership roles in delivering award winning technologies such as Macromedia’s Director 7. Anders holds a B.SC from MIT.

talk.title: Micro services architecture - lessons learned
talk.description:
The speaker works as Director of Software Engineering at Capital One. In this talk, he will share lessons from implementing microservices architecture for a regulatory initiative.

The talk will focus on –

- What are the business drivers for the microservices architecture?
- What are the lessons we learnt from an architecture perspective?
- Why Devops practices are important?
- What cultural and software engineering best practices help?
- What are the communication imperatives when you are building an enterprise microservice?
talk.notes:
I am a Director of Software Engineering at Capital One. My focus in on Marketing and Decisioning Technologies. I am in their Richmond, VA location.  I lead a team of 70 engineers developing architecture, building APIs and devops platforms. Over the last couple of years we built several mission critical APIs most of them are for customer facing and highly regulated capabilities. We learnt a lot breaking a monolithic application into micro services. I led delivery of several enterprise APIs and deployed into production. Hope to share my experiences in the session. I will also have some time for questions and answers at the end. The talk should last for 30 min.
I will be explaining the following success factors and considerations

Why did we go with micro services?

The initiative that I led was a regulatory project for Know Your Customer (KYC) regulation. It has very tight timelines and dependencies across the organization. The best way we could have accomplished the timelines is to go with a microservices architecture. So the business drivers for microservices architecture are

- Ability to break the solution into manageable micro services and have small teams solve them. That increased the speed of development by taking advantage of public cloud, strong devops, and automated testing
- To drive accountability and ownership in a cross enterprise initiative
- We also wanted to break some capabilities away from a monolithic application that was getting difficult to change

So, it is the business imperatives that drove us towards the micro services architecture.

In general, if it is a differentiating capability for the business (say credit decisioning for a bank) and agility is important, microservices approach helps. If it is not a differentiating capability like payroll and HR, better stick to a vendor product.

Architecture:

- When re-architecting a monolithic application, we achieved better success starting with the head (or customer facing functions) of the monolithic application. As we get deeper there will be more dependencies making it difficult to decompose the application.
- It is important to Identify the business capability and design the contract accordingly. The architecture should be aligned with product owner and it should clearly articulate the problem the specific micro service is solving.
- Use domain driven design as much as possible. It is important to define the domain and the bounded context for the micro service. This also helps to define the granularity of the micro service. If the service is too big, it replicates the monolithic. Maintainability and agility should be kept in mind while designing the micro service. Our definition of a bounded context was driven by the following:
  - Autonomy of the domain, its business context, and self-contained data store without need for replication across microservices
  - The domain is simple to explain
  - In one instance performance dictated its domain. We separated a high performing calculation engine as its own microservice and developed it in GO language.
- Architect should focus on the API contract, interplay of micro services, and ensuring the non-functional requirements are met. It is important for the architect to know where to stop in the design
- What you design for real time may not work for batch. We first designed the microservices for real time first with a requirement of low throughput. But when we started using the microservices for batch use cases that had a higher throughput requirement, the infrastructure design did not work. So, we had to tune and scale up the microservices.
- While building individual microservices was easy, orchestrating the services wasn't easy. We built Java orchestrations, but very soon the orchestration services became too big to manage. We are experimenting with reactive frameworks.

Devops :

- Benefit of micro services is speed of development. Unless the code migration and deployment is automated, it is difficult to manage a micro services factory
- Automate integration testing and performance testing. We built automated testing for individual APIs, but did not build automated integration scripts. That became a bottleneck at the end as we had to do manual testing.
- With micro services, there will be frequent release. Hence, doing blue green deployment helps to minimize the down time
- A cloud first approach works better for micro services
- ATDD is a mandatory practice for micro services

Best practices and culture:

- Encourage Small teams of 4-5. If a micro service takes more than 1-2 developer to understand fully, it is too big and will become unmanageable
- Encourage pair programming
- Encourage knowledge sharing. Leverage demos to ensure teams get the big picture. Otherwise, developers will know only their micro service and miss the big picture. We moved away from separate production support teams. Teams support what they build. When we deployed the microservices into production, initially it was difficult to support as developers did not have the entire architecture context.
- With small teams, teams slowly have to graduate to full stack teams that can do everything the micro service needs.

Communication to stakeholders:

- It is important to communicate to clients often and in detail. Write a blog and publish every detail
- Version management is critical
- Contract first design helps in better communication

Other practical considerations

- Level of granularity is very important. Be ready to redefine and re-architect often as you go along
- It is impossible to have a separate support team to whom you hand off the micro- sevices after they are built. The eco system gets more complex for some other team to own manage. integrate support into delivery teams
- Alerting and monitoring is extremely important. Automate to the extent delivery teams spend less than 10% of their time on production support

talk.title: Pragmatic Architecture, Today.
talk.description:
Software development has evolved. Agile is now the de-facto standard. The role of an architect in an agile project is very different than the typical role in a more classic waterfall approach. Using an updated interpretation of ‘viewpoints and perspectives’, this talk will demonstrate how to make rapid, agile delivery sustainable in a constantly changing world. These viewpoints and perspectives will be linked to easy-to-produce models that can be used immediately in your projects. The talk will provide examples on how to determine which models are architecturally significant and worth the effort.

Developers have always been very important stakeholders of an architectural description. A good agile architect needs to strive for consensus and buy-in.
talk.notes:
Software architecture has a bad name. Developers often think that architects have no feeling with the actual application that they're building .. Sometimes they're right. But having no architecture is also a recipe for disaster.

I want to present a model (observe-orient-decide-act or OODA) with feedback loops that can lead to better quality software. Sharing ownership, making the architecture valuable for everyone is necessary to deliver successful software products. I've been using this approach for multiple projects and want to share how architecture, change and development methodologies go hand-in-hand.

Outline:
- What? (theoretical)
- Really? (practical, attractive example)
- Visual? (tips & tricks, focus on change)
- Why? (how much up-front, greenfield vs. existing)
- How? (OODA)

Thank you for the submission. I have a few suggestions/comments: 

1. The relation between agile development and architecture work has been examined and discussed for a decade. I'm curious to see your OODA approach. Indeed, I think you should name it in the talk description and make sure it is well described in the talk. 

2. As a sanity check, ask yourself if the approach works well for geographically distributed and/or outsourced teams. Also ask if it requires developers who are well versed in software design (in addition to architects who can code of course). 

3. Years ago I gave an interview to InfoQ. One of the questions was exactly about the topic of your talk. I'll reproduce here my answer. It's just food for thought for preparing your presentation...  

"It is a well known misconception that agile development means no documentation. In fact, as a [survey shows](http://www.ambysoft.com/surveys/modelingDocumentation2008.html), agile teams are more likely to model than traditional teams. A few things that agile architects (or perhaps any software architect) should remember: 

The key aspect of design/modeling in agile projects is not to avoid designing, but to avoid "big-design up-front" (BDUF). In general, high-level architectural strategies should be worked out up front, but many design decisions and design details can be left to when you need them. 

Only produce design documentation that will fulfill a need of the stakeholders. Stop designing as soon as you're ready to start coding. In the next sprint you can expand/refine the existing design as needed in order to capture design decisions required by next sprint's features. 

If it's not worth updating the design, throw it away. Some design diagrams are used to guide implementation, but at the end the code sometimes looks different from the diagram. If you don't have time to update the diagram to reflect the implementation, it's better to remove it than keeping an out-of-date diagram that may confuse a future reader. 

Many times, sketches are all you need. Don't spend too much time crafting the neatest diagram using the latest and richest notation available. Don't spend too much money on sophisticated modeling tools if you just need a drawing tool. In many agile projects, especially the ones with small, co-located teams, the true value of design diagrams comes from drawing them, which forces you to think through the issues; once the issues are solved, the diagrams lose much of their value. Many times the design is represented as a sketch on a whiteboard or piece of paper. If the sketch can be used to successfully convey the design to the team, that sketch, as is, can be *the* diagram in your architecture view. Why not?"

talk.title: Quality metrics: Nutritional Labels for Code
talk.description:
Software is an increasing part of our everyday lives. From the phones we carry, to the cars we drive, the thermostats that regulate our homes, even our lightbulbs - software is everywhere. But how much do we know about it? How secure is the banking app you use? What bugs might turn your home into a tropical paradise during your next winter trip? How convoluted is the code that runs your car? The last plane you took? The last traffic light you went through?

As consumers, we take nutrition labels on food for granted. A few simple, standard numbers let us make smart choices about the food we consume. Similarly, quality numbers should be routinely available for software, which is omnipresent and unavoidable in modern life. As consumers, we should have the data to make smart choices. After all, candy bars will only kill you slowly. Bad code could kill you very quickly.
talk.notes:
This is a lightning talk.

I work for SonarSource SA, the company behind SonarQube, a FLOSS platform to measure and monitor code quality. The purpose of the talk is not to flog the product, but to talk about why all software should be analyzed (by _some_ product) and the results published. But because it is easy (and the product is free!), I will propose that the 3 ratings from the SonarQube quality model be published: Reliability, Security, and Maintainability (Best Practices). Those ratings take the form of letter grades, which should be understandable to the general public. Teaching them _why_ they should care will take more time, but become more and more obvious as we're all able to correlate software failures with low ratings.
talk.abstract: Nutrition labels give us the chance to make smart choices about the food we consume. But there's no data to help us make smart choices about the software we consume. Quality metrics are easy to collect and should be just as universally available as nutrition labels.

talk.title: Refactoring with Cognitive Complexity, the new option for measuring understandability
talk.description:
For 40 years, Cyclomatic Complexity has been the de facto standard for measuring testability and maintainabiliy. While it's absolutely accurate for testability, the same can't be said for maintainability. Cognitive Complexity solves the problem, and returns "fair" relative measurements of control flow complexity. 

In this session, you'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, and why you should add it to your metric suite, see how it applies to a number of code samples from open source projects on SonarQube.com, and learn how to use a method's Cognitive Complexity score as a guide to designing better code, and refactoring existing code to be simpler and, more maintainable. You'll also see that because there's no "cost of entry" / increment for methods, high class-level Cognitive Complexity is a reliable indicator that a class contains a lot of logic, not just a lot of methods. That is, you can use Cognitive Complexity to sift domain classes from the logic-intense classes that impose a higher maintenance burden.

Cognitive Complexity is already available as a new rule in some Sonar code analyzers, and should be available throughout the SonarQube ecosystem by the end of 2017.
talk.notes:
30min Tech Talk

SonarSource (the company behind [SonarQube](http://sonarqube.org)) is introducing a new way of measuring complexity: [Cognitive Complexity](https://blog.sonarsource.com/cognitive-complexity-because-testability-understandability/), which gives a far more accurate measurement of the relative understandability of a method than Cyclomatic Complexity. 

I'll cover these topics:
* Cyclomatic Complexity: what it's good for and what's it's not, i.e. why a new standard/metric is needed
* Cognitive Complexity: motivations, specifics, benefits
* How to use Cognitive Complexity to guide refactoring. Hopefully I'll be able to use an IDE for this portion, but may have to fall back to slides, depending on what I can get the IDE to show.

I'll begin the presentation with slides and then hopefully switch to an IDE. Examples of code to be refactored will come from [sonarqube.com](https://sonarqube.com/issues#resolved=false|rules=squid%3AS3776).

I'm the best person to present this topic because, with the help and support of my SonarSource colleagues, I formulated Cognitive Complexity.
talk.abstract:
Cyclomatic Complexity measures testability, but not understandability. Cognitive Complexity fills the gap. 

You'll learn what the Cognitive Complexity methodology is, how it applies to a number of code samples, and how to use it as a guide to refactoring for simpler, more maintainable code.

profile.bio:

Dr. Joachim Fröhlich is ACM Senior and IEEE Member and has written 20+ publications in the fields of Software Engineering and Fault-tolerant Systems.

## Florian Krautwurm

talk.title: Reliable Statements about a Fault-Tolerant X-by-Wire eCar
talk.description:
A dependable cyber-physical system (CPS) correctly performs the functions for which it was conceived in its intended environment, without adverse effects. In particular, a dependable CPS responds correctly and timely even in situations where system parts have failed, either temporarily or permanently. This requirement also applies when tests check reliability, availability and performance properties of these systems in the lab and in the field. A CPS with test probes built-into all HW/SW-components throughout the CPS lifecycle can fulfill these requirements. Applied to an eCar, non-intrusive, deterministic fault-injection tests executed by test probes provide strong evidence for statements like: “While driving, the eCar can safely be steered when a fault fails a central, redundant HW/SW component that executes steering operations”.

Tests of such systems and properties pose various challenges, for example (1) stimulating selected CPS parts with correct data and with faulty data in rare and critical situations, (2) checking selected CPS parts at selected points in time, or during time intervals according to focused and measurable test goals, (3) differentiation of the CPS's treatment of temporary and permanent faults, and (4) absolute non-disturbance of the tested system's functionality or timing. The fourth challenge applies in particular to fault-injection tests that check CPS safety, or that operate near the border between the CPS and the physical process.

Meeting the challenges outlined above requires that the architecture of the system under evaluation be designed for testability. Starting from here, we first characterize the CPS we use as an example: an integration platform of an X-by-wire eCar (www.projekt-race.de/en). This motivates the need for reliable statements on the real-time behavior of the system from different tests, from which we derive testability requirements. Afterwards, we elaborate a series of design tactics that enable or improve the system’s testability, focusing on test probes. A test probe is a kind of Built-in Monitor (SEI: Testability tactic) or Maintenance Interface (R. Hanmer: Patterns for fault-tolerant systems) with particular demands in probe environments. When these demands are fulfilled, test probes can execute deterministic, efficient and reliable real-time tests, or act as safety monitors that observe and potentially intervene in a system.

Independent of the system domain you will learn two key aspects: how to design a testable system that incorporates test probes as central system elements, and how to write non-intrusive tests that yield reliable results.
talk.abstract: We discuss the practical use of novel HW/SW test probes to non-intrusively check functional, performance, and safety properties in fault-tolerant cyber-physical systems. The talk covers the application of test probes to test the dependability of automation and control systems of an eCar.

profile.name: Eoin Woods
profile.bio: Eoin Woods is CTO at Endava, the European software engineering services company, where he leads the technical strategy for the firm.  Eoin is a widely published author in both the research and industrial communities, and is co-author of the well known book "Software Systems Architecture", published by Addison-Wesley.  He is a regular conference speaker and an active member of the London software engineering community. His main technical interests are software architecture, distributed systems and computer security.

talk.title: Software Architecture as Systems Dissolve
talk.description:
The way we build systems is changing. From our history of monolithic systems, then distributed systems, to Internet connected systems, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice based, pay-for-usage system development. What does the history of software architecture tell us about the challenges of this new environment? And how does our approach to software architecture need to evolve in order to meet them?

Software architecture has been a mainstream discipline since the 1990s and in that time has become a recognised, widely researched and often valued part of the software engineering process. However architecture approaches must reflect the technologies and priorities of the systems we are building and in this regard its future has never looked more uncertain or more exciting. 

From our history of monolithic compile time architecture, to many tiered distributed systems, to Internet connected services, we are now entering the era of cloud-hosted, microservice-based, pay-for-usage systems development. In this new world the boundaries of “my” system are no longer so clear and our systems are dissolving into complex webs of independently owned and evolved services, with nothing more in common than a shared credit card for billing and an agreement on the format of network requests. 

What can the history of software architecture tell us about the likely challenges in this environment? And how must it develop in order to meet them?
talk.notes:
The genesis of this session was an invited talk at OOP2016, exploring the history of software architecture, which I developed into this much more practical talk aimed at working architects, for GOTO London 2016, where it went down well.  Since then it has been presented at Endava a number of times and has always interested and engaged the audience.  It has not been presented in the USA yet.

The talk at present is a slightly full 60 minutes and so I would suggest extending to 90 for SATURN which will simply involve using more examples and questions to the audience.  However, if it fits better as a 30 minute talk, the essence of the message can be presented by just using the "Internet as the System", "Internet as the System Principles" and "Implications" parts of the talk (see the outline below).

Outline
-----------
The 5 Ages of Software Systems
	- Monolithic
	- Distributed Monoliths
	- Internet Connected
	- Current Era: Internet as the System
	- Future: Intelligent Connected

Internet as the System
	- Public API and mobile UI are the default interfaces
	- “Always On” is moving to “Access from Anywhere”
	- More dynamic architectural styles emerge (Microservices become popular)
	- Vendor concern now providing “platforms” (PaaS)

Architectural Drivers

I-A-T-S Principles 
	- Evolve continually
	- Respond dynamically
	- Analyse don’t ask
	- APIs for everything
	- Secure by Design
	- Internationalise instinctively

Implications
	- Design in CD from the start (remove obstacles to automation, testing, deployment)
	- Allow modular evolution (bounded contexts, “micro services”)
	- Assume “cloud” deployment (“cattle not pets”, no “snowflakes”, no static config, …)
	- Provide measurement in the core (instrumentation, store, analytics engine)
	- Structure around “public” APIs (the “Amazon” pattern)
	- Design and build to be securable (security principles, threat models, scanning, …)

On the Future
	- Intelligent Connected
	- Data and algorithms become key to achieving architectural qualities
	- Architecture becomes (more) runtime emergent
	- Vendor concern moves to “intelligent behaviour”
	- “Access from Anywhere”  moves to “Intelligent Assistance”

Summary and Conclusions
talk.abstract: We are moving from a world of static, monolithic systems to a point where systems are composed dynamically from fine grained "pay as you go" components.  This talk explores the history that led us here and presents a set of architecture principles for systems to meet these new challenges.

talk.title: The life and times of an architecture - Architectural decision making throughout the solution life cycle
talk.description:
Over the last decade, the architecture discipline has matured from up-front design to a stream of architectural decisions that address the concerns related to ever-evolving software systems. The word “stream” implies a continuous process, but in real life that stream is far from homogeneous. Architects (or whoever else owns the design decisions) find themselves making decisions with widely varying impact, based on information with differing levels of uncertainty, throughout the life of a software solution. On top of that, the way these decisions and their impact are communicated evolves as the audience and the focus of the architectural communication change.

In this tutorial, we explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making, throughout a software solution’s life cycle. Amid all the fluidity of the stream of design decisions, we will look for anchor points with common concerns to address and recurring communication needs. We will see how the nature of architectural decisions changes when we go from birth (the first architectural outline) to graduation (making the business case), and find guidance on communicating the architecture at times of life-defining milestones like marriage (committing to the architecture) and revolutionary changes to the solution. The points will be illustrated by real-life examples from an interesting case study.

The tutorial is based on Risk- and Cost-Driven Architecture, a popular approach to improve architecture practices in both traditional and agile contexts, with the aim of providing “just enough anticipation” in the architecture. No prior knowledge of RCDA is required to attend.
talk.notes:
This is a 90-minute tutorial.

During the product lifecycle, key aspects of architectural decisions change, depending on the life stage:

* level of risk and cost control: the cone of uncertainty
* available information to base architectural decisions on
* impact of architectural decisions
* number of architectural decisions
* cost of change to the architecture

Certain milestones like graduation (approving the business case for the solution) and marriage (the moment after which it becomes very expensive to change the architecture) occur in every solution life cycle. Such milesones lead to standard stakeholder concerns, like affordability, level of risk control and predictability. We use the commonality of these concerns to provide the architect with standard views in their documentation, enabling them to show how the architecture addresses these common concerns.

Contents
-----------

1. Introduction: 
 * Architecture as a stream of design decisions
 * Cone of uncertainty
 * Project vs. product life cycle
2. Birth:
 * From stakeholder need to solution concept
3. Graduation:
 * Making the business case
4. Marriage:
 * Committing to the architecture
5. Career and home life:
 * Fulfilling the architecture
 * Emergent architecture
 * Evolutionary changes
 * Health and debt control
6. Children:
 * Revolutionary changes
7. Legacy
talk.abstract: Explore the metaphor of a human lifetime to illustrate various aspects of architectural decision making throughout a software system's life cycle. Find guidance on communicating your architecture at birth, graduation and marriage, after which changing the architecture becomes very expensive...

talk.title: Turning projects into products and wind into profit, or how GE Renewables was transformed into a Cloud SaaS Provider
talk.description:
At SATURN 2016, I introduced a novel lean approach to developing product architecture that combines Lean Model Canvas, Design Thinking, and Agile practices.  This year, I am excited to share a case study of how it was applied at GE Renewables Digital to bring software products to renewables assets.

In partnership with IT, field engineers, data scientists, and software engineers I watched an entire digital organization grow agile and innovating.  My fellow architects were the guides who captured the tribal wisdom and rallied both executive and product management sponsorship to launch two product lines in 2017 – Digital Wind Farm and Digital Hydro Plant, both demoed at GE Minds and Machines 2016 event. 

This session is based on my experience leading GE Digital Renewables architecture strategy for Asset Performance Management and Operations Optimization.  Renewables energy presents unique and diverse challenges when it comes to delivering software at scale.  Connecting hundreds and thousands of wind turbines and solar panels, fine-tuning analytics at the edge and the cloud, and assuring NERC compliance through Secure DevOps are some of the concerns to consider.

The participants will be walked through the journey and challenges on the way to migrating both existing applications and building brand new applications on a cloud platform and how architecture best practices accelerated the management and minimization of technical and functional debt.

The session also presents the trade-offs both at tactical and strategic level for moving forward with new technology without missing the beat of capturing the market opportunity for innovation leveraging horizontal products such as Asset Performance Management from Predix to accelerate renewables business objectives.

Two major product portfolios - The Digital Wind Farm and the Digital Hydro Plan were enabled with Common Renewables Asset Model based on IEC and S95 standards.   Model development was crowd-sourced to both IT, service engineering, and software development to capture both domain knowledge and leverage break-through features of distributed graph storage and scale with micro services.

feedback.body:
Thank you for your submission. 

You've explained the context and the parties involved nicely. Could you explain a little about what the systems for a Digital Wind Farm and a Digital Hydro Plant have to do? The talk sounds interesting but the domain may be unfamiliar to listeners. I like your plan to walk listeners through your journey. Stories -- problem statement, challenges, actions, results -- are very effective.

What are some of the experiences or lessons learned that you will present? Or some of the architecture best practices that worked for you? A few examples would help me understand how new and novel your approach is.

Thank you for the fead back. Here are the details that you have requested:

Digital Wind Farm is the product line for asset performance management and operation optimization for wind turbine assets and farms.  It is a cloud based solution leveraging Predix Platform for the industrial internet.
Digital Hydro Plant is the product line for hydro plants and hydraulic turbine asset performance management and operation optimization which is a hybrid system of an on-prem and cloud solution both based on Predix platform.
Some of the lessons learned are how to transform culture from waterfall projects to agile scrum teams, how to apply architecture decisions and involve key stakeholders, how to crowdsource asset modeling and common micro-services catalog.  At SATURN 2016, I presented the approach for applying product line architecture using agile, lean canvas, and concept maps. This year I would like to share how that approach was piloted and adopted at GE Digital Renewables organization.
I am not sure what you mean by functional debt, Arila? Gold plating?

I look at functional debt two ways - one is when there is no technical debt, but an organization ends up with multiple implementation of the same functionality across a product line, for example user management.  The other type of functional debt is when from a product owner perspective the portfolio looks complete and the functionality is not complete - common example is NOT implementing user context as the end user navigates  between micro apps.  I am not quite sure what you mean by gold plating.

talk.title: Ultimate Architecture Enforcement – Write Your Own Rules and Enforce Them Continuously
talk.description:
The software architecture discussed and carefully created is often not entirely followed in the implementation. In this talk we'll examine the factors that lead to this disconnect between the architecture and the code. We'll learn that consequences of this problem go beyond maintainability issues. But most important, we'll look at an easy to use, automated solution to improve architecture conformance. This solution has been successfully applied in a mid-size organization. It uses free open source tools and also helps to raise architecture knowledge across the development team. 

Things you will learn:

- the importance of architecture conformance. 

- how to use free open source tools to create your own design rules. Through examples, you'll learn the basics of the SonarQube custom check API. 

- how to enforce the architecture continuously by integrating the custom rules to your CI infrastructure. 

- how to make this setup effective, based on lessons learned by the author in the past 6 years. 

No pre-requisite knowledge is required other than basic understanding of object-oriented programming.
talk.notes:
This talk is supposed to be a 90-minute tech tutorial. 

Early results of the approach discussed in the presentation were described in a [SATURN blog post](https://saturnnetwork.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/ultimate-architecture-enforcement-prevent-code-violations-at-code-commit-time/). 
More recent results were described in a [SPLASH Wavefront paper](http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2508433).
The SATURN presentation is updated to reflect recent improvements and results.

*Session mechanics* 

This is a slide-based presentation. I'll also use the IDE to show and run some code. Questions and comments are welcome during the talk or at the end. 

*Talk outline*

- Introduction: Motivation for architecture conformance; factors that lead to lack of conformance; consequences of lack of conformance.
- Creating a custom rule: intro to static code analysis tools with an API to create custom rules
- Example 1 - enforcing a layered architecture (for each example, we'll examine the code and comment on the SonarQube API)
- Example 2 - enforcing mandated generalizations
- Example 3 - enforcing REST service design standards
- Automated tests for custom checks: quick overview of how to build and run automated tests
- Integration with continuous integration
- Running critical checks in a pre-commit hook on git or svn
- Our experience with custom checks: results and lessons learned in 6 years 

*Target audience*

This talk is particularly important to software architects, but is of interest to software developers in general. 

*Previous presentations* 

SPLASH 2013; The Brazilian Conference on Software - Theory and Practice 2013; 3er Congreso Internacional Escuela de Ingeniería de Sistemas y Computación (Peru); invited talks at different organizations.
talk.abstract: The architecture carefully created is often not entirely followed in the implementation. If you want to learn an easy to use, automated approach to avoid this issue, come join us in this tutorial. The approach has been successfully applied in our organization for over 6 years now.

feedback.body: Thanks Paulo for a great submission. An Architect makes a variety of decisions beyond what could be captured in the code.  How would suggest handling these concerns beyond what could be addressed in code or would the topic limit itself to focussing only on code level concerns?

Hi Yogeshwar. Good point. The scope of the approach described in this talk is limited to design decisions that are somehow expressed in code, be it the application source code or other artifacts such as xml files.
